Culturally Rich!. The history, culture and customs here are something else!
The rich customs including the cremation in the Hindu custom can be watched up close.
Our guide was incredibly informative and was able to answer every question.

Famous Hindu Temple by the side of Bagmati River. This is a famous Hindu temple by the side of Bagmati river. Every years, tens of thousands of devotees from India pay visit mainly during the time of Shivaratri. Entrance to the main temple isn't allowed to non-Hindus given the historical reasons, however, I always see foreign tourists watching and photographing from another side of the river, mainly witnessing the cremation which is performed by the side of the river.

biggest Hindu temple in the world.. middle part of town bank of the bagmati river with golden roof view of pasupati is majestic because of Sivas power i feel when i was in front of temple totally different. security is really kind and responsible for hindu won culture.i am glad to meat main priest it was my good luck.

Evening Aarati time was awesome. Pashupatinath temple is one of the biggest temple. In this temple we can see the lots of shiv linga as well as many goddess statue also. Evening aarati was awesome to watch and singing over there.

Jai Shambhu !. Its one of the most sacred,visited and known hindu temple of Lord Shiva in the world.Its only allowed to Hindus to enter the temple but all other religion followers are allowed to visit upto the gate and also watch some religious ceremony from the other side of the temple.As bagmati (sacred river)flows besides the temple, evening rituals (Aarti) are performed along the river and has a beautiful and serene atmosphere.You need to reach a bit early to find a good spot to view the aarti and the temple premise is big enough to take good time if you want to explore full.It has lots of other temples nearby like Guheshwari (15 mins walk) etc. Lots of devotees visit the temple and it has enormous crowd during special events,day, month for eg. during Shivratri and Shrawan and also on Mondays. Hence, pls plan accordingly.Temple remain closed during noon time.

Ancient, Spiritual Temple of Shiva. The ancient Pashupathinath temple is close to the airport, and is one of the most iconic attractions of Kathmandu. The ancient Shiva temple is grand, and there is also the attraction of daily evening arathi along the river. Bodies are cremated close to the temple as well as part of the rituals conducted at this temple.

a rendezvous of religion, architecture and nature. a great golden temple built in 15th century is a meeting place of Hindu religion. It is one of the most sacred Hindu shrines dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple extends to a huge forest place with thousands of smaller Shiva shrines around the place.located on the bank of holy Bagmati river. The ghats are famous for hindu final rites for cremations.Many hindus are cremated along the Bagmati river bank everyday.A must visit place to see the lives of hindu devotees in one of the World Heritage sites.Hindu Sadhus live in different sattals( small houses) and meditate in different forms.Some are even Aghori babas.Entrance only for hindus in the main Pashupati temple premise but one can visit to see the lively activities everyday.

Temple where the truth of life reveals!. I wanted to encounter the last truth of life and was there in the temple premises. The final truth revealed in front of me and i could look inside myself for a moment.Now from the viewpoint i could see the Golden Pagoda of the Pashupatinath temple with an assembly line of the smaller temples made in the middle age. As the time passed and was evening, the temple started sparkling in the lights and also with the evening spiritual music.A place where you see only the temple but encounter the truth of life ! Dont miss in your trip to Kathmandu.

Temple for cremations. The area for cremations was interesting, but the surrounding temples were not in great shape. It was worth a visit, but nothing amazing. There were hundreds of red macaque monkeys.
Holy place to visit. It's one of the jyotirling and most respected temple of lord Shiva in Nepal. One must visit this whenever in Nepal

Not just another Temple. We visited the temple in the late afternoon and it was fairly quiet from a tourist perspective. There were some cremations in progress, so be aware that this happens in full sight and that makes this Temple unlike others you will visit. The place was pretty clean, but beware of the monkeys, who will try and lift things off you. Also be aware that the "Sadhus" (Holy men) will want money to have their picture taken.
Temple. It is at the bank of Bagmati river. Only meant for people with very high religious thought. Evening aarti is good.

Expensive but worth the fees. Beautiful site where one can feel the culture and religious element. Only drawback about this and similar sites is the fine thin line to make tourism sustainable without endangering the religious aspect.
Divine place. The temple has given a divine blessings to me when I visited there. Beautiful place & very close to Kathmandu airport.
Great tempal. Good locetion really intrested palace in kathmandu and historical nile and heritage palace and magic pawer amreally gating by gad shiva

Nepl replies to Varanasi. This is where bodies are burned for the funeral process.It is a nice area,not all along the river.You can climb up the hill and go through the woods.Along the way you'll find multiple shrines,it is a very nice walk.It takes a short time maybe half an hour at leisurely pace,wooden area,very pleasant.

A cleaner version of Varinasi. Worth visiting. . The temple grounds are so so and foreigners are now charged 1000r to enter. Way overpriced, but if you want to see cremations and don't know how to enter from the back side across the river, you don't have a choice. But to be honest, it's worth $10 to witness how they send off their dead, as well as walk around some of the temple grounds. Near the river is where you want to be. The rest is not very interesting. The main temple is for Hindus only. There are lots of Sadus here, all wanting a tip for photos and such. They add a colorful back drop to the grey temples. Monkeys are plenty. It's a good place to spend an hour or two. It's a cleaner, more organized version of India's Varanasi. The cremations take place 24 hours a day.

Sacred temple of peace. This is one of the best attractions of tourists in Nepal.Indians find this similar to many such places here like Banaras,Tirupati balaji and many more.We were taken here by localite who also works here as volunteer and so he explained it in detail.We had darshan from all the four gates.A must place for visitors.

Divine Place!!. We all know about this place and I was lucky to visit it twice within 6 months. Never been able to see all 4 ends(Open gates) of the main temple but the feel of the lord itself gives the ultimate satisfaction. Ghats and the river are not something I will prefer to visit but its a must to go place.

Spiritually Undefined. When we search for Peace and Prosperity, we all have common question, who is superpower. To feel the peace i always visit one of the best Sacred Place of Nepal which is Pashupatinath Temple. Place is having Rich religions value and historical architectures apart from Baghmati River adjacent to the Temple. This place having cremation centre to realize your final destination.
Beautiful. the beautiful place with lots of religious value.when i entered the temple was stunned by the area it covered and the monkey but after the puja i was at peace.Happy place

One of the Sacred Places in Nepal. This palace is considered to be one of the famous and holy places in Nepal. If you are going to study the Hindu religion, its birth and all the aspects of it you will frequently hear and see Pashupatinath Temple because according to their religion it is one of the sacred places. That's why if you visit this place there's a lot of people praying and meditating. Aside from the historical architectures and temples here, you will see a lot of birds, cows, and monkeys freely living with the people as if they are part of the human race. Truly amazing!
Famous palace. Pashupatinath is one of the best and famous Shiva temple in around the world and historical heritage and cultural palace in kathmandu

A sprawling Hindu holy site.. A short taxi ride from central Kathmandu, Pashupatinath is a large complex of temples, with monkeys darting about all, that gives a fascinating taste of Nepal's Hindu traditions. The 1000 rupee cat to enter does not allow non-Hindus to enter the main temple, but views within can be archived from the hills surrounding. Beware the touts and guides and sadhus who will ask for contributions for any device rendered and just wander the site, cross the river and meander the peaceful parks behind (which are also the starting point for another 20 minute trek that will take you to the Boudhanath Stupa Buddhist site).
Peace of Mind. It was dream for me to visit Pashupatinath Temple. one of the thirth place according to Hindu religion.

Mystical & Moving. Be prepared for an emotionally moving experience if you are fortunate enough to be there during cremation. I have never seen or felt anything quite like it and will never ever forget it.

Har Har Mahadev. What a surreal experience. Apart from the sense of peace and tranquillity that this temple has to offer, the lack of commercialization makes this a very pleasant place of worship. No one hounding you for money, no one pushing you around asking you to hurry with your worship and a general sensibility amongst most devotees lets you be with yourself, in the presence of the lord, even in a large crowd. Monkeys, Rams, Calves, Dogs, Pigeons roam about freely in the concourse thus making it such a beautiful sight to see. It screams of peace and oneness with the divine. One of the most peaceful experiences that I have had in a long time. It could be a little cleaner though. Having said that, I travelled during the monsoon and soon after a sort of a downpour - so expecting the place to be dry was a little bit of a stretch. A must place to visit.

good experience. Went there as a devotee of lord shiva. At first visit at 4 pm tyne temple was closed and i was told that the doors will open by 6 pm. Later went there, and was lucky to get darshan within 15 min. But the problem is upkeep, security etc unlike the more famous temples in India like tirupathi etc.The view of baghmati river and the burning bodies at the banks was tantalising and reminds us of our limitations and the truth of life.
Holy and Mesmerising. Visit to the temple was great, and the Maha Aarthi that happens around 1830hrs in the evening daily is a must see experience...

One of Nepal's Holiest locations. Pashupatinath on the Bagmati river is where many nepalis are cremated and for those dying live out their last days. It is also home to colonies of monkeys and a few Sardhu's (Holy men). It is not for those who wish to see neat and tidy and golden temples. It has its own holiness.

god bless us. the hindu 's the big temple is pashupatinath.all the people s they are bealive the god of shiva .i was many times in there ..pashupatinath is historic, traddisional, culturel, art and world heritage.

A must visit.. Best is sunset- non-Hindus not permitted in primary shrine but no big loss. Colourful pilgrims and sadhus. Cremations at the gahts along the Baghmati. Don't miss the climb to the top to Mrgisthali for earlier mandirs (temples) many still unrestored from the '15 earthquake. Peaceful sunsets too. One of major temples of Shaivites in all the subcontinent. worth the trip to Nepal alone.

Must visit place for pilgrimage. This is one of the world heritage site located about 10 min drive from Tribhuban International Airport at Kathmandu. Very well maintained and clean. One can visit the temple without any usually hassled by touts. The temple is located in the bank of river Bagmati. You can spend some good time in the temple premise, it should take about an hour or so to go around the temple properly. Special puja can be arranged on prior bookings. Saturday and Monday are usually most crowded days as locals visit the temple on these days. Usually the temple is open for darshan from 7-11 AM.

Holy place. One of the holiest place for Hindus. Non-hindus are not allowed to enter the main temple premises but there are a lot of other places to see here.There is a stairway leading towards another temple just behind the Pashupati temple. Climb the stairs and you will find a place to sit and enjoy the view. It is just wonderful to just sit there and gaze at everything thats going around. The place si crowded in evening and on holidays. Climb to top of the stairs to see some artistic temple with religious significance. The 2015 Earthquake did quite a lot of damage to the temples but they are still standing.Note : Try and go to the temple in evening(just before sunset) and ask anyone for 'evening aarati'. It is done everyday and is one of the hidden gems in Kathmandu. A must see.
hindos tempal. one of the largest big famousu shiva temple call pashupatinath is really great dursan i did not much croude i really like shiva tempal

One of the holiest place for Hindus, but poorly maintained. One of the 12 Jyothilingas (sacred form of Lord Shiva) - this temple is said to house the Lord - who is the protector of animals (Pashu - animals Pathi - Lord). Har har mahadev. As per my experience Nepal draws visitors who come for a diversity of reasons. Some are lured by the call of the mountains and seeking to climb or trek in the Himalayas, others are intrigued by the culture and the famous city of Kathmandu, and yet others come hoping to find some sort of spiritual awakening. Nepal can be an adrenaline adventure, a cultural eye opener, or a life-changing experience, depending on the itinerary and mindset of the traveler

The ancient most temple in Nepal. Pashupatinath Temple, one of the most sacred places on earth for Hinduism, and one of the oldest temples of human history, and UNESCO declared World Heritage Site. The ancient temple was built around 400BC, that means a 2416 years old temple it is! There are also evidences that on that place Lord Shiva was worshiped for another 1300 years before 400BC in a shorter version without having a temple. That implies, Lord Shiva is being worshiped here since 4000 years!You must visit the temple if you really wanted to know about the subcontinent religion and the ritual process and also their worship of Gods living in the nature.

Huge!. Wow I had no idea how hue this place was! I got a guide that joined up with me at the entrance - really helpful, I wouldn't have known what i was looking at. Negotiate the price beforehand, though. I had a little trouble there, he wanted more money.
Not a Place to "Rate". I am not sure if it appropriate to rate a place that carries out cremation. That said, it is an interesting place to visit to understand local culture.

Beautiful and emotional. This area is a must see of Kathmandu! I would definitely recommend getting a tour guide- we had a young lad called Reuben who had perfect English and was exceptionally knowledgable. Obviously with Kathmandu bargain hard for your price! The cremations that take place here occur frequently, be aware of this, it's highly emotional! But it really can connect you with humanity to feel so much kindness towards a stranger in grief. To see the rite of passage of another culture is also exceptionally interesting! You will also see the sadhus in their caves, and possibly women who have come to pray for help with regards to fertility. There is also a welfare area for the elderly. In all, well worth the entrance fee of one thousand rupees!

Best Divine place.. I went there with my friends to seek the blessings. While entering the gate I saw a lot of pilgrims. People from all over the world come here to seek blessings of Lord Shiva. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the main temple. Lots of pigeons are there.

Amazing experience of lord shiva. I went to Nepal to attend a meeting however my only attraction was Pashupatinath Temple. Apart from temple there is a river passing near to temple. watching aarti of this river was an amazing experience.

Awestruck. Sobering.. Wow. Even as I try to recall all that I observed and saw at this temple site, I still can't seem to take it all in. I am not a Hindu, but I do respect everyone's religion, so I entered this site with an attitude of a "learner". First and foremost: if you are a "westerner": someone or anyone who has not grown up in a traditional "Hindu" or Buddhist worldview but now claim to be a "Hindu" or a follower of Hinduism; DO NOT claim that until you have personally come and observed the daily rituals of traditional Hindus. Don't just make something up and call it Hinduism. Come and see real Hindu worship, death rituals, ceremonies and true Hindu faith in action before you simply "claim" to be a Hindu (I'm looking at you, Hollywood Hipsters).I saw death rituals and families seeking to find peace for their loved ones who have passed on. I saw Sadhus trying to impress me with face paint and strange antics using their "private parts" (I can't go into more detail here). I saw women seeking "identity" by asking these Sadhus to help them have children. I saw people worshipping idols, gods and statues. A mass of humanity seeking peace. I heard chants and laughter; crying and small talk. I smelled the burning of flesh and the rancid smell of sweat, trash and monkeys. This experience is simply overwhelming.

Hindu Culture + Panoramic Views of Kathmandu. Pashupatinath is the oldest and most well known Hindu temple in Kathmandu, Nepal, situated on the banks of the Bagmati River. It is a UNESCO World Heritage site, which means you will get charged 1,000 rupees ($9.50 USD) to visit. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the actual main temple but you can walk around and enjoy the sights and take pictures. You can get a really good panoramic view of Kathmandu here as well. Myself and three others from my home stay visited here and were immediately approached by a youngish Nepal tour guide. We saw temples devoted to Shiva, Hanuman the Monkey God and several cremations happening along the river. The Hindus have a much more pragmatic view of death; it's just another part of life. There are specific rituals start differently depending on the age, gender and caste of the person who died but everyone ends up as ash in the river. Our guide said it can take two or three hours for a body to burn completely. We met a group of Sadus hanging out around the temple who speak English and will ask for money in exchange for blessings or photos. I'm not sure if they were legit or not but our guide assured us that they use the money to buy food for themselves and the poorer communities in the area so I obliged. On the other hand, I was really annoyed by the vendors that kept approaching me and trying to sell me crap that I didn't want or need. Our guide also took us to a nearby elderly complex where Mother Teresa used to work. The old ladies and gents were lined up for their lunch and had colorful laundry drying all around courtyard. In the center of the courtyard was a temple with a bell that one old woman rang incessantly for several minutes. At the conclusion of our tour, we tipped our guide and headed in the direction of our next destination. A black temple dog with white paws that we called Puppy escorted us as far as he could but had to leave us and turn back when we got to main road because that turf apparently belonged to other dogs.
Shiva. My favorite temple out of many in Nepal! Very intense cultural, spiritual and historical auspicious place of holy worship.

Not for Kids. This place is a crematory for Hindus. When I arrived, I had not idea that temple was a crematory. At first I saw people burning straws and turned out they were cremating bodies; gross me out!

UNESCO HERITAGE PASHUPATHINATH TEMPLE. It is a famous, sacred Hindu temple dedicated to Pashupatinath and is located on the banks of the Bagmati River 5 kilometres north-east of Kathmandu Valley in the eastern city of KMT. This temple complex is on UNESCO World Heritage Sites's list Since 1979.Innermost part of the temple is only reserved for true Hindus!All the rituals are active and alive.Crowded always!A few remarkable scars of 2015 earthquake are evidently still there.One interesting and love to observe is a lot of vendors along the entrance way to the temple.All have their own peculiarities, colours, fragrances, movements, sounds, etc.
Monkeys everywhere. Good place to visit in the afternoon. Monkeys running around like in their natural environment and one of the most important places for buddhists and hindus :)

Eye-opening experience. It was one of the most intense experience of my trip to Nepal. The things that they did there was so "raw" and unmasked, which really allows visitors to see the "real" Nepali culture for themselves.

Respect is a must at this Holy Hindu site. At this sacred Hindu Temple you will see mourning families staying near their deceased family member who is wrapped and placed on a funeral pyre beside the river. After cremation the ashes and pieces of bone are washed away in the Bagmati River.
For a small charge you can have your photo taken with colourful Sadhus, Holy men.
Mandatory for Travellers. You can reach the temple by walking from Kathmandu. The place is very interesting related to Indian culture.

Real spirit of Hinduism. Well... For us,european people ,this is unusual sight. Maby too heavy for our stomach but unique with its energy. Like in India, you'll adore it or you get sick. I adore it. All hindu customs are a bit strange for us, but this is right place where you can see spiritual part of Hinduism.

Typical hindu temple. Yes, if you never been to India, this is the place you can see the real India.
While as usual, many guide will approach you to ask for service, many "special" people ask you to take them a photo and ask for money.
Just ignore all of them and enjoy 'India' in Nepal.

SHAME ON YOU NEPALI PEOPLE!!!!. I have travelled a lot around the world and unfortunately this is my worst rewiev ever!!This is absolutely tourist unfriendly and racisstic place !!!! They would try to Rip you off on Many ways so:DEAR FUTURE TOURIST PLEASE READ:Entrance fee is 1000 rp (10$) and be careful because they would just start follow you to "show you the way" and start guiding you without asking you anything !Be careful about that and always know what are you dealing with. SHAME on you!Place is interesting to see the Way they cremate dead people and to see a lots Of monkeys but is also quite devasted during earthquake :/
Amazing sacred place. This is one of the most sacred places in Nepal. If you are visiting Kathmandu make sure you visit the Pashipatinath Temple. Be respectful

My bucket list ticked again. This a place where every HINDU would want to go and also be the brought to when life had called THE END. 4 faces of LORD SHIVA who guides and guards all. I felt the completeness when I stepped in. I am glad I came with my dearest daughter.

Good Bless yo us○○○○○○○○○. Pasupati nath is one of famous temple where we can get to pray to Mahadev(Shiva).Lot's of prayer comes from early morning 5am because here comes many many people .so if any people wants to come just come early morning otherwise come aroundly 11 am or 11.30am

Don't know what to say. First of all the entrance fee for people from the western counties is 1000 rupees which is discriminating (for others is about 250 rupees) in my opinion. Second, even one year after the earthquake they did absolutely nothing to rebuild the place. UNESCO should definitely do something about it.Third, is totally absurd they showing their funeral traditions to the tourist. On one side there are families which cry and on the other side there are tourists who take photos. Absolutely crazy.Fourth, you can't even see the main Golden temple, it's only reserved for Hindu people (even though you paid 1000 rupees).Fifth, be careful with people who represent as tourist guides, they would just start walking by you explaining the place (event though you didn't ask them anything) and in the end they want money from you. Unesco World Heritage Site. This site is considered sacred by the hindus located along the banks of Bagmati river. For foreigners, theres an entrance fee of 1000 npr which is quite expensive considering there has been no improvements done on its public toilet at least.

Holy place. Biggest temple in nepAl pashupti nTh ji its ia a temple of lord shiva an ancient temple you can get different types of pujas done here like rudra abhishek and all and if you re interested in buying rudraksh then you can find plenty of them in shops outside the temple

The old monuments and the religious belief around makes it good. The temple is crowed but the beauty of the temple is the golden Nandi. This is one of the oldest temples and is one of the one of 7 monument groups in UNESCO's designation of Kathmandu as a cultural heritage site.

inspiring. Went during off season and it was a beautiful sight. The temple per say is constructed beautifully on the banks of Bagmati river. You can visit at any point of the day. Vast temple. You can get a guide if you wish for a tour.See Shiva in one of his avatars. DOnt forget to get rudraksh from one of the stores on the outside(but ask around, some are fake)

Ancient history... I guess it's a must visit . Beautiful temple... Intricate carvings... When in Kathmandu this is a must visit. Only it's so unfortunate that it hasn't been maintained as a heritage site like it is... Hopefully some day it will get its status it deserves

Very special and very Nepali. I visited this place four times during my visit in Kathmandu. It looks great in the night, day, morning and evening. I saw the funeral service, the worshiping and just walked around. Beautiful place with unique spiritual atmosphere!

Get Sumit Kharel to Give You a Tour!. Fascinating place, a must-see in Kathmandu! I ran into Sumit Kharel (local tour guide) and he gave me a brilliant tour for a bargain price! The experience went from good to amazing because of Sumit. If you go to Pashupatinath ask for Sumit Kharel - he was so friendly and gave me a brilliant tour of the grounds (he gave me a detailed cultural history of all the many temples in a really fun and engaging way).
Holiest Hindu site on the Earth.. Spiritually the holiest place for on the Earth for the Hindu community. You can see the cremation site, shiva temple and other holy sites.

Rip off for non hindus. At this temple you are charged a full entrance fee, which is higher for foreigners. Once you enter through the gate, you cannot see anything, because the temple is for Hindu's only. Why would they charge you money and then not let you in? Behind the temple is a river, which you can access without paying. There you can watch cremations of bodies by the river or take pictures with local gurus, who charge 500 rupies for a picture.

Abode to the Mahadev. A visit to Kathmandu is incomplete without a visit to the Pashupatinath temple. It is one of the most reverred Shiva temples. The pagoda style architecture is mesmerizing. When we went thee..some music was being played which was powerful.The market outside the temple is buzzing and if one is interested can get a vast variety off Rudraaksh
excellent. Visit and Darshan to Pashupatinath was great experience. More cleanliness should be observed. Details of temple should also be put at various places. Security should also be tightened.

A mystical must-see!. Having spent several months in Nepal, Pashupati is hands-down one of my favorite spots. It's a great place to experience the "living culture" of Nepal beyond its incredible heritage. I took a walking tour with a local guide, Sumit, (find him if you can!) which is highly recommended. Watching the ritual enactments take place is one thing, but understanding the web of symbolism behind it is surely another! You won't be disappointed.

Nearly "overwhelming". Depending upon when you visit, you can experience so much, not just the "Place", it's architecture and it's Heritage, but as a truly visceral experience into the culture of this remarkable city, it's inhabitants, their religions and customs. Come on the right days during festivals, and the colours will amaze you with all the beautiful women dressed in their finest colours. Pilgrims come to pray at the Temple. Families performing the last rights and Cremation ceremonies . It all happens here, at Pashupati Nath. A visit to Pashupatinath on Monday. Every Monday in the Nepali month of July ( by the Nepali Calandar) is celebrated especially by the Hindu women, who dress in their brightest clothing, mostly red, adorned with plastic bangles on their arms, getting Henna applied. Here to go to Temple and pray for long lives for their husbands. Pashupatinath is also home to the cities main Cremation site. Tho's families with enough money witll cremate their loved ones on a traditional wood fire. there is an electric Crematorium close by for those that cannot afford the more traditional ceremony. Loved ones feet are lowered and dipped into the holy Bagmatti River one last time, sprinkled with the holy water, adorned with fresh flowers and then placed upon the traditionally arranged stacks of wood. If you are a tourist here, please respect the families and what they are going through, you are a guest in their private moment. Stay across the river , take photos with discretion, and respect. While it may seem like a tourist attraction, it is real life. This is also a very large Temple area, there is an adjacent Deer park, and you can walk completely around this place in about 1 hours time. many many steps if you want to circumnavigate the entire place. There are also many "Holy"?? men, in various places, they seem to situate themselves in conspicuous places closest to where the tourists are. They are 99 % Naked, covered in grey ash. Yes, you can take pictures if you pay! Why else are they there??? Still interesting, and free to look. There are a dozen ways into the Temple grounds, go with a guide, and they will take you through the main gate so they get a cut of your admission fee (very pricy for Nepal, I think 1000 Rupees depending upon what day and how greedy they are at that moment. Don't pay it, go around, find your own way in, they are just pocketing the money. This is free to everyone, else except tourists, so ignore them if you can, keep walking, say you are on pilgrimage, whatever... and of course, you can always pay. But... that still won't get you entry into the Temple itself. Want access, ??? you must be Hindu, at least for the day, yes it can be done, just go it alone, not as a large group if you really want full access to this incredible place. Also, if you come, get change from one of the change people just outside, they will give you a handful of 5 and 10 rupee bills to leave at all the many important sites, where if you want to wax Hindu you must leave an offering.
Pashupatinanth Temple. One of the beautiful temple I have come across. Don't miss the evening aarti. You can the dead bodies being cremated at the banks of the river bagmati at the bottom.
Divinity. Jay Shambho! Must visit for realization of reality of life and transformation. At the same time visiting Kirateshwor Mahadev Temple, Cosmic Temple, and Guheshwori Temple is meaningful.

Holy Visit!. I was travelling with my wife and the purpose of my trip to Nepal was to visit the Pashupatinath Temple. We could visit the temple twice in two days. Booked for a Puja which was performed at 9.00 in the morning. We had darshan from all gates.This is a major pilgrimage site for Hindus. It was a beautiful experience. The duration there was done very smoothly unlike you do at any Shiva temples in India. Credit goes to the team who does the temple management. People are very cooperative.

The greatest lord in the world for Hinduism.. Pashupati Nath Temple is the heart of all Hinduism situated in Kathmandu, capital city of Nepal,

Awesome place. I really love the Pashupatinath-Temple. It's great to see other methods of saying farewell to the loved ones.But the business is hard around here. Several guides, sellers, and so on will annoy you.

In the Lap of Lord Shiva. It is one of the most famous temples of the world. Quiet and peaceful. You will find many other temples within this temple. Holy Place. One of the main and most famous temples in Nepal. The temple outer area was little destroyed because of the earthquake but inside everything is as it is. It is the most important temple dedicated to god Shiva. One of the most astonishing decorations of the temple is the huge golden statue of Nandi - Shiva’s bull.A must place to visit if in Nepal.

Must Vist. The inner sanctum is only for Hindus, but, everyone can visit the rest of the facilities. it is clean and has some really old architecture structures.
Worthy but very expensive. We paid a lot for a visit to this place. Cremations are a different experience but we were not able to see any temple inside. I think the fee should be lower

Beautiful and Strange. Coming from an American perspective, it was so strange to me to see open funeral ceremonies and cremations. But it was definitely an interesting experience. It's emotional, and a bit heavy, but definitely cool to experience that aspect of another culture.

Place for which I travel to Nepal was excellent. this is the place for which I have visited nepal and I have to visit this. According to me noone will go without visiting it from Nepal. The divinity in Kathmandu. I had missed visiting the Pashupatinath during my first visit to Kathmandu.Hence during my trip in May 2016, I had decided that I would not miss visiting one of the most holy temples for Hindus.The temple, a UNESCO world heritage site, is very well maintained. Once you enter the temple, there are many shrines dedicated to lord Shiva, including the main temple, a site where there are supposed to be 555 Shiv Lingas (did not count, though seemed to be a fair number). After exiting the temple went to the shore of the Bagmati river right besides the temple where here are some smaller shrines. Also, one may see a number of cremations taking place at the site. Overall, the place just calms you down. A divine experience indeed.
Best of Hindusm. This is really good to know about hindusm.This is very ever to learn about Hindusm.Deffinaly like it.I will recommend you you.and don't miss this place to visit in Nepal

must visit holy place!. felt the divine power , being inside the temple. it was our first time to visit pashupatinath, and the experience was overwhelming, I strongly believe one can't visit shiv, unless he calls, after my several visits to nepal, Shiv finally called me this july to visit HIM. the main shrine has four dwars and one must take darshan from all direction. the temple has many small shrines for ganpathy, hanuman and others. make sure you visit all of them. going around the 108 shivlingams are very special , so don't miss it.

Great Temple. We visited the temple early in the morning . Before entering the temple complex there are shops on both sides of the road . Flowers and essential things for Puja are available there.We entered the complex bare footed keeping our shoes in a place . In addition to visitors there are hundreds of pigeons ,giant goats and lot of monkeys.As we walk past the exterior we saw shadus sitting outside.. Till the gate of main temple complex photography allowed after that not.. Lot of people are queued to have darshan and offer Puja.Beside main temple there are temples of small deities.People are offering oil lamps. In the East of the temple river Bagmati flows . From the temple plain itis 100 to 150 feet down. On the constant cremation fire is on..In the evening there are aratis onin the Temple and in te far bank of Bagmati . In the tranquil atmosphere music and religious dance is really wonderful and fills one`s heart.

well maintained and divine place. certainly a well maintained temple. fully neat and clean. this place gives huge peace of mind and its very divine. wow the pigeons near temple are almost one of the attraction where one can feed pigeons with thier food which can be purchased from stores outside temple.if you wish to attend pooja aari kindly make sure this is performed only in the evening by 7 pm sharp.photography not allowed inside the temple but you can carry your mobile phones inside.overall very well maintained temple and no cheating or frauds by any people. a safe place to visit.

An incredible place for Hindus. it's worth going to pashupatinath temple particularly, in off season, you can see the in a relaxed way, which is not possible during ON Season visit. A very interesting place. Well worth a visit. This is an important Hindu shrine although non Hindus cannot go into the main area. Much to see. The crematoria are part of the same complex.

Divine enlightenment . For Hindu's this ancient temple offers a site where the can worship lord Shiva. This site has immense religious and spiritual value for Hindu's. many tourists. many tourists but then again i am one of them. For those interested in temples it is a must. and the monkeys running around are funny but take care, they can be very agressive.

Pashupatinath Temple. The sacro sanctum, or the main idol is a stone Mukhalinga with a silver yoni base bound with silver serpent .The lingam is one metre high and has faces in four directions .These faces represents various ascepts of Shiva; Sadyojata (also known as Barun), Vamdeva (also known as Ardha nareshwor), Tatpurusha, Aghor & Ishana (imaginative).Facing West, North, East, South and Zenith respectively representing five primary elements namely earth, water, air, light and ether.[10] Each face has tiny protruding hands holding rudraksha mala on right hand and a kamandalu on the other.Unlike other shiva lingams in India and Nepal this pashupati shiva lingam is always Dressed in its golden vastra except during abhishakam, so pouring milk and ganga jal is only possible during abhishakam through the main priests

Don't Miss this Temple . I almost didn't go this temple, but am very glad I did! The temple is very interesting and you see and last so much about the Hindu religion. The area itself is beautiful and open the curious. As with just about everyplace in Kathmandu you will pick up a "shadow" or guide if you don't have one. Lord of the lords....Mahadev. Once again... i am short of words to describe the feeling that i was so much overwhelmed with. Life is short and one must come here to enhance it. Our breath become lost here....and we both couldnt relate with each other.......that was the devine phenomenon we experienced. So much connected to lord....so much of his glory is defined here....so much of love...so much of truth of life from beginning to end is experienced in our few hours of visit here. The purity...the love...the grace of the almighty mahadev..... all felt and just felt. Lost in transaltion i am...and we bith were there. Once in a lifetime event.....which we want to experience every other time.

Deeply spiritual place. Amazing.. This is a must-go. Absolute must go. There are so many aspects including mingling with the holy men and seeing where Hindu services are held.

A discovery on how pther cultures pay their last respects to their departed loved ones. I chanced upon a couple on the Mt Everest flight couple of weeks ago which was pne pf the highlights.of my two week sojourn to Nepal. As I didn't have any other activities for that day, I gladly joined them for the city tour they booked with their driver.Our first drstination was the Pashupatinath temple, one of the many UNESCO World Heritage sites in the capital city of Kathmandu. I gladly shelled out the equivalent of about 10 USDollars to ger inside and was toured by our friendly driver who knew a lot about thencity and culture that hewas like a tourist guide as well. Once inside the sprawlibg area, you get to see a very unique custom Hindus have of cremating their departed ones. I won't share too much details only because I might give misinformation-but suffice it to say that all of us were very curious.

Best complex in Kathmandu. We payed a local guide (5$) to enjoy better this expensive attraction (1500R). We enjoyed the visit. To take a pic of the Bull is not easy (entrance only for hindus) . The best was to see all the crematories ceremonies, etc.etc. Worth to visit!

Pashupatinath temple is a must-visit. A must visit when in Khatmandu.This Shiva Linga has stood blessing people since all the 4 yugas. The temple Panditjis conduct a very fulfilling Rudra pooja in the temple premises.
DEVINE. ultimate hindus holy temple quite spritual and relexing place i can not express the divinity in words

the environment and feelings inside temple is quite relaxed and spiritual.. inside the temple the environment is quite spiritual here i found so many locals also do visit in the evening time for relaxation from the stressful wholeday and overall i enjoyed alot while worshiping and visiting the temple and its premises.

This is the main place in kathmandu and the only reason to come to the city.. I have recently visit the temple. Only Hindus are allowed to enter in Temple premises.

Buggest hindus temple. Biggest hindus holy temple , there is a lot of sadus - like a holy man and monkyes around the pasupati temole, cremation deth body with hindu culture ....nice place.

Intriguing place. Pashupatinath is a hindu temple area built on the banks of the river where cremations take place. It is said to have been built on a sacred site where Shiva and Parvati mated in the form of animals. It is a highly worshipped place and many big and small temples have been built over the centuries. The damages by the quakes are relatively minor. Really worth a visit.

Very-very Sacred place.. I have visited the temple last week.Only Hindus are allowed to enter in Temple premisesMany other temples are in Temple premises also such as Bhairav temple.Really a very attractive and holy temple.I extremely recommended to watch this place.

Take some time for this Holy abode. It was the first visit to Nepal and since it was a business trip didn't had much time in hand for sightseeing. But Pashupatinath temple was un-missable. It's very close to Kathmandu airport.Now, if you are visiting here, make sure you have at-least an hour's time just for main temple courtyard. It's almost nothing like ever seen. From main entrance, you can only see a huge bronze Nandi's back. Since camera not allowed, this is the only view you can click of the inner part. There are many small cupolas around with idols in the courtyard. There are lot many steps where you can peacefully sit and even meditate.The main temple itself is amazing. Probably completely made of wood and stone, with beautiful stone and wood carved figurines of Devatas. The two story building with these features is mesmerizing. The view of the main Shivalinga is through a very small door. Take enough time to look at it if there's not much crowd. The inside is only lit by Diyas.Behind and around the main temple are other structures with idols. Just behind the temple and downwards flows Bhagmati river and there is also an area for cremation of bodies. On the opposite side of the river, again there is a line of beautiful small cupolas in front of which Aarti of Bhagmati river is held. Somewhat similar to Ganga Aarti in Kashi. From here only you can click the proper pics of main temple building.Overall it's a very soulful and peaceful experience especially being among the old and beautiful structures.You may take a guide too but I was not having much time so left the option. Lots of monkeys around! Careful while carrying the Prasad packets.
interesting. found this place very interesting and informative, lots of heritage and culture and simply takes your mind back to this place where it begain

Over priced for non-Hindus. Non Hindus have to pay 1000 rupees but are not allowed inside the main sites. This is on top of the 1000 rupees return taxi fare. Unless you are very interested in watching the burning pyres next to the river I would suggest the Buddhist sites at Swayambhu and Boudha are far better excursions.

Close but not close enough. This looked good as I approached,But as i got nearer was advised could not go in as religious festival. which I respect, what i did see of it was worth the taxi ride, Also to sit by the river and soak in the atmosphere was a great experinece
Peaceful. The temple is peaceful and calm dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is a UNESCO heritage site. There are many shops outside the temple.
Magnificient Temple. The temple is very beautiful and depicts the cultural heritage. It opens early morning and in the evening.

biggesst holy place of Nepal!!!. biggest hinduism piligramage sites of Nepal and lots of temples!!!this the place where people cremation so we can feel How we burn when we died !!while visiting there feel we have nothing...there is everything!!!
Feel Blessed . This is the perfect place to feel blessed. A must visit place for Hindus. It is calm and peaceful. Visit the place and feel the divine power

authentic and humbling. Ended up spending about 2-3 solid hours here. Make sure to walk around to the riverfront. We almost didn't! It isn't clear that you can walk that way because the ground is all muddy and not paved, and sort of a mess (maybe due to last year's earthquake, but I'm really not sure). It cost us 1000 rupees each for entrance. You can't enter the actual temple unless you are Hindu, but the cremations are going on 24/7 and being able to watch this process from across the river was pretty incredible. The ritual has so many steps. It was all performed in a way that made me feel like i was watching a celebration of life, rather than watching mourning of a death. It was beautiful and completely different than anything I had ever experienced before. Be careful of the hippie priests hanging around, they lure you in for photos and then ask for steep donations in return! Otherwise, visiting this temple was a highlight of our trip to Nepal.

An amazing place for contemplation and reflection ...... Pashupatinath temple is the most important temple dedicated to lord Shiva in Nepal and one of its most scared Hindu temples. Located on the banks of the holly Bagmati river (which much further down flows into the Ganges) and at about five km from Kathmandu, Pashupathinath is the place where Hindus from both Nepal and India come to die and be cremated, in the belief that dying in Pashupathinath guarantees their rebirth not as a worm, a pig or a dog, but as human, irrespective of the misdeeds in their lives... You can, of course, observe the bodies being brought to the cremation ghats, the oldest son pouring some incents and holly water from the river before lighting the funeral pyre, then ashes being discarded into the holly Baghmati and further down the river kids playing into the water and women doing their laundry. Here, death is not the end but just another step towards Nirvana.... The temple itself (available only to Hindus) is a masterpiece of Hindu architecture and, if you are interested in religions, in other ways of thinking of life and death, then you may not like to miss a visit Pashupatinath.. .

Authentic cultural experience . The best time to go is 5:30 pm. Go for the interest of the cultural differences, explore the temple grounds, and stay for the Aarti ceremony, which starts at 7pm. You will want to be seated by 6 pm for the ceremony. I think it lasts an hour. It was definitely an authentic experience I truly enjoyed the Aarti. Seeing the burning ghats and basically "attending" a Hindi funeral was quite powerful and felt almost intrusive; however, coming to the temple and watching the "funerals" is what many people (including locals) do. Oddly enough. I never hired a guide, but wish I would have. Apparently one of the Mother Theresa homes is nearby and part of the guided "tour." I have found temple guides to be very hot or miss. When they don't know information, sometimes they make it up. It is best to check with your hotel and see if they recommend anyone. Also, taxis in Nepal are crooks. Be prepared to haggle and stick to your guns. I am hoping Ola cabs or Uber will come to give them competition.
it was excellent. gud and best historical places to be in nepal pasupatinath gives u a pleasure of everything combined peace,nature,mind and spiritual excercise.

GREAT TEMPLE. In a total disappointing tour this was the place which makeup my wastage of time and money. A great temple and place of worship. Non Hindus are not allowed but if you are Hindu you must go and seek blessings of Lord Shiva at this place. That will help you in your future lives for sure. As lord Shiva has promised all that who ever come and pray here will never be reborn as an animal.

Wonderful temple...worth one visit. Old Hindu temple is a must visit place for all Hindus.Temple boasts of a central structure which houses the four sided Shiva linga.Guards control the crowd.While support staff present in large numbers, the are still needs more cleaning.Not withstanding, a must place to visit.Do pick up great bargains on rudraksa and potas ( glass beads) outside the main complex.
Visit to Temple. Wonderful experience, a must place to visit to all Hindu devotees. Other communities can take a overlook of the temple from other side of the temple. Peaceful place.

Worth visiting, though strict rules on entry. Pashupati Temple is beautiful, with lovely grounds especially at sunset, but only Hindus are allowed in the temple itself, so many westerners and tourists will not be allowed in the temple proper. There are some scammers around as well - "shamans" who dress in full traditional attire and demand money, then try to "curse" you if you don't give them a donation. These men are not genuine, and you should not feel pressured to donate to them, even when they hold swords to your throat. Just be firm and walk away.

Prepare yourself . Not at all what I was expecting. So much culture but not prepared for the cremations happening everywhere. A guide nominated himself to us, he was at first annoying but then it was good he could share his knowledge. Freaky to see dead bodies being cleansed in the Basmati river, the smoke was from the burning bodies and it was all quite confronting. There was a funeral taking place, the body lit from the mouth to burn is not for the feint hearted to see. Not a place for children who are not prepared for what is happening. Such a memorable place to see and it's a must see, just be prepared for a confronting experience

If not Hindu, maybe not worth it. It's an interesting place, but if you are not Hindu, you will not be allowed to actually enter the temple. They will allow you to walk almost to the door and take a picture, and then they tell you about a "back door" where you can see everything. Not so! You can go around the back and see some cremations, but you still cannot actually see anything inside the temple. Considering the price (about $10) this made me more than a little frustrated. Furthermore, despite saying so on the sign, locals do not have to pay. So, the only people paying for the temple are the ones who can't even go in!Also, guides will chase you and try to tell you about the place even after you say no, monkeys are aggressive (I accidentally looked at one as I walked near it and it ran toward me to attack, but stopped when I turned my back to it), and lots of people will try to get money from you in some way or another.I give it two stars because you can walk around outside and there are some interesting things to see, but I would never go back and sort of felt that I had wasted my time.
Pashupatinath Temple. Great sight and very unusual for someone who is not Hindu. IF you are in Kathmandu it is a must to visit.

Must to be visited temple for heritage. One of the heritage hindu temple in the world where still the priest from south India appointed as a priest. It is at walkabale distance from Kathmandu Airport (hardly 2 KMS). This is a UNESCO heritage site. The temple is good, peaceful and as soon as you enter, You feel the divine touch and calmness. You are not allowed to take any photo, so be careful. You will find many shops outside where you can buy original rudraksh (considered to be part of Shiva) garland. Just behind the temple is a flowing river where people do ritual/ last rite which is not a happy scene. Beware from monkeys there

Great e to visit. Historical temple, spread in huge landscape. Well managed, maintained. Ideal time for Darshan is early morning 6-7 or in evening same time. One must attend evening Aarti to feel the aura.

Hindu Experience. A reflection of Hindu and Nepal culture. When not hindu you cannot visit the temple but you can still see the burning ghats. Just walk around, sit down and see what is happening. Don't judge, just wonder!Walk around and enjoy the holymen. They are nice photo objects, but they want to be paid for it!

superb location. superb locationnice areas views,medation surrounding peace and problem removel plazcevery nice to see ktm valley and do ing yoga's suitable for couples,friends and group too,lots of monks and touristic invironment.

Place with historical and religious value. A vibrant and great gathering of people. A large number with religious expectations. But you can't ignore the historical value also. Lots of differnt kinds and shapes of statue with heritage. A small lake inside added the beauty.

Nice temple. If you are in Kathmandu and like temples do on not miss this. Very un beautiful temple. A reflection of Nepal culture . Avoid the en guides. You can do it yourself . Watch out it will be crowded .

Feel the Hindu experience. A vibrant place which allows only Hindus inside the place. You can use the other side of the temple, if you are a non-Hindu, to feel the lively atmosphere of this ancient place

Interesting Cultural Site. quite interesting for locals. You can actually see cremations taking place. I take students there on a cultural comparison trip. It is done much differently there than in the western world. A good experience

Ultimate Divine place for Hinduism. The visit was good and had good 'darshan' but the entire visit was marred by people including the priests trying to make some money from you. It seems you can buy yourself better views and help in worshipping rituals if you are willing to spend. Indian and Nepalese go free but foreigners have to pay a fees for entry around 1000 Nepalese currency.

Like most temples in India. Unregulated crowd, dirty surroundings, monkeys waiting to catch you unguarded, a moderate-sized queue is what welcomed me at Pashupatinath Temple. An important spot to visit for Hindus for the blessings of Lord Shiva. But avoidable for non-Hindu tourists though it is a world heritage site. Just 5-7min from the airport, it is a little off from the city center.
cultural shock!. interesting to experience. take local 'guide' to hear interesting tidbits! (we were listening to dude explaining pre-cremation process - VERY interesting!)

Interesting but high entrance fee!. The entrance fee to this temple is 1000 rupees for foreigners. When I went, I saw many people just walked in and out of the temple freely but as soon as I entered, a "tourist police" stopped me and said I have to pay entrance fee. When I asked why the others do not need to pay even though it says so on the board, he merely said because I am obviously a tourist. So tip to avoid entrance fee would be to dress local and look local maybe. I point this out because I see many people walk in without paying. Anyway, the temple itself is very interesting - many stories, histories to learn and things to see. There are two places where they burn the dead bodies and usually they burn about 2.5 hours to 3 hours depending on their sex. There are fertility temples and an old sacrificial temple too which is no longer in use. A man who works there approached me as I was sightseeing the place and started giving me information about the places, I really appreciate the info he gave me and while I did not ask for his help, I decided to tip him anyway when I left. Instead of being grateful however, he lamented the tip was too little. The tip was definitely not little for such a short time of "service" but his response gave me a sour feeling throughout the rest of my day. Hope others wont have similar experience!

Eternal dilemma.... Pashupatinath Temple is a sacred place where must surely have seen during Nepal visit. Here is not only the biggest crematorium in Nepal, but also the temple which is devoted to Hindu deity Shiva. Evening time visit is strongly recommended. There is a beautiful sunset and fire dance ceremony for Shiva by the locals.

Lord Shiva's Abode. Dears, it is wonderful experience for religious pilgrimage and individual religious beliefs. persons having faith in Lord Shiva will find it as one must to do place. Lot of people thrive to this spot and enjoy the serenity and peaceful environment and religious fervour/ fragrance in the atmosphere there.

A Look Into the Hindu Culture. The Pashupatinath Temple is a very fascinating and unique place to visit in Kathmandu. Those of the Hindu faith who have passed away, are cremated by the side of Pashupatinath temple and Bagmati river.

Beautiful and unique religious complex in Kathmandu.. Although some parte were destroyed by the devastating earthquake, there are many beautiful temples to see. Essential temple area to visite once time in Kathmandu. I wish the river was cleaner anyway it is a mystic and important place for cremations. Also there are some sadhus

Excellent Clean Temple. This is one of the place hindus consider holy and a must visit to offer prayer to lord shiva. The temple is clean and the day we visited it was less crowded. No visible damage to the main temple structure due to earthquake

A historical place for cremation of deceased persons from Hindu community. For any Devotee of different religion, this is regarded as a holy place. The dead body of Hindu people is cremated here with religious honor. Before cremation, it is kept in the bank of canal where parts of body washed to purify from all misdeed. The relatives and loved ones of the deceased person pay their last homage with due profound love. Throughout the area one can get in touch with religious mind. One can take picture at some designated place and can take memory of being part of a farewell ceremony human's soul toward LORD.

Religious Pilgrimage. Pashupatinath Temple is the Temple of Lord Shiva, who is one of the three renowned Gods as per Hindu religion. There are four doors in all four directions and in each direction you can see face of Shiva. Though one door remains open all the time, all four doors are open only two times a day.The temple is decorated with ancient arts. You will see different activities of deities in the art. These include also the sexual activities. Around the Pashupatinath temple, are different statues of other Gods including monkey god (hanuman), Bishnu, Bhairava, Basukinag, Krishna, etc.Shiva is also considered having responsible after the death of people. So, dead bodies are cremated by the side of Pashupatinath temple and Bagmati river. Cremation ceremony is also new thing for people of other religions.

An interesting place. Not being Hindu were weren't allowed to enter the temple but we could approach its entrance which showed a large bronze statue. It was very busy with Hindi's visiting, because of its importance we wish we'd had someone to describe more about its significance and what in inside the temple.

Mixed Feelings. Its a famous temple of Hindu faith & its a must visit if you are religious. I was overwhelmed by cremation happening at the bank of the river , where bodies are washed and cremated. There's smoke and ash in the air. The temple, the deities and some of the structures are good and worth a view. Some of the priests are very uniquely dressed. Whats surprising is that the non SAARC country tourists pay a premium amount to enter the premises but they are not allowed to enter the temple as they are not Hindus. There was an American with us and our guide told him not to enter. Thats funny and sad !!

Temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. This is the most revered Temple of Nepal. We visited on a Monday hence had to wait long to get darshan with mile long queues. Very orderly with no pushing and shoving which made the experience pleasant. Photography prohibited inside the temple. For Hindus this temple is a must visit to seek the blessings of Lord Shiva.

Large temple and area. This was a nice visit with a guided tour. Again to fully understand these sites it's worth the money ( which isn't a lot ) to pay a guide. The "holy" men at the endWill take pictures with you but they except to be paid. From what my guide told me, they come from India during tourists season and lay around by temple take pictures for money and then go back after season is over. Not completely sure that's a "holy man" in my world but a couple bucks will get you a cool photo id you like.

place of eternal peace. The holiest of the holiest temple is one of my favorite place when i need to seek for peace of mind. The carnation place is where the dead are burnt is where you will find the answers to a lot of your unanswered questions.

To be seen, but maybe only once. Having said that this place is obviously a must for visitors, as it is a deeply meaningful journey for any Hindu follower from anywhere, here more than any other spot I saw in Kathmandu I had the feeling that visitors were out of their place. The temple has a distinct religious flair, a sizeable section of its grounds are not accessible by non-Hindu visitors (you can only peer at it from the opposite bank of the stream). Cremation grounds are (a bit sadly) an attraction for visitors, photos can be taken at will (contrary to what happens in Varanasi where photos are a more sensitive issues). The sadhus waiting for visitors, available to pictures against a small handout, do not add very much to the sanctity of the place. The stream (as you can’t call it a river) flowing within the temple grounds is not a beautiful sight either. As compared with the other spots I have visited in Kathmandu, this is probably the only one where I thought that, having been here once, I wouldn’t feel the need to be back.

A vibrant location. Located on the Bagmati River, Pashupatinath Temple is a beautiful location. This hindu temple is dedicated to the god Shiva. The roof is made of copper and gold!Since we are not Hindu we were not allowed to enter the temple but there was plenty to see and do in the area.Multiple funeral fires were burning along the river. We were able to see the entire ceremony from the arrival of the body until the final flame went out.Sadhaus, wandering yogi's can be seen yellow tight paintFind a place to sit along the river and just watch.
An experience.. An opportunity to see a different approach to death - but not if your squeamish. You will see dead bodies.

Open air cremations . We went with a guide which was invaluable. This Hindhu temple is where you will witness open air cremations, (we don't have these in our country). We felt like intruders but our guide talked us through what was happening and led us in closer. This was intriguing, educational and for me an emotional visit witnessing the ceremonies the families were conducting. My teenager said it was one of the best things we did in Kathmandu. Allow yourself plenty of time.

Pashupathinath temple, Kathmandu. Just about 10 to 15 minutes walking distance from the Airport, (taxis are available but ask a lot if one can bargain can get for a good price.). Very ancient temple, with lot of religious and Historical importance, one should include visit to this temple in their itinerary , supposed to be one of the Jyotirlingas of Lord shiva of Hindu mythology. The 12 JYOTHIRLINGAS IN India are the body and lord pashupathinath is considered the head of all those, gives a sense of peace and serenity which I could get during a visit to this temple
average temple. not really maintained, very crowded. It was full of priests trying to get you to do a puja. Didnt find it as exciting as it is made out to be
A Must. Go with a Nepali friebd who can explain what you are seeing - enrich the experience. If you are here in KTM for Sivaratri this is a fascinating time to visit, but will be crowded

Very intense experience . While I've learned that there are ghats I felt that it is something I don't want to miss. I got some hints that during this part of the year the river has a very little water. Paying 1000 npr as a renovation fee feels that you could see some progress and there was one part under reconstruction but probably it would be even better to use it for cleaning services. I was amazed that this holiest place is as dirty as any other part of KTM. Funeral ceremonies and cremations are intense but maybe more natural than our 'western' death hiding approach.

Very disappointing. I expected it to be similar to Varanassi..... It is far from it. It is expensive to get in and then there were lots of beggars so if you give take some change too. The water is filthy and Kathmandu needs to re think the effects of its rubbish on this river.

One of its kind. This place is one of its kind. You may find a lot of sadhus here in the backside of the temple. There are burning ghats on the back side of the temple where the dead are burnt according to the hindu traditions.
Kathmandu is incomplete without this visit. A truly divine place which invites everyone visiting Kathmandu to seek blessings of lord Shiva. the architecture of the temple is ancient and beautiful.

filled with holy mantras. i find this place very very beutiful. me and other 2 friend who are hindus came here for some prayers and at the same time to explore this beautiful holy place.we went to this place around 9am..it was packed..everyone came for rituals.. not being a hindu..this something very intresting for me.. we were brough in by our tour guaide..and we visited almost all small-small temples. and started our prayes.. being a sikh..i was amaized that this place actually has a gurdwara in it.was so happy to visit this place and witness all the prayes and rituals that was done:) i wasnt chased out of this place just because im not a hindu..and i respect that alot
Very good for Hindus . Excellent - clean- spacious-properly arranged- god can be seen from all 4 rides- funeral going on one area- 500+ Lingas look good- must visit place in kathmandu

Somber moments. There was a lot of cremations being carried out while we visited the temple. We learnt a lot from this. Temple areas were very busy in general. Worth a visit. Check out where the sadhu's live etc

One of the best temple in Kathmandu. If you're looking for religius places in Kathmandu, i recommend this temple for you. But, the ticket is quite expensive. It's cost NPR 1000 for each person. You'll see a lot of temple and little monkey. And also, there's a river for funerals.
Interesting. One of the most holy places in Nepal. Public cremation is not something we are used to. The whole process is very respectful.

worth the ticket price. You're foreign, you'll get dinged. I did not like that they did not let my Hindu friend into the Hindu temple because she was foreign, so, if management is reading this, your security guards are rude and unpleasant. Otherwise, this is an incredible place to be respectful and visit. It is a beautiful and holy place, and please be respectful of the dead. A very interesting cultural experience and while morbid, also beautiful to see life, death, and rebirth. Worth going to, worth even paying for, and or getting a guide.

Mice pray. I been early in the meaning to very pice place for prayer to almighty. To much happy to go there.I prayer to almighty and get maid refreshment.There also have lookrative something which one attract me as well.

Temple of holi god Mahadev or Shiva. Most religious Hindu only temple (Non Hindu are not allowed to enter), temple complex is on UNESCO World Heritage site. The major Festivals of the temple is Maha Shivaratri, on that day around 1 Million devotees visit here. Temple has 4 entrances in all 4 directions.Temple is also Famous for cremation. If you are non-hindu you can see the view of temple from the other bank of Bagmati river(holy river).

Meet Mortality Face-to-Face. There aren't many places in the Western world where one comes so directly face-to-face with mortality any more. Because of that, you'll either love or hate Pashupatinath. You either think the open-air funeral pires are a natural way to send loved ones back to the earth (dust to dust) or you'll find it a grotesque death ritual. Or both.Pashupatinath is also more than that. It's a huge Hindu complex (although some parts are off-limits to non-Hindus). You'll see, meet, and take pictures with holy Sadus. Bring a guide; you'll need one to get the most of your experience.
Sadu. Pashupatinath is one of riligious and tourist palace near temple one small river and small jungle call ban cali around their to meny hindu munks call sadu also to meny more good thing....
Must see place in Kathmandu!. It is absolutely not damaged after earthquake so it is nr1 object to visit in Kathmandu! And of course you can witness the rituals in local crematoria.

Good day trip. I visit Pasupati temple which is really good Experience.i really enjoyed their.My tour guide was very professional and helpful.Highly recommended for all who are interesting about culture and Hindu religion.

Beautiful Hindu Temple. This is the most sacred Hindu temples in the world. The architecture of the temple was very beautiful. There are lots of monkeys around the temple. You must to see this Pashupati Temple, if you are in Kathmandu!!

Confronting if you witness a Cremation, but a Must See !. Definitely a must see, and most european visitors will be polarized by it. For myself, I was fascinated and it was a highlight, but i suspect that for some it will seem to be a shadow of what it used to be and displays something that they would consider to be distasteful. However, it must be remembered that this is a working temple for Hindu's and they are less concerned about what tourists think and more concerned about the way that they grieve their lost ones. Culturally it is as authentic as it comes and therfore for me it was perhaps one of the highlights of Nepal, along with Treking. Make sure yu get a guide, as it will make all the difference. Also don't plan to do any more temples that day as it will be hard to get your head out of this visit.
The holy temple. I only know its the biggest temple and the holy temple in our Hindu community and i know more by getting with this guys.

Extremely interesting. This is another of the "must-see" places around Kathmandu. You'll get to see people getting cremated. I would recommend hiring a good guide who will teach you about all the rituals, the culture, the meaning of the various statues etc. Lots to see apart from the cremations of course, it's a big place, make time for it.

The pashupatinath. One of the most famous blessing shivas temple is called pashupatinath . Its a major temple of Hindu religion its a place of the UNESCO heritage place . So please visit there and feel a Hindus religious culture ~♥

Not for the faint of heart!. This temple is the msot important Hindu temple in Kathmandu. Peolpe from all ver coem here as pilgrims or for their loved oens to be cremated. The grounds are very large and you will need at least 2 hours to take it all in, especially if you want to assist to the whole ceremony of cremation. Not for the faint of heart!

Fascinating. It costs 1000 rupees for foreigners. Non-Hindu's cannot enter the temple itself. The fascinating side is the river where the bodies are cremated. Tourists are allowed to watch from the opposite side (quite close) to see the burying rituals they perform. Allow at least an hour.
Best historic monument for Hindus. Pashupatinaths temple is large in area. there are lots of shivalinga can be seen here and the area is clean except river side better place for Hindus...

Cremations and relentless touts. Free and scary monkeys. The monkeys here are aggressive, big and fearless. they will take things from you and stand their ground when challenged. I was warned they bite and told they may have rabies. I was told not to make eye contact with them as they may attack. How nice!This temple is where they publically cremate people. The river was low and there are piles of ashes. There are also stacks of wood for the burnings. I was told it usually takes 4 hours to burn a man and 3 to burn a woman.Lots of religious men who want money for photos. Not pocket change either! The 'guides' are quite forceful but mine was good and I am glad I hired him. He told me a lot. 1000 Rupees to get in and 500 for the guide.

If you are Hindu devotee, this is the place you should visit.. It is believed that the culmination of the Panch Kedar Yatra (pilgrimage) to Siva temples is at Pashupatinath temple. As a proof, it is stated that Lord Shiva’s head is worshipped here.For a casual traveler, better avoid, as the place is not clean and always stink and smoke from the cremation of dead

A shame about the squalor. A recurring theme in Nepal is sadly the needless filth. People seem happy enough to just toss things from car windows etc, resulting in piles of garbage everywhere. Nowhere is this more obvious or saddening than heritage sites like Pashupatinah. The riverbanks are awash in garbage, despite this being one of the most sacred sites for the local community. Why they do this is beyond me, as is the government's failure to employee people to clean it up. Easily fixed, I hope they take note. The area is fascinating, with rich architecture and ceremony on display. Watching the dead be prepared for cremation is a somber experience but also a spiritual one. It can feel strange to observe this and walk amongst mourners but it seems to be the accepted norm. A great place to reflect on your own existence and mortality.
Spiritual abode of Supreme God. Nice place and good for spiritual people who dont look for modern facilities. Impressive temple complex with River ghat for funeral services. , very nice place
Holy Temple. A must visit in Kathmandu for every one. A big, holy and ancient temple. You have to be careful with the fleecing middlemen and the monkeys.

Over rated. Filthy river, dirty monuments, expensive entry fee, no access to main temple. Sadhus (holy men) offering themselves in photo for a fee. Not my thing, in spite of the impressive size of complex.
HOLY TEMPLE. A must visit place in Kathmandu.A big temple to visit.You need no guide to visit this temple.Very ancient temple of Hindus.

An eye opening experience. Truly an eye opening experience. As our guide explained to us how the bodies are burned and then disposed into the river, I can't help buy to have a million questions in my mind as to how amazing this place is. Go with an open heart and you will learn a lot.
Unparalleled religious asset..... Mixture of religious pilgrimage, learning ancient culture, developing positive psychology for future endeavour

Highly commended, but expensive. As regular visitors to Nepal, we have always made it our business to go to Pashupatinath, as it is a very sacred and revered place for Hindus. It use to be free to attend, but costs were introduced when it was adopted as a World Heritage site and over the years the cost have risen to Rs1000, which in my view is a little too much for those on a budget. Some travellers may think it is a bit morbid to watch cremations, but within the context of Nepal, local people are interested that we are interested in their practices. On the day we went, we saw an unprecedented number of deceased persons brought in; at least 9. This time we observed a very elaborate cremation with the ghat decorated with a canopy and garlands of marigolds. Alongside the cremations you will see all the people working to prepare the ghats and clear up after each event. As a cremation is taking place, you will see the mourners, the role of different family members, and at the same time there are the youth's with large magnets on string dredging the river for coins, dogs napping in the sun and monkey's chasing each other. Other bereaved people have returned to undertake required rituals. You may see a snake resting on a sandbag and worry when it drops into the trickle of pre-monsoon river.Away from the river the Sadhu's ply their 'trade', but be aware they require payment if you photograph them!There seemed to be little evidence of quake damage and I was told that the original design of the buildings meant that they are quake resistant. Some parts of the site are only open to Hindus, but this does not deter some tourists from over intrusive closeup photography!I understand that an electric crematorium is due to be installed in the future, so life at Pashupatinath will change, but this may reduce the number of trees cut down.Given the amount of entrance money collected over the years, there has been some improvement to the site and development, but facilities for tourists are still limited and signage and information could be improved. This is a site that is worth a visit.

Return to Pashupatinath. This was my first visit to Pashupatinath since the earthquake. I have always liked visiting this place as I find it quite peaceful and moving in a strange way.The charge of 1000Rs to enter I find to be too much and always object but end up paying. This year the area was dirtier than previous years. It really does need to be cleaned. Not much water although I appreciate the monsoon is awaited - but the areas in front of the ghats do need some attention. One of the little bridges looked very precarious with a huge crack.Some tourist were very disrespectful by crossing to the temple side and interfering in funeral rites by taking intrusive photos - please don't do this. Stay on the opposite side and use your long lens if you have to. It gets very hot in full sun do if you are thinking of sitting and watching for a while make sure you have water and a hat and sunscreen.

Ancient Hindu Temple dedicated to Lord Shiva ( Pashupati Nath). Its an ancient Hindu Temple located very near to Kathmandu Airport... on the banks of River Bagmati... Only Hindus allowed to enter here...

Good spot to visit. Covers a large area, and only Hindu's can go into main temple. There is a charge to visit the area. Suggest if someone offers to guide you, go for it but bargain on the price, it will be worth it for the information etc.
amazing. I have visited pashupatinath temple during my kathmandu visit. it is really worth full to visit. i suggest to visit once whice travelling kathmandu

Interesting but worth a visit. It does cost 1000 rupees to enter the ground but not the temple itself. you have to be hindu. No notification of this when getting the ticket.
