I did meet some other tourist who walked around the same place I did for free.Cremations at the back of the temple were interesting but sad in my opinion. very public with tourists taking photographs and video.Worth the trip and decide if you wish to pay or not. You can walk from Thamel maybe takes a hour but interesting walk to see life in Kathmandu

Oldest Hindu temple in Nepal. Pashupatinath is the oldest Hindu temple in Nepal. The temple is an old architecture building and is surrounded by a big park. behind is a big lake. the temple says and ask only hindu to visit inside the main campus. the temple also has a lot of monkeys around. you will see many smaller shrines and the cremations on one side of the Bagmati Rivier, and priests ministering to the faithful on platforms on the other side. This was the highlight of our cultural tour of Kathmandu.
one . pilgrimage place once visited pashupatinath to meny Hindu manks also nice sankaa ghanta nearly bagmati rivers but rivers was very small
Never forget.. Diferent culture. You must to see if you are in Kathmandu. Just seat down and stay for a half an hour.

Expensive, but a must see. 1000 rupees for foreigners, but you have to make a special effort to walk into pay. I think you could just walk down the street for free, I'm not sure anyone would stop you. We were with a guide, so he made us pay. Sat by the river (not much water and filthy) to watch the bodies be cremated. Absolutely fascinating. All the rituals they perform and setting up the funeral wood. May not be for the faint hearted as you can see the dead people's faces in 1 part. Constant cremations going on. Walked up the hill for a view of the temple. Non Hindus are not allowed in. Well worth a visit. Allow an hour.

A bit of a con but still.... If u r not Hindu they won't let u in! Beware. U pay the 1000 Rps entrance fee and all u r permitted to view is the burning ghats at the back plus the ancient stupas dotting the compound. So make the most of your money and see all u can c! Cremation starts at around 10:30 AM and u wanna b there for that. To get to the stupas at the back u will need to climb a steep set of stairs. It is nice and quiet over there. I took a taxi from Thamel amid paid 500.
Vast temple complex. This important pilgrimage site on the edge of Kathmandu draws the faithful from around the Kathmandu Valley.

Sunset visit. Not sure what time is the best to witness the whole ritual taking place real time. But sunset visit is enchanting. Go around 5, walk around and up to the top. There are seats so you can comfortably watch the sunset.

The Tempels in Kathmandu. Yes, there have been several earthquaks in Nepal. The Tempels are beeing rebuilt allready and it is worth visiting them all though some of them are demaged. The Monkey Temples were a great experience. Don`t take a taxi all the way up. It s much more interesting to walk all the 365 steps together with Nepalis and others, surrounded by monkeys. Take a extra strong grab orund your wather bottle and belongings. The monkeys are much faster than you think they are.

"Hindu Most Need to Visit". The Temple is the one of the oldest temple and also the very important and historical.The temple is the place where Hindu believed that the Lord shiva stay and protect the animals. so its is known as the Pashupatinath Temple. Many people go there to worship and visit but the special day is shivaratri.  If you are not hindu you are not allowed to enter the main temple of shiva. Vey Beautiful place to visit if you are in Kathmandu Nepal.
A must do for believers. Ancient temple with huge faith in Lord shiva. Remains closed during the afternoon. Rudraksha is given here as Prasad. Be aware of monkeys.

Spiritualistic visit with a scenic view of Kathmandu. Pashaputi Temple's extensive grounds include many other old and important temples, shrines and statues. A very interesting and worthwhile place to visit.

A unique experience. If you are ready to climb a bit and are interested in seeing Hindu devotees performing rituals, this is the right place for you. The temple compound is quite big, and has a lot of interesting things to offer. You better go there and experience it.

Shame on Nepal. We returned from Nepal a month ago. First visit since the earthquake one year ago this week, but my 5th or 6th visit since 1967. Pashipatinath used to be a fun place to visit. It, and Muktinath, are two of the 51 Shakti Pithas revered by Hindus, that are found in the hills of Nepal. Located on the bank of the Bhagmati River, and now a World Heritage site, it is a 20 minute taxi ride from the center of Kathmandu, and just west of the airport. In 1967, there were open fields and rice paddys around the temple, but now there is solid suburban sprawl. And, as before, only "Hindus" are allowed into the temple. Us heathen non-Hindus can only peer into the entrance around the giant Nandi, or look down from across the river, which in itself is entertaining, but not satisfying. I say shame on Nepal because this sacred river is now a sewer filled with trash and plastic bottles. Why they would allow this to happen to a World Heritage site is beyond me. The universal attitude there, and many other areas in Nepal, is "It's not my job." Nepal has received millions of dollars in foreign aid, but the government and the overseers of the temple can't even organize a trash pickup. For a country that earns most of it's foreign exchange from tourism and mountaineering, revers a sacred river in its capital, and has hoards of destitute citizens looking for work, why they can't accomplish such a simple, low-tech task like picking up trash, is beyond me. Instead of Pashupatti, I suggest going to the nearby Baudanath Stupa. It too suffered damage from the earthquake, but repairs are well underway. Visitors can circumambulate the stupa and unlike Pashuaptti, are welcome to enter the numerous Tibetan Gompas surrounding the stupa. There are several places to get lunch or tea, and a nice selection of shops. Best of all, there are no cars or motorcycles allowed in the walkway around the stupa. Highly recommended.

Very interesting. A very interesting and worthwhile place to visit. I thought I'd be grossed out by the cremations going on, but wasn't bothered by the it. We actually hired a guide to take us around... Definitely worth the 1000 rs for the hour long tour. Interestingly enough, some of the visitors there thought we were and attraction and there was a line of 5 people wanting to take pictures with us.
Pilgrimage. Ancient and very famous temple of Lord Pashupatinath... worth visit...on tge bank of river Bagmati... very near to international airport...

A somber site worth visiting. This is not the easiest site to visit in that it is, in its most fundamental sense, a disposal site for human bodies. Every society has a methodology for accomplishing this task but here it is all very visible to anyone who wants to watch. That said, it is interesting and educational to see how Nepalis accomplish this task.

Great experience. This temple was rebuilt in the 17th century after the moghuls had torn it down but the original temple was built many hundreds of years prior to this. You are only allowed to visit the temple if you are a hindu but there is still much to see for non hindus including the main ghat area where bodies are cremated. Whilst there were many tourists sitting watching intently, this aspect of the temple area wasnt for me, but this ancient Shiva temple is a must for anyone visiting KTM.

Disappointing. The temple is beautiful but it is absolutely dirty. There are way too many animals, and garbage piles everywhere. They didn't clean the goat/dog/cow crap inside the temple campus. Extremely disappointed. Its a shame UNESCO has not taken over the temple knowing that Nepal needs money to upkeep the temple. As I walked through the temple buildings (its a huge complex with lots of temple buildings) I could conjure up an image of what it would have looked like years ago (better than any Chinese hollywood movie that showed long corridors and elegant walkways)
I felt Blessed by Lord Shiva !. Our main objective was to visit Pashupatinath Temple. I felt like I was in god shiva's heaven. Our family were blessed by God Shiva.

So interesting and unique!. My husband and I typically travel without a guide. I'd have to say, we would've made a huge mistake if we didn't have a guide here. I wish I could remember his name, but a very nice university student (there are many "guides" around) gave us a fantastic tour. Well worth the stop. We were even able to observe the end of a cremation.

Skip the entrance - sneak in. Very interesting temple to observe the crematoria and funeral ceremonies. Entrance fee is 1000 NPR, that's nonsense so we sneaked in. Follow the crown towards the Hindu temple, stop before the entrance because non-Hindus cannot enter. Hike up the hill to your left, about 100 meters in you will see a fence. Follow the fence to the right, the fence ends in 50m where you will see the river. Cross the fence (no climbing needed) and follow the path down to the river, that will lead you to the crematoria which is exactly where you need to be. Good luck.

Hindu cremations. I visited today. The entrance fee is 1000 NPR. It is just a shame that the area is so dirty with rubbish and beggars and filthy children and the drug addicts.Whilst I was there they were carrying out the Hindu ceremonies and cremations. There was a very elaborate and colourful ceremony and across the bridge a simple one. I didn't stay for the actual burning. I have never seen anything like that before, so interesting.

Jai Bam bholenath. Good who believe in God very beautiful temple You love to the go Pashupatinath temple one off biggest temple in Nepal Tere was write in Wall of entry gate only Hindu comunity will entry in this temple this is only one temple in world there was only Hindu enter this templ Thank you

75% of the country is Hindu so go to the main Hindu temple!. Seeing as 75% of the country is Hindu it makes sense to go to this beautiful temple. It is very busy every day but generally follow the crowds and you will be ok. The site is free entry so don't expect to pay for anything unless a guide picks you out. I didn't have a guide so wasn't able to learn much about the site. Unfortunately the main temple is strictly for Hindu people only. Go around the back of the main site across the river and you can watch the emotional and religious cremation of the recently deceased. It is a very interesting and touching to watch. From there I recommend going up the steps as there are plenty of photos to be taken. Keep an eye on your possessions as the monkeys (yes, actual monkeys) are very sneaky.

Powerful and fascinating. My family and I visited this temple late afternoon on a Friday. Entry fee is $10 per person and we did choose to hire a guide- we have done this at many temples here and found it added to our understanding. Learning about Hindu funeral rites was most fascinating. Also seeing the vast amount of monkeys, dogs and goats roaming the place. Non Hindus are not allowed in the pilgrimage temple but that seems right and correct. The body preparation is done right out in the open and this is so different from my home culture. It was spiritual and communal- we were all feeling quite vulnerable and adding to our understanding of life.I am so glad we made this part of our trip.
Informative for Eastern Culture. place to observe ceremonial activities of Hindus. Visitors can observe the dead is being ceremonially cleaned and cremated using wood
Hindu area. There you can see where the people goes when they died. You can follow one ceremony and get a internal guide to explain to you. It is much better, but make a deal about price first.

Rich in history. This Hindu temple dates back hundreds of years and is a must for the Kathmandu tourist. A sacred cremation site that sits on the bank of the Bagmati River and is a hive of activity any day of the week. There is also the usual markets. Entry costs 1000 rupees per person. Beware of the guide that you pick up along the way without knowing it before it's too late. Be sure to negotiate the total price before the 'tour'. What out for the 'it's a per person' price line at the end. Actually tour might be best booked with a reputable company in Thamel.

Always gripping. This is a very holy place where cremations take place behind or in the temple for Shiva. The ceremony of washing of the body and preparing it for purification by fire is very beautiful and respectful! If you go on a full moon evening you may see priests doing a fire ceremony !

Expensive to Enter!. We did a 'temple tour' around Kathmandu and the adjacent cities and this was by far the most expensive to enter. But in saying that, the ticket also gave you entrance to the Crematorium as well. The temple itself isn't too dissimilar to some of the other temples in Kathmandu, but it's well worth checking out. Be warned though, the air is very heavy with smoke from the Crematorium.

The Hindu Place to be. Back in time. One of the most ancient paces in the world. Only beware of the monkeys. Entry fee for non-hindus is 1000 Nprs. With the money the site is preserved and one can see construction works going on.

Definitely should be on your list of Kathmandu sights to see. As one of the most sacred Hindu temples in the world, it's definitely a place to visit whilst in Kathmandu. Entry is 1000 rupees, so one of the more expensive temples to visit. You WILL be inundated with 'guides' who will accompany you around the temple and explain the significance of the temple/carvings/paintings/architecture. You may try to escape them but they will loiter after you until you pointedly tell them 'no'. That being said, they are rather handy with providing you with a route around the grounds and for taking tourist pics for you. The cremation pyres lining the river Bagmati, which is rather dirty, are in regular use. The day we went to visit there were three cremations. There is something rather... unsettling about being a tourist and witnessing a widow's grief at cremating her husband, all the while watching other tourists snapping furious pictures with over-sized Canon cameras. Brightly coloured and well-humoured Sadhus can be found and they're happy to take a picture with tourists, for a price. Around 100 rupees to take pictures with them. Don't be cheap and take pictures from a distance, fork over your 100 rupees. The monkeys that lurk around the temple are harmless and certainly less frightening than the hawkers that lurk at the entrance to the temple (and they WILL follow you to the car park!!) All in all, it's a holy site threshed with tourist features. Go see it.

good temple, very poor maintenance. the architecture of the temple was very nice but the temple maintenance is very poor- floors were very dirty. Crowd was a bit loud and unruly- not dangerous in any way but just spoils the experience.
Burial site. This is where you go to watch the dead being burned as per local traditions. Beware of the strong smell and smoke.

Fascinating but beware the funeral pyres. Walking to the Pashupati entrance is an experience in itself. The way we went was through a mass of crowds thronging a street market. Monkeys walked along the stall roofs and the power lines. 1000 rupees gets visitors into the temple area but only Hindus can go into the main temple. There is plenty to see - from the buildings themselves to the monkeys, the Sadhus (Hindu priests) and, not least, funeral pyres.The temple sits on the banks of a river that flows, eventually, into the Ganges. So, the Hindus build their funeral pyres on the bank and scatter the ashes onto the water. Be prepared for clouds of pungent smoke issuing from these fires.And, if you want a photo with the colourful, seemingly eccentric Sadhus, be prepared to pay.

Serene and. The Nearest landmark for the temple is Gowshala with the best time to visit being around sunset.This is definitely a place worth a visit. The entire aura is quite electric and there is a peace that is undefinable.There are some restrictions based on the religion practices. For e.g. Only Hindus and Buddhists are allowed in the Sanctum Sanctorum.Photography is prohibited in the temple compound and is enforced. Shoe Stands and Potable Water are available.The Aarti of the river in the evening is amazing.You may be surprised by the monkeys' 'playfulness', but they are harmless,

Mecca of Hindus. It was 1997 when I first visited Nepal. A bunch of my relatives are settled there in and around Birganj, Nepal Ganj, Pokhra, Biraatnagar, Raxaul and Kathmandu. My parents joined me the second time and we happened to be there just 5 days prior to the massive earthquake that devastated Kathmandu totally. Pashupatinath is one of the greatest Hindu temples in Nepal. It is one of the World Heritage site as well. The view of Pashupatinath from the Kailash Danda was really amazing. It was great visiting this place. It is quiet similar to the Kashi Vishwanath temple of Varanasi in India but on a smaller scale. Unlike Varanasi they allow you to take pictures here. The burial ground in the vicinity adds a touch of difference out here, however post the quake things now have a very different picture.
Pious temple with great energy. This temple is one of the Jyotirlingas and everyone must visit this temple as it has great energy In the main temple as well as the Bhairarnath temple.

Most important Hindu temple in Nepal. Not only is this the most important Hindu temple in Nepal, but it's one of the most important Shiva temples on the subcontinent and draws devotees from all over India. Colorful place, you'll enjoy the numerous monkeys. Not well maintained, but still impressive. The holy men are "worth the price of admission." Plan on giving them at least 50 rupees if you want to take their picture, and you will.

Highlight of Kathmandu. I've been to almost every must-go history attractions in Kathmandu but Pashupatinath can be the most interesting one. The ticket entrance is more expensive than any other place in Nepal and the main temple is not allowed for non-Muslim. However, we have unforgettable half day walking around here and listen to a local guy explaining about the circle of life. The highlight part of the temple, must be, to me, is the cremation where you can see people burn the dead bodies in the river.

Teaches one a lot. This is probably one of the places in Kathmandu that is most striking. Since there are so many dead people burning there, it definitely challenges once perceptions of death. However death in Nepal is looked at differently, it is just the in-between step to another incarntion. Burning the dead, according to the numerous rules and rituals, is very captivating and striking to see. Defintely dicates a lot of respect and appreciation. The only thing that disappointed me were the saddhus over there. Anyone that has at least a simple idea about saddhus knows that they are rather solitary, very serious practitioners actually, not approaching other people lightly. The saddhus we saw at Pashupatinath are attractions. They approached right away with offers to take a photo with them or asking for money directly. Saddhus are normally considered very holy men, so for me, it was a bit disappointing to see these "saddhus" creating a very misinformed image. Hopefully in some of the many caves around Pashupatinath, there are some practicing ones too.

Er what? I paid £6 for a temple I can't go in.... I only wanted to go to the Crematoria and thats what I did, I didn't really see much of the temple grounds at all, certainly not 1000Npr worth!I was told i could go anywhere so I did (except the temple, oh and the army bit) I went and watched a few baby funerals and then a few full size adults, because I'm interested in that and it was fascinating, very.I ended up with a front row seat in fact, at one point all the mourners (there's not actually much mourning going on except by perhaps the main relative) moved themselves around me accidentally whilst they talked business as they moved away from the burning body I was completely in the middle of them all, nobody minded in the slightest.If you're not sure of how to behave at a funeral then i wouldn't recommend going in close but if you have some genuine compassion then go take look.I wonder if people on the other side of the river don't pay if they arrive from that side.
Don't pass this by... This was an amazing surprise! Alluring and striking! The grounds are extensive be prepared to walk them, it's well worth it!

Truly divine to watch the Arathi. It was a monday and i was told the best time go in the evening between 6 and 7. Reached the gate to see walls in ruins after the earquake of 2015. But the air and the chime of temple bells simlpy was divine enough to rush in.As you enter the amazing 25feet bronze Nandi rests right in front . Pass thru and up the stairs and its was a blessing to see all the 4 doors open of Mahadevs inner chamber..wont forget the moment and amazing feeling.

Great. its a great place. very old temple, many monkey around you for see food. its not far from Kathmandu city center (Thamel). There have HIndu Religion funeral ( born dead body electric way). This temple is bank of Bagmati River. Recommend if you travel Nepal.

The holy place. The only holy place in earth for Hindus after kashi, the holy temple located be side of river bagmati and river also holy for Hindu,and for tourist can understand how devoted by Hindu. Just say jai sambho.

Nepal's No. 1 Hindu Religious destination. Worth a visit, even tho' Nepal's new constitution no longer considers it to be a Hindu nation.There's a lot going around Pashupatinath: open cremations; frolicking monkeys who are always looking for a bite to eat; to avoid this don't carry anything edible. On the burning ghats - cremation platforms - there is always someone being cremated. Poignant scenes and, some quite gruesome to watch.

Not a great tourist attraction but such an important site. Pashupatinath is a very holy temple by a polluted river (as usual in this part of the world sadly) where devout Hindu's cremate their loved ones. Considering non-Hindus cannot enter the temple itself, the Rs.1,000 fee to enter the grounds is quite steep (unless you are a Hindu visitor I guess) but I actually understand that to some extent this is a place for deeply sombre occasions so perhaps it is a deliberately high fee to restrict numbers getting too huge. Nevertheless what you get for your ticket is access to the side of the river and to some sections where worshippers burn bundles of paper. By the river you may witness a funeral and it feels a bit voyeuristic. There's nothing to stop you taking photographs of a woman wailing at her late husband's funeral (albeit from a reasonable distance) but do you really want to be that person? That said, there was a boy selling candyfloss to some of the non-funeral visitors so make up your own opinion.Surrounding this temple are people with probably some of the most photogenic outfits in Nepal. Many of which may be dressed so in order to solicit tourists to pay to photograph them. I don't know if this is just something extra on the side for them or if they dress purely for this purpose. By the look of their waistline I suspect it is the latter.And that's pretty much it. It's not a big site. And surrounding the temple grounds are the usual tourist predators. Someone will slap a dot on your forehead and then expect you to give them money. I avoided my encounter with a Matrix-like duck backwards. To be honest I didn't really enjoy my visit. It is one of those things you HAVE to do when you visit Kathmandu. Tight lipped travellers with baggy clothed trousers will point to their guidebooks and insist that you're wasting your valuable time in Kathmandu if you don't visit and "you've flown half way across the world". Personally I'd rather visit a bar and find some locals to chat with. Then the tight lipped ones will return stressed and sweaty. The red dot on their forehead will show you they've been liberated of a couple of extra dollars and mark them out as targets for vendors for the rest of the day. Kathmandu is actually pretty laid back and tourists don't generally get hounded. This place is a bit of an exception. Visit. If you must.

Soothing . I have visited nepal three times earlier on business but never got the opportunity to see this historical temple. Feeling blessed to have visited the temple just before evening reopening at five p.m. I visited on a day when fellow tourists were less. The experience cannot be described in words. Especially the maze with numerous shivalingam is a surreal experience.

Visiting the temples during funerals. This place has a deep spiritual connection and witnessing the funerals and burning of those who have past was certainly a different experience. The guides are very pushy and wont actually leave you alone even if you tell them that your not interested. The guides and people demand a lot of money and make you feel very uncomfortable. They will force you to pose with temple men and charge in excess of a thousand to have a photo taken. I have been there once and would not be in a rush to return there are more temples in Kathmandu that are beautiful and have a nice welcoming vibe to them. Not a place I would fully recommend unless your able to say no to a guide quiet forcible and have them actually listen and not block your path and harasses you until you agree.

Interesting but not for the faint-hearted. Personally I did not enjoy visiting this place but I know others do. The smell can be nauseating and it's very dusty when the wind blows across the river. There are normally several cremations going on, across the river, at the same time. It's all very respectful but I really didn't like being there.

An wonderful place on any day, overwhelming on Maha Shivaratri. I was one of 1.2 million people to visit Pashupatinath on the day of Maha Shivaratri, that it wwas a full-on experience is an understatement. Walking from central Kathmandu along Pashupatinath road was an unusual experience in itself because there were very few vehicles around and as I got closer, none at all because the road was closed. The silence during rush hour was a little unsettling in itself as was the stream of people heading solemnly in the same direction rather than the usual early morning energy from commuters and people opening their businesses. As I crossed the rise at the ring road the atmosphere and noise changed; in front of me were tens of thousands of people, many queuing patiently in the already long lines to get into the main temple (Hindus only), others milling around seeing what the street sellers had to offer (food, clothes, watches, household goods and no doubt more) and buying candy floss and balloons sold ny young boys (exclusively, I don't know why) who skilfully sought out those interested in making a purchase. There were just too many people by the main entrance so I headed to the first bridge and crossed the river to enter the site (not that I was evading the 1000 rupee entrance fee, I was told there was no charge on this day). lots of other people, the majority Nepalis, were doing this too. We had to pass by an open sewer depositing raw sewage into the holy Bagmati. A few minutes later I reached the first of the many small shrines to Shiva where his adherents, the Saddhus had set up camp and were offering blessings to pilgrims and selling cannabis. Some 7000 Saddhus were reported to be present most of whom smoked weed which is a gift from Lord Shiva and a key aspect of worship.. There was a heady smell wherever I went. The authorities had warned non-Saddhus not to buy or smoke the stuff and although there many police, armed policed force and army personnel around (another big number - 12000 in total reportedly) there were plenty of people, mainly young men who were openly partaking with no action by the authorities it seemed to me. I watched proceedings from the the other side of the river to the cremation ghats (I didnlt see any) for a while to escape the hustle and bustle for a while. Watching proceedings merely entailed several queues moving very slowly into the main temple but only the top tier of the pagoda is visible anyway. The queues were marshalled quite strictly with people who tried to jump in given short shrift and by that I mean handled roughly. (On the way out I saw one guy attempt to enter by an exit only to be floored by a rifle butt to the chest.)I moved on to the temples at the top of the hill hoping to get away from the dense crowds but this was a forlorn hope; it was as busy as near the river. Saddhus lined the steps offering blessings for a price. I bought a snack at the top only to regret it when I was surrounded by dozens of monkeys. I gave vegetable pakoda up causing quite a squabble. The residents of the deer park were also very skittish if not spooked by the occasion - they are usually calm.On the way out via the main entrance there were lots of social service organisations offering medical care, food and water to the pilgrims and the invitations were so warm and determined they were difficult to turn down. Entertainment of all kinds was available outside the sacred site including fairground rides, music and dancing. I left after three hours or so and the intensity of the crowds and noise had increased since the early morning and it was something of a relief to leave Pashupatinath and its devotees behind and find a cafe for a cup of restorative tea.Pashupatinath is a wonderful lace to visit at any time because it embodies and reflects the Nepali Hindu culture. It's turned up to 11 for Maha Shivaratri. It takes place towards the end of February to early March, in 2017 it's on 24th February. If you are in Kathmandu, don't miss it.

Really interesting, but be prepared to be hassled.. Initially, I was having a good time, walking around and enjoying the atmosphere of worship, but I had an issue with the number of people pestering you to let them give you a tour. We had a guy latch himself onto us, and refuse to leave, telling us random things about the history of the place and the nature of the worship, although we politely rebuffed him numerous times. It kind of took the pleasure out of the experience for me, but by no means should it deter anyone from visiting. It's a very interesting experience, just be aware that you might have to be very firm with some prospective 'tour guides'.

Heaven of Earth. The place of Shiva! The magical heaven! Spiritual Blessing! Clean, peaceful, calm... The tourist are allowed to sit and watch the burning cremation, sitting across the river under the trees and small shiva stupa temples. For all hindu's, it's definitely the gate way to heaven.
Excellent place. ambience of the place is just awsome ...gives you an ancient/historical/divine/mixed architectural vibes .

Interesting for me. On my 2nd day of trip..i havent planned anything because i wasnt expected that kathmandu is a big city..luckly my local nepali friend helped and bring me to this place..im so luckly because alot of people thought im nepali because i can speak nepali & face like "tamang"..so i just walk inside..for me, its a very different way of hindu religious..especially those member who pass away..i dont dare to take picture because its really disrespect when taking pics during people pass away..anyway, when i go up the stairs,i saw cute small monkeys too..So my tips:*Learn nepali language (unless u have nepali face & local nepali friend, u will be safe)*ignore and dont give money to the beggers on the street and stair.*wear mask always because of pollution*for those who come from asia country, please wear 1 thick cloth only because it will be cold for asian people

Pashupatinath Temple. Pashupatinath is a Hindu temple on the banks of the Bagmati river in Deopatan, a village 3 km northwest of Kathmandu. It is dedicated to a manifestation of Shiva called Pashupati (Lord of Animals). It attracts thousands of pilgrims each year and has become well known far beyond the Kathmandu Valley. The temple is barred to non-Hindus, but a good view of the temple can be had from the opposite bank of the river.

Privilege to see. I would highly recommend visiting this temple. Very interesting and an amazing insight into the Hindu culture, albeit emotional. Only negative is the scabby monkeys that are everywhere.
Lacks solemnity.... The river was dry and there was largely a dusty haze. Worshippers everywhere, but I felt there was something lacking in this temple. It could be a very subjective opinion of mine.
Just ok. The temples are beautiful but over priced 1000 Rs. The smell is not for everyone. The view is from the other side of the river and very impressive.
very beautiful. love this place ,very impressive to see that that temple was build almost 200 yr ago.i want to go nepal again only for this place .

Fascinating temple with crematoria. Very interesting place where you can experience how close is from life to death. Burning corps and mourning families are not for everybody though. No tourists when I've been visiting (March). Some local guides will try to show you around. Interesting but pricey if you don't agree pricing in advance. The entrance fee was 10$ which is expensive anyway.

Spiritual satisfaction. Visiting Pashupatinath will be a great experience, especially at evenings. The environment and atmosphere driven by everyone worshiping god, the lighting and passion of devotees are worthwhile to stop for a spiritually satisfied mind.

Old temple. Old temple are visited for their pilgrimage value .and for Hindus Pashupatinath is no less a pilgrimage . It is a nice and big temple of Mahadev . The shiv ling temple is open from all four sides People say that all the four doors are opened rarely but when we visited all the four doors of the shiv ling were open so could see the shiv ling from all directions.The temple is having sprawling area .There are many small temples in the area which reminds me of Jagannath Puri,Orissa. There is a space were 84 shiv lings are build and passage is made so that devotee can touch all shiv lings. People adore this place. No photos allowed inside the temple .
lacks gud mgmt of temple. lacks gud mgmt of temple. if it rains everything gets messy, however, Darshan is some how managed well, cleanliness should be addressed with top priority.
Imbuement of Hindu religion. Love this temple, very surprise with what you can see here. The rituals, the landscape, the architecture are all memorable.

a must for all Hindus to visit. Got there at Aarti time. Amazing feeling when you visit one of the 4 'dhaams'.
Would recommend highly

Interesting place to visit. Visited in march 2015 as the shadows were coming from India and Nepal to take part In a festival. Paid npr 1000 to get in saw some cremations going on went to the opposite side and saw a few monkeys running around everyone was friendly there was a tourist market on the way out foreigners and non Hindu people ar not allowed Into the main temple.

Disgusting smell and filthy - not worth visiting if you're not Hindu. No disrespect to anyone Hindu, as this is a sacred place. But for tourists that are not Hindu, be prepared for some new levels of disgusting. This place is the most filthy and dirty religious site I have ever visited in the world - any country. Every surface, interior and exterior, is covered in dirt and black mold. It also runs over/around the river and the awful stench of sewage made me gag even though I wore a mask. It is a nice opportunity to see real cremations and religious practices along the river, but if you're not that interested, it's not worth the steep entry fee. There is nothing architecturally exciting or significant with the buildings either.

Visiting the hindu temple. They charge foreigners 1000 rupees fr entrance and as a foreigner you are not allowed in the main part of the temple - I would say it's a bit of a rip off. But cool to see the Baba's (holy men).

Real bliss. . I do not leave Kathmandu without visiting this temple. A very blissful place to sit in silence. The Nepalese by nature are very simple and content people. The temple also has similar vibes.

Shivaratri at Pashupatinath Temple. I was planning to visit before the festival but was told that the best time to go would be at Shivaratri when the temple invited over a million visitors and many holy men. It was quite an experience I must admit and I would urge anyone in Kathmandu at the time of the festival to visit. Its 1000rps to get in and be sure to keep plenty of small bills on you if you'd like to photograph the holy men. Try not to be ripped off too much, because I was obviously a tourist the prices were jacked up tenfold so don't be afraid to give less than they ask, just not too much less! Also, I went with a Nepali man from my hotel, something I hadn't planned in advance but if you're alone (and definitely a lone female) I'd recommend taking a guide. One last thing was that whilst at the Temple there were many cremations taking place, with the families carrying the bodies through the crowd. Although I know this is a sight for some and I was told I could photograph them by a local, I felt it was disrespectful to raise my camera. Just think about how you'd feel if if was your relative's cremation and that'll give you an idea of whether or not to photograph!

Temple. This is considered a world heritage site but I found it to dirty and you can't enter the temple unless you are Hindu and the Bagmati River that runs beside it has places for cremation ghats as they call them. It was not something I wanted to watch as the hospice house is just above where the cremations are taking place. You can here the families crying and see the body. Not a place for me and besides there are plenty of temples to see in Nepal.

Rich colors, rich culture. There's so much to see within. Take at least 2 or 3 hours to see it all if you can - I wish I had stayed longer than 2. I took the most time just sitting by the river and watching the whole process of the cremation. With respect, I didn't take any photos which allowed me to be much more present than usual through observation. I was also there right before Shivaratri holiday so there were more Sudhas hanging around than usual. You can ask them if it's ok for you to take a photo of them - they will say of course but then DEFINITELY ask you for money. I was prepared with 200 rupees in my pocket, though they asked for 1000 rupees (total rip off either way). I handed the 200 quickly and took off before they could get mad at me. Later I was talking to a local who said even 200 rupees is something they shouldn't get just for photos. If you get a chance to connect with the Sudhas, great, if you want to give them money, go ahead...but that was just my experience!The markets around Pashupatinath are also great as well as the multiple meditation caves within the area. You are welcome to meditate in them if you'd like, which was peaceful and wonderful as well.
god is great. As Pashupati Temple is consider a largest Hindu temple in the world there is no doubt. I really like this place, beautifully settings.....
Worth a visit . It was really interesting to see, but I highly recommend paying for a guide there. We got a lot more out of the experience.

A good Temple and must visit for Shiva followers!. People in India believe that after Chardham yatra this place is must to be visited to please lord Shiva. Good place from religious point of view and worth a visit.
Very harrowing but a real experience. A wonderful truly Nepali/Indian experience with numerous spectators and monkeys a vibrant place despite the morbid cremations

Interesting but many scams around. Visited Pashupatinath in Feb, 2016 and liked pretty much things around it. There are few scams such as you can't go in, can't visit the park inside, can't visit crematory etc. We avoided other people saying such things and tried to visit all the place we could. Apart from the main temple we were able to visit all.Everything went great!

Must visit if you are in Kathmandu . It's a great place to visit. An ancient temple of Lord Shiva. There is is really big statue of Nandi in front of the main temple. Also there is a big statue of Hanuman ji beside Nandi's statue. You'll find lot of monkeys jumping around and looking for Prasad/food... Photography is not allowed inside the main temple premises... But still you can capture few glimpses through you mobile camera secretly... The small market outside the temple is quite cheap... You can also bargain there.

Beautiful temple!!. A must attraction, if you're visiting Nepal! But do some research before you visit the temple. It will give you a greater understanding of the history and culture of this historic and beautiful site!

Prepare before your visit. The most sacred Hindu temple is well worth a visit but good to read up in advance in case your guide's accent is too strong. I wasn't keen on the "Come and see a dead body incinerated" sales pitch and preferred to the a seat up on the terrace overlooking the river to watch from a distance. Don't go when it's too hot, there are lots of steps; be prepared to pay as foreign tourist ( I think it's 1000 rupees £7 entry); keep some small change for the Babas who will bless you with an orange thread around your wrist and offer you a photo - I'd forgotten my camera and money even though my sadhu conveniently accepted pounds, dollars or euros. Avoid the public toilet! Not too much earthquake damage to the site. NB non-Hindus are not allowed in inner areas of the temples.

Lovely temple to visit. Much more peaceful than other temples, you can just walk around and silently observed religious rituals. Temple is well preserved with not too much damage after the earthquake.Tip-take a guide who will explain everything and show you various places.

Fascinating tour. Our tour guide for the day, Susan Mandahar, took us to famous sites in Kathmandu.I found this place very interesting, open air cremations at the side of the river, the golden roofed temple, the unique buildings.Susan explained all about the process and the culture.

cuturally fascinating. if you can handle the smoke this place is amazing and cuturally fascinating. even thought the subject mater is very heavy (active cremation grounds) it's quite an amazing place for knowledge and reflection. i would very much recommend a visit and hiring a guide so you do not miss any details.

Scenic View from the river side.. This is a significant Hindu Temple which is on the banks of the river where dead bodies are burnt on the pyre. Only hindu s are allowed inside the temple premises, which is like any other temple. But the main attraction is the back side, the river side where you can sit on the banks and see cremation of Hindu dead bodies happening round the clock. Though contrasting but there is something peaceful about the place.
Shivling - The God of God. It is a historical temple as per Hindu Mythology. It is really a very very old temple and one of the valuable temple as per all Hinduism.
Very famous shiva temple. It is a very famous temple of lord shiva. One of the main lord in Hindu religion. any time a lot of devotes are there in the temple. Many religious rituals keep on going.

Fascinating glimpse into Hindu culture. Largest Hindu temple, cremations happening regularly, holy men gathering for big festival, smoking hashish. Well worth the hour or two and the $10 entrance fee, especially as there's a lot to rebuild after the earthquake. We took an independent guide (and driver as well) who helped us make the most of our limited time, and negotiated costs down for photos. Pity we couldn't go inside the main temple but still lots to see and do.

Hindu Temple. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the Biggest Hindu Temple in Whole Nepal and very famous for its holiness and one of the World Heritage Site in Kathmandu. Dont forget to visit if you're in KTM. Entrance fees are too expensive, its depend on how badly you wanna get in then you can pay for it. Enjoy your time in Nepal.

Biggest Hindu Temple. Pashupatinath is one of the greatest Hindu temple in Nepal. It is one of the greatest temple for Hindus around the world. It is one of the World Heritage site in Nepal. The view of pashupatinath from the Kailash Danda was really amazing.

Utterly Fascinating. Sensory overload, great historical and social experience. I must say that I had no idea what I was about to see, I just had a couple of days in Kathmandu before an Everest Base Camp Trip and I thought it would be cool to see some of the area attractions. Ace the Himalaya provided a private shuttle and a very well educated and knowledgeable guide in Dil B Lama Tamang. Everything was new and exotic, I had hundreds of question and took hundreds of pictures. He was very patient, allowed me to take my time and absorb everything. I was allowed to tour at my pace and he was very knowledgeable. The Pashupati Temple is one of the most Sacred sites in the Hindu world. There here hundreds of Indians on pilgrimage. There were monkeys roaming the area and there were ongoing cremation ceremonies. The cremation services were very strange and foreign to me as a westerner. Witnessing these ceremonies and listening to his explanations, help me gain a real appreciation for their beliefs and see it not as a morbid display, but as a loving sendoff for your family member to the next life. I made this trip totally focused on my Everest experience, the Kathmandu Valley and World Heritage sites were not on my radar, but I can say that I thoroughly enjoyed the experience and I would recommend that you take the time to visit. COntact Ace the Himalaya, they are true professionals.
Expensive Entrance Fee. Expensive entrance fee to see this Hindu Temple . Only go if you really want to see the cremations . The temple itself is not that interesting .

Great place to visit. It was great viisiting this place. I imagine this is the place much like the Varanasi in India but much smaller. Unlike varanasi they allow you to take pictures here. Atmosphere is strange, but deep.

Awe inspring. Humbling.. I was hear two weeks before the April 25, 2015 quake and then I visited two days after the quake. This is a holy spot for Hindus so if you visit you will see bodies being cremated. Typically see very little of the remains. You will, however, see people mourning and worshipping. It is not a light-hearted spot for obvious reasons. If you're interested in how Hindus say goodbye to their dead, this is the only place to go. Lots of holy men are around to see as well. Don't miss it.

Place For know about life... '"Pashupatinath'" Where we can know about the life when we go there.There is more than thousand temple which one also world heritage site.Near the temple River (Bagmati) in there i spent more than 2 hour watching the river side many people comes with dead body they burn and they go back and i thought bout the life they came nacked in earth and go nacked .fell know about the life..

Bring Kleenex...Be Prepared to Possibly Shed Tears. I knew they cremated bodies here.I knew this place was where the loved ones said goodbye to their deceased. I knew Hindi from all over the world traveled here to worship.But I was not prepared for the emotions that swept over me and took their hold upon me as I saw the left living ones mourning over their deceased loved ones. Clearly they were not ready to let go - who is when death comes calling - especially unexpectedly? The sounds of the crying wails ripped into my heart and my own tears came pouring out in great abundance. This was the 1st time I smelled burning human flesh and saw my 1st cremations. If you enter with the Hindi pilgrims, you may see multiple vehicles bringing in the dead. The crowds moved me along and then I felt something hit me on my side. It was a dangling arm from a skinny naked dead woman with a purple cloth on top of her. I wondered who she was and where her clothing went. Did they recycle it? Did someone steal it? I was glad that someone threw the purple cloth on top of her to provide her some dignity in death. There were no mourners following her. She was alone except for the the cremators and the workers preparing her body to be burned. I watched her being prepared and stayed with her for part of the burning. They say an average body takes 3-4 hours to burn. If it takes longer time than it has a negative attachment I was told. I walked alongside the river and came upon the sadhu's little hut. I smelled pot wafting thru the air - a pot smoking sadhu taught in the hut I was told. I did not enter.Be sure to check out the old folks home on the premises and the sadhu quarters that are shared with the cows.

Impressive cultural site. The complex is a must-see for everyone interested in Hindu culture. It is forbidden for non-Hindus to enter the main Shiva temple, and also foreigners have to pay an entrance fee of around 10 euros for the area around the Shiva temple, but that money is well spent. I was lucky enough to be there with my Nepali husband, who could explain to me the meaning of the rituals being performed all around, the goats running around freely, the dead bodies being prepared for cremation, the religious symbols and the hundreds of Shiva temples on the site. After fighting your way up a lifetime of steps, past the sadhus, beggars and fruit vendors, you can stretch your legs at a little street food stand, watch/feed the deer behind the stand and then enjoy a view of the Kathmandu valley. I definitely recommend this place to everyone interested in Hindu culture and heritage.

Heart of Hindus. This the temple of Hindus main powerful god 'maha dev'. Maha mean main and dev means god. This temple is mostly famous for it's Historical and religiously important. We can see Hindus dead body funeral also. Which is unbelievable for us

Wonderful temple!. I'm so glad that we got to visit this temple- but only Hindus are allowed into the main part of the complex. Some of the priests did want more money for darshan then we were able to give, which was a bit off-putting, but we are glad that we went and were able to pay our respects to Lord Shiva.

One of the most sacred Hindu Temple. As i visited this hindu holy temple which is listed in cultural world heritage site, i feel so lucky to explore the beauties of the temple and the way of the Hindu religion. You must visit once in your Nepal visit. Don't miss it.

Sacred Hindu Temple. Pashupatinath (lord of all animals, Lord Shiva) temple is an ancient temple situated at the banks of Bagamati river. It is a very sacred place for Hindus. It has unique four face Linga unlike other Lord Shiva temples in India. The wooden carvings on the two tier pagoda style temple are mesmerizing. You can also see the replica of this temple at Bhaktapur Durbar Square. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the temple. Others can see the temple from the other bank of Bagamati river.
Historical Place.. Be loved god hara hara mahadev. The pashupatinath hindu's love but pashupatinath love for all. one of the historical place in kathmandu nepal. love it.

Favorite sight in Kathmandu!. The scale of the 5th century temple complex is mind-boggling and viewing it from the top gave it a grander feel. It's a beautiful sight. Best for a day's immersion into Hindu temple activities - you will meet Sadhus and worshippers alike. Reminder to always be respectful of everything & everyone : this is a functioning temple (and one of the most sacred) where people give their respects so admire the view and be mindful of taking photos especially those who are mourning their loved ones at the open-air cremation area / funeral pyres.

Mind-opening. We people from the Western world will need to get used to sky burials, as they are not part of our culture.I experienced the Pashupatinath as extremely peaceful, calm and with a feeling of community. The temple itself can only be visited from Hindus. I came back towards when it gets dark to see the daily rituals with fire and music (keep the entry ticket when returning). Wonderful.

People of Nepal are Incomplete without a visit here.. Yes its a Rarest of Temple in the world were there is Cremation Area attached to Temple.Its Religious Importance is one of the Uttermost. I felt Quite Peaceful (I am Normally not a Temple goer) here, A sense of Presence of God.

A great privilege to contemplate your life and what it means to you. You don't have to be Buddhist or Hindu to appreciate the sanctity and holiness of this sprawling temple complex. Worshippers of both religions perform prayers (puja) and rituals in this place, representing and practising religious harmony. Many ceremonies and devotions are conducted here in this holiest of places in Nepal and people make pilgrimages here from all around the world. Many make their way to die at this place and it may be confronting to some to see these folk, generally alone, lying motionless on nearby pathways.The temple complex, a World Heritage Site, is rich in historical and architectural values and is also a vital social and cultural centre. Non Buddhists and HIndus do not have access to all areas however all are able to respectfully witness the elaborate Hindu cremation rituals which take place daily beside the Bagmati river. Two bridges cross over it and sometimes hundreds of people (both tourists and Nepalis) gather to observe the proceedings and to understand more about tradition, culture, respect and, of course, to contemplate their own life, spirit and time of passing.The complex is about 5 km from KTM cbd, admission in NPR1,000 and an ATM is located near the ticket booth. Unintrusive photography is allowed. At the entrance there are many people offering to guide you and offer interpretations of proceedings, customs and the environment. There is a taxi rank nearby, and trinket markets (if you must).Inside you will find holy men, mystics, sadhus and other practitioners of various esoteric knowledge, with whom you can consult, pray with or simply photograph for a small fee. Monkeys abound but will generally not bother you unless you engage with them. Don't touch them or look them in the eye and keep food hidden.I'm no expert but the reverent cremation process involves bathing the deceased, covering the person with special cloths, grains, garlands and other offerings. Incense is burned, prayers uttered, and grief is openly on display - the latter not so common in Western funeral practices. Men and women each have a different role to perform, and the deceased is finally lovingly placed on a pre-prepared pyre, which is attended to by a skilled man who ensures the pyre burns effectively. The family and loved ones remain until the ashes are placed in the river. You may wish to remain an uninvolved observer but you will most likely be "involved" by breathing some of the smoke arising from the pyre. Also the river itself is very sluggish here and efforts are being made to clean it up.Take time to wander along the stupas on the upper side of the complex and also on the less crowded side of the bridges if you are looking for more than just a view of a cremation. Talk with the locals there to learn more about the rich traditions and rituals and to understand more about your own beliefs about death and dying. By the way, remember that we Westerners cremate our deceased as well - we just don't tend to see death as an important vital part of life, as these people do - and so we try to sanitise the process and delegate funeral duties to others, perhaps to help us disconnect from it.These are only my uninformed observations so please forgive me if I have not well interpreted the fundamental processes - there are certainly many intricacies.If you have time, you can easily walk to Boudhanath from here.
Outstanding: Jai Bhole Nath Baba Ki. The temple is very amazing. you will feel the inner peace the moment you enter the main complex. There is so much places to see & so many things to understand.

People (and monkey) watching. This temple is a very holy place for a lot of Indian people, I was told it is one of those places that Indians travel to outside of India, as it is very significant.Just be aware, that when you arrive, the ticket office will sell foreigners a ticket but will not tell you that you if you are not Hindi, you can't actually enter the inner square and temple itself; so NRP1,000 (US$10.00), and you can only walk around the outside of the temple. In this regard, I think they need to inform people of this at the time of ticket purchase, as I found it a bit unethical as they aren't fully disclosing the entry terms.After paying, you will be swamped by guides (some official, some not); who even after being told their services are not required, will attempt to stay with you and begin telling you information - until being told in no uncertain terms, that they will be receiving no money from you.At the rear though, their is a small river/stream, where numerous funeral pyres burn and bodies are prepared by family members for cremation; they mourn their departed family members, cleanse them in the river, some relations shave their hair, and the bodies are then cremated and the ashes pushed into the river. My wife and I found it very interesting but didn't take photos of the bodies as we wanted to be respectful of the moment. *The photo we have included is only of a pyre being prepared, not actually a body being cremated.Their are a number of small stupas at the rear, and a few 'Holy' men sit up here, you are permitted to sit up here too and take in the experience. There are monkeys (Resus Macaques) here too, so be very aware of your belongings, especially if you have food of any type. These monkeys are very brave and sometimes aggressive if they want what you have; we watched a male monkey attempt to take a 6'3" well-built man's food, then stare him down and call other monkeys to back him up - be aware of them at all times.All in all, we were disappointed that we were not told about not having access to all parts of the site, until after we had already paid; however the people/monkey & funeral watching experience is something we appreciated immensely.
Om nama shivaya. I found this place very nice which is located in the bank of river a big hindu tample,lots of dead bodies taken everyday for their funerals!

quite morbid but interesting visit. The place is just incredibly beautiful. Havent talked for hours with my partner as there was just to much to see and understand. The morbid part comes with the burning of the dead people.

The most important temple of Kathmandu . Visited this beautiful temple with friends and really felt very good and divine. Beautiful made. But what I liked the most is terrible outer side monuments and burning ghats. Specially seating there in late evening is so peaceful. And if it is full moon night then you are really lucky to be here. Must to visit this holi temple.

Insight into the Nepali Hindu Culture. Pashupatinath is definitely worth the visit. Although non-Hindus cannot enter into the main temple, you can still roam around the area which is quite large. There is so much to observe so there is the potential to learn a lot about the Nepali Hindu culture! Be courteous and respectful and enjoy watching the monkeys that often climb around everywhere!

Interesting . Was worth visiting again,Unfortunately it did sustain a bit of damage from the quake, some nice monuments and statue's damaged. not as many monkey's as there was last time. Still very interesting to visit. And there is a $10 entry fee.The only bad thing I can sayUnfortunately there is a deer park attached, but the deers don't look like they are being fed.

Sightseeing . Amazing experience of a cultural heritage of Kathmandu Nepal.
Place where you should respect the laws,local customs, religious and cultural value of Nepal.
A holy place. I had an early morning visit last week with my family. The environment were so clean. I found much improvement than before.

Interesting, but felt pressured.... This place is great to see 14th-17th century Hindu architecture, as well as current culture. It cost 1500 rupees to get in, and then be prepared for someone to immediately follow you and want to be your guide for a fee. I allowed a guide to come with me, but he was often difficult to understand and made the trip take a bit longer than I had time for. They won't tell you up front of course that they are doing it for a fee, so be prepared to pay at the end. It took about 2 hours to see everything.
Holy place for Lord Siva. Another sacred temple to visit while you are in Kathmandu. The place worshipped for Lord Shiva, sacred and amazing view.

Place taken by hindus. It's a pity that to visit BUDDHIST place one needs to pay to hindus enormous entry fee, and the most sacred buddhist place - Golden Temple, which never was hindu and belongs to Buddhist religion as one from five Vajrayogini temples (buddhist female aspect) they will not allow to enter, because they think it's hindu. But it's not. Hope that this unjustice will stop one day. Stop it and we will come.

Amazing temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. I 1st saw this temple at National Geographic's show "Taboo". I finally got my chance to visit and it's brimming with life (well, metaphorically speaking, it's a crematorium). It's fascinating to see how Lord Shiva is revered and the culture that comes with cremating the departed. Bring a good guide that will explain to you the all the important details like what the river represents, the actual cremation and the like. When I came a friend of mine died a few days prior, so I asked a Holy Man to perform the Shradh ceremony on me. I went down to the foot of the bank and did what the Holy Man told me to do with translation help of my guide, and hopefully it would bring my friend's spirit to heaven. Had to clean myself up because the water is heavily polluted and a biohazard due to it being the place where charred human remains are poured on. Overall, a fun and educational experience and makes one reflect the concept of death and the afterlife.

Not for the faint hearted!. This place is amazing! A beautiful Hindu temple where the dead are cleansed in the river and then cremated on pyres in rituals of tradition (in full view!) with sacred monkeys running loose in the background. It's hard not to feel emotional here.

Hindu Prelgrimage. One of the oldest Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Good architecture of its kind. Beware of the pandas asking you for various rituals. No need to ask any one. Can go directly inside the temple complex and have darshan.
Really nice famous place. It was a famous place for Hindu...it was a great Temple. ...situated in a large area...and very nice and clean place.....

Very good. The entrance fee was a high 1000 rupee. But it was worth it since the money will be used for maintenance of the place. There will be some local tour guide that will be very friendly to you and start guiding you. Be sure to ask how much before proceeding. I opt not to have a guide. There's some temples that are only accessible for hindus. First stop I went all the way up the stairs to some monuments that look like ancient lost city. There's lots of monkeys and a deer park. Heading back down to the same path I went up just now, is the cremation area near the river. You have to walk past the cremation ceremony to reach the end where you'll see narupa cave. It was closed , you can only peak from outside. From there you walk up the stairs all the way to what I call the highlight of the place. It is an open field, but looks like a scene from the movie sound of the music. Great atmosphere for love birds enjoying the view from any of the edge. Buy some snack there from one of the many sellers, and pick a spot free of cow dung, and just sit and relax with the cooling wind and Sun on your face.

Fascinating insights into the Hindu religion and culture. We visited this temple after seeing the four other World Heritage sites in Kathmandu, and this really impressed, even after the others. Only Hindus can go into the main temple itself, but it is part of a massive complex, and you can see a huge amount without going into that main temple. One of the things we found really fascinating is seeing people washing their family members who have died, and performing ceremonies to cleanse (spiritually) their bodies in preparation for cremation, and then the bodies being burned on funeral pyres. Being a westerner, I was initially taken aback by this all happening out in the open and felt like I was intruding by watching it, but our (Hindu) guide happily explained to us that they are happy to have people see it, that this openness is part of the religion, and that they actually believe it brings more luck/goodness for the spirit of the deceased, the more people who watch it. Definitely something I think is worth seeing, to see how different cultures approach death and its rituals differently. Do watch out for the touts though, we had one lady follow us all the way to our car trying to sell us necklaces, even though we'd already bought some!

Amazing place to visit. Pashupatinath a sacred Hindu's place, which is one of the oldest and biggest Hindu temple in the world. You can enjoy its surrounding by seeing the old architecture and structures however some of it has been devastated by earthquake. We ca see cremation ceremony as per Hindu religion which we can see live. Be careful with Monkeys if you holding something on your hand.

Temple with a Cremation in the background. This temple among-st the most important for Hindus apparently. The temple itself is spectacular and there is a river behind the temple, on the banks of which the dead are cremated.This is the only place in Nepal where the priest almost forced us to donate money. "You have to give 100 Ruppes for this....." for whatever he has chanted. We never asked for his services. What a shame !

"Great Shiva Temple". It's a divine temple which stood untouched in a place which was devastated by a deadly earthquake. Always an amazing experience to visit this temple. Participation in evening Aarti is an experience one should not miss. it gives you an opportunity to get blessed.

Very interesting and well worth a look. You cannot go into the temple if your jot a Hindu, but you can walk all around it, and the interesting part is the cremation ceremonies along the banks of the Bagmati River. It is definitely a unique experience, and a cultural experience.
#Religious#Visit#QUIET&Relaxing!. One should Must Visit while travelling Nepal ! As it is religious place Dedicated to Lord Shiva... :)

"Om Namah Shvayah" - "adoration to Lord Shiva". It is a one of the most holy pilgrimage site for Hindus - dedicated to Lord Shiva. The main temple has gold plated roof and silver on the floor. Only Hindus are allowed inside the temple. However, there is a nice spot at the bank of river Bagmati, from where tourist can have a nice view of the temple and surroundings. Cremation of deceased bodies takes place at the bank of the holy river Bagmati, believing that the soul will then go to heaven.

Avoid on Shiva's birthday. The crowds were ridiculous on Shiva's birthday. Millions of Hindus everywhere. It was awful, almost a nightmare. I had visions of my wife being fondled in crowds of Indian gang rapists. I don't know what else to say.
nice place to visit. this is the great palce to visit where we can hindu cultures n rituals.also we can see there crimation

Religious place with historical values. As a hindu i am much fond of this place as it brings me a enormous amount of pure energy and devotion while visiting pashupatinath.the amount of devotion towards this place from Hindu people is extraordinary.the main problem that i see pashupatinath is that it is very much unsanitary and polluted and respective personaas well as government should emphasize in getting the place upgraded for revival and increasing of tourism in the place.

A MUST SEE TO EXPERIENCE HINDU CULTURE. Beautiful Hindu Temple from 5th Century on the sacred Bagmati River where Hindu's from all over the world bring their dearly departed family members to cleanse them in the river as preparation for their departure into the after life. The bodies are then cremated on the banks of the river. Just be aware of con artists pretending to be Hindu Priests collecting money from unsuspecting tourists. This is a must to see when you are visiting Kathmandu if you want to experience the Hindu Culture.
Lord shiva temple !. situated in on the bank of holy bagmati river, this temple is one major tourist attraction of Kathmandu. open crematory is the one which may be new things for Western tourists.
Interesting hindu site. Interesting to see, lots of monkeys around, you need someone to explain the things you see to get the most out of your visit.

Interesting experience. Definitely worth the entry price, and to get a guide to talk you through the tour was great as I was told many things about the history and goings-on that I would otherwise have no idea about. An eye-opening eperience to see beggers sifting through human ashes while fresh bodies are prepared for cremation.
Amazing temple. A mixture of feelings as you enter the temple. It s a very big area where weddings are celebrated next to cremations and where yogis find a place to live. A must go.

Visit to Lord Shivas Abode. A places where you can sit cool down your system and seek blessing from the almighty.Wish the river flowing near to it had been kept and River front developed to make it beautiful.
Short visit in a site that really suffered from the earthqhake . Lots of monkeys and few things to really see as mist parts are closed to the public or hidden behind tents until they are fixed
Eye-opening . Never seen anything like it. Highly recommend. Smells a funky sometimes but yeah really interesting. Some dudes will try show you around if you pay them.

Cremation at the banks of the river. One thing that really intrigued us when we visited this temple were the corpses lined up at the river bank, which we later saw were being cremated. We were able to witness a little bit of the ritual/practice later. People seem to be fond of spending time near the bank of the Bagmati River especially in the afternoon, as we saw many of them just sitting there.

Very interesting spot to visit. There is a lot to see here and it is worth taking a guide with you to gain an understanding of the rituals and spaces in which you are walking. The cremation of bodies by the river is very interesting and there are a lot of temples up on the hill. Very interesting spot to visit.
loved it. cremations are done here next to the river, it can be a little too much. There are monkeys everywhere and it is a little bit dirty
A must-see in Kathmandu. Definitely a must-see while in Kathmandu. The place has a very special spirit. Take a guide with you to understand the Hindu rituals!
Must visit when in Kathmandu. Not sure how you rate a temple. All I can say is do visit if in Kathmandu. Serene environment. Keep in mind clicking pictures inside the temple area is not allowed

Fascinating, interesting sight. First it looked like not much worth for the 1000 rupees of entrance fee - but when you walk around, there's actually a lot to see. The cremation of bodies by the river is, of course, very interesting and when a climb up the big stairs, there are a lot of temples up on the hill. This is definitely one of the most the most interesting sights in Kathmandu.

Mr. It is a holy place for Hindu Relogious , it is a Hindu temple in the centre of kathmandu, Only Hindu peoples are allowed inside the temple without carring any leathers items like purse shoes belts etc , very nice place of olden age.

Gateway to heaven. . Located north east at the bank of Bagmati river in kathmandu. Pashupati nath mean lord of beast, this place is very much popular for cremation in puplic. Every day many death people are brought by family for final rituals in human life that is performed with great honored. Only hindus are allowed to enter the temple but other can have good time walking around and watching cremation. Beautiful place to learn lot about life.
Place of peace. I would recommend this place to see not only a temple but some of the local traditions too. Popular with locals too

Interesting place but very crowded. It is a beautiful place to visit and my guide told me that this is the most sacred Hindu temple in the world. I loved the surroundings but the place was very dirty and crowded. Why do not the government clean and properly manages the place?

LORD SHIVA TEMPLE. Only Hindus can enter the temple, temple is historical and very old. this place is very crowded.The cremation area is just behind the temple and its doorstep to enter heaven as per Hindu believe.

Not to be missed when in Kathmandu!. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the holiest Hindu temples in the world. I was very fortunate to spend time there with a Nepalese friend who explained how, in the past, the while building by the river was to house those who were near death. It was like a hospice with doctors and caretakers. As the person came close to taking their last breath they are wrapped in cloth and taken to the river where their feet are washed (the river flows eventually into the holy Ganges River in india) while family/friends chant until they pass. The Hindu belief is that how we leave this life is how we enter the next, so they want the person to leave with only peace and thoughts of God. Today people are sent to hospitals and so do not come for this until they have died. After this ritual the body is cremated. There were many cremations going on while I was there. if you have time, it is a beautiful place to sit, observe and contemplate how spirit moving into the body, living in the body and leaving the body are all natural phases of life to be embraced. We were there in late afternoon and for the beginning of sunset. I am not certain about this, but I believe it is the best time to view the cremations.

Only Hindus allowed inside the main temple; quite polluted river near the cremation area.. Being a Hindu, I was quite skeptical visiting yet another temple, not expecting it to be much different from the ones I had seen back home. But the architecture is quite different, for similar to Tibetan/East Asian style pagodas. There are many hawkers selling ceremonial-peripherals and souvenir items on the way to the temple. Once at the temple, you will be asked (if you are a Hindu) to remove your footwear and place it in a temple bag that will be kept safely in a shoe rack and a token for the same handed over to you. All non-Hindus can walk right up to the entrance of the gate and Hindus can proceed inside. There were idols of various deities inside and the prominent sight here that everyone on Trip Advisor seemed to be raving about was not quite pleasant/interesting (in my humble opinion) to watch. The river where the cremations were taking place was quite polluted and it was sad to see that nobody cared to clean it up.

Moving experience seeing Hindu culture!. This place is truly spiritual. Seeing the shrines and cremation spots was unlike anything I have ever seen before ... certainly different for westerners to see. The way the local people deal with death is truly fascinating and I would encourage people to get a guide who will explain the meaning of certain functions in the cremation procedure and how relatives grieve for their loved ones. My guide talked me through the steps involved in the process and I was lucky to witness actual cremations taking place. It was truly moving.

One of the Most Unique Site I have Visited. This is a place where people bring the dead for cremation. The process is actually quite interesting and unlike anything I have ever visited before. It is outdoors. Out of respect for the dead, we decided not to take photos.Entrance is 1000 rupees. There is a temple where only Hindus can enter. We spent about an hour here.

Unplanned visit. I had been here on a previous visit to Nepal, however I accompanied a friend and although I find it quite an oppressive place I also find it quite calm. We had a guide that befriended us at the entrance and this was worth the few hundred rupees we paid at the end to learn about the temples, steer us away from the monkies and protect us to some extent from the hawkers and beggars. Always be aware of your surroundings if visiting here

Blissful!. The visit to Pashupatinath temple always brings in me a very blissful and tranquil experience. This is one one the most ancient and sacred Hindu temples in the world, a UNESCO heritage and is especially very crowded on Mondays and certain days in a month per lunar calendar. Only Hindus are permitted in the actual temple premises, however, there is a lot of fascinating and mysterious culture to explore beyond the actual temple premises. The temple lies on the banks of holy Bagmati river (like the Ganges in India) where the many Hindu rituals including cremations take place. Sights of sadhus dressed in colorful yellow and orange robes with ashes and long hair and beard, signs of worldly renunciation are common in the temple area; there are also a number of ashrams and 'bhajans' singing groups of people along with numerous temples and shrines in the area that adds a sense of spirituality in the region.The view of the temple, flocks of people paying homage in the temple, the sadhus, the rituals, the river Bagmati, the architecture of the main temple and other temples - all of these add bliss to the environment. The view is most fascinating from the east side of the temple across the Bagmati river, where there are places for people to rest and experience the beautiful ambiance.

Cultural Experience. This is another UNESCO world heritage site, a must visit place when in nepal for cultural experience. You get to experience and learn about the traditions and religion. Wittness live the processions and ceremony.

The temple is viewable from a distance. Pashupatinath is the cremation area and temple along the river Bhagmati. Although you can't walk through it as you can in Varanasi, you can observe the cremations more easily from the bridges over the river. The temple is viewable from a distance although you can only enter if you're Hindu. Taxi rates are about three times higher in Katmandu than they were when I was here two years ago, so visits have to be better coordinated. Entry fee here is about $15.
A worthwhile visit. A must see on your list of places to see around Kathmandu. Have a great time walking around and taking in all there is to see.

Breathing in former-human smoke. It may sound morbid to anyone who hasn't yet been there, but it is strangely meditative and calming sitting on the bank of a low dirty river watching human bodies go up in flames.Be sure to set aside at least a good half day to explore and absorb Pashupatinath. Follow the staircase that leads up from the east bank of the river to find some of Kathmandu's best relaxing trees and a good view of the city, watch out for monkeys (I have a friend who got randomly attacked), and walk around the old city part too. Can be linked with a walk to Boudnath.Would give 5 stars, but the 1000 rupee entry fee is a little embitteringly steep, especially if you're spending a while in Kathmandu and end up having to pay it several times.
