lord of all living pashupatinath. various legend exist about the temple and origins but visiting this really old temple which is one of the important temples / place of worship for Hindus.it has a ghat (cremation and prayer area for the departed, with a part reserved for royalty)one can see people from all over the country and India offering prayers.

Favourite Temple. Of all the temples we visited this was by far the best. The entrance fee is high at 1000 Rps but there is so much to see it's worth it. Once inside we also hired a guide which was a good idea as he explained all the gods and temples really well. His name was Diamond (like the stone). We were told all about the cremation ceremony's and it was the best cultural experience we had during our trip. There are also lots of monkeys to see.

Yes and No.... This temple is one of the "must-see" experiences in Kathmandu, even more so if you haven't seen Varanasi in India. However, it presents the tourist with a few ethical challenges that I wish I'd had more time to consider before visiting. You will see families mourning. You will see the dead being prepared. You will see cremations on the banks of the river. You are allowed, even encouraged to spectate. You are also allowed, and even encouraged by guides and local "holy men" to use your camera. I ended up taking photos, but I was acutely aware of the grief of the families on he opposite bank. Just something to consider. A key detractor are the monkeys who are a pretty militant lot. It is easy to walk into or be surrounded by a full-on monkey brawl. These are not placid monkeys found elsewhere in the city so exercise caution. I am not sure if the combined effects of being covered in smoke and monkey pooh make up for the novelty of this site - I'll leave that to you to decide.

Great Architecture. The spiritual journey to new heights. On of the most ancient temple and a must to visit. It carries a great legacy of Lord Shiva Temple. Often flooded by tourists, I felt a bit crowded but this place has one magnetic aura I felt.
Interesting sight. One of the Important place for Hindu and interesting place for me. Their culture is just surprising.

Must see in KTM. Its like another planet or era, from one side you are admiring the spirituality and amazing architecture, from another you feel empathy for the inevitable poverty of people and believers living in the area. The Babas, are definitely the highlight of the monasteries. Their eyes sparkle when they talk about simplicity of life.

Watching Dead people is very entertaining. People seem to just hang out and wait for a funeral procession. It is really interesting to see the body come in, people secure it near the water, wash it and then burn it. I would highly recommend seeing this site while in KTM
Visit in October. Partial damage to temple but open for visit, Hindu Temple 5k from Kathmandu Valley. A must when visiting Kathmandu

Like from a different world. Worth to visit. This was one of a few places I definitely wanted to visit in Kathmandu. Holy and world heritage site with a remarkable atmosphere. There are lot of cremations undergoing throught the day, so be prepared for a typical wood burning smell (I expected something even worse). You also have to pay an entrance fee - 1000 rupees, so quite a lot, but its worth to visit this place, as you can see the whole ritual of the last farewell from the distance including burning the body and mourning - not something you can experience in the western world.

Historic temple. I went twice to this place as i was meant to go there. Its was on my way to mukktinath n kailash where we spend 2 days in kathmandu. Its breath taking temple as i can feel Lord Shiva's presents there.A huge brass Nandi welcomes us.we had a god darshan blessing from the priest there. You also can see death bodies been cremated here at the Bagmati river which later meets the holy river Ganga.You can also see many Sadhus seeking for liberations. You can take photos with them but not free you pay..but i was scared even to see them..

A holy site-world heritage site.. Be prepared to take off your shoes and walk barefoot.The temple is open only to Hindus,and tourists and they are averse to muslims entering. It is a symbol of strong Hindu Faith and interesting to see even cremations going on inside.

Must see temple but be prepared. The temple itself is only accessible by Hindus but everyone is able to answer the whole site. It's worth getting a guide (I paid 500 rupees) as you will learn a lot about the site and the rituals completed as part of the cremation process. It's sad but also beautiful how people care for the dead. If you want to take photos of the holy men you need to pay a small amount. A good guide will tell you who are the real ones and which are fake. Definitely visit but be prepared as I saw 6cremations while I was there.

One of the most sacred Hindu temples of Nepal - Pashupatinath Temple is located on both banks of Bagmati River on the ea. Usually tourists have the chance to see at least one open-air cremation.The majority of religious rituals are culturally unusual and even mind-blowing for Westerners, but probably the most culturally unusual thing in Pashupatinath is the specific smell of cremated bodies. Unlike any expectation the smell has nothing in common with the smell of decaying flesh, but rather reminds the smell of clabber mixed with different spices.
NICE TEMPLE. Be careful of monkeys, dirty. Not much to see around except for archaeological importance. Nearby food not available.

Great Hindu temple in Kathmandu. It is a great heritage site. Very good art crafted in the temple. Many interesting small temples are in around. A culture of dead body cremation in the permises of this Holly sight makes bad smell and smokey environment. It is a bit difficult to digest. However, it is good place to visit at least once in life time.

INTERESTING WAY TO CELEBRATE DEATH. My husband and I were very intrigued by the cremation process at this temple from beginning to end. Families hire men to wash the bodies in the holy river and prepare them to be burned on cement slabs over open fires. Once the bodies have been cremated the ashes are pushed into the river. We had never witnessed anything like it before and found it impressive.

OLD TEMPLE WITH OLD BELIEFS. this is their special and most scared temple , though very poorly maintained . you will have monkeys all over place and people will surround you for pooja. you have to park your vehicle almost 400 meter away from temple and walk down to temple.
Good location for hindu sightseeing. The temple is very famous for the indian diaspora, and you can get a feel of Indian Hindu tradition in Nepal if you decide to see the place

Wonderful Hindi cultural experience. Pashupatinath Temple complex in the Kathmandu Valley is a fascinating and significant Shiva landmark and a pilgrimage place for many Hindus. The main entrance is bustling with stallholders of all kinds, including one very talented watercolour painter who creates evocative scenes of this ancient city. The many sadhus wandering the grounds are always interesting to see and the ghats on the river, where cremations take place all day are a humbling reminder of impermanence. There is a park and seats a fair way above the ghats where people can sit and watch at a discreet distance. You may also get into conversation with a local about the religious significance of what is happening. Many temples and statues are also dotted around the complex.

Divine Abode. One of the very important Shiv Temple in the Hindu Nation. Our visit was so precious that we were able to see the Chardwar (Four Door) darshan of this special divine place. Here the Shiv has Four faces and you get rare opportunity to have all four face darshan. We felt divinely blessed to have this darshan during our visit to this temple
Amazing. Amazing place to visit! A must!!!You can not enter the temple, if you aren't a Hindoe, but you can see beside The temple.Take a good guide, who gives you a good feedback.

Excellent. Very good wives from temple. We visited temple for three times every time it was different experience. I started loving and believing even more. That god exists. Thanks god to give me opportunity so we got the pleasure to come and have Darshan of yours. Har har mahadev, dev dev maga dev dev. Om namah shivay

A must visit. This Holy temple of Lord Shiva is situated very close to Kathmandu Airport. If you are on a short trip to Kathmandu, will recommend visiting the temple while you are going to your hotel / office from the airport directly. Temple closes around 6 in the evening

A most fascinating place for anyone interested in culture. This temple is a place where the families of those who are dying or recently died find a place. Staff assist the family in the cremation process and also provide a hospital of sorts for those dying to come. Across the river from the cremation pyres many people come to sit and watch. It's a fascinating process, meant to be observed with dignity and silence.
A holy visit. A holy place but very crowded...there are a thousand of lingas inside the temple which is worth seeing...

Divinely. The history of the temple is very rich and its very beautiful. Hire a guide for a perfect tour of the temple "PARIKRAMA". The temple has a unique combination where apart from seeking blessings, the temple also provisions to carry on last rituals according to Hindu religion.

One of the holiest sites in Hinduism. Pashupatinath is a Shiva Temple and a major pilgrimage site for Hindus. There is the main temple and many smaller temples on the grounds. The structures straddle the Bagmati River which is ritually pure and holy but terribly polluted. There is so much going here it is advisable to read about the site before visiting. People line up to get inside to worship the linga which is the representation/presence of lord Shiva. This is open to the Hindu only so unless you are Hindu you cannot enter. I have met people in India who on the mention of Nepal say that they hope to make a pilgimmage to this Temple before they die. On the ghats or platforms on the river side of the temple cremations are constantly occurring. This may be shocking to people from developed countries but it is great example of how close the Nepali people are to the rhythms and cycles of life. I remember one visit where cremations, children playing in the river and women washing clothes were taking place within 100 feet of one another. There is a also a building on the upstream side of the river. It is called a nursing home by locals. Families bring people about to die here and the people who run the place are good at knowing when death its imminent. Individual are brought to the river's edge and placed on a slanted ramp with their feet in the waters of the river - the belief is that if a person's feet are in the Bagmati's waters at the moment of death s/he will be liberated from the cycles of reincarnation. There is also an old age home and a small infirmary run by the nuns of Mother Theresa's order. Cross the bridge and walk up the steps to the smaller temples and you will see numerous sadhus who are devotees of Shiva and make various claims about their diets and abilities to perform various feats. Pashupatinath is a kaleidoscope of activity - a must see.

It was my dream to visited !. Pashupatinath Temple darsan is like dream come true after log time plaing. It is best temple for me . Truly blessed after darshan of Lord Shiva here Pashupatinath temple is must visit for hindu divotees.

Holy visit with family. Had a very different experience to visit this temple. Considered one of the biggest and oldest temple for Lord Shiva. Devotees from all over the world can be seen in large numbers every day.A quick visit is worth. Felt little uncomfortable with the cremation area.

Very Intersting, get a guide. There is so much there to see wiht so much significance, pay the extra $10=$20 for a guide, you will learn a lot more than just wandering around. Don't be surprised by the cremations going on right in front of you with spectator seating.
Holy Hindu temple. I visited Pashupathi nath 15 days before Earthquake. such a holy place. but very crowded. i liked the thousand lingas temple inside the pashupathinath temple

Must see if you are in Kathmandu. Pashupatinath has not been damaged much by th April 2015 earthquake. It is very interesting to walk around the area alongside the Bagmati River. the Temple is Napls most important Hindu Temple.
The Sadhus will have their photo taken foor a small amount of money. Non Hindus cannot enter the main temple.

Special but interesting experience. We walked from Boudda to Pashupatinath in about 30 minutes. We went there from the hill side passing the river and some small buildings looking like an older temple, where a lot of monkeys lived.We passed a guard, where we paid 1000 rs each and got a ticked. The path from the hill side can be a bit steep at som places.When we arrived to the crematorium a funeral ritual just started. It was really interresting to see the hindu culture, but also a bit stange to be watching as a tourist. It's different from our culture, to burn dead family members outside while watching, so some people might find it a bit macabre.But it was a very peacefull and quiet cermony, which gave us a good insight in the hindu culture.If you want to take pictures of the painted men sitting outside the temple, they will charge you.

Fascinating place. It is a magical place where one can sit and think about life and death at the very same moment.Best moment to visit in our opinion is just before sunset.Having been more than once to Varanasi (the Indian holy city on the banks of Ganges), we can definitely say thay Pashupatinath has kept its authenticity better with time passing... You will not be bothered by touts: the only "tourist attraction" there seems to be "businness-sadhus" and it's up to you to give them a few Rupies and have a funny photo together if you want.

Sacred Hindu temple. We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010. The Pashupatinath Temple is a very popular sacred Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva(Pashupatinath) and is located on the banks of the Bagmati River 5 kilometres north-east of Kathmandu Valley.This is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Photography is not allowed inside the temple complex, which is very well maintained. We helped by a priest did small puja inside the temple premises and the priest was happy with whatever we payed at the end unlike some temples in India. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the temple premises. Must visit when in Kathmandu.

Pashupatinath Temple. Quick tour to Pashupatinath Temple in Nepal ,its very close to Tribuwan Airport and can be easily visited in short interval of timeI had been helped by my Cab driver as well as a garland selling lady-Manju didi here to see the place,Do buy genuine Roodraksh here,if you find one
Culturally interesting. Pashupatinath largely escaped damage from the earthquake and is certainly worth the time to visit. Try to go there without quoting Monty Python "bring out yer dead".

The Head of Hinduism," Pashupatinath Temple”. Pashupatinath was a very interesting place..This is a magnificent Pagoda style temple with great architecture and wonderful metal doors. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the temple, but even views from across the river are not bad. it is a place of sadness it is where the hindus bring their dead for cremation.you can spend quite time on Shelshmantak Jungle.

Pashupatinath Temple. Pashupatinath was a very interesting place. it is a place of sadness it is where the hindus bring their dead for cremation. It is also a very peaceful place the river running tru it. I had a local guide to get the full history well worth a visit.

Temple and Ghats. Really interesting and historic site of hindu temple. Its where bodies are cremated so be careful where you photograph and indeed go if families are mourning. We had a guide which we often don't but worth it - as always sort price out. Also take some smaller notes for offreing to Sadhus and pics with them. From here its an easy walk to bodnath temple its around 20 mins walk- keep walking up the steps and then left at entrance of temple over the bridge and straight on through the town - just ask if right way

Only Hindus allowed to enter. This is a magnificent temple with great architecture and wonderful metal doors. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the temple, but even views from across the river are not bad. There is a strong aura of death around the temple with its cremation ghats facing the river

suprisingly quiet and serene. I hadn't been to Pashupatinath for many years, and went only because guests in town had put it first on their list of places to visit. I am so happy that I went. The Bagmati River, which runs through the temple complex was running nicely, although it was filthy as always. We went on a Nepali holiday, and there were many families visiting the temple, dressed in their best. At the main shrine, which we, as non-Hindus could not visit, we could hear the sound of a lively bhajan, or religious song. being sung. As dusk fell a huge troop of monkeys came thundering past, the big alpha males standing guard to make sure all the mothers and babies made it safely past the humans. All in all a lovely visit, which I would highly recommend to any tourist.

Mesmeric, sobering, moving experience. Everything about Pashupatinath surprised me - the size of the place, the throngs of people, the emotion, the respect given to the dead in the cremation ceremonies. It was a complete eye opener; one that I will never forget. You must visit here to get a truthful experience of Nepalese culture.

Interesting but mixed feelings!. Came with a few friends to visit the place before our flight out of Kathmandu. Outside of the temple is crowded by locals trying to sell stuff and push to be hired as tour guide! There are so many monkeys running around. You can take pictures of the monkey but can't cross them. They can be very aggressive.Following the smoke to the entrance of the temple. For foreigners, we will have to pay 1,000 Ruby ($10 usd) to enter which is one of the most expensive one in all religous and historical sites in Nepal. There are many ceremonies and cremations along the river which you can observe and taking pictures. I did not take pictures of these ceremonies out of respect of the death and their family. It is interesting but to some, it may be a bit disturbance to see bodies and smell of burning flesh. There are many sadhus hanging around the temple and calling you to come taking pictures with them for a fee! They are a bit creepy though!Overall, it is interesting place to visit and observe the local rituals. You might want to wear a mass for the smoke and watch the direction of the wind!

Pure Blisss.... Do not miss the evening aarti!. We went her twice on our trip... once during the day and once at night for the aarti. Both times it was so peaceful. It is beautiful and the vibrations/energy here is great. The evening aarti/prayer is not to be missed... the best I have experienced thus far. I love this temple and plan to go back here again. Note: No photographs allowed and I do think its best that way so you might want to leave your camera behind and just enjoy the temple.

Very Sad World Heritage Site. The condition of such an important shrine will sadden you. It appears the victim of mismanagement more than earthquake. Still, there are touching moments as the devout practice their faith and you can feel the reverence afforded to this temple.

Deep connect and touching heritage. A visit to Pasupatinath is like a visit to Benares. The ancient temple is an epitome of charm, quiet and spirituality. Take your time around this temple and do not be in a rush to be a tourist. Take in the sights, sounds and smells and sit on the steps of the temple to contemplate on the age and place. Photography is not allowed, and that is a plus because you can rely on your senses capturing the experience rather than just visual photos.

Ambivalent feelings.. Awful feeling to smell the death, I was unable to clean my nose and lips for long hours. I understand them and respect but as a European I was unwell when I saw / smelled this. My stomach was upside down. Otherwise it's a nice holy place.

Great hindu holy place. One of the most important holy temple for hindus. You will feel like being in a real lord shivas place. Its a great place to be and also symbolize nepals national glory. you can find hindu funeral which is done with hindu rituals. its simply a place where you should be when you are in kathmandu. One of the most valuable asset of nepal.

Unassuming exterior for beautiful site. Must stop by here when you're in Kathmandu. Foreigners may be asked for 1000 rupee entrance, depending on how noticeably 'foreign' you are. Many people travel here (some by foot from India) for pilgrimage; often, deceased are cremated here. Can do a quick walk-through or sit for awhile with a book or people-watch.
Impressive site. Every time I visit, I am amazed by this "living" temple; people are using the site for daily life all the time. The juxtaposing of life and death rituals side by side is a must see.
Old Temple. We visit this place at morning. It was crowded. This old temple has great historic & religious value to Hindu Religion.

Great pilgrimage shrine. Oh! there is new things face to face i see. Openly dead bodies burnt around the perimeter of temple. while other pilgrimage busy to worship. It is expensive for ticket, 1000 rupees. sense of Hindu books and history are reflecting in the live.

an emotional experience. a real insight into the Hindu religion and their customs after death, hiring a good official guide is well worthwhile as he can explain what is going on and take you to areas you think you can't go to if you are not Hindu,

Hindu cremations. Fascinating place to visit. Beware of the presence of a guide who suddenly offers to help you. Our guide was brilliant and very knowledgeable but foolishly we did not negotiate a price first! Despite this I would recommend a guide to learn about the place and its history. We felt that it was slightly voyeruristic to watch families say farewell to their love ones and then put them on a wooden pyre to burn but our guide said this was not a problem.

Intriguing and a must see !!!!!!. My wife and I recently visited this Hindu site with our Himalayan Social Journey guide and 4 or 5 other westerners. This was a site where cremations are carried out by the river each day. We watched as funeral pyres were constructed out of wood and butter and then saw a number of bodies being cremated on their journey into the next life. We also saw a number of ambulances bringing dead bodies to the site for cremation. While at first I thought that this site might be confronting I was intrigued and surprised to find that I thoroughly enjoyed it. This might sound macabre but I was impressed by how open the whole experience of death was for these Hindus. This is one thing in the west that we try and hide away from our minds, each other and our kids and it was so refreshing to have it out there for everyone to see. I guess I felt the same about a number of things with respect to Nepal and Kathmandu. Our world in the west is sanatized in many ways. A great example for me was smell. On my return to Australia and then heading back to work on my first day I tried to take notice of the smells that I encountered on the way. It was all so sanitized and I got a whiff of my deoderant and really not much more. This was totally different in Nepal as you are constantly bombarded with the amazing smells of life including the good ones like food and wood fires of many types and some of the not so good ones such as burning bodies, dung and decay but which when added to the good ones make up life. So come and visit this Hindu site to open your mind and visit Nepal to re-awaken your senses.

Huge amazing site. many temples, ghats for cremation on Bagmati river, try to be aware of ceremonies and being respectful, gratuities for photos of people expected, remember, Nepal is a poor country, plenty of monkeys and cows

A somewhat somber place to visit. This is the site on the outskirts of Kathmandu, by the river, where human creations occur on a daily basis. While somewhat sobering it is interesting to see the death rites of another religion and culture.

Fascinating. We walked a cross to Pashupatinath Temple from Thamel on a bright morning and paid for our tickets and walked into the grounds. There were hundreds of Hindus going into the temple but as non Hindus you cannot enter. So we walked the grounds and then went across to the opposite bank to view the cremations as a number were taking place. It is a solemn experience and fascinating to watch the rituals of the families. There are also lots of Sadhus (holy men) who will pose for pictures in exchange for cash and watch out around the entrance as there are lots of 'guides' who will take you around for over inflated prices!!
Peace lies here. Every time when I am here in this place makes me to forget what am I. Just sit and feel the place sound of mantra and chanting of bells

Intense experience. This was my second visit to Pashupatinath and I came with some reluctance. On the afternoon of this visit, nine cremations were going on so you could watch the funeral rites at different stages. This is not a place to come if you are squeamish or have recently had a death in the family that you want to avoid being reminded of. On the other hand, the practical steps that families make to send their loved ones off, the swiftness of the process, and the sweeping into the river of any remaining ashes has its own reassurance. As on my first visit, I spent most of my time on the hill on the other side of the river from the main Shiva shrine. There are lots of charming small temples dotted among trees. Teams of children and young people come to practice martial arts. There are friendly dogs. Be careful with the monkeys, which are used to being fed by visitors and can be pushy.On this visit, there were fewer sadhus (holy men) asking for photos in exchange for money.

spritual place. if you have seen the movie 6th sense visit this place and understand why creation is important in our life. this place is full of everything this, happiness, sadness, spiritual and more, visit this place to understand life better
30th Anniversary Trip. We spent half the walking amongst the buildings that had an interesting insite of the people of Nepal.

Religious. For Religious Travellrs ; its a must to visit place .
From the Cultural point of view, you will know that the Old time Rituals and traditions
intruiging insight to Hindu religion. This is one of the most important Hindu places of Nepal and gives you an intruiging insight of the religion and customs.

One of the best experience.... I do not think ,I will.not see anything like this for the rest of life. It waa totaly weird but good experience. I shared all this ceremony - burning dead boddies - and leaves the ashes to the rivers and praying after them. The monk was so interesting . I think paspupatinath temple is the first place in nepal for visiting....

Such reverred deity deserves better upkeep of premises. Pashupatinath is a revered deity and a very important temple which every devotee of Lord Shiva seeks or aspires to visit and worship. This temple admits only Hindus and has large parking areas on all sides. After walking through sprawling walk ways, one enters the main gate where celestial bull, Nandi's backside is seen prominently from outside.Once inside, there are serpentine queues after which one enters crowded and lowly lit passages around the main hall which is even smaller. Place around has dozens of smaller temples but all around monkeys scare you. So do crowds jostling, burning offerings to lamps. All in all, one feels such an important temple must be kept cleaner and flow of visitors directed if not controlled better.
Amazing, "must see" site. The steps of the temple area along the river were an amazing display of ritual, tradition and local culture.

Beautiful, worth a wander round with a guide.. This is a really fascinating temple on the banks of the river. Very much worth a wander round, very much worth having a guide, it's a really interesting insight.
watch the ceremony/ies. if your vist day was the day ,have a chance to see and understand the ceremony of death people preparation....

What A Site.... To start with Pashupatinath is Lord Shivas temple... Itz huge and definitely a place to visit when in Kathmandu.The Temple itself is beautiful... Lots of worshippers n preachers... No cameras allowed in the temple... But the outside compound is also very beautiful...Itz one off the best temple I have visited...

Feeling peace of mind!!. I have visited pashupati nath temple, it is really amazing, inside the big temple area there are many many others gods, I saw main shiva god inside of temple from all doors in my visit, i feel peace of mind after darshan.

Big complex of Hindu Temple. It has nice surrounding, with monkeys, goats and cows. But some people seems to take advantages by using children to beg. So be prepared to be surrounding by beggars in many forms, youngsters and olds, yogis and all.

Insight into lives of Nepalese people. Visiting Pashupatinath and its cremation part provides an insight into the most difficult time of our lives. You can see the whole process from the preparation of the bodies until their complete burning. It's a very spiritual place and it's better to be ready for what you'll see. Worth to hire a local guide to show you around and explain what is happening. The entrance fee is 1000Rs. From Pashupatinath you can walk up to Bodnath Stupa.

The Great Shiva Temple of Nepal. This is a beautiful and famous temple of Lord Shiva. You can find the pigeons (a lot of them) flying around the area of this temple which gives an even great view to the place.In this temple nobody is allowed to touch the Linga of Lord Shiva as it is believed that anything that touches the Linga will turn into Gold (A Myth!). Anyways a very peaceful and soulful place to be in Kathmandu.
Har Har Mahadev!. Darshan at Pashupatinath Temple is like dream come true. It is best temple. Truly blessed after darshan of Lord Shiva here!
Hindu Divotees paradise. Place where you will get peace of mind and ...Pashupatinath temple is must visit for hindu divotees.

Depends on your time of visit. Being an Indian,I had heard a lot about this place,and this was the first place I visited when I was in Kathmandu.Went there around 4 PM,what hit me was the melancholy with the burning bodies and mourning families.Photography is prohibited,and the main shrine was closed.apparently they only open it once a fortnight.The crowd depends on what time to visit,and also the days of the weekMake sure you visit the adjoining hilly area where you can enjoy some nature sans the smell of death.

Worth a visit. A short ride from Thamel district (on the road to the airport) interesting buildings and to see the Cremations along one side of the river and the families sitting eating and offering prayers and gifts on the anniversary of their dead.

Be prepared for what you are going to see.. I'm not sure how to rate this. I was unprepared what I was going to see even though I had read about it. It has left an imprint in my mind, the wrapped up bodies, grieving families, the ash in the air, the garbage, the heavy heavy feeling of death. This is how I felt as a foreigner and a non Hindu. I would never take children. I paid the entrance fee, but left after about 10 mins. I won't forget this place. My rating says average but I need a whole different category.

Holy Shrine. This is a very popular Hindu shrine and worth visiting if you are in Kathmandu. In the morning there are lot of rush but if you visit very early in the morning or around noon the crowd is less. I visited the place at 12:30 and there was no crowd. Photography is not allowed inside the main temple. There is a cremation place on the bank of the river which is visible once you are inside the main temple premises.

Visit early morning to avoid crowd and queue. Reach there early - it will be really clean, no crowd, prayer can be offered in peace. The main temple opens at 8 but by the time it opens, other smaller temples can be visited.
Also don't fall into the trap of numerous shops trying to sell you puja material at a very steep price, especially fake rudraksh beads.
A Special Place. I visited here during the Teej festival and it gave the temple a special atmosphere. Please don't take photos of the cremations it's disrespectful!
Non Hindus are not allowed to go main temple. Non Hindus are not allowed and had to pay 1000 NPR just to see main temple, how ever the cremation part was something to see.

The holiest shrine of Lord Shiva in Nepal!. "Pashupatinath Temple", a Unesco appointed "World Heritage Site, is an absolurely must see in Kathmandu. As the holiest shrine dedicated to Lord Shiva in Nepal, the main temple is not opened to non-hinduists. Visitors are allowed only in the outer areas. The atmosphere of death is present at almost everywhere. On the "ghats" of Bagmati River (a tributary to the Ganges River), cremation rituals are performed continuosly. Ailing hinduists come to die here, living their last days on the temple's premisses. Misteries and faith! Moments of silence, meditation and respect. Be aware of monkeys (they are all over - keep your belongings safely secured, as they are not at all reliable), fake saddhus (the "ascetic yogis" always ready for "paid" pictures with western tourists) and street vendors (free souvenirs do not exist in anywhere in the world).I visited Kathmandu last February, nearly two and a half months before the terrible earthquake that devastated Nepal on April 25, 2015. As a Lord Shiva miracle, "Pashupatinath Temple" has suffered only minor damages and is normally opened for visitors. Enjoy!
An odd sight for a non-Hindu to see open air cremations. An interesting insight into funeral rituals of the Hindus, you definately need a guide. Really interesting and a must see.
Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu. Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu is a Hindu temple. The major Siva temple in Nepal..a must for Hindu, but not compulsary for others religion.

Great place to experience Teej. I only visited at Teej, but it is a great location for seeing and experiencing festivals like Teej, when women gather to celebrate and dance and the entire place becomes a beautiful sea of red saris!

Temple Through The Lens. Apart from religious value, If you're a photographer then this might be your spot. You can take slow shutter snaps of pigeons, different geometrical structure all around the temple, different types of people with different color can give you better portrait too, blur/movement images also comparatively easier to get here. And yes, there's monkeys too! Just be aware as there are many clever guys roaming around who can impose you to buy something, talks with you nicely, give something like gift then demands for money, offers sight seeing guidance and may ask higher price. Sorry to say, I got this situation in a hot and full of crowd day. I dodged, bet you can too. ;-)

Best place for walking at night time. Most quite, calm and high energy place which I ever visit. All time when I'm in Nepal I'm going to that temple... Just to think, relax... may be kind of meditate... There two parts which is divide by Bagamati river. One part where is Shiva Temple - if you are not hindu, you anyway can't go inside, and place for cremation... where is very hard to be. And another part with stupas. Bright side. It's like hell and paradise... Full power!I can recommend to go there at night with many reasons: 1. There no people, no tourists, no sellers, no fake-sadhu. Just almost nobody. Dogs, monkeys and may some cremations... You can seat and think about eternally. 2. At night time visit of Pashupatinath is free ))Enjoy!
Immense religious significance. One of the most eye opening experiences, dispalying the futility of life and efforts. This will change you.

Great Shiva Temple in Himalayas. Pashupatinath Temple is oldest Shiva Temple worshiped by Hindus. It is situated in such a on the bank of Bhagmati river that, the temple didn't get damaged during recent earthquake in Nepal. The Shivling has 4 faces and can be seen from all the four sides. Hindu rituals are performed at the temple and at the courtyard. It has beautiful architecture. Worth visiting during trip to Nepal.

Our Family visit to Pasuphathinath Temple. Pashupatinath temple is very famous among Hindus, where Hindus come and working Shiva in Pashupatinath temple. Behind the temple where you can see Bagmathi River and where before burning the bodies, the dead person is dipped in the river then taken cremation. During Monday's a big ceremony done behind the temple where various priests handle lights in various styles. It is worth watching.Inside the temple, watch out the monkeys. While we were there, we watched a monkey snatching a women's purse and taking out the phone and dropping others on the floor and climbing on top and holding the phone on the mouth and trying to catch things thrown by others expecting the monkey to drop the phone. People making calls to the same phone and the phone ringing, but the same money did not even drop the phone. So, be careful with your belongings.

Unique visit - view cremations on the banks of the Bagmati River. Located on the bank of Bagmati River on the eastern outskirts of Kathmandu. The temple is dedicated to god Shiva and is important for Hindu and Buddhist cremations. Their last journey traveling the Bagmati River which meets up with the Ganges River. The smell of decaying flesh mixed with spices and reeds is overwhelming (wear a mask). Colourful Sadhus wander around - it is worthwhile tipping them to take a photo. They are there trying to acquire liberation from the cycle of death and rebirth by meditating. A definite visit.

Interesting but expensive. Huge temple grounds and lots to see, like funeral ceremonies and people living on the temple grounds. Definitely worth a visit but a bit pricey, 1000rupees per person. Also, rubbish everywhere doesn't make it very appealing.

Wish they could have ramps for wheelchair to see the whole temple. One of the Dhams to sure visit. Its really huge and very beautiful. the car parking is very near to the temple it was sad they did not allow even a car with handicap person in but anyways to my luck there was not much rush the day i went so i took my automatic wheelchair from parking point to the temple. had very nice darshan. if i could walk would have gone around the whole temple surroundings which had fantastic architecture but they did not have any ramps so it was not possible. but yes they give preference to handicap people the pandit and all have a way to make us do the fast darshan.

The Holy Shrine. The Holy & historic place where you can feel the last truth of your life as me tweeted after visiting there"Yesterday i went to Pashupati for funeral & came back ,thought on mind someday i ll go & only others ll return back.". but its really beautiful with all Pagoda style Lord Shiva temple & more scenic view of River Bagmati & Shelshmantantak jungle.

Great landmark. Off limits to foreigners.. This great historic site (and many others in Kathmandu) are actually hostile to foreign visitors. An expensive fee is charged, but foreigners are not allowed to enter the temple premises. Atheists, agnostics, Buddhists, Christians, Muslims, and other Nepali and Indian nationals are welcome. But not devout Hindus from other countries. It is a shame that Hindus from other countries are banned from a Hindu temple.

A very intresting temple . If you interst local culture and being familiar to funeral of Indian people; this is the best palace for this purposes.there are many funeral services in this temple. They wash the body of dead person, by water of Baghmathy river ( as a holy river )and then burn it totally. Non Indian people only can see funeral and different small temples in front of pashupatinath temple and they were not permitted to go inside the temple.

Very interesting, lovely photos, cultural, religious, fascinating. If you love taking photos, love quirky stuff (like Varanasi India but on a much much smaller scale)... you can see cremations, photos are allowed... you can wonder around and just sit and watch, there is so much to see if you do this. Take a stroll up the steps to some lovely temples, loads of monkeys around. Easy to get there via green Sahja Yatayat bus about 20 rupees..... well worth the trip, entry is 1000rs which is steep but as I like this sort of thing it was ok to pay this amount.

For the Devotees!. This Temple holds a special place for its religious value for all Hindus. The temple is situated just 5-6 km from Kathmandu airport and is a part of a modest compound. You can easily walk down thru the lanes to reach the main temple witnessing the last rites and rituals being performed across the river running beside the temple.We went to this place in December of 2014 and it was a nice sunny day.The temple compound is well manged and clean. There are a lot of monkeys (really a lot many!) inside the main temple area... but they do no harm...:)You can hire a temple guide who explains the history and significance of this place and the rituals.... the one we found was quite reasonable and we felt much more aware and contended after he showed us around the temple.Overall we had very good Darshan and felt accomplished!

Beautiful Religious & Historical Site. Beautiful temples and old temple grounds. Main temple cannot be entered by non-Hindus. The remaining areas were filled with history and culture, everything was outdoors. There are many smaller temples to see and live Hindu cremations were going on while I was there near the stream/river. There are Sadhu's (Hindu holy men) asking for donations to cleanse your spirit and other Sadhu-types offering astrological charts or readings for a fee. There are monkeys roaming around and a lot of tourists and religious visitors. It was worth the trip to see it all.

Please don't judge, be aware of cultural differences. This must be mind-blowing for us, westerners, and we might just be like oooo they are burning bodies non-stop and its so filthy and smells and weird.. But in fact its a holy place, people from all over Nepal and India come here to spend the last days of their ilves and meet death. Very very interesting and amazing!

An absolute must do. This is a must see site, it is a very large site with numerous temples. A guide is suggested, as the history and explanations for the temples, customs, etc. was very worthwhile and didn't cost much. We did see cremations taking place which was mysterious and creepy while at the same time awe inspiring. This is a unique and special place.

Absolutely Blissful !!! ❤. One of the most sacred , Historic protected monument which is absolutely blissful , neat and clean Temple in Kathmandu.Hats off to the maintenance team for maintaining this wonderful temple, I went there on 25th August and due to it's overall attraction I was forced to comeback on 2nd September before boarding my flight to Chennai via Delhi.Situated in the heart of Kathmandu and easily accessible from all parts of the city.Must visit for all age groups when you are in Kathmandu.When we sit in silence after doing all the formalities, we will be absolutely peaceful and feeling relaxed.The whole atmosphere is full of positive vibrations and Bagmathi river adds to the beauty of this glorious place.Thanks a lot for everything,Loving you so much,Peacefully yours.S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling... ❤ ❤ ...

Superb temple. The home of Lord Shiva and centrally located in Kathmandu photos are strictly forbidden so dont try to sneak any this is a place of worship to be respected - I visited prior to the earthquake in April

"Lord Shiva's Home". Pashupatinath is one of the 12 joytrilinga of lord shiva ( I hope I am correct). I have visited the temple before the earthquake. Outside of the temple you will find verity of "Rudraksha" and it is believe that one can find original ones here, provided you know how to identify. One advice is that if you don't know anything then don't purchase such things. Thank you.

Historical but not very clean. This temple has a wonderful history and is the main attraction for Hindus. The place is vast and shoes removal is compulsory (as is customary in most temples) but sadly the place is not clean.It is better to have a pair of disposable socks to be worn for the visit and then thrown away.Preferably allow yourself 60-90 minutes to visit.Not sure if I would like to visit again !

Holiest Shrine of Nepal and arts!. Pashupatinath temple is the holiest shrines of Nepali people and respected by both Hindu and Buddhist located by the bank of holy Bagmati river. Where in the world one can see the the ritual so live.

Temple with 5 faced Shivalinga. Temples territory is surrounded by small and large statues of Hindu gods and goddesses. The crematoria is also placed on the bank of holy Bagmati River. The place which has both religious and cultural importance is a worth place to visit. Along with the view of temple we can also have the view of the deads being burnt according to the Hindu ritual. Plenty of monkeys in and around the area make the trip amazing.

Not to be missed. Pashupatinath is the holiest temple for Hindus. The main temple premises is reserved for Hindus only so if you are a non-Hindu, you can not enter the main temple premises but it does offer a lot. For Hindu, early morning is a good time to visit and enjoy the religious feeling. For non-Hindu, an hour before it gets dark may be the best time to witness the beauty of the temple from across the river, and then the Aarati - lighting of lamps - in the early evening, something you shouldn't miss.

Wish there were some direction boards guiding through the various temples in the complex, and also their significance.. Beautiful temple, with order in the apparently chaos around. Best tiem is the evening aarti at 7pm.Go a little earlier as it gets dark fast and might not be able to see the temple in detail.

Great historical temple. I highly suggest going here. The crematoria here is something that's emotional that's hard to replicate in any other place hit the ancient stupas everywhere with the large number of pilgrims definitely make this a must see.
Must visit for Hindus. Only Hindus are allowed. Remarkably old architecture. You can book pooja in a day advance only starting from NCR 1100. One must do
Superb. If you are visiting Nepal, it's a must visit...you feel inner peace after darshan...if you can, attend evening Aarti (evening prayers)..

Spiritual place and religious!. This is the best place of mine, spiritual, religious, and circle of life. I spend 2-3 hours at bagmati river bank, where you can see everything, beginning of life to end.
OM NAMASHIVAYA. Visited this temple two times during my stay.. OM Namashivaya.. Very Holy & Divine place.. gone into Spirutiality..

A Spiritual Journey. A must visit when in Kathmandu. The place is charged with energy as you are surrounded by all the five elements - Earth - Fire - Water - Sky - Air. The burning ghats bring you face-to-face with mortality and yet there is a serene and spiritual feeling the moment you enter the complex.
Jay Sambho. All Hindu must visit this Temple at least on time of there life time. Lots of visitor comes from whole Nepal and India.

Great to view from the eastern banks of Bagmati River. This is a very sacred and spiritual temple to the Hindus and as such only followers of that faith are allowed to enter. It's usually part of the visit in conjunction with the Crematoria on Bagmati River and we found both are best viewed from across the other side on the eastern bank. It is a wonderful looking structure and very old.Apart from Pashupatinath Temple, there are other smaller temples and buildings to see on that side, but we felt as intruding tourists so we crossed back onto the eastern side of Bagmati River across the bridge. Here we could witness the burning of the bodies on the pyres and the rituals leading up to the final fiery moment, as well as the last step - someone cleaning off the pyre ready for the next corpse. The view of the temple, the surrounding buildings and the river are all quite good from the other side.As several of the main sites to see in Kathmandu Valley are now either destroyed or badly damaged by the earthquake and "squares" may not take so long to visit because of it, this is a good option to put on the list of places to see and experience.Recommend visiting here and with a guide who can explain to you the importance, significance and rituals which will add to the experience.

Very interesting to see. It was incredible to see the history and the ongoing cremations of the dead. However it costs 1000 rupees to enter and they do not allow into the main temple. On top of this, people harass you and try to sell you merchandise.
Interesting insight into the Nepalese way of life.. An interesting place to visit - beware the self-appointed guide who told me that 2000rp was not enough at the end.

Understand the sentiments before going here. A major part of this temple is a burning pyre for humans. While foreigners are excited at the prospect of clicking pictures, pl. understand the sentiments of locals who come here.
I really saw the dead body there.. The building was beautiful. The funeral just beside the river, so you can see many people come to the funeral and burn the dead body . It was very interesting.

If you are in Nepal then you have to have the blessing of Pashupatinath. There is no question of dislikes... Just be there, its something like when you are hungry you want to eat, so its all about your spertural hunger..
God's place.. This temple is very old and has mythological importance. For the benefit of devotees from various parts of the world there need to be more cleanliness and more signage for guidance.
Very sacred to Hindus of the world, must see and feel. A place to check your relations with death - would be certainly a shock for European traveller - must see and if possible meditate there

Costly and disappointing. I was very disappointed in this site. It's THE most expensive ticket in Kathmandu at a whopping Rs1000. However, there really isn't that much to see. Perhaps you just go for the atmosphere. There are many, many mini temples all over the grounds, some up very steep stairs, some in amongst tranquil gardens, some along the river bank, but they all look very similar and after a short time I had a sense of "seen one, seen 'em all". Down by the river side, you may catch a funeral taking place and it's best not to photograph this activity.Sitting around the temples are holy men in full make up and 'costume', but rather cynically, it appears they really are there just to have their photos taken with tourists and charge for the pleasure. I can't imagine The Archbishop of Canterbury sitting outside Westminster Abbey in his full regalia charging for his photo. Alas, the most interesting part of the complex is not open to tourists or non-Hindus. A massive, resplendent, golden temple structure sits separately and only believers are permitted to enter. Even if you somehow convince you are a follower, you still are not permitted any photography inside. You can however climb above the compound, up some steep stairs and you can then get a few snaps inside the grounds, but the view is still restricted.For the price of this complex, I was disappointed. There are far better and far cheaper options in Kathmandu.

Must visit Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu. Nepal. On my way to Kailash Manasarover Yatra I had a two day stay in Kathmandu.i visited the pashupatinath Temple.The temple was erected in the 15 century by Lichhavi King.The richly ornamented pagoda houses the sacred Linga or holy symbol of shiva.Pashupatinath Temple is located on both banks of Bagmati River .The main temple of Pashupatinath is a building with a bunk roof and a golden spire.It is a cubic construction with four main door ,all covered with silver sheets. Only followers of hindusim can enter the main temple, But all the other bulding are available for foreigners to visit.Along the right bank of Bagmati river numerous platforms for funeral pyres are built.The cremations on these platforms are a common activity everyday.It is also very common to meet sadhus in pashupatinath temple.Sadhu are wandering ascetic yogis, who are trying to acquire liberation from the cycle of death rebirth by meditating.It is belived that those who die in Pashupatinath Temple are reborn asa human,regardless of any misconduct that could worsen their Karma.If you are attacted to the places where death can be felt,consider Pashupatinath as your first destination.It is a temple with special atmosphere of death, death is present in almost every ritual and every corner of it. OM NAMAH SHIVA.

One of the most memorable experiences in Kathmandu. I loved seeing the evening Aarti here in Pashupatinath. It was one of the most beautiful I've seen in Nepal/India and quite memorable. The architecture was fascinating and the campus spans far and providing lots of space to roam and explore. I also observed my first cremation ceremony here. So many small buildings and sculptural elements. Very unique, a definite must see.

Must visit for a Hindu. Very holy place and must visit for all Hindus every year. Wash away your sins and thank god for all his help. Avoid buying anything here as they will crook you. Wear rubber slippers, do not carry any leather. Catch hold of a nice old pundit who will show you around. Tip him 100 NR at the end. Avoid those elaborate 'poojas' as it is just a 'con'. No photography permitted inside. Beware of the monkeys that snatch your Prasad etc. spend a good one hour here. Carry a lot of change to tip at all the prayer points. ( bundle of INR 10 notes fine). Buy a basket of flowers and coconuts @ NR 100/- before entering.
A must visit when travelling to Kathmandu. Beautiful Temple! A must visit when travelling to Kathmandu. A trip to Kathmandu is incomplete without going to these beautiful temples.

We found this sunset visit simply amazing. An atmosphere you wont find anywhere else!! So much going on- singing, drums, burning bodies- lots of pilgrims. This is a good place to see the law of nature and culture of the Indian people in Nepal. Instead of the going to Varanasi in India, this is a place to visit on a much smaller scale.

The Haven for the Hinduism.. Pashupatinath is God Father of Nepal. It is really a heart pleasing experience to me visit such a holy place. You will really found your self tense-less as the sound of Bells will touch your soul.

Om Namah Shivay.... The Place of Bholenath....Everyone should visit this temple...very religious place for Indians....you will feel really good if you visit this palace....it will relax your mind, body & soul.I am feeling lucky to visit this place...Om Namah Shivay...Har Har Mahadev.
A must see. Assuming that it survived the earthquake this is a well worth while temple to spend some time viewing.
Har har Mahadev!. Visited a temple after five years and I thank god Mahadev for the darshan. Powerful and inspiring if you believe in almighty.

The Hindu Rome.. Construction started on this temple in the 7th century. It sits on the Bagmati river in Nepal and is one of the holiest sites in the hindu religion.The entire complex has 500+s other shrines and smaller temples. It is guarded by Nepalese police. Pashupathinath admits only Hindus. it is encased with silver walls and has a gold pagoda roof The complex is a world heritage UNESCO site. Gat's jut out into the Bagmati river.These are used by a dedicated cast to cremate the dead. Similar in fact to the use of the gats in city of Benares on the Ganges( India) The cremations are a sobering sight and the river looks polluted but this has been a center of the hindu faith for many centuries,as such will remain for many more.

1000 year old temple and surrounding structures.. This is one of the most religious destination for believers of Hindu religion. The temple is situated on banks of the river. It makes you think several centuries behind

Not what I expected. The first time I came here I was expecting a little bit more from this place. I heard it from a few travelers on what is done here, where families would come to burn the deceased members body and into the water. I visited with a friend and entered through the wrong entrance. We ended up watching the ceremony. The part I did not enjoy was seeing dozens of foreigners snapping photos of this from the distance. If it was my family I would hate people taking photos of this emotional time. Entrance fee was 1000 Nepali rupees too. quite high in my opinion. Average price for an attraction in Nepal for the entrance fee is usually 200-500 Rupees
nice but.... of course nice, like most of the temples around Kathmandu, but the vibration here was not so high like in other places... it worth anyway to go...
Temple. Loved visiting this Hindu temple and took around 1,000 photos , watch out for monkeys and local tourist guide, it's only 4 kms away from the main town and taxi fare is around $250 rupees.
Why to miss?. Visiting nepal and not seeing this temple of Lord Shiva, impossible. Very old and magnificent, but needs more maintenance.

Lord Shiva Temple. The biggest temple of Lord Shiva in Kathmandu. The Architecture of Temple is excellent and attractive. It is said that once in a year, the king of Nepal comes for pooja and use the paras mani. That day, the temple is closed for common man.

An absolute must see ...an explosion of color and culture!. This is like stepping into the most amazing assault on your senses ever.... Pay for a guide and let them tell you all about the place. Watch the bodies burning by the riverside, the kids swimming and diving to collect gold from the teeth of the burned corpses, the colorful sādhu sit and smoke marijuana, (Sanskrit: साधु sādhu, "good; good man, holy man") is a religious ascetic or holy person. Have a picture taken with them and donate to the pour. Walk to the shopping area and bye some religious paraphernalia.... If you do one thing in Kathmandu do this!

Visited in September 2014.. One of the Greatest religious place for Hindus, visiting pashupatinath is considered equivalent to visiting kedarnath & you can stay in Dharamshala , it is govt. subsidized & walking distance from main temple.
An attraction ?. Personally I can't get my head around Cremation Ghats as a tourist attraction . . . . If you are happy with that, then it's a fascinating place

Learning Hindu Culture. Our first full day in Kathmandu, we visited this temple and it was a great way to learn how the people of Nepal live their lives around what happens with the temple and their gods. I liked being able to see how they ritually went through the cremation of the dead and how each person handled it. This temple received some damage from the earthquake but not as much as other places. However, I did not like that there were locals every where in the temple who had set up little places to sell things and were constantly going up to tourists trying to sell their items. It just didn't seem very sacred to me. But it could just be how their culture operates.

Holiest place to visit in Nepal, alas only Hindus allowed. This is the most holiest site in Nepal. This was the place where lord Shiva took incarnation of an animal (all that anyways you can wiki around). This temple only allows Hindus to visit, don't understand why the restriction. It is very peaceful inside and really beautiful, the roof was made of gold they say now not sure but surely the color is golden still :). Apart from the main temple there are many other temples also and you can also directly go to the Bagmati river from the temple itself. Non-hindus are allowed to visit temples on the other side of Bagmati you can see Pashupati standing in all her/his glory. Should go there at least once if you are in Kathmandu.

Pashupatinath. This is the most important Hindu Temple site in Nepal and is also a UNESCO World Heritage site... Many fascinating things to see and well worth a visit... feeling refresh. i really refresh the environment of pashupati temple.pashupati temple is one of the great hindu temples. many artful structure of the temple.i really refresh when i went to the pray time in pashupati temple. and i went to the mrigasthali and brindaban.many visitors are visiting thmple.i really impress.when i will come back in nepal again i will go again the pashupatinath temple.

Temple of Lord Shiva. This is one of the main Temple of Nepal. Whenever I visit the place, I feel free from stress and any type of anxiety. Great but watch out for some things!. this Temple was really great to explore! it was fun because they also had all the wild life. Heres a few tips for non local travelers1.) beware the monkeys! :they are not nice and will steal things;clothes, snacks and gagets2.) fake religios people : we went with locals who knew all the ins and out and there would be people at the temples who pretended to be things they weren't. they would dress up in very cool traditional (looking) outfits and offer pictures but then would want money. it is a scam .3.) cremations :being a temple they do have real ceremonies and such there including funerals where they would burn the body's in the open then dust the ash off into the river. so watch out for smokey areas cause your probably breathing burnt flesh and to be respectful and not intrude / take pictures of these events because it is someones family member.but its truly amazing to experience this place the list off good is just way to long to rite out :)

Weird to vist such a scared place. I wasn't sufficiently prepared to visit a river with funeral pyres on either side. Every culture does things differently, but here I felt a bit of an intruder. My local friend assured me that it was ok, but I was not comfortable seeing people in distress. There were several several holy men willing to pose for photos.

One of the great Hindu Temples. I have been to Pashupatinath Temple twice in my recent visits to Nepal, but unfortunately I have not been able to actually offer my prayers to Lord Shiva as the main temple was closed on both occasions. It is one of the few major Hindu Shrine Temples where non-Hindus are not allowed. The 1100 shiva lingas are a major attraction and you get peach doing puja to Hanumanji. I'd like to go again at Lord Pashupatinath Temple. A Must visit for all Nepal visitors.

Hinduism and tradition at its core!. This is one of the most sacred places I have ever visited, I was lucky to be able to enter the premises on a sacred day. However very crowded, it was beautiful to see all the women in red, fasting, dancing and singing for their husbands. It is a place of fertility worshiping. It has opened my mind for traditions that are unconceivable on the western world.
Standing tradition, must visit. A place not affected by the agonies of nature, robust and traditional. If its upkeep could be guaranteed many more visitors could come

The river beside the temple and cremation ghats remind you of Varanasi. If you know and understand HINDU culture then you may appreciate the grand Pashupatinath temple of Nepal. The river beside the temple and cremation ghats remind you of Varanasi. Tourists from other faith may find it amusing and disturbing. Go there with an open mind.
Visit to pasupatinath. Pasupatinath dedicated to Lord shiva.photography is not allowed inside the main shrine.must visit temple.

Holy hindu temple. Most tourists getting into Kathmandu, will make a visit to this temple considered a very holy shrine.The temple is built centuries ago and is evident from the structure of the building. This temple has restrictions like no photography allowed of the main Shiva temple where the Shivling is. More so, you will need to keep your footwear at the designated place and walk to the main temple area barefeet. In case of rainy days, this becomes a little messy.The holliness of the shrine has been well accepted by hindus over the years. The positive vibrations of the place is well evident and you will find it quite tranquil in here.After the massive earthquake this year, the temple structure has stood still even after 380+ aftershocks! That is quite a marvel. But on the flip side, which is also normal, is that tourism has been hit in this country and my last visit there hardly saw much visitors from abroad.
Holy and Peace. The most holy and spiritual place. Glade to visit it in my life time. The environment and the spirituality wondered me.

A brief glimpse for Westerners into a Hindu holy place. We were approached by a guide and -- for once -- took him up on the offer of a tour. We were glad we did. There is so much here that we would not have understood on our own.

Check to see if Pashupatinath Temple has survived.. This was an interesting place in Jan 2015, I hope this fountain survived, as it shows so much of the old city ...

A must visit UNESCO site. We visited this famous temple upon completion of our EBC trek in Nov 2014. The complex is huge and clean unlike other religious places. Photography is prohibited beyond the entry gate of main temple. The typical pagoda style hindu architecture attracted me. The unique lingam with face deity is hugely popular. I don't know how but I recognised the place where I was laid down as a child of 15months [ Mother told I was suffering from high fever and suddenly got cured after visiting the place] when my parents visited the temple 28 yrs back.

Good Place for Religious Tourism. One of a few temples where entries are restricted to Hinduism only. Situated at outskirts of Kathmandu it is one of the most important temple of Lord Shiva and believed to offer Moksha to people who die here and hence attracts old age Hindus from across Nepal and India too. The River Bagmati flows at the side of the main temple and is an active Hindu cremation place. Most of the priest are from South India. Apart from religion I found it a great piece of ancient Hindu architecture. The main temple & the Nandi outside are crafted very nicely and indicates highly developed architecture of those period. Apart from stone crafting the wood work at the temple is excellent. The silver, copper and Gold crafting too adds to the beauty and indicates to wealthy temples of Medieval days. A nice place to be religiously or beyond.For non Hindus too the site offers good insight to history & architecture and they can spend an hour or two outside the main temple.The market outside offers handicrafts but I suggest Darbar square as a much better place to shop these article.

Sensory overload- especially on Shiva ratri. Like most Hindu temples this one has the usual grime, cattle, holy men and cremations but easily Pashupatinath is the standout for its rich history and the fact that it is among the most revered holy Hindu spots on earth-

Must see once . After powerful desaster , mostly old city was fallen down but I wonder how is possible 100 of years old temple standing without any damage . I start to believe more on some hidden power .You must visit once this amazing place .

Must see!. You should go if you are in Kathmandu - no doubt. The best place to see it is from across the " river" (very little water flowing). Sit in the steps there and enjoy the place. You have a full view of the temple, and of the burning sites at your left. A place to reflect on life and death.

Humbling experience!. As you walk down Pushupatinath Temple there are so many different smells, sounds and sights. A place where monkeys and cows roam freely and families say goodbye to their loved ones. I felt very humbled and emotional watching people carry their loved ones to the pyre. I got quite angry when I saw some tourist filming and taking pictures, I thought it was quite disrespectful!I would recommend you visit but please respect the dead and their families by refraing from tweeting/facebooking/instagraming pictures of the funeral site.

Culture, culture, culture!. Watch as families say their final goodbye to their loved one. What a cultural difference from the West. Admire all the little details on the stone carvings, just marvelous!
Must see. Even though the main temple is reserved for Hindus, the surrounding grounds of this pilgrimage site are well worth a visit. See the cremation sites on the bank of the river.

Jai Bhole baba. I visited the Pashupatinath Temple again after a gap of 15 years...
While the city looks dirty and flithier than before... the temple was surprisingly better maintained than my previous trip.
It seems the Government has taken care of this major pilgrim attraction
Very positive feeling. Pashupatinath is a temple where you cannot think negative. Being there is one of the best feeling of getting blessed.

Religious place. Pashupatinath is one of the main sacred places in Nepal. Many Hindu temples and the main temple for Shiva with a golden bull can be found here. Open after the quake - worth a visit. Pashupatinath temple complex is sizable, and it is one of the Kathmandu UNESCO World Heritage sites to survive the April quakes with minimal damage. Non-hindus are not permitted to enter the main temple, but you can get good views of it from high on the other bank, and you can see plenty to other interesting sights including cremations. Pick up a local guide on the way in for an informative tour, and have your picture taken with the sahus (tips expected for both guide and sadhus).

A must to go. I visited again Pashupatinath temple this year with my crew. It´s a wonderfull place where you can find peace and learn the history of Lord Shiva, one of majos deities for Hindus. All this temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva, also known as Pashupati. Sometimes can be a bit smelly because they cremated dead body all the time, but you can assist to ceremony from other side of river in a high place, away from the funeral. Don´t miss the pujas in the temple in end of day, with thousands of candles. Also you can see the big gold bull from outside of temple, they don´t allow non-Hindus inside the temple.
Divine Experience. It's worth visiting for every Hindu, Divine Place. It's one of the jyotilings of Lord Shiva. Apart from temple, Whole city and Whole Nepal is Really very very Beautiful.

Lord Shiva's Temple. Pashupatinath is a must-visit temple for me every time I travel to Nepal. For Hindus, it is as important as the Dwadash-jyotirlingas or the 12 key Shiva temples which are located in India. A unique aspect of the deity is its four faces , one in each direction. During my recent visit, I went to the temple around 11 am on a Friday morning. I was pleasantly surprised that the ubiquitous queues were missing this time. I was able to spend ample time in front of each of the faces of the Lord without being pushed away by the priests as happens on the busy days. After the darshan, I spent time looking up some of the other temples in the complex. There are statues of some the Nepalese kings who had been involved in several constructions within the temple precinct. I watched with interest as many locals were offering prayers to a large idol of Hanuman. I also explored a small temple established here by Adi Sankaracharya, the greatest exponent of Advaita philosophy. It was quite humbling to have visited this temple which has such a rich history.

Huge and fascinating!. A must see for anyone interested in Hindu religion and culture! The site covers a very large area and includes temples and shrines with much intricate carving. The most interesting to me were the cremation Ghats along the river, which are right next to a hospice so that a devout person can die and be cremated quickly but in the very best location.

An important Hindu temple. A very unique Shiva temple where the moorthy has multiple faces, facing every direction. There are four doors through which we can have Darshan of all these faces.One of the most renowned Shiva temples.

I felt peace at my heart after visiting tat temple. Me and my family members went for pashupati darshan. Me and my 2 sis and her son went there .. It was very good there . That little baby was enjoying lot wid pigeons and monkey . He was enjoying lot. Hope to have next darshan soon with all

in the heart. pashupatinath temple is within the heart of mine.in this temple,people comes from the world to see and worship.this is some thing that is within the heart.i became so peacefull on sitting the bagmati river sides.
Extremely religious. A must visit. The place is auspicious and temple reflects the carvings on stones and on the doors. It's an apt place for all kind of people and age groups.

two visits to this temple. the four faced shivalingga, my first experience was when I arrived at the shrine and got a chance to view it at a close range, my eyes became teary and was not able to view it completely that was in 2010, then in 2014 I got a chance to see all the four faces of the shivalingga and was really the best thing that ever happened in my life

Go and have an experience you will never forget. This place is filled with tradition, the Ghats near the river a used for cremation, be still and respect their traditions. Walk around the Place, see the Holy Saddhu's walking around. Take care because for pictures with them you need to pay. So once more be carefull. Some of the Saddhu's can be really annoying. With Shiva Ratri (The night of Shiva in January/February, depending on the year, these Saddhu's come from all over India to Nepal to worship Shiva. It is spectacular to see this night.

A place to invoke strength. An History was seen , It is a part of the old heritage and a symbol of Hindu Culture in the once a upon a time the only Hindu Kingdom in the world , the temple has high inflow of tourists and worshippers , the complex is clean and well maintained. Must visit when in Kathmandu

Great UNESCO heritage site , visit is a must !. Visited the Pashupatinath Temple complex on the afternoon of 1st January 2015 ,arranged by our guide , Mr Prasant from Outshine Adventures.This temple is one of the most sacred Hindu temples of Nepal,dedicated to God Shiva.The complex is located on both banks of Bagmati River on the east of Kathmandu city.The main temple of Pashupatinath is a building with a bunk roof and a golden spire, on the west bank of Bagmati River ,considered as a masterpiece of Hindu architecture.Along the right bank of Bagmati numerous platforms for funeral pyres are built. The cremations on these platforms are a common activity , and we witnessed some cremation process while we were there, the first open cremation we ever witnessed.There's some chairs on the hills opposite the cremation area, facing towards Bagmati river.We took photos with the Sadhus on little stupas opposite Bagmati river , of course with a small sum of money, be careful ,deal with them first before you take pictures.Overall , a one of a kind experience ,worth the time spent , we highly recommend a visit to all tourists visiting Kathmandu.We hoped that no significant damage to the temple and surrounding building after the 25 April earthquake and the 12 May 2015 aftershock.

Ok. I had gone in may 2015...it was after the earthquake so not much of a crowd was there...the small temples in its vicinity were all destroyed. .we could get darshan very easily..behind at the ghat ...it was too busy at the crematory..i didnt go there...
Shayakon. Non Hondu cannot enter inside the temple, just come here to see the cremation. The entry cost is too high and not worth for just only this.

Visiting 26th April'2015 Morning. 26th April Morning 07:20AM Visited Pasupatinath Temple.Visit was very quite only few person in the Temple due to the Earth Quake.There was no damage of the Temple Structure.

Significant Hindu Temple. This is (was?) an impressive UNESCO World Heritage Site in eastern Kathmandu. We saw it just days before the earthquake and an mot sure how extensively it was damaged. Well worth a visit when things settle down and everyone is safe again.

Visit with many Emotions. Great heritage site. However this visit was to pay respect to those we lost in the earthquake.
A must visit temple to all Hindus

Place of worship. Must see all the four sides of the shiva temple as well as other temples around the area. Though the temple prakaram is cleaned, can be improved vastly. Watching people saying farewell to their loved ones forever are touching. Indeed a different and interesting place to go

visit to the one of the shiva linga temples. the place is super mystic and to the uninitiated a pure waste.. if you have a craving for hindu religion, its mysteries and architecture, then only visit this place...do not forget to see that 'ghat' behind the temple and the rudraksh tree.....you will find out why???

Complete the journey. This Hindu temple is the place which is essential to visit or complete the journey of Kathmandu (By Hindus) by visiting Pashupatinath Temple. I didn't like that non Hindus are not allowed to visit inside the temple. Others are human being too.
Survivor of earth quake. Pastupathinath was largely saved from the earth quake. Great place to watch the cremation ceremonies. On first day after the quake there was mass cremations.

Interesting but no info. My first inrtoducation to the temple area was a fence with signs posted on stating Wold Heritage Site, through the fence howver was open area, covered in mounds of litter with cows, donkeys and people digging around. The temple area is full of interesting sights. Unfortunately, if you are not a muslim you cannot get into it but have to watch from the outside, the best view is across the river on the raised area nearby. The Sadhu are grat photography subjects, and they know it, and they will charge for it. R50 is the normal going rate although some will demand R100. Make sure you secure the rate BEFORE taking photos. There is a wonderful old age home on the right, before the temple and river river area. Go inside and meet the the folk there, they are lonely, without families and super friendly. It is also heart breaking. If you are sensitive you should avoid looking out over the river as the locals celebrate and prepare their dead for burning on the river banks, they then walk them over to the otherside of the bridge to the burning platforms where they light them and watch them burn, before sweeping up the ashes into the "holy river". The smell is not as unpleasant as expected when you think they are burning bodies, but they are well prepared and covered in some herbs and spices, but if you are sensitive it, you may wish to avoid this part.The local monkeys move freely across the whole area, occasionally flinging themselves from rooftops into the "holy river" to cool dowm. It act of childlike play enjoyed by both the monkeys and all how watch. There are plenty of local ladies who will - for a donation - bless you, paint you and pray over you.
