This is fun and unless you are very religious (in which case you may feel uncomfortable partaking in some other religious routine) makes feel you welcome.The temple area is strange collection of differnt buildings and it is worth exploring them all, however unless you have a guide to explain, there is no or little info there. I enjoyed my time at the temple.
Strongest and oldest Temple in Nepal. The temple is very near to airport and one of the oldest and strongest temple.The temple took all the quake beating still stayed tall. The Gods are really there
Another Amazing Historical Site. When visiting Kathmandu a city tour is essential. I hope that the earthquake has not eliminated all of these sites as it is an invite to feel the soul of the nation.

Very calm area. I walked to the temple complex. You can not take photos once you enter the gate, so put your cameras away and respect their wishes. The temple was very calming. I culd not stay for the evening Aarti as it had started raining, but ot would be worth waiting if you can. It's so calming.

hindu's place of must visit in lifetime. the temple is as said the hindu religion's 1 of the most worshiped place. the temple is made in nepal old architecture building and is surrounded by a big park.
behind is a big lake.
the temple says and ask only hindu to visit inside the main campus.
the temple also has a lot of monkeys around.

Amazing place. I really liked pagado style temple , very big surrounding and great carvings. This place is amazing. Only bad thing was smell of burning flesh and not so clean surrounding. We visited in evening and it was nice experience to see 'aarti' at river. You can see lot of sadhus and sadhvis around. Spiritual place indeed.... not to be missed experience.

Fascinating!. This is where people bring the deceased to wash their feet in the Bagmati river and then be cremated. It is shocking strange and beautiful to witness this. The temple and grounds on the opposite side of the river are filled with statues and carvings of Hindu and Buddhist deities. Best visited with a local guide so that you do not miss anything.

Emotional. Although this is an interesting place, I found it quite difficult to watch people saying goodbye to loved ones. I felt bad witnessing the heartbreak of mothers and families like a spectator at a sideshow. Not my favourite at all.
Extensive grounds and old and important temples. I really liked the two-tiered pagoda temple. It has richly ornamented gilt and silver-plated doors on all sides.

Wow Amazing. Wow what a place. We only had half an hour and were amazed at how lovely the surroundings were, Just wished had visited in the day time. Removed shoes and some kind soul assisted us to go all around the Temple as what to do where - was like god sent! They have a river flowing at the back where cremation takes place. If one is lucky, you will meet some spiritually blessed Sadhus.A must visit.Please do not take photos - i was screamed at by a security officer in a very very rude tone -- something he could have done calmly and politely.

Soulful and sacred place -- a must-see. Out of all the temples I've visited in Nepal, I found this to be the most inspiring and with such ceremonial significance. Boudanath Stupa looks more impressive, and Swayambhunath is a lot of fun, but there's nothing quite like Pashupatinath. I was fortunate to have my good friend Naba (a local and an excellent guide to boot) show me around the temple complex and explain to me in great detail what each statue, each area and each ceremony meant. During my visit there, I was able to also witness a cremation ceremony, which is powerfully moving. Since majority of Hindu Nepalis are cremated in Pashupatinath, there's something quite awe-inspiring about witnessing the end in a sacred place like this.I would highly recommend getting a guide or a local to take you around, as the grounds are wide and there is much detail to look at. Wear comfortable shoes as you may end up climbing up and down some very huge steps. For a bit of fun and cultural experience, have your photo taken with the saddhus (holy men) for a small token fee (they like accepting currencies from different countries, by the way!). I also got to talk to them a bit, which was quite nice.There is a small cafe near the top of this temple complex where they serve really good milk tea. For foreign travelers like me, entrance fee to Pashupatinath is Nepalese Rs 1,000 (US $10) which seemed pretty steep to me at first, but was actually worth it, in the end.

Soulful and sacred place -- a must-see. Out of all the temples I've visited in Nepal, I found this to be the most inspiring and with such ceremonial significance. Boudanath Stupa looks more impressive, and Swayambhunath is a lot of fun, but there's nothing quite like Pashupatinath. I was fortunate to have my good friend Naba (a local and an excellent guide to boot) show me around the temple complex and explain to me in great detail what each statue, each area and each ceremony meant. During my visit there, I was able to also witness a cremation ceremony, which is powerfully moving. Since majority of Hindu Nepalis are cremated in Pashupatinath, there's something quite awe-inspiring about witnessing the end in a sacred place like this.I would highly recommend getting a guide or a local to take you around, as the grounds are wide and there is much detail to look at. Wear comfortable shoes as you may end up climbing up and down some very huge steps. For a bit of fun and cultural experience, have your photo taken with the saddhus (holy men) for a small token fee (they like accepting currencies from different countries, by the way!). I also got to talk to them a bit, which was quite nice.There is a small cafe near the top of this temple complex where they serve really good milk tea. For foreign travelers like me, entrance fee to Pashupatinath is Nepalese Rs 1,000 (US $10) which seemed pretty steep to me at first, but was actually worth it, in the end.

Fascinating Hindu complex. Pashupatinath is the oldest Hindu temple in Nepal. Although non Hindus are not allowed into the main temple, you will be able to see many smaller shrines and the cremations on one side of the Bagmati Rivier, and priests ministering to the faithful on platforms on the other side. This was the highlight of our cultural tour of Kathmandu.

VISIT TO THE TEMPLE ON A RAINY DAY. Couple of Days we couldn't do Pashupatinath Temple on our Tour because we were late in Reaching to the Temple in the Evening but Finally we got our Chance to Visit here on Monday Morning just before we could leave to the Kathmandu Airport. It was Raining in early April. The Shops outside the Temple helped us with an umbrella so that we could visit the temple nicely. It is a Huge Temple and There were lots of Tourists in there and ofcourse many localites as well. It Took us sometime really to Visit the Temple as the Area and the Facade is huge. There were people in Lakhs out there. We Could not miss this on our Way to Kathmandu as we had heard a lot and really its a Beautiful temple to Visit. Must Visit place in Kathmandu

How many steps?. A good morning/afternoon visit with plenty to see. Some of the shops a little/lot tacky which detracts from the temple buildings. Monkeys and stray dogs abound but no real problems. Worth a visit.
Pashupatinath Temple. Always wanted to go there...very energetic and spiritual place. Be aware that they have a very strict access policy and will only let you in for religious purposes.

Life time experience to be able to watch cremation by the Bagmati River. A holy sacred place for the Hindus. Could not enter the temple proper because I am not a Hindu. The whole area is vast. Spent some time by the Bagmati river to watch cremation. Many Lingam statures.

Only if you want to see Hindu cremation ceremonies would I recommend.. This was interesting but had I known that primarily the highlight would be witnessing Hindu cremation along the river, I would have passed. For me, this was somewhat of an intrusion as foreigners and visitors watched these families say goodbye. It was sad to see and hear the mourning. I was as guilty as everyone else as I watched but in hindsight I wish I wouldn't have visited this site.

Holy temple. A Hindu cremation ground and where the living Hindus goes to have bath in Baghmati riverTo free themselves from the cycle of rebirth. No leather bags or jackets are allowed in main temple complex. Personally I had a mix feeling to have witness cremation for the first time. It made me to review my own past and present life.

Temple of Lord Shiva. Its considered one of the most sacred temple in Nepal, its a very old and sacred temple.It is a Chaturmukhi (four faced) on a Lingam opening out to four gates, the ancient carving and the stone art is simply superb. It is heavily crowded as it attracts a lot of tourists due to its values.The not so good part was the monkey's which was scary and was all over the place, and would scare people trying to snatch the Prasad from them.Overall a very nice and serene place, good for photography as well and a must visit in Nepal.
Real Hindu temple. You can see the crematorium of a lot of the hindus, very shocking but you can see an important part of their culture.
Eye-opening. A very interesting experience. Try and hire a guide to learn about the customs and traditions. It was hard to believe that you could witness cremations at such a close distance.

Pilgrim Hub. This is one of the most important and sacred place of hindu religion. Its a temple of god Shiva. There are many temples in fact. The ancient architecture and stone art are clearly visible all across the temple. It is surrounded by a forest as well as a river which gives you a unique feeling of natural peace. A nice place to explore some hindu culture and history. Non-hindu followers are not allowed to go inside main temple building.
a good place to experience Hindu culture. not only the place, architecture and religion, but also the funeral would tell the beliefs of Hindu!

If you go nowhere else go here. What an amazing place. If you go here ask for a guide to take you around and tell you about the history of all that is going on. The history behind the cremation ceremony is what is so fascinating. Finding out the differences behind the HIndu and the Buddhist traditions are very interesting. Then to have the fertility temple explained, the holy men traditions, and the temple itself. Then to visit where they elderly are held and cared for is also very interesting. So much to see here. Plan for at least 2 hours if not 3. Without a guide you may not stay as long but the activities going on around you won't mean as much either because you won't understand the significance of what they are doing.

Sacred temple - very earthy and raw - a working olds of pilgrimage. This UNESCO listed world heritage site is a sacred place for Hindus and while non-Hindus can't enter the actual temple, we are permitted through the precinct and are allowed to visit some beautiful places - great for photography and people watching. However, many Hindus choose to be cremated on the ghats beside the river as it is considered sacred. You will see up to a dozen cremations daily - frequently with clear views across the river to the Pyrex. Show some respect for the families - it is a very emotional time for them. also, if you are squeamish, steer clear - you will see corpses and you will often see limbs sticking out of the flames. Also, that smell of barbequeued pork isn't what it seems... Those with a weak stomach should stay upwind
Hindu Temple. Most of the Hindus visit kathmandu for darshan of pashupati nath as it is a temple of shivji. unforfunate is thetemple is not well maintaiined.

A must visit in Kathmandu. # A must visit# very old temple# located on the banks of the Bagmati River# UNESCO World Heritage SitePlease note - Practicing Hindus of western descent are not allowed into the temple complex along with other non Hindu Visitors
Peace of mind. This is very old temple. So many small temple also there inside the premises. You must visit this temple while visit Kathmandu
Pashupatinath. It is a Chaturmukhi (four faced) on a Lingam opening out to four gates. Darshan was very exhilarating The river and smaaler temples around are nicely kept

Must visit cultural sites in the world. Though non Hindu tourist are not allowed it will make more curious to know about whats inside the temple? Similarly you can also see Hindu community peoples rituals of burning the dead as well as take photos if you wish.
my life. om nama Shiva i like to always visit temple the worlds best and power full temple our country keep well by the same temple ,,,,,,

shiva devotee. I am a devotee of lord shiva so this was the main point of visiting nepal could found my soul here sitting for hours and meditating the name of lord gives you everything which you wish for
Temple that talks Nepal. A temple situated in a huge premise. I wish I had more time to spend and explore. You can see saints sitting there and take pictures with them. The enormity if mind boggling.

Visit early morning or past 5 pm. A must visit for most travellers. Only Hindus are allowed inside the main temple premises and the gates open only in the morning or after 5 pm. So plan your day accordingly.

The Main attraction for Hindus in Nepal. as this known as One of the Holiest Place of Lord Shiva.. The pashupatinath temple Located bank of River bagmati is one of the Holiest Place of Hindu who Follows the lord Shiva. it is told that One who visited kedarnath in Uttaranchal,INDIA Must Visit Pashupatinath Temple. Without this visit the Kedarnath Visit is treated as Incomplete as the Back Part of nandi is at Kedarnath while the Front Part is at Pashupati nath. This temple mainly visited by Hindus. while Non Hindus are NOT Allowed. they can view the temple from(outside) Opposite of Bagmati river. Lord Shiva is Worshipped here. Darshan is beautifully managed by the administrator. Temple is wooden carved. If you've intrested in archeology, lots of things is waiting here for you.

Very Old and Historical Lord Shiva temple. Temple is big and must visit when visiting Kathmandu . River bed is next to the temple .Shivarthiri is considered a bug day for Lord shiva and the special poojas are performed on that day .
Nice place. A must see place for Hindus, nice temple. but outside can be maintained a lot cleaner. We were lucky to have darshan along with aarthi.

Not for everyone.. Pashupatinath is Nepal’s holiest Hindu Pilgrimage site but we could not go in. But this place was a big surprises for us. Open cremation were done in the just outside of the temple. The river was a small stream but the guide said it is part of Ganges River. We also saw few sadhu sitting there and collect few dollars from a tourist who want took a picture with them.It is an experience for us but I will not recommend to every one.Non Hindu were not allowed into the temple.

Very different and Interesting. We travel a lot, so we appreciate things that are unusual and interesting. This place was both. They prepare bodies and cremate them right on the river here. It's quite a spectacle. Felt weird to be watching what is normally (for us) such a private affair, but we had a decent guide who filled us in on a lot of the background. There are also a lot of strangely and traditionally dressed people around here that were cool to see. But note that they expect tips if you take pictures of or with them.

Really blessed to visit this place . Being a Hindu this place is spiritual for us.if you are really lucky I feel you can get chance only to visit this place and can take blessing from Lord pashupatinath. If you are not Hindu then not allowed to enter the main temple. We went this temple early morning like 7 am and at that time also crowd was almost full.may be we were in pick season Durga puja time. At the entrance you wil find a big cow structure made by copper and its look like so live. There are few temples in this compound. Back side there is a river which is holy river for Hindus. After coming out from temple you will find some guys dressed and put make up like monkey god hanuman ji. Take some snaps wih them and they will be very happy. Overall experience is very good and must visit place in kathmandu Nepal.

Holy place for Hindus. This temple is primarily for Hindus. A visit here may be a bit disturbing for a western tourist as one is greeted by the sight of dead bodies being cremated at the Ghats on the banks of the Bagmati river. This reminds us of the impermanence of life.The Main shrine has a Shivling with four visible faces - 'Tatpurush' faces East, 'Aghor' faces South, 'Sadyojat' faces West, 'Vamadev' faces North, and the fifth face 'Ishana' is supposed to face the Sky. There are 4 entrances to the Main shrine to view each face. The Main shrine is surrounded by smaller shrines.Tip: The path from the entrance gate to the Ghats is dotted with small shops which sell, among other things, Saligrams. Some of these are Ammonite fossils from the Kali-Gandaki River.

could easily spend a day here. The ghats are surreal, the shiv temples are energetic, the sadhus are amusing and main temple is very spiritual. Wish that non Hindus were also allowed to visit inside the main temple

Ancient temple. Its an ancient temple with lot of following. Kathmandu rather Nepal is famous for this temple. Although cleanliness and maintenance is shabby but for religious faith its great. You can see lot of carving on stone and wood.

Ghoulish and Overpriced....... Unfriendly ticket staff ~ Unsavoury subject. We walked down to this "Attraction" from the Boudhanath - pleasant interesting treck down. The guy at the ticket office was almost insistent that we pay extra for a tour - we didn't want a tour and he was quite unhappy about this. We wandered down to the main temple (Not open to non Hindus) and couldn't immediateley find our way to the rest of the site and the ticketing guy is after us - wouldn't help us find the way even though we had paid an overpriced ticket - stil said we needed a tour. Only place be were subject to such an annoyance.We eventually found our way to the main paret of the complex - the Ghats. OK It's interesting, but it's also pretty ghoulish with groups of tourists being quite intrusive as families burn loved ones.Apart from the Ghats there really isn't much to see.If you are short of time and long on taste suggest you give this a miss.....

probably not best for tourists, better for worshippers. This is a Hindu Temple so it is not fair for me to review this, really. That said this place will probably be better appreciated by those who are travelling to worship. There is a NPR 1,000 fee to go around the grounds but the inner section is available only to Nepali and Indian Hindus.

An interesting experience. This is the main crematory for Hindus. Although you are not allowed to enter the temple you can watch how the dead corpses are wrapped in cloths and burnt in an open fire from the other side of the (holy) river, similar to the procedures in Varanasi.
PASHUPATINATH TEMPLE. My belief, Pashupatinath is over rated and certainly over priced, spend more time at either of both Durbar Squares, or Boudhanath.

VERY INTENSE BUT A MUST SEE!. Having never witnessed cremations first hand, I came in with an open mind and appreciated the beautiful death ritual as families said good bye to their loved ones. A very sacred site that deserves a great deal of respect and a must see to gain a greater appreciation for both the Hindu and Buddhist cultures. You also have to take a picture with the Saddhus, they're awesome!

Looking into life and death in Nepal. Is difficult to say what is most fascinating about this temple, the smells and sounds hit you first - totally alien in the main though the smell of goat brought back a few childhood memories. Troops of monkeys roam the environs of the temple making for the some useful snaps to take back home but unfortunately the temple itself is out of bounds to all but worshipping Hindus. You have to content yourself with the view through the main door from a respectful distance which does give you a glimpse of the massive golden bull, the centrepiece of its central courtyard. Unfortunately perhaps its from the rear end so you are greeted by an infeasibly large pair of golden.. well I'm sure you know water.Round the back you cross over the holy river and usually an incite into the funeral rites of the Hindu religion. Remember the significance of this place and if you must take pictures take them discretely. Our guide informed us of overenthusiastic tourists who barged mourners out of the way just to get a snap to show off to their friends back home. The locals were not best pleased.
Nice temple. Nice temple and we had good darshan of Lord Shiva. Spent few hours at temple. Temple design was good.
Excellent. One of the main temple for hindu pilgrimage. Must see if not for religion purpose but for architecture. Great place. Busy and bustling. Beware of monkeys who might gran stuff from you.

Interestingly Visiual and Spiritual. Huge rambling temple which is extremely holy for Hindus...the site of cremations. So interesting to see this. Side benefits of seeing the macarque monkeys (hold on to your bags:-)) and the saadus.
Hindu Temple for sending off... My sister and I saw 3 Sadhus..it was lots of smokes as the place is used to cremate the deceased by Hindus. Lots of small temples.

A must see. This is a very solemn place. Non-Hindus cannot enter the actual temple. But, they conduct cremations every day on the lake. This is something special to see...especially how respectful and peaceful this can be.

A despotic visit. When you first enter the perimeter of Pashupatinath you are disoriented and tormented. You’re not sure which direction you need to take to visit the site. The price is outrageously exorbitant for tourist who can't even access the temple.Then you have beggars crawling at your knees, as well as tourist guides everywhere willing to offer you a tour at a bargaining price. Also some some people try to paint your forehead without asking your permission. I was a little disappointed.

Hindu Funeral Ceremony. This is a such a great place that who want to experience Hindu funeral ceremony. I couldn't remember how much money demanded to enter for tourists (I guess approx.15USD) but it worth it. I strongly recommended to get a deal with local guides (I gave 400Npr) he could give a lot of detailed information about hindusit funeral ceremony and that place. You could have to chance to met reel sadu(Holly Mans) people in this place. There is a must see place in Kathmandu.Some people think burning dead body terrifying but it is a daily routin and every religion have different application funeral.

Atmospheric place. Visited here on 2 occasions. First being as part of a city tour on festival day, when it was packed with locals and sadhus put on a show! Also witnessed cremations at the bagmati river.Visited again when it was much quieter and gave opportunity to wander around and soak up the atmosphere and see more sadhus.
expensive. Arrived on a self funded day tour from Kopan, Bodhnath and didn't have enough cash, so no entry! Just had enough for taxi back to Centre. May need to haggle more.

Unusual, uncomfortable but thought provoking.. An open air cremation site is not a common tourist spot but this holy place on the banks of the Bagmati river is special and will get you thinking. With naked sadhus on one side and burning bodies on the other it is not a comfortable place and yet it is a striking introduction to life in this country and highly recommended. The temple buildings are fantastic.

Main purpose of my trip. I went to Nepal mailly to visit the temple of Pashupatinath. Lord Shiva and his blessing to my marriage anniversary has blessed my family. There is large statue of the lord and don't worry the sacrifice of the cattle does not happen in temple.

Must visit. I visited in the early morning hours with a temp of 8 degree Celsius. The view of magnificent. There was not much crowd and we good easily do the darshan. We visited almost all temples present in the Pashupati nath and visiting gave me really solace.I also saw the banks on which cremation takes place which is supposed to be the most pious place on earth. Am glad that I visited the temple
average. management can do more .. its dirty like other shiva temple.. somnath is far more better than this. still we visited nepal and if we miss it then we miss actually one place..

Serene place, must visit. Go to the back side and sit on the river front. Great to see the evening river worship ritual. You can also see the Hindu cremation ceremony as there are always some pyres burning on the rover ghats.

For the cultural experience . So one comes to this place not so much because of the physical architecture but for the ceremonies that happen. This place is alive. The main thing is that the cremations take place  here and I think that is every day. First they bring the body that is entirely decked in Orange and yellow flowers. They have to sacrifice an animal right at the thoroughfare to the bridge. So one will walk past the headless animal. Then there is this entire ceremony happening by the river. It takes quite long, all this happening in the hot sun. If this is your kind of thing, then it is a superb rich cultural experience to see what happens here. Personally for me, it's not my sort of thing. One can also see a lot of holy men and women around. And a lot of goats. Hindus are not allowed to go inside the temple so that whole area is fenced off. And all at the same time people coming to ask you if you need a guide etc.
truly holy. one of the lings of mahadev and very nicely made temple with good space neat and clean, must visit place is you visit kathmandu

Well worth a visit. World heritage and Hindu pilgrimage site, and Kathmandu cremation site. Wander through the complex, see Saddu's and have a chat. Cremations can be a little gory to westerners but you don't have to look too closely.

Ghoulish but really worth it. We arrived without knowing much about the temple. A young guide offered his services and he was well worth $10. There were 3 open air cremations going on. Weird if from our culture. We found it the most interesting of all our Kathmandu visits
Great Jyotirling temple. This time I could see improved vicinity, cleanliness, good pathways leading to the Temple. very nice crowd management systems employed.

Awakening Experience. i visited the Temple at 4:30am with hardly anyone in temple and had plans to move early and come out early but could not come out as I was mesmerized by beauty of itThe place fills you with positive energyThe view from other side of river is even betterIt's a place where would like to go again and again

A living place, astonishing. It i one of this places that i not just monument, but is actualy alive with the people in the crematories, prayers and local visitors. It is shocking and very interesting to watch the ceremonies on the side of the river.

Amazing site but sneaky guides. We walked from Thamel to Pashupatinath which took about an hour but was great! They catch tourists at the entrance and ask for 1000NPR entrance which was fine however a guide followed us, gave us a really interesting tour but demanded $10 from each of us at the end. Incredible site to see but beware of the sneaky friendly guides
Pashupathinath Temple. Pashupathinath Temple on the Bagmathi river’s banks also know as Crematory, is one of the most important temple dedicated to Lord Shiva in all the Hindu world.

Advise: don't go there!!!!. This kind of places always call my attention.But today we just arrived at this place and they ask for 1000 rupees or 10 U$.It is so pricy, probably we can spend only 10 minutes inside and the Golden Temple is just for Hindu People.They offering a service of third world, but they charge like First World!if I were you, don't spend your money with this bull****!

One of the oldest existing Hindu Temple. Your visit to Kathmandu Nepal is never complete without going to Pashupatinath Temple. Lord Shiva is worshiped here. You can not take pictures inside. Only Nepalese and Indian are allowed free. Foreigners need to pay 1000 Nepalese rupee to enter. Well, non-Hindus are not allowed to enter at all but they can visit the adjacent burning ghat.What made me really concerned was the condition of the sacred Bagmati River. It is dying due to all man made waste from the burning ghat.

A rich paradox. By far one of most powerful experiences while in Kathmandu was attending Mahashivaratri at Pashupatinath with 1.5 million others. Much of the sacred grounds are littered with garbage, many of the holy men have their hands out for show and money and as a "foreigner" you will have the privilege of paying to enter the grounds but NOT the temple. Granted, many tourists are rude and obnoxious taking videos of cremations and deserving to be excluded entirely. And I would not trade away a second of it. Pashupatinath offers a soul shaking glimpse into ancient Vedic culture and is saturated in deeply seated devotion that transcends time like few place can project. You'll see.
costly fees, get nothing. not valuable . entrance fees costly get nothing. just hang round 10 minute. It can be good temple for hindus people
Thought provoking. Remarkable site - we didn't use a guide but wandered, sat and contemplated the different culture we saw.

worth a visit. Whilst non-Hindu's don't have access to the main temple, you have the opportunity to see cremations happening along the river, which is an interesting experience. There is also a homeless shelter for elderly Nepalis which you can visit.

Gods own place. The temple management is very good. Temple Management offers POOJA on request. So if you want to go for Rudrabhishek, or Mahamritunjay Jaap etc just contact Temple. No need to book from Out side Pujari ( Priest).

Very Conscientious Priest. Very sacred Hindu temple complex. Our priest made sure we did all the rituals while he conducted a 20 minute puja to ensure that we were blessed with the Grace of the Almighty.

A life and death experience, not for the fainthearted. This is the second most important Hindu burial site after Benares/Varanasi in India. The main temple is not to be entered by non-Hindus, but even so one can walk around in a Necropolis of white temple structures. This is an active and very busy cremation site, so pick a day when you're in the mood to face the liminal experience of being accosted by hopeful tourist guides right next to groups of relatives bewailing the passing of a loved one as scavengers search the river for gold teeth or jewelry left behind from earlier cremations.

Sacred Offerings, Sacred Returns. A place for spiritual and religious seekers. A place for prayers and a place for learning by observing how believers dedicate themselves and surrender to the powers of the temple complex. Keep in mind that going inside the praying complex is only for Buddhist and Hindus, but nobody asked me what I was. So, if your go with respect and sincere desire to pray and not to hang out the photographing tourist, you may enter smoothly. Enjoy!

Just soak it all up.. This is a very important site for Hindus and has an amazing atmosphere of a religion in action. As a foreign tourist, you are superfluous, except for the inevitable scams and fakes that you should obviously avoid. Most of the visitors are not camera wielding Europeans or Americans but religious tourists from Nepal and other parts of the sub-continent. Some visitors have problems with Pashupatinath: 1. "Those burning bodies were gross!" 2. "It's so so rude to say that only Hindus are allowed in the Temple"Ref. 1. This site is revered and famous for its cemetery ghats. If you are that squeamish it would be better not to go. But a great pity as this is an important aspect of life, (and death), in Nepal.Ref.2. I felt much happier knowing where I could and could not go. It seems perfectly reasonable to reserve some areas for practising Hindus where they can make their religious observances away from our prying and camera snapping eyes. Few of us would object to the common signs in English Cathedrals "this chapel is reserved for silent prayer". It's not really that different.This was my 3rd visit to Pashupatinath in the last few years and I nearly didn't go as I had been to Varanasi, (world's most famous cemetery ghats?) earlier on the trip and felt that Pashupatinath would be a pale shadow of that site. However, I was wrong and now feel that this site is a unique and special place and like Bodunath Stupa is a useful reminder that Nepal is a country steeped in a complex mix of fervently held religious beliefs, irrespective of our own views.Unlike several other reviewers, I would advise anyone to avoid a guide, however authoritative and cheap they are. It is so easy to end up like a school child on a trip, where the endless transmission of facts, figures and information actually stops you from just experiencing the place in your own way. So my advice is........"Just soak it all up!"

Do visit and have some respect.... You can't go inside the temple if you are not Hindu. But still it's worth to see the cremation site. It's best to go in the morning as not so many people visit the place. It gets crowded in the afternoon. Be careful with the guides, they are not professional guides.Have also one thing in mind - this is a cremation site . It's someone's funeral . I see this tourist with big cameras taking photos at someones funeral with no respect. I felt terrible for the families who burned their loved ones.Think how would you feel if someone for touristic reasons would take photos at the funeral of your loved one ?Have a heart and some respect.

old temple. temple is old and maintained well. there are many monkeys in temple especially near the main deity area though they do not disturb the worshippers. the main deity doors open only during aarti, which is in morning and in the evening.

Nice but not at itsbest. Most of the places for Budh religion are very clean and tidy but i saw some of those in Nepal which were not but nonetheless this was clean and just not properly managed but still a must see and also If you are interested in gettiing clicked in traditional Nepali dress it is possible at this location.

Always something interesting going on. I visited 1 day after Maha shivarati and the temple grounds were still full of sadhus from all over Nepal and India...the cremation process and locals seeking sadhus to perform some simple chants and rituals are interesting to watch. I walked from Boudanath to Pashupatinath so visitors can easily put this 2 attractions in the same day's itinerary.

Fantastic!. A big, picturesque temple complex. The fee is a bit expensive for foreigners (not so much for SAARC countries) but it's really worth it. Peaceful atmosphere amongst monkeys and sadhus. Nice views of Kathmandu from the top. Fantastic experience!

pashupatinath. This place is most holi place in kathmandu but please don't take pictures of burning place for the rest you can take pictures as forever you are not allow to entering the temple the price is 1000 NPR place respect this place

Aww - !!!!. I like the walk to the Temple, see all the sale of Puja items,. Temple is really Old and Unique., with puja & rituals going all over the place. Outside the Temple is a market, where one get crystal lingams; all items for different ceremonies. Spiritual experience!!

Surreal. We were there a day before Maha Shivratri ( Lord Shiva's Birthday) and it was simply outstanding... unfortunately one is not allowed to click pictures inside the temple .... but trust me.. if you love photography ..it is just a must visit place...there is chaos and serenity at the same time

A very moving experience. This is a sacred Hindu site and has cremations occurring whilst tourists are passing by, the whole complex has lots of interesting parts for the visitor. Apart from the rather inappropriate behaviour of some tourists, I found the experience here emotional and a fascinating insight into other belief systems. Some have commented about fake guides etc but I would not travel around this area without a knowledgeable and experienced guide.

Get a guide . We navigated the place on our own, which you can certainly do. However, I recommend paying for a guide just so that you don't get hassled the entire time you are there. There were a couple of cremations going on and there were monkeys running around everywhere. Lots of poverty and people with deformities begging for money.any people dressed up ( be prepared to tip them if you take any photos)

A Fascinating Place. I loved the whole Pashupatinah complex - the temples, the colors, the solemn cremation sites,the sadhus, and the market place.We had an excellent guide. His name is Sumit Kharel 9813987133. Email: sumit.kharel@yahoo.com. Thanks Sumit! You shared so much in a delightful way.This was a very memorable experience and you made it doubly so.

an oppressive feeling. I visited the Pashupatinath temple and felt really oppressed from the entrance until the exit! The entrance price is way too expensive comparing to other temples but also comparing to the overall visit. You cannot enter the main temple and you are constantly harassed by beggars, tourist guides, or gurus. Be careful of those people as they will come to you, paint your forehead with a colour point without asking, and then ask for money (plus these painting may give allergies to some people so be careful).Finally the body cremation is not really attractive and the smell is awful.I saw some monkey but very few compared to the buddhist monkey temple where there are loads of them.

Authentic but be careful. Went only to the cremation part, not to the zoo or park. It's very authentic. There were actually some cremation ceremonies taking place. However be careful for the fake guides and all the scam going on there. Right after you enter the site some noon official guide will offer you guided visit. Price will be outrageous of course. The tour is 30 mins. You can choose to take the tour, it can come out as great and you'll learn and feel more about the place than by going alone. However if you do so don't pay over 500 NPR in TOTAL (at first they will ask for 1000NPR per person which is just insane)They will also try to bring you to other places like the Buddhist temple or the zoo in exchange for some more money... Up to you but this is extra charge of course.

UNESCO world heritage site - one of the most visited Shiva temples. The temple was not too crowded, which made the experience pleasant. The darshan (idol sighting) lasted only a few seconds. That was not disappointing as it was more than what most of us get at teh busy temples in India. Did it stand out as a world heritage site? Nope. Durbar square had better views and more intricate architecture. Did it stand out as one of the most sacred Shiva temples? I dont know, but the buzz of people, the stores selling rudraksha(sacred seed) garlands all along the pavement gave it its own charm. The graveyard which is situated just behind the temple was a bit unpleasant. I was not comfortable watching people burn their dead. Since Shiva is the known as the protector of the Graveyard, its location is apt. Its just good good to know what to expect before you visit. Its a religious Hindu's dream to visit Pashupathinath. I think it deserves one visit. People practising other religions are not allowed into the main temple. Leather bags and cameras are not allowed.

Temple of Cremation. Located at old baneswhor where it close to tribuvhan airport kathmandu...this old temple preserved by unicef...i think this the the center of nepal hindu activity...taking photos of cremation activity is not polite..take ather object other than that.
Divine Temple. its sacred to me, but i love the serenity, the beautiful architecture, the priests are pious and sincere, no one comes to bother or bug you.......it is breathtaking!!!

Best thing to see in Kathmandu. This is the most interesting and fascinating thing I've seen in Kathmandu. The temple itself you cannot go into but the cremations taking place on the Bagmati River are the highlight. It's 1000 rupees to get in (a bit steep compared to other temples, especially as you cannot go in) and I paid another 500 for a guide, but it was well worth having the guide because he gave me so much information I never would of had otherwise. It's fascinating to see how another culture handles death and what ceremonies they have for the deceased.Definitely worth a visit, especially if you are at Boudha Stupa which is only a short walk away. Both are walk-able from Thamel if you have the time to do so.

very interesting and educational. on a recent tour we stopped for a half hour at this site where you see cremations going on. It was most interesting to see how cremations are done and our guide was excellent in explaining the rituals. I did not find it any sadder then funerals which I go to all the time as I am an organist at a church. In a lot of ways throwing the ashes in the river makes a lot of sense compared to buying a burial plot with an expensive headstone.We also saw some wisemen there. We were across the river from the cremations so did not interfere with the families or the services. It was interesting to know that very sick individuals are transported there before they die. We saw other cremations on the Ganges in India but this was the most interesting.

Very Interesting. If you are not Nepali or indian you won't be able to go actually inside of the main temple, but still the surrounding area is very interesting, its the main place for cremations in Nepal as it's right next to a holy river, there are many "holy men" around, and there is also a dear park.

Must visit when you are in Kathmandu. We walked from Bodnath stupa to Pushipatinath. The walk is interesting, you see rural life from the people of Kathmandu. The site is very crowded but you can come close by the cremation ghats. Sit down, have a look and take the time to watch the rituals. Very interesting!

A little Creepy. This is the temple where the poor go to cremate their dead along side the holy river. You cannot enter the temple area unless you are Hindu. Unless you just want to see other peoples sorrow I wouldn't recommend this area or make a quick stop on your way from or to the airport as it is right next door!

An experience, but blatantly overpriced. The Pashupatinath is one of the most sacred Hindu temples, and for non-Hindus it is definitely an experience. It is full of "sadhus" (pilgrims) and worshipping Hindus, and it is also a place of open-air cremation on the banks of a small river. The cremations are public, and crowds of spectators gather readily; this is something which may irritate many "Westerners", and I admit that even though I consider myself an open-minded and seasoned traveller I was more shaken up by the spectacle than I had expected, too.However, I was even more shocked by the temple surroundings: it was full of beggars, but also of maimed and visibly sick people. I have read that many Hindus wish to die at the Pashupatinath temple; some people that lay crammed on the ground gave the impression that they were soon going to. Again, this may be an important part of Nepali / Hindu culture, but nevertheless I could not help getting more uneasy than I had expected. In fact, I was so uncomfortable that I completely skipped visiting the main temple.All the above points concern my personal, subjective experience and I believe that for other travellers, the place may have a completely opposite effect: the way that the worshipping Hindus deal with death (their own or that of loved ones) in this place may surely appeal to many, and the sadhus and crowds of worshippers give the precincts a buzzing vibe.However, I believe that objectively the entrance fee of 1000 nepalese rupees (about 10 USD!) is far too high. Signs claim that the money goes into the maintenance and renovation of this UN heritage site, but I am not sure how reliable that is in a corrupt country like Nepal. But in any case, I quite frankly did not think that the place was worth that entrance fee as a tourist site.

Awesome Experience. We visited the Pashupatinath Temple twice. Once the guide took us in the evening stating the doors would be closed in the morning. When we reached at around 4.30 pm, only one main door of the temple was open. Rest most temples in the compound were closed. The next time we went in the morning at around 10.30 am. All 4 doors were open and we witnessed the grand abhishek of the shiva linga. Surreal experience.Better to check the timing when the 4 doors are open.
Special. Nice to see unique Hindu culture. A visit to Cremation ghat was interesting to see different culture.
Spiritual place. The place is like Varanasi in India, but here you can make photos of burning in Ghats. The Saint Rivier takes the ashes to Ghanga River and then to Varanasi. Amazing expierence.

Don't look the monkeys in the eye.... ...and you're less likely to have one decide he wants your sunglasses. This UNESCO site is a phenomenal experience of architecture, religious tradition, and contemplating The Meaning of Life as you watch bodies being cremated across the Bagmati River.

Fascinating (and we found a great guide). The temple was fascinating. We learned about Hindu cremation and attitudes toward death, as well as the history of the temple. We were really lucky to meet a guide whose English was really good. He was very knowledgeable (and he wasn't pushy at all). His name is Sumit Kharel 9813987133. Email: sumit.kharel@yahoo.com. Thanks Sumit! You made our afternoon.

traditional atmosphere of hindu. At a glance I feel , somewhere different world. Mourning the people at the place of the cremation .from terrace see the main temple gate. I become more profound to see the dead bodies burning to ashes.

Not too much to see. If your not near by I would spend my time going elsewhere. There is so much more to do in Kathmandu. There are religious ceremonies there and there was one when we were there. But not to much to see there but it's worth a visit if your near by.

...not much to see when there. As much as it was tantalising to go and see this temple, the only space open to non buddhist/hindus was the pool area, all other areas were closed off. Dont know if this is an all year round rule to visitors.

Hindoe temple in Kathmandu. Very interesting temple to see, you can spent few hours here.
Go there early in the morning and you can see the hindoe people have ceremonies and prayers"
The cremate (burn) their dead family , friends here which is amazing to see.

Unique in every aspect!. Visited the Pashupatinath Temple the day before the Sivarati Hindu festival and wow!!! We had the most incredible visit. We walked through the temple, saw the public Hindu funeral and cremation, watched the hundreds of Sadhu (holy men) lining the Temple, visited the Elderly Public Assistance Home inside the Temple complex, and visited the Naga Baba (Naked holy-man). The Naga Baba even invited us onto their platform to sit with them, drinking masala tea and watch their daily actions. We would recommend coming to Pashupatinath to everyone with a mature mindset!! Be sure to take a tour also with a guide - it was incredibly helpful to learn all of the intricacies of what was happening.

Beautiful Hindu temple. We visited nepal in jan ,we did Kathmandu tour among them holy Pashupati nath is best and wonderful world heritage site . You meet be there when you been in beautiful country nepal

very agressive guides. don't get a guide from here, bring one with you or walk around on your own if you can. the place itself is amazing and gives a great insight into the funerary customs of the Nepalese people. The guide I got was only interested in money and showed no regard to the families that were paying their last respects.

Imaging Festival. Today, I have visited Pashupatinath Temple which was I never saw before. Many people are waiting to go inside the main temple. Sadu, some one told me Nagya baba ohoo, I have not word to write here. The colorful woman, sadu, smoking and took fire in day time very nice nice. if any one plan to visit Nepal come in Shivaratri festival day. Regards,Mira Korth
Wow. The world heritage. The pashu pati nath temple , try to visit around 9 AM in the morning & you will be able to get the darshan from close as they open all the gates

Serene and Holy. Fantastic temple, was very impressed with the intricate architecture and the layout. The temple requires a lot more care as far as tourists are concerned, people are very reckless and the place is not maintained well. This is a heritage site and should get all the necessary support to ensure that the temple stays intact. A MUST VISIT in case you are in Nepal
Visit for moksha in life. Pashupatinath tample is very famous tample for Hindus.You must visit to get the moksha in life. The tample open morning and evening. Be aware of monkeys in tample.

Interesting for the open air cremation. I hired a guide to see the site but I could have done just as well without one. As a non Hindu you may not enter the temple itself. But you still have to pay 1000 rupees just to look around the site. I mainly went to see the burning ghats for the open air cremation. Some of the sadhus around there are fake ones -- they want money to take your pictures.
TEMPLE OF PEACE. Great place of pilgrimage. Well maintained. Just the sadhus can get a bit aggresice. Apart from that great place.

Very interesting temple and ceremonies. We spent a afternoon at the temple. It was very humbling and different from what we expected. You will witness the ceremony of cremation, but don't worry, as it is not too graphic. We happend to take a guide for the temple which turned out as a very worthy experience. He asked us about mentioning him here and I will because I really can recommend him. Sumit KharelTel.: 9813987133sumit.kharel@yahoo.comHe's a very nice guy with a sense of humor and he did very well on the tour.We're two students from Germany.

Divinity at its best. Pashupatinath Temple, temple dedicated to Lord Shiva is a must visit place for Hindus. Visited here twice, once in the evening to see the Arati and then again in the morning to see the Abhishek to Shivalinga. Jai Bholenath..

Pashupatinath - a holy place. It was full of many solemn and pensive moments for me. Seeing open air crematorium was a reminder of how simply things can be over but we seem to make a big deal about everything in life. Beautiful temple, the huge Nandi (the bull) was amazing. We went with friends, one of whom was able to recite the rudram. Enjoyed every moment of it. It was crowded, but I expected it. So no surprise. The day we went the floor was all wet and a little uncomfortable. Foreigners were not allowed into the sanctum sanctorum, like many Hindu temples. Even though I did not like it, our friends did not seem to mind. Worth visiting.
Worship. A place where u can really enlighten your soul. A place where I like building monument and yes after all it was Jai Pashupati but one thing I dislike lots of beggars around and poverty

In the feet of the Divine. Great experience while doing Puja here. The best thing to do is book your puja beforehand and reach the temple by 08:15 in the morning to have great darshan and puja experience. Must Must Visit and get Abhishek done

Not for everyone but sooo fascinating as well. What an interesting place! This is an open air crematorium alongside a beautiful temple that is listed in the UNESCO World Heritage List. You absolutely need a mask, preferably with a dash of perfume as the smell can become unbearable at times ( not all the time) . The family is there and friends as well. The workers put the body on something like a stretcher and pile lots of wood and stray for a good and fast fire. The five elements, air, fire, water, earth ( ashes) and sky ( Heaven) are all released as a result and all take their original form. The burning takes about 3 hours.The person who lights the fire is supposed to be the son of the deceased. If the deceased has no sons, then the closest male family member does this. The eldest son of a dead father and the youngest son of a dead mother fulfill this task. The husband takes this responsibility for his dead wife.The photographs will tell you more.
Divine. It was a divine experience to visit this temple. Felt great peace and a must visit for lord shivas devotees.
Holy Grail for Hindus. Certainly a place to visit once in a life regardless of your belief on religion. Certainly a place to visit once in a life regardless of your belief on religion.

A destination, complete in itaelf. It is said that an uninterrupted visit to this site signifies that the human being has overcome her animal being. She is now beyond her needs of basal survivor needs. Back to the site. This is a huge complex, full of temples, havelis, ghats, and gardens. The main shrine alone could be a reason to visit Kathmandu. Must visit. Keep aside a whole day. Best to go for early morning darshan at 5am and then stay the for the Kirtan Jam sessions and other interesting rituals.

Death, peace, beauty.... Pashupatinath Temple is the oldest Hindu shrine in Kathmandu, located on the banks of the Bagmati River. It is a complex of beautiful, old pagodas and temples banded with lanes. Lots of trees, some stairs…. You can have a nice walk, surrounded with all this beauty, or sit at the river bank and in peace watch traditional burials/cremations on the river. If you have a guide, or a local friend, you can hear some amazing stories about Hinduism in general. It is definitely a place to see when you are in Kathmandu.
Best place to see a little bit of everything. Best place to see a bit of everything, busy streets, monks, temples, beautiful temple paintings everywhere

very impressive and a little creepy. It was very interresting to withness the rituals around the cremation of hindu-people. I also found it a little bit creepy and i felt a bit weird to be looking on during such a personal event. The tempels are also very nice to see and the walk to the top of the hill is tiring but worth your while. However, do not walk up or down the hill when is starts to get darker, the monkeys are aggressive sometimes.

Experience beyond words!. A must visit place, not just for the Hindus but for everyone. Words cannot do justice to the feeling you get when you are in the temple. If you are in Kathmandu definitely visit this temple, you will understand why its so difficult to express it. Word of advice - Beware of guides and other people trying to sell you things. There are many shops outside selling prayer offerings, be sure to bargain with them.
Interesting ceremonies. Very interesting place to see hindu ceremonies. Go at night (after 6pm) and you dont have to pay the entrance fee. Also, non hindus are not allowed inside the main temple.

Funerals. This is the place where the dead people are burned. There is a big area for "common" people and a smaller and more peaceful for "VIP" people. You will meet a lot of holy men here, and they expect to be paid if you want to take their picture.

Historic importance but like any other temple. It's just that the temple has some historic importance that it is known for. I had signed for a special puja for which we had to stand in a queue for about 45 minutes. The river flowing behind the temple is good. You will see a lot of monkeys jumping on the temple roof.
Must Visit place in Kathmandu. One of the oldest temples, this has a must visit charm. Once getting inside, you feel proud to be a Hindu and it is quite an unforgettable experience.
Must Visit In Kathmandu. I had a great experience. I would recommend everybody who is visiting kathmandu to go and visit Pashupatinath Temple.

Crowded, but a must visit. Pashupatinath temple is a must visit on the trip to Nepal, more so after having a harrowing day of flight travels. Our first point of visit, and thankfully with moderate crowd and sunny atmosphere after a rainy day the day before, this temple just makes you feel like home. Since only hindus are allowed inside, the foreigner crowd was cut out. The surroundings could have been maintained a bit better though.

interesting. pashupatinath leaves you with mixed feelings and many questions about life itself.... watching all the cremations on the riverbank does make you think about life itself. it's a very touching and interesting place and being one of the most important hindu temples it is a must visit.
ONLY HINDU. Very Ancient temple located in Kathmandu city 4KM from Thamel market.Please book your abhishek puja in advance 1 or 2 days prior.

Fascinating.. Our host took us to Pashupatinath Temple after our morning flight up to Mt. Everest. It was quite a contrast. Our host explained many of the ways and traditions associated with the cremation temple and many of the rituals associated with the life and death process and ceremony of Hindus. Also had a couple wonderful conversations with some of the Sadu's at the Temple.

Not really worth it. If you really want to see dead bodies cremated, you should go here. It is a cultural experience that is worth it if you are not used to Hindu culture. That said, this temple is rather unwelcoming to tourists. They will charge you 1000 nepali rupees (10$) for entrance, which is incredible expensive for the country of Nepal (and probably adds on to the other 40$ in entrance fees you paid for other places that day). In addition, you won't even be allowed to enter the temple grounds of either of the two temples on the grounds. So all you can really see is the river and the bodies burning by the river. The rest of grounds are rather uninteresting or off limits. Plus that, and there are a higher-than-average amount of touts and people looking to get money for photographs and blessings here, so be warned.

Real life, show respect to the things you see. That's not a show for tourist or something like that. It's the real life you will see there: Cremations tak eplace just in front of you. Show respect to the people that lost a friend/ relative/...! Unfortunately there where tourist groups, chatting and laughing while on the opposite bank of the river Bagmati the cerenomies took place.That was the most irritating thing to see.Many "holy" people around. Lot of things to see, to smell, ...A place you should have seen, when being in KTM.

Awesome but Crowded. A must go place for all the Hindu tourists and even others wont regret going. The architecture is very old but intact and beautiful. Better to go in the evenings when the premises are relatively empty to stroll around nicely and peacefully. Faith is redefined here.
Forty year relaionship with Kathmundhu. This is a Ghat, a Holy place, worth a quiet visit to dwell on the Rituals of deaths that the Nepalese follow.

Life. Death. Believe. Ancient culture.. Even thou you can't get inside the sacred temple. But the cremation site will make you think about Life, Death and faith. Within one place you will see people pray to Hindu God for good thing in there life and by the river, they send the body of the departed back to god and everyone just watching like nothing happen. It's shown how this ancient culture think about life and death. Only a few place in this world can make you feel like this.

FOR THE CURIOUS. For the morbidly curious. This is where they cremate the dead. There are about a dozen platforms for the cremations and no matter when you come some are in use. If you are lucky, you'll see the ritual from beginning to almost the end when a body is brought in (washing the body on the stairs to the river, placing garlands and tumeric on the body, carrying to the funeral pyre and lighting the pyre). The entire ceremony can take an hour or so - the cremating can take several hours (so an attendant stays with the pyre, adding wood until everything is ash, at which time it is brushed from the platform into the river). The alley way/street leading to the area is lined with lepers begging and sadhus (not holy men here, just pan handlers), so it is not for the faint.
A bit of a culture shock. This is where most of the Nepalese cremate their departed. If you're in for something traditional and cultural, this is a must-see!

Awesome when empty!!. Another place where you can just stroll along and sit for sometime. the famous Pashupatinath temple reminds you of how biutuful this place would have been when there was no construction around i.e. 100 years ago. Worth a visit at least once when you are in Kathmandu.

late afternoon and evening is best. I was there myself and sitting and watching the process those families sending their loved ones to heaven.. late afternoon and till it's dark.. in the daytime, the carvings are beautiful and of course, respect what the local culture not taking photos of something nor walk on something they don't want you to step on.. I did experience something unique and unforgettable.. try to spend more time and connect with this place

Not a "must see" place. This is a Hindu temple but I saw more western tourists (sometimes totally disrespectful!) than hindu people.Maybe it could worth a visit for people that have never seen hindu temples, but personally I think that it s better to see buddist temple in Nepal and Hindu temples in India. I did not have big positive impressions and feelings during the visit.Definitely it does not worth the ticket price (1000 rupies)...

Spiritual reality. The building itself is very impressive and you will feel its aura soon as you step in.Shoes etc will have to be kept outside where there are facilities for storage for free.No foreigners are allowed in the temple but can view the site from across the river. The priests do not pester you for pujas and secuity will only let you view the deity for a few seconds. The cremating of the bodies below was a sobering sight of life and the river seemed polluted. You are free to spend as much time as you like and can enjoy the sights of the temple. A must visit place for all Hindus.

The real Nepalese deal. If you want to get the real Nepalese deal, then go to this cremation site and sit watching the cremations together with the locals and the monkeys that roam freely! It sounds grim but it is fascinating. Be prepared for a culture shock as the river that that runs through this site is heavily polluted and there are actual burning pyres. Lots of photo ops with 'swamis' dressed up to the nines for that very reason - to make a quick buck. Be generous, they make such an effort!
Disgusting & filthy. A terrible temple for the filth and sad human conditions seen. A shame Unesco doesn't force the government to do more.

A must visit for all Hindus. Normally Hindu temples are chaotic.However Pashupatinathji is different.No wonder it is one part of the group of World Heritage Sites in Kathmandu.If you visit with a vehicle there is a parking lot.You then walk through a road to the temple with shops selling Puja articles.Good thing is that as in most Hindu temples the shopkeepers do not pester you.The temple is spacious and the premises are well maintained mostly.You take off your shoes which are stored for free(look for dirty bags lying around to put your shoes in).You are then expected to wash your hands at rather dirty wash basins before entering the temple.Non Hindus are banned from entry(they are allowed to see the temple across the Baghmati river) .Also mobiles and cameras are not allowed.The temples open quite early and there are two queues to the inner sanctum.Security guards do not allow you more than a few seconds in front of the deity.The architecture of the temple itself is very impressive.Be prepared for a big crowd and people just hanging around.If you are up for it ,after visiting the temple ,walk across to the Baghmati river and you are sure to witness a cremation.The river itself is dirty as the remannts of the dead bodies possibly are thrown in it.There is a move however to clean the river.There are other temples in the sprawling premises where you can go to and exit the temple premises through another get on the other side of the gate by which you entered.Unlike most Hindu temples priests do not pester you in the temple.You feel good visiting the temple.

So expensive I couldn't afford it.. I was looking forward to visiting the temple but when I arrived they told me it was 1000NR for foriegners (as usual with all tourist spots the locals or anyone that looks local gets in for free)Whilst I understand that they have to make money from tourists, most of the other sites in Kathmandu are only 250NR for entry. I genuinely could not afford to pay the admission fee, and I'm not sure if I did have the money would pay to go in.A man that worked at the ticket office followed me out and told me to come either very very early (6am) or late at night to get in for free as the ticket office would be shut. I'm not sure how much you would be able to see but it might be better than paying the hefty sum.I hate to leave a bad review but I would go and see all the other sites in Kathmandu and if you have money left, then visit the temple.

Interesting place. Interesting and 'different' place for us Westeners, but it has way more important to Hindus - something that is hard to grasp and understand as 'outsider'.Please note this place is absolutely packed during cremations of important people in Nepal and especially during Shivaratri Festival (entrance is free then).Non-Hindus are not allowed in the famous Pashupatinath temple as far as I know (I was told it was not allowed for me to go there during the Shivaratri Festival).
Rituals on the Ghat. Only the courtyard is accessible to non-Hindu, but you can observe the burial rituals on the ‘ghats’ on the nearby Bagmati River.

Worth a visit at least once!. After having visited the temple a number of times in last few years, I can definitely say that the management has improved and the entire premise looked better maintained.The shops selling Rudraksha and other temple offerings are away from the main Puja complex as they are on the path that leads to two entry gates of compound so one need not be worried about being bothered by sellers.A huge bull stands in front of the main temple inside the complex but clicking pictures within the premises is not allowed. I think I also read somewhere "only Hindus allowed" which is why I could see the other western tourists on the other side of river bank. The river bank is not pleasing to eyes and mind from any sense as it is always dirty and to add up there are cremation processes that happen here.
speechless. faith is absolutely redefined in pashupatinath. in depth, in breadth, in greater.the locals said millions are coming during the Lord Shiva's birthday during Feb-Mar period.
Pashupatinath Temple. A fascinating insight into the Hindu religion. Our guide was really knowledgeable and helpful. Well worth a visit, but it would be worth going with a guide.
beautiful temple. quite; river bank ; water is clean then before.management is good then before.pigeon and monkeys activies are the most attractive!!!! is the best hindus place!!

Sort of disappointed. Went there with great spirit, but was dampened by the cleanliness. It is one of the major hindu temple in world and also a very famous tourist place. It would be good to have it clean.
A thousand of Pigeon. You can take amazing picture with pigeon here. I Like the atmosphere. Monks doing routine activities. tourism activity is still running.

#1 Spot in Kathmandu. When I think of all the things we did while in Kathmandu, the images from Pashupatinath Temple area are the ones I remember first. Pashupatinath Temple with the Sadhu monks and the cremations across river, are both unforgettable visions. Because it was a holiday, there was lots of activity, which made it all the better. No matter where you looked it was a scene worthy of a postcard.

Great view of Cremation. I found Pashupatinath temple, The river bank there was many Cremation. and other view was good, the people every one own there were looks busy and some of them were at relax on hanging..

Better managed than the temples in india. There were a few pushy sellers, but the good news is they are kept out of the temple area. The security check was well managed and so was the place to keep our shoes. Another thing to note and appreciate is that all offerings (money) are directed to be placed in the donation box.

Beautiful temple, but poorly managed. For my fellow travelers, if you are visiting the temple for the first time1) Beware of Touts... Do not entertain them2) Do not purchase anything outside the temple, as it will not be taken for offering to the main deity (Pashupatinath)3) Poojas are performed in the temple. You need to book one day in advance at the poona counter4) Beware of Monkeys inside the temple, as they will snatch all the food that you carry5) Do not carry any cameras for Photography inside the temple6) Keep the foot wear outside the temple inside the bags hanged opposite to the foot wear resting place. Kindly give the bags inside the counter and collect a token7) Wash your feet and hands before entering the security cordon of the templeHope this helps all visitors

Crematorium attraction. If you are not a Hindu you are not able to enter the temple, so the main attraction is the crematorium which I guess means you might get to see a ceremony or not. You might think this morbid however it is part of the culture and once again helps people understand the Nepali. I found it very interesting to observe and listen to our tour guide explain the process and beliefs.

Spellbinding. Must see!. Hindu temple/cremation site - the main one in Kathmandu. An absolute cultural must in Kathmandu/Nepal. Speak to the Hindu shamans, see the rituals involved with end of life for the Hindu faith tradition, watch the celebration of culture, life, death and reincarnation. I was spellbound by this visit. The rich and vastly different, at times affronting, cultural is out in the open to see and experience. Awesome. A must see in my opinion.

Religious Place for the Hindus. The place is popular for its relevance in the Hindu Mythology and for its World Heritage Site status. If you know the story behind you may like the place. For all others it is a popular temple. The temple complex is comparatively clean compared to the extremely dirty Kathmandu city. Strange architecture is found. Lots of Pigeon capture a part of the complex. Whenever somebody walks there they all fly away together and again return after 1 minute. I enjoyed this view a lot. I think Pigeons are the best part of the temple. The entry to see the Pasupatinath's idol is restricted to the Hindus only and photography is not allowed. One needs to remove his/her shoes before getting inside.I was made to delete the two photos I took by the security personnel. The shrine is always overcrowded and in a stampede mode. No view of the peaks from this temple.

Witness burning of bodies- if you can take it . For those sensitive, this site might not be for you. You witness the burning of bodies by the river, literally a body is placed over wood to be burnt in their funeral ceremony. It takes several hours for the process to be complete. If you do choose to visit this section of the temple area, I advise to hire a guide for about 10$, it is well worth the money since you really get explanations about what you see, the rituals and traditions.

Sacred Hindu Shrine. Its is one of the greatest hindu shrine of Lord Shiva, The entire area of Pashupatinath is a collection of ancient temples and also a UNESCO world heritage site. This place is also flooded with lot of monkeys be careful with them.They are a little more aggressive than any other place in Nepal. Also be careful of people sitting in the compound dressed up in saffron or yellow robes and with their foreheads painted with red and white ochre. These people might ask for 500 to 1000 NPR for a picture, don't get fooled by them. Going back to the temple, its a beautiful piece of architecture with wooden sculptures and the nepalese 5 storied architecture. Ask for any wish you want he is the number one bestower of all wishes.The only shock of my life was the public cremation on the banks of the river in the temple compound.
Go only to the temple, not the cremation area.. Monkeys all over the place, but the temple and the golden cow stand out. Skip the cremation area behind the temple. It's where they burn the bodies.

Fulfilled our dream!. We were dreaming to visit Pashupati Nath Temple for long time and finally we did it. We hope the God of God, Mahadev will fulfill our dream come true! Thanks Breakfree adventures for arranging this wonderful tours.

Really Average!. While this place may have a lot of religious significance, it has not been maintained. Pretty dirty and the crowd gets bad as the day ends. Finding a taxi here can be tricky so its better to hold on to the one that takes you there. Its usually crowded so if you expect a nice quite darshan - then thats not happening. Its a quick visit and can be skipped!

Lord Pashupatinath The Great. One of the holiest shrines.. A must visit place. The temple has exqusite architectural design. Remember to visit the place after 9 am as the doors are closed before 9.am Do not go in the evening after 7 pm . Rather go in early in December as it get very dark at around 6 pm itself. The plus point of going around 6 pm is that you have a beautiful view of the temple at night also. Good places to shop around the temple

So much happening. This is one of the most sacred temples in Kathmandu. We got off at a gate that takes you past small shops, and then to the banks of the Bhagmati river. On the other side of the river a lot of bodies were being cremated as per Hindu customs and rituals. We then walked across the river to the main gate that had a few monkeys, a man dressed as hanuman, the monkey God, and some sadhus. The temple complex had a giant Nandi bull facing the temple of the Lord. You can stand in the line and do the prayers, or quickly walk up the ramp, see the Lord, and move on. There are also a lot of small temples around. Indians and Locals get in for free but foreigners have to pay USD 10 for entry.

Over commercialised, with corpse smoke stinging your eyes.. This is one of the most sacred places for Hindus, a place they should visit at least once every life. For non-Hindus it is an opportunity to see corpses being burned and your wallet being lightened. The entrance fee of 1000 rupees ($10) is really a lot considering they are pretty clearly doing nothing in the way of conservation at this Unesco World Heritage site. - Hopefully one day they will use that money to clean up the place and fix the dilapidation of places like the state run home for the elderly. At the ticket office you will be aproached by a guide who may or may not call himself a guide. This person will follow you, whether you want it or not and inform you of where it is alright to photograph (in my mind, funerals are not for gawking at and definitely not for tourists to take pictures off, but there you go...) - If you managed to land one of the good guides, he'll also provide you with a wealth of knowledge about the history and customs related to the temples, shrines, cremation and the Hindu dieties and their avatars... So here's hoping you get a good one. The temple is only accessible to Hindus and it seems only if you "look like a Hindu" (converts beware!) which may be even more racist than charging foreigners an entry fee much higher than a local's daily wage, but the rest of the site is open to all. The riverside embankment has 10 terraces for funeral pyres and they burn constantly, 24 hours a day. You will more than likely see at least 1 fire being lit, another mid burn and a third being cleared away, the ashes being swept into the murky waters. By tradition a body should burn in four hours, any slower and they are considered to be burdened by great sins. - The wealthy and especially politicians are often burned with sandal wood and animal fat as catalysts to make sure they aren't seen as sinners. The Sadhus hanging around the temple complex are one of the biggest places where you can go lose money. They will gladly pose for photos, actually it seems to be all these so-called holy men do all day. It is a well known fact that these "Business Sadhus" come from all over the region, including India and live off the money they make. Do not be fooled by them, anyone can grow a beard and dress in orange robes, after all! The guide will probably ask you for about 1000rs, but the going rate is 500 per tour. Some people have been fleeced for many thousands, but do not be one of them! It is highly recommended to have a scarf or other device with which to shield your mouth, as the smoke and ash from the constant burning bodies is both annoying to breathe and rather disgusting when you think about it.

Not for the squeamish. A fantastic bit of Hindu culture - steeped in history and tradition but be prepared to witness Hindu Cremations on the riverside Ghats - bodies, mourners and all. The locals do not seem to mind the tourists photographing their funerals but my wife and I are not comfortable with the intrusion into peoples private lives.

too many people that wants to do special pooja for you. It is so annoying when every minute somebody comes and asks if you want to do some special pooja. These so called priests, in the temple complex claim to get a fast darshan and it would take a long wait if you go in a normal way.How on earth can they dare be dishonest?The queue is not that long that you pay 200NPR and follow this crook and end up angry and cheated.Temple complex needs serious cleaning. Monkey,birds poop makes it horrible to walk barefoot

don't miss it. You don't have to be Hindu to enter and appreciate this amazing site. You do have to be Hindu to enter the temple however, but don't worry the rest of this sprawling site will fill you with awe. If you only have time to see one thing in Kathmandu then this place is a top contender. We saw it at the beginning of our visit to Nepal and again before we left. First time I felt a little out of my comfort zone (especially around the cremating areas) but second time round just wanted to take as much in as possible.
Original medieval city of Nepal. A great spot to spend half a day looking at more yogis, medieval buildings and shops. Lovely ornately carved buildings.

Om Namah Shivay. How can a devout Hindu not worship at Pashupatinath when he/she visits Kathmandu? An enormous metal Nandi guards the 4 faced shivlings. A good time for darshan is mornnings after 9:30 when all 4 gates of the sanctum are opened.

Worth visiting but I wish it was kept a it cleaner. its hard to visit Kathmandu and not visit this place, it's a must but it's a shame like a lot of other things, that it's not kept cleaner. There was a huge military funeral service on the day we visited so the place was a little over crowded

Hindu Temple - Oldest one. Pasupatinath temple is one of the most oldest temple and very popular among Hindus around the world. This is located near to the International Airport.
