Therefore, ideally, you may visit this place either on your way back or to the hotel and save your time. This is located next to the International Airport and near to the Kathmandu city.

Jai Pashupatinath. This temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. The statute/Ling inside the temple is having 5 faces, 4 on all the four directions and the one on the upper side. I visited this temple thrice during my Nepal visit and found the same to be attractive and appealing. There is the arrangement for special Pooja (worship) also in the temple but you have to visit for the same in advance thru the website or by other means as there is always the crowded booking. But if not boked you need not to worry as there will be good Darshan of the Lord even otherwise. The Camera is not allowed in the temple premises. Beware of the monkeys there, as there are lot of monkeys.It is presumed in India that the face/upper body part of Kedarnath is at Pashupatinath, but there I found that it is not the Pashupatinath itself rather it is the "Doleshwar Mahadev, popularly known as Kedar Sheesh", which is in the area of Bhaktapur. If searched on google search engine one could find the details of kedar sheesh also. In Nepal it is also said that there is a separate tale for the appearance of Pashupatinath and the Kedar Sheesh is at Doleshwar Mahadev. One could go by car there as the road is metalled.Both Pashupatinath and the Kedar Sheesh-Doleshwar Mahadev are must visit places.

Why is it difficult to keep it clean. You cannot goto Kathmandu and not visit Pashupatinath. Its a great temple with great history however not kept clean. Also non-hindus are not allowed access into the main temple area. Photography is prohibited in the main temple area however you can take pictures before you enter the main area. You will be tracked by 'guides' and we chose not to engage them. Overall in about 15-20 mts you can cover the entire temple.

Mixed feeling. I love knowing the religious culture and therefore going to this Hindu temple, and I saw the Hindu funeral, burning the dead body in the open area. I feel sad when seeing people crying. You may sit and reflect about life and death.

Not much to see. Perhaps when I was there it was raining so there was really little activity along the river. There is a 1000 rupee ticket charge and I did not really feel that it was worth it. There are a lot of old crumbling temple structures with monkeys everywhere, but at the same time, litter everywhere.

Scenic and peaceful place. This temple is like any other famous Hindu temple. Although much cleaner and serene. Because of it being on the banks of the Bagmati river, its very beautiful. Specially if you can visit at the time of AArti at the Ghats [Bank] in the evening. Another thing to notice are thousand of scattered temples of gods around the compound. These are almost hundreds of years old giving you a peek in to design and architecture during those times. Beautiful place. Half a day in the evening will be sufficient. You can visit the market around and buy some memoirs too.
Famous Hindu Temple. Very busy and crowded temple -- with lots of cows and pigeons around. For Hindus, this is a must visit place for worship.

Nice history of temple. Once the temple visit is good. The guides there are not very attentive and after 30 mins we felt that even though we are Hindus we are just roaming around as there's no body to tell us history and give more info. The place definitely has lot of good energy and power. Entry and exit was well managed without any issues of lot of people's presence

Disturbingly drawing attention. Not being able to go to Varanasi on my journey across India, I was recommended visiting this place as a close but smaller equivalent in Nepal. A very interesting area to walk around, get lost in, as no clear direction of routes, as they want to sell guide services; I did not think it was necessary. Deers enclosure, Temples, stupas, with monkeys jumping into the river having fun, one Monastery not allowed for foreign visitors to enter. The one - attention drawing even if very disturbing and making me extremely queasy was witnessing - not one but three cremation/ funeral proceedings at the river bank:-0 Sat down and watched speechless.

Cycle of Life. Not far from the Kathmandu airport, this Hindu site is one of the "must see" spots in the city. Reminiscent of Varanasi, there are a number of cremation ghats along the river--all in various stages. So if you spend an hour or so, you are likely to be able to take in an entire cremation ritual. Photo ops abound, even though non-Hindus are not allowed inside the main temple. Tourists are charged a fee (but you may be able to get in if your appearance matches the locals)

It's different. I've been to many temples back here in India, and although i dont beleive in God, it felt peaceful to visit here. We visited between 5.30 pm and 6.30 pm, which is when they do the Aarti--and the music that accompanies, kinda puts you in a trans. Further down, you can often find the priests letting go off, or burning dead bodies per some rituals, by a pond. I dont know the significance (maybe cause Yama -God of death , is a form of Lord Shiva , whose temple this is). Good to visit once. Tons of monkeys around, and photography not allowed inside.
Very Calm and Holy. One of the great Word Heritage Sites. The holy feel in the temple is just great. it's a therapy in itself. Must visit site.

So much to see.. Although non-Hindus are not permitted in the main temple, there is still much to see. If you have never witnessed the burning ghats, there are places you can sit and watch quietly. Take your time. Did a small puja at the Shankarcharia Shrine which is open to everyone.One surprise was an "Old Folks Home" within the temple grounds. How auspicious to spend your final years at such a holy site.

An excellent opportunity to reflect on life and death. This is the most holy place in Kathmandu for Hindus and this is where cremations are ongoing. Unlike Varanasi, India, you are allowed to take pictures here. Take a guide (we found 500 NRS for 1 - 1 1/2 hrs an ok deal) to avoid feeling awkward/insecure. Evening Pooja is impressive. Stand/sit on the opposite ghats for a good view. The deer park behind the temple grounds is accessible from here but closes at 4pm already.
Must Do. Note you can stand right above the cremation, you don't have to view from across the river on the steps.

What an experience. This Unesco world heritage place was definately an experience. We where there after some major event and the place was still grouded. The are was full of Sadhus or I would call Junkies smoking away their enormous chilumis with not tobacco. The bodies were cremated byt the very, very dirty river. The place is not maintained enough, it could be much more attractive. But how it was it definately was an odd experience to remember.

ohm namah shivaya. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the main temple of lord Shiva in Hinduism. It one of main holy place in hindu religion. only hindu visitor can enter the temple and visitor with other religion can view from north east part of the temple.

Amazing voyeur experience. Watching the whole procedure of the river-side cremation was amazing. I could have stayed here all day taking it all in. The painted sadhus or holy men line up for their photos...for money, but I guess that's the way they make a living. They certainly add colour and entertainment to the experience.
Intense experience. It was an intense experience looking at the bodies of the deceased being cremated right in front of your eyes.

A Good Temple to visit in Kathmandu!. Very good temple to visit in kathmandu. Entry inside is allowed only for Hindu's. Temple is maintained very well and clean. If you are in Kathmandu then this must be on top of your list.
nice temple to see creamations. Nice hindu temple along the holy river. you can take photos while in Varanasi you can't so this place is unique

Perfect for Morning. I started from Thamel at around 5am and was in the temple by around 6am. I spent close to 3hours in the temple, and the tranquility before the crowds came in, made the hours fly by like minutes. Do roam around and explore the interesting sculptures which are all around. The huge Nandi(bull) in front of the lingam is just too beautiful to look at(Note that I am a Nandi afficianado).

A True Hindu Temple. With soft and holy hindu vaidic chants, the temple opens before dawn, but the good time to visit it is around 10:00 and 18:30 when you can enjoy a esteemed sensation of ancient rituals and Aarati (in the evening only). It does not necessarily be hindu to mingle around the temple and take part in the evening Aarati, but is must to enter the temple. When you cross the river to take the photographs, forget not to go upstairs to visit another holy and ancient temple "VishwaRupa" and then further downstairs to see "Guhyashwari".It is, I believe, the only temple of lord shiva in the world where only the 4 'Bhattas' are aloud to touch the holy "Linga" believed to be made of "ParasMani" that has the capability to convert the Iron into the Gold.

Lots to see here. It was a nice surprise to end up here because I wasn't expecting much. You can even end up over the other side to see the crematorium from across the river.I was disappointed it was so expensive to get in (1000NPR) and i was chased by an angry monkey, so beware not to look them in the face or get too close to the baby (I wasn't that close and got chased anyway).

Don’t take it religiously, take it as tourist. No other than follower of Hindu religion can enter the temple. You can see and capture pictures from the outside. You need to pay 1000 rupees for enter inside. But if you can realize the existence of this temple and the culture, it will be money worthy. It’s not as clean as other temples are. Don’t miss the side where cremation of the dead body.

odd but pleasant. the pashupatinath temple was weird at the start, we had to pay money to enter and there were shops alongside the pavements. But the cremation of the dead bodies is a must see. It was interesting yet very religious. I would definitely classify this as a documentary worthy place. there were many temples and the temples were beautifully crafted. although only Hindus were allowed into the temple and i couldn't enter, the cremation along the bagmati river was enough to intrigue my thoughts.

A cremation site. Paid Rs 1000 entrance fee to watch cremation along Bagmati river. Non-Hindus are not allowed into the temple so could only watch and take pictures across the river. The place was quite crowded because a Hindu festival was going on.

A must see. Hindus are only permitted in the temple itself, but there is plenty to see without going inside. The sheer mass of people who congregate there is a sight to behold. A very worthwhile trip.
A very holy place. The temple itself is intricately carved and beautiful. Only hindus are allowed into the temple. Other tourists are only allowed in the temple grounds.

OM...God Shiva. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the Hindu Temple in the city of Kathmandu, Nepal...Only Hindus are allowed to visit...Cannot take the leather things like Belt, Purse, Slippers, Shoes inside the temple...There are lots of beliefs about this temple...The main Pujaris are from South India called Bhatji...There are lot of monkeys also and need to be careful of your belongings...Behind the temple is the Bagmati River where the dead people are burned...called burning ghat...The temple is very big...I have visited this temple many times...

"Bit dirty but that will do it...". The place is bit dirty but isn't so much disgusting. Though the feeling of strong divinities being around gives you quite a chill. I saw this place much more maintained than other places in kathmandu. And like every other places in Kathmandu this temple has very ancient history too.

Moving insight. For those not informed in the Hindu way of death and burning of bodies this is very informative and moving. You will be rewarded by getting a guide too. I'm not a guide type of person but I'm glad I did. This is not a cheap day by Kathmandu standards once to travel there pay entrance and get a guide but I feel it's worth the trip.I would suggest not paying the Sadhu the crazy money they ask for pictures and watch out for the monkeys.

Lots of Monkeys :). This was an experience I enjoyed. You were able to see family members saying goodbye to their loved ones who passed away and their rituals they do before cremation. It is very different from the Westernized world and I would highly recommend going. Do be careful with the many monkeys that hang around and keep your valuables close.
Dirty. Went there as it is a must do if in Kathmandu. Was very disappointed with how dirty the temple premises were.

Amazing, must visit. It is conditioned that only Hindu can go inside,,,any way i can not comment on this as i am not familiar with rituals but as a common man i think God belongs to all of human beings...
Not on my "must see" list. Interesting, but too dirty. A lot of noisy people, the entrance fee is really high compared to what they offer. A lot of "holly men" asking money for a picture

For devotees. The best place on earth for Hindus devotees, this temple is one of the holiest spot in all of Asia and I never miss to visit when in Kathmandu. However, I think it should be open for all and be appreciated by tourists too.

All part of Bhaktapur Cultural City. Do not be confused. This is all part of the Bhaktapur Cultural City adventure included in the NPR 1500 admission. There are a total of six different areas to visit. This is one of them. Read my review of Bhaktapur.
Nice. Like golden roof temple and Yogi maharaja. and place is beautiful. i like. Good temple of ancient architect.

Beautiful place to be. The place was good. Since m a nature lover, it was quite a good experience for me. The only bad sight was seeing the cremation of hindu people, families weeping.The trek and mandir is too good.

Pashupatinath Temple. If you have a weak stomach maybe not the site for you. There are cremations held here all the time so be prepared for the sight and smell. I felt odd/rude staying too long to watch the cremations. Although there are other spectators there are also weeping family and friends. After all you are witnessing the loss of a loved one. If you take a hike up the steps you'll get to see a few more smaller temples and a TON of monkeys. I didn't enter the actual temple just the cremation site on the Bagmati River. There was a 1000 rupee charge ($10 USD).

Pashupatinath. This is probably the best place for Westerners to get a glimpse of Hinduism- it being Nepal's holiest Hindu temple. It is quite a shock even for the seasoned travellers- a huge very intact bull was the first thing I encountered- wandering about among the faithful.  Parts of the temple are for Hindus only but there is plenty left to see.I fount the washing of the dead and then cremating in the open moving , humbling and upsetting . Go down to Arya Ghat and then Ram Ghat. Then there are the Sadhus- holy men who have given up everything -I suppose like Christianity's mendicant friars though with uncut hair rather than a tonsure!

Must Visit. If in Kathmandu, this is a must visit place. I suspect it is busy every day. We were able to watch funeral ceremony going on, many holy men offering their services to the faithful, and all different stages of the cremation ceremonies. Colourful and ecelectic.

See it and decide for yourself.... This temple is to Nepal what Varanasi is to India: Hindus come here to cremate their loved ones on the Ghats (steps) on the Bagmati River, a tributary of the Ganges. There are almost always cremations happening here and although the ceremony is fascinating to see, it has become almost a spectacle for visitors and I was uneasy about the appropriateness of Western travellers lining the steps on one side of the river to witness the family mourning beside the funeral pyres on the other side of the river. Go and decide for yourself perhaps is the best advice I can provide here...

Dodging the entrance fee - a how to. Today my girlfriend and I went to see this place, recommended as a nepalese varanasi. We knew the entrance price was 1000 rupees and we were both set on dodging this fee, since nepalese tourist sites are all overpriced and have a racist profiling price scheme.Here's how to save 1000 rupees.If you walk up the hill with the fence on your right, you'll get a good view of the complex without the hassle.If you walk the other way round the complex with he fence on your left towards the cremation area, you'll soon pass by guards who are not paying that much attention, and you'll be able to walk right in as we did. We talked to some locals who were hanging around there, explaining the only risk we took was maybe beig checked for a ticket by a guard. But other than that it felt cool to outsmart them somewhat for their racism and general bullying of western tourists. We did this in kathmandu squarebas well.

One of the most sacred Hindu shrines in the world. on the banks of the holy Bagmati River, a tributary of the Ganges, is renowned for its beautiful architecture, home to Kathmandu´s funeral ghats, a series of cremation platforms are spread along the river. You will experience throngs of devotees, meditating and praying on the steps throughout the temple.

A Great Placed To Visit. Regardless of your believe Pashupatinah Temple is simply a great placed to visit. Sometimes seating at the terrace above bagmati watching religious ceremony keep you think far ahead.@My recommendation stroll up and explore entire complex and keep slow pace and enjoy every pieces of monument and greenery surrounding this complex..@Simply worth and no regret

Nepalese Varanasi. I visited this temple early in the morning, it wasn't too crowded then and around 4 cremations were taking place. This place reminded me so much of Varanasi in India as hindus come here to cremate their dead along the banks of the river. Visitors can see the way in which hindus deal with death, completely different to western ways. Photography is allowed from the non mourners' side of the river. Plenty of holy men can be found around the temple and you can take photos of them for a small amount of money. I feel that this is a must visit place when in Kathmandu.
Must visit for Hindus. Pashupainath , temple of Lord Shiva . It is must visit for all hindus. The place is still holding its antique aroma .

Intense and breath taking rituals. Its a place where friends and family say for the last time farewell to the person who died. So respect and dont disturbe them.You can see is all, saying farewell and till the body is burned up.. So its pretty intense and kind of lugubrious..

Quiet and interesting. The temple here was perhaps the best of the religious areas we visited. A cremation was in progress, and the preparation for another was taking place by the water. A smaller copy of Varanasi in India, but peaceful and quite good. One of the local characters, sorry, but cannot remember his title, was parading around in full costume and heavily painted body, together with a great head adornment. Took photos of him, but as expected, had to cross his palm with silver. Still, he then did the photo poses with my travelling companion. Would recommend this place for a couple of hours
hindou. very loud energy, you can see crematory. It's the most expensive place (but the biggest on aera) 1000 ruppies. But it's beautifull place. like in monkey temple, you have so many monkeys here

Fascinating and a little morbid at the same time. A strange way to spend a birthday - by memorable. The temple complex is large and interesting. The cremation area where several bodies were being prepared and in the process of burning, was an interesting insight. Felt a little intrusive at times, but they do allow tourists to enter the complex and charge an entry fee.

Temple is excellent maintained by the management.. Temple is excellent maintained by the management,for abhishek in temple one day prior booking is very difficult for tourist coming outside Nepal specially for Indian Hindus.There should be one the spot booking for abhishek etc to allowed.

One of the Holiest Temples - Outstanding!. We paid a memorable visit to the area around Lord Shiva's Pashupati Temple on the banks of the Bagmati River. Even several streets away, we could feel the religious fervor of the people who throng here. We saw Linga stones in the street where the puja was recently performed. We saw people with bare feet performing rituals; further on we saw holy men resting on the Ghats; and we saw many cremations on the Ghats at the river bank. I was fascinated at the spectacle of it all...the shouts and chants; the mourners' cries; the scent of burning sandalwood; the exoticism of the site. Cows and goats and monkeys run free as they do in other parts of Nepal.Though non-Hindu visitors to the temple are not allowed, we saw much and experienced rituals and religious ceremonies that Westerners don't normally see. The golden roofs of the temple can be seen from many vantage points and the mountains rise high above all of this. The place is magical and must be experienced by any and all who come to Nepal.

An impressive sight. I was intitially apprehensive about visiting a Hindu Cremation site, but we were well briefed by our guide to keep us apart from the mourners on the other side of the Bagmati river. After a short while, it no longer seemed morbid or intrusive. It is very much a part of hindu life and as much a tourist destination for the Nepalise as the visitors from overseas.The saffron clad holy men add to the atmosphere and provide a great photo opportunity. The visit helped me to start to understand the hindu culture.
Religious place. Pashupatinath temple is a place of worshiping lord shiva. The temple is beautiful & sacred. People from all over the world visit Nepal for having a darshan of lord shiva.
Must visit pashupati. Pashupatinath is biggest gods of Hindus so must have to visit pashupatinath at least once a times during their life.

Lord Pasupathinath. The presiding deity of Kathmandu, Lord Pasupathinath reigns in the famous Paupathinath Temple in Kathmandu. This is typical Hindu temple devoted to Lord Siva and is must see for a visitor to Kathmandu and Nepal. The typical arch door depicts Nepaly architecture and the steps lead to the sanctum sanctorum.

Majestic !. The Pashupati Nath Temple , Amongst the holiest shrine for Hindus, is dedicated to Lord Shiva is located at the banks of river Baghmati. It takes 20-25 minutes considering the traffic from Airport and City Centre to reach here. You may only take darshan or you may perform a special Pooja called " Pinda Dana" or offerings to your forefathers. I performed one which took roughy an hour at the hands of a Brahman who typically takes Rs 2500 ( Nepali) for this pooja. He gets all the material required for the pooja included in this cost. This kind of Pooja is done only at Tyrambakeshwar ( Nasik, Maharashtra) and Gaya ( Bihar, India) and Pashupatinath.When you enter the temple you will see a huge Nandi ( Sacred bull and carrier of Lord Shiva) offered to the temple by the King of Nepal. Lord Shiva as Pashupatinath has Five heads and hence there are four gates to the temple for each direction. The fifth head is on the top of the Linga. You have to take darshan visiting each gate one by one. Aarti of River Baghmati is performed as of Mother Ganga in Benaras, India. Its a treat to watch. It is performed at sunset. Please check for time difference in Nepal as Nepalese time is 15 minutes ahead of Indian time.Overall its a deeply spiritual expreience to be at one of the holiest shrines of Hindu Religion. Must go in a life time!

A must experience. A must experience for the Hindus who want to get darshan. But also the non-Hindus can watch the cremations and the sunset aarti. Its a great photo opportunity if not anything else! Loads of monkeys around chilling, just doing their thing. Lots of Holy men as well, cant make out if they are real or not but they will pose for photos for money :)If you want to go inside for Darshan you have to deposit your shoes and bag/camera in the locker provided. If not then u can keep your shoes and camera and just go directly for watching the aarti. The architecture is lovely and its close to the Bagmati river. Watching the cremation is definitely eye opening. Once dead we are just a body after all.

Holy cremation ghats. An amazing site right in the centre of the city. While we were there, there were cremations in every stage of being carried out, as well as families paying their respects to the dead. The sadhus look a bit put on for the tourists (pay to take my picture anyone?) and the approach is a lane of tourist stalls but it's well worth it when you get there. You need a knowledgeable guide to get the most out of this if you're not Hindu

One of th 12 Sacred Jyortilinga. The Paupatinath temple is a very sacred Jyotirlinga. Hindus have beliief that if they visit all 12 way to heaven is clear. Thousands visit every day. Most travellers from India visit Nepal to offer prayers at this temple.
must visit place in kathmandu. amazing temple that gives you powerful vibes. Be there by 5.45 pm to get a good darshan. don't expect orderly queues and be prepared to be pushed and tossed around

Quite an experience. Although there is, what feels like a hefty price of 1000rs (about £10) entrance fee, this museum complex was an amazing experience. On arrival, there was no clear signs as to what part of the temple complex non-Hindus could enter and we ended up being told off by two people when we tried to enter a building. At first we thought it was because we had our shoes on still, but a kind woman told us that the area was for Hindus only. At first we thought we had paid to just stand in a courtyard, but after walking around we realised that we were to go behind the temple. This is where the cremations were happening. After exploring the rest of the complex, we sat on the opposite side of the river and watched a cremation ceremony. It sounds morbid but the actually experience was moving and sincere. We watch a family walked around the pyre and conduct various rituals before it was lit. Yes tourist were taking photos, but they were respectful of the family and were quite quiet during the ceremony. Certainly an experience. Also, this place had more monkeys than the so-called 'Monkey Temple'!

Pay a Hefty entrance and then what?. From the entrance (from the road) to the actual entrance where you pay, I did not feel something was worth seeing here. The entrance fee is a bit high. (I would have paid this for Bhaudanath with no hesitation). Though I am used to many smell in India, the putrid smell of urine was blowing from the entrance. I had to go use the BR and it was awful. So I stayed only a few minutes and left. Sorry so say, this place did not steal my heart or did not leave any positive impression.

be prepared - quite expensive. the burial ground for Kathmandu. interesting to observe a different culture but many tourists were quite disrespectful of those in distress. many Sadu men make a handsome profit by posing for photos which makes you wonder how genuine they are.
A glimpse of history. Grand temple with spacious premises. You can see Naga sadhus here near the ghats. There is also a deer sanctuary inside. If you have the time, there is enough to explore around,
cleanse your soul, visit pashupati nath!. never a complete trip to Kathmandu for a hindu if you haven't visited this temple. go very early in the morning to avoid long queues.

They deserve respect. Whether it's a heritage or not, it really doesn't concern me. I wouldn't have entered if it wasn't my travel mate who wished to enter. Family of the deceased were crying, deceased was being cremated, tourist stood by the side for photos shooting and observation. Like minded people would made good guess on my further elaboration. Hence, enough said.

Stunning temple complex. wonderful temples and adjoining buildings, fascinating old peoples' retirement home (and more shrines), ghats by the river, a few shops on the way out...we hired a guide who was worth every penny

Nice Place. As we saw cremation sites on the Ganges, this place, though nice to visit, was not as great as the one in India was. But it certainly was a pleasant site to see the temple and other buildings and the river with some cremations going on.
Beautiful. We saw a funeral service while there....very very moving. It is worth asking the holy men to have your picture taken with them, will cost a dollar
Amazing. If you want to see the burning Ghats this is the place to do it. The process is fascinating and you are not made to feel voyeuristic. Climb the steps for further walks and shrines.

Divine, versatile and worth visiting. The only temple that will not cost you a penny but truth is it should. the largest temple of Kathmandu with versatile sculptures and idols, The majestic Nondi gavi (made of brass) an excellent piece of work.

Wauw. I saw a cremation going on, it was a special experience.
Nice place to meet the locals, true religious place.
Be careful with the monkeys they are very aggressive.

Beautiful temple. As a Hindu I was able to see the temple, but be warned if you are a non-Hindu you wont be able to go into the temple complex. you can, however, walk across the Bagmati river to see the arrays of sadhus, monkeys, religious ceremonies and deer in the forest so still worth a visit.

DO ATTEND AARTI !!. My visit to Pashupatinath was fabulous. The cremation center behind temple makes you realize about 'NOTHING WILL BE YOURS'. Darshan are comfortable with a proper system. You could also darshan Nav Graha & Balaji temple inside. TRY TO ATTEND AARTI done by Local People. I do not know its done on daily basis or it was because of Sunday. Local Aarti was done with gathering of Some around 40-50 people with Flute, Dholak & many musical instruments. You will surely feel REJUVENATING.
Confronting but well worth it. Amazing to see such an important part of life - Death.Is an amazing place but people should be respectful of what is going on here

Beautiful sacred temple complex of Kathmandu. Pashupatinath temple and cremation ghats is a truly amazing sight to visit. A beautiful sacred temple complex by the Bagmati river is one of the holiest for hindu people. where on average 50 bodies a day get cremated according to hindu traditions.
beautiful. this is a temple of special significance. we were lucky to go on dasshera, the crowds were much lesser than usual

Pashupatinath Temple. This is where the cremations are carried out in accordance with the Hindu faith. Beware of all the street vendors trying to hook you on the way into this temple area. From the car park we walked approximately 500 meters through "The Gauntlet" and everyone has their hand out looking to snag you. In addition to the entry fee of another approximately US$10 each we hired a tour guide for about US$10. His English was very good and he was well informed and showed us all around the place. It is kind of a dreary place and while we were there we saw two cremations. One was already burning away furiously and the other was a man's body being cleansed and then set up for cremation. The Bagmati River flows by the site and the ashes are dumped into it at the conclusion. The river and the surrounding area are not very clean at this place. However, the river is treated as a sacred thing and it flows to the Ganges River in India. I was surpised by the number of tourists and other vistors. I am glad I saw this as I was told it is a must-see. I agree with that but also caution to not encourage by even a little bit the people walking around trying to see you scarves, jewelry, rocks, and anything else you could imagine. They absolutely will not take no for an answer. I finally told our guide that if he could not convince these hawkers that we were not interested it would start costing him money off his fee. The message was received and understood and then he started interceding on our benefit.

Faith Of Religion. For believers in Hinduism it is must place to be visited It was my second visit .I visited this temple more than 30 years back At that time the whole place was a shabby small place crowded by rudrakash mala shops sadhus and beggers To day it is a big complex divided i three parts for smooth flow of visitors .The whole complex is much cleaner both outside and inside. Temple Visitors must have increased thousands time during last 30 years since i visited last time but today the whole complex is very nicely maintained The day I visited temple it was crowded but the flow of visitors was very smoth and darshan was easy without anybhassle. Surprisingly I could not see guides harassing visitors nor I could see beggers near the temple .May be they were so small in numbers that I could not notice them .I was told by locals that guide target foreigners .It is very badI saw few foreign visitors retuning disappointed as they were not allowed entry in side main temple .Only Hindus are allowed inside main temple. I have never seen such a big Nandi in any temple and very neatly kept with a small Nandi just in front of it For darshan of main diety two raised platforms have been put on which 2 or 3 person may stand and have good darshan from a distanceThere is provision of free distribution of small quantity of parsad A feeling of faith and peace is felt inside main temple complexRudrakash and other shops have been moved out from temple complex to away on side of main roads The river at the back ;the cremation place for Hindus ;was surpridingly clean without any burning body but pandas were sitting in large numbers for puja and rituals of pind-dan etc .It is very sacred place for pind dan and and similar ritualsIt is most important place to visit in Nepal

SADU HEAVEN. I've always found Pashupatinath to be a somewhat dreary place, but then, I guess watching Hindu cremations is not any ones idea of a good day out. The river looks dirty & the idea of being dumped into it after cremation is not appealing. The Sardu's live above the cremation area, on the opposite side of the river & are unique in their outlook on life. About R100-200 will get you some interesting personal photos. I believe the Sisters of Loretto have a Hospice within this complex. An item not to be missed when in Kathmandu. Mountain Monarch always takes its clients here as well as the big Stupa as part of your trekking package.

important and interesting place. although if you are not a Hindu you are restricted to some areas, you still can go (for 1000 Rps) and spend as much time as you want on bserving the whole process of creamtion- this is uncomparable with any other experience

What an experience. First of all the entrance fee is quite high (1000 NPR if not totally mistaken). With the access you'll be confronted with loitering people offering their guidance services. The temple serves as al cremation place where the dead bodies are burnt (right side for the ordinary, left side for the wealthier humans). Monks try to make their money with and praying for you. When I was there with friends we witnessed the cremation of one of the richer peoples and were able to follow from the preparation until the first flames were ignited. Compared to our western world where cremation is done is strict privacy, and normally you cannot witness it at all, this experience is somewhat great and impressive. Also if you see the crowds of people (kids, adults, school classes). Even music was played .

Interesting place.. We paid our 10000 rps to get in, we were hassled by guides to use their services.. But we went on alone, of course we couldn't go in the temple but the grounds around it. We walked for ten minutes and I felt I needed to know more about this place. So I engaged the services of a young man, 18 years old and very good English. I am glad I did as I learnt a lot about the life and death of people in Nepal. You will see dead bodies here, so be prepared. but I didn't feel we where intruding in the families grief..local young boys dive in looking for any metal brushed into the river off the funeral fire right under the noses of the next family.. you have to visit this place to understand the atmosphere. Beware for the fake holy men! Why would anyone give them money.. We saw a real holy man in mother Therasor's old folks home, he just prays and chants and feels no need to ask for money. And the monkeys are a wee bit aggressive.
More hassle than it's worth. Too many people trying to sell you a guided tour (unlike the Buddhist temples in the city where you can explore on your own).

A Deep Experience. I visit here on every visit. I sit opposite the great shrine and watch the ghats. I also birdwatch all around the area. History and culture superbly conbined. There are hawkers but the sell very nice bowls. Do not miss im this awesome place.

An absolute must-visit!. This Hindu temple complex is something not to be missed. Includes a cremation area, which is truly a profound and humbling experience. It is rare that non-Hindus are allowed to witness such a solemn spectacle. The sadhus, holy men painted in white clay and colorful markings, are a sight to see! They also have a sense of humor. But, please know that they expect to be tipped and depend on that for their survival. Be prepared to be accosted continually by people trying to sell you their wares. Be respectful and firmly say no if you are not interested, sometimes repeatedly. Again, they are only trying to feed their families.

Very interesting to see the ceremony. A beautiful tempel complex by the river, where on average 50 bodies a day get cremated according to hindu traditions. We had a good guide who told us Beautiful stories and we sat and watched the ceremony for a white. Only negative point was the hackers who followed us during our visit.

One of the Jyoti Lingams of Hinduism. A holy site of Hinduism, it was a good experience in spite of the crowding, especially when somebody from the security staff returned a bag with a substantial amount of cash we'd forgotten somewhere!

Death And Life. This visit both represented death and life. This is one of the holiest hindu temples that stretches across Nepal and India. This temple represents the head of the Hindu God. Only Hindus are allowed in to the temple. This does not mean that it is worth a skip. It is still very much a good place to visit. The cremation ceremony behind the temple was just .... surreal. Be prepared for the smell of burning flesh and ashes. Bring a facemask or cloth to cover the face. The motorikes near that area were all very chaotic. So be careful when you cross the road.

The most important place for Hindus. An important place for Hindus and the stench of burning bodies always hang in the air. Non Hindus are not allowed inside the site but visitors can view the complex from the opposite bank of the river which is little better than a filthy open sewer.

Just go see. There were so many so called guides around who will try to get you to enggage their services. The entrance fee was 1000 Nepalesse rupees. The giude fee was expensive and we just left the place.

Worth a visit if you don't mind seeing the dead. Is one of the holiest temple but for cremation of the dead in the open air. Is a whole ritual where the dead will be wash in the river, pray and then burn while their family uses the river water to wash their own head and feet. They believe is the holy water. Lots of monkey around and if you walk up the stairs to the top you will have a nice view.

Get a guide and it will be worth every rupee. The temple complex itself is not very big but there are so many stories in each post and pillar that you must take a guide along. He will tell you that each door to the "garbhgreh" is different and how, he will tell you the stories about the idols and places, he will guide you to ticket counters and storage room for your cameras and other stuff (photography is prohibited inside the temple complex)......and he might even add some folk lore and tips of other places to visit!

A very dignified place. One of Hindu's most sacred sites on the banks of the river Bagmati and a place of pilgrimage for Hindus. As non Hindus, we were not allowed to enter the main temple, and we fully understood this, but the surrounding area is fascinating. The human cremations on the ghats seem very strange to westerners. They are public cremations and no one minds if you watch and take photos, though we did not venture onto the cremation side of the river. Some did and it looked and felt intrusive, though locals didn't seem to bother at all. The cremation ceremonies seemed very solemn and dignified, unlike those in Varanasi that felt grubby.
Pashupatinathnath temple. Its very nice please to visit. Holy Hindu temple.It was sad that we are not allowed to enter on maintample where only Hindu were aloud.....
Pashupatinath Temple. This is an Ancient Temple around 3 Kms from the City Center Thamel and almost the same distance from the Airport.

important but eerie. well worth seeing given the scale and representation of life for believers .... the cremations in progress complimented by the monkeys make it just that bit eerie... not to mention the Sardus

Neat and clean Shiva Temple. I liked the management of the Temple .We Took Rs. 1100 slip for puja and had nice Darshan . ( For two people) They gave a Rudraksha Maala and Prasad . Had a nice time in the Temple.
Har Har Mahadev. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the jyotirlinga of Lord Shiva. This is one of the pilgrimage for all Hindus. Beautiful temple.

I could not get inside the temple.. One Thousand Rupees to go into the complex, but only Hindus could enter the temples. I believe there is much cultural significance here but if I am to pay for the restoration of this temple complex as least I should be able to take a look. There was a language problem at the gate, and the whole thing put me off the visit. Still a nice place to wander about inside and outside the gates. And even though I had a problem I would still recommend a visit. At least you will be prepared for the strange "pay to not see the temples" thing.

Life and Death. An amazing place. where you see several temples ans sharine including Pasupatinath. The holy river Bagmati , Sadhu and creemiation (After death activities) are attractions. I highly recommend one to visit there to study about hinduism.
Interesting. If you know little about Hindu cultural, you might want to go see the cremation process there, It's a bit shocking but ineresting.

An emotional and tutorial place. Where in the west burials are private here Pashupatinath you learn the opposite. People are together with their lost love ones until the very end and it makes you think. One is with the lost in every step of the way, there are many rituals before cremating and after the cremation.Every body is welcomed to bid farewell . The small private ritual masters sitting by the riverside and the many Sadhus around is an extra dimension . All though a very different culture to gasp this place is powerful and takes you into many thoughts however difficult to explain. Read and learn before you visit the place it is more rewarding . This is one of the musts while in Kathmandu and you will not regret it .

Very revealing and a bit challenging. The house of the dead, where bodies are burnt and last prayers for the departed said over a meal and a picnic, quite challenging to a western head, but very much life and death as it is celebrated. lots of holy men around and trinket sellers, but don't be daunted, its a world heritage listed area and worth a visit.

Aa powerful sensory and emotional experience. This Hindu Temple complex, visited on my last afternoon in Nepal prior to my flight home was a powerful sensory and emotional experience, which only those who experience the place can fully appreciate. A photo is just a two-dimensional view and cannot begin to capture the atmosphere of the temples, the holy Baghmati River and the Funeral Ghats. Nepal’s equivalent of India’s Varanasi is dedicated to Shiva. Sadhus and Hindus come from all over the Indian Sub-Continent to worship at this holy site. Many Nepalese are cremated here on open Funeral pyres along the riverbanks Families take the bodies of the dead to the river; remove all clothing and wrap their deceased on yellow robes. They take the bodies to the river for ritual bathing; where the mouths of the deceased are filled with water from the holy river. The cremation pyre is prepared and lit with the families and friends in close proximity. All this happens with the background sounds of the music and chanting from the temple above.Walking among along the river Ghats alongside the mourners; feeling the heat of the pyres, the smell of the smoke and the aural stimulation of the music was an almost unreal. I’d seen photos and films of this; but to experience this at first was an unforgettable travel experience like none other.

See local culture at work!!. My first experience at the custom of funerals. Culturally enlightening. Plenty to see and take in. Plan on staying a while watch the events from beginning to 'end'. I recommend this for anyone looking to expand their horizons. It is difficult to add comments, the other reviews were great.

Pashhupatinath Temple-Kathmandu, Nepal. Cremations occur here night & day along the Bagmati River. It is a very moving site to behold. Male friends and relatives of the deceased prepare the site and perform the cremation ceremony. They perform the cremation only a few hours after death. Rhesus monkeys abound around the site. Sadhus are found here and there begging after photos are taken of them. Lots of marigolds, red dyes and powders on the bodies.

Pretty Amazing at Pashupatinath. I loved it here, at the temple where funeral pyres are attended by mourners. Where I come from in UK, funerals are miserable occasions, everybody in black. But here, the serenity of the funeral ritual is joyous. But, if you want to stay away from the funereal scene, the temples and gats are gorgeous, there's a great (and cheap!) cafe and a wonderful riverbank walk where you can watch the monkeys climb the rock in single file, taking it in turns to jump into the river. A real sight for sore eyes. Unfortunately, my camera was on the blink and I couldn't get any photos. Boo-hoo.

Aarti time...best time !. My friends had told me that we should visit Pashupatinath Temple in the evening when the aarti begins. As advised, we reached the temple around 6 pm when we found that the aarti had just started. We were able to sit through the aarti, which lasted for more almost around 2 hours. It is a place to be visited for every visitor to Nepal.

Life and death on the river. This is a special place of worship for Hindus. The holiest outside Varanasi. Here people come to cremate their loved ones. You can see it all from across the river. It is a moving place full of sadhus especially if you go during a festival such as Dassain. Entry to the temple's sanctum is for Hindus only but others have free rein all around. Worth a visit.

The Holy Temple. We went to this Temple twice while in Kathmandu. The first time as part of a conference group when we were honoured to take part in a festival celebration and the second time just as tourists.this is where cremations take place so be prepared to cope with the smells associated with that. We saw the traditions that go with the cremations from start to when the body was well alight which was very interesting.It costs foreigners 1000 rupees to go into the Temple precinct but it is worth the payment.
Amazing.. A real glimpse into another culture and a world of funerals totally different from anything you would experience in Europe.

A very unique and humbling experience for a westerner.. I was lucky to have a great guide to explain the whole funeral process to me. It was a humbling experience to basically join a family during their loved ones funeral. I was saddened to see a tourist video the funeral using a mobile phone right next to the grieving family. This was a very rude and tasteless thing to do. Please visit this world heritage site but please give the families the respect the deserve at the hardest of times.

Self Realization... You will realize that no matter how luxury life you have, on the day when you pass on, there is nothing you can bring along... Is a very good place for us to find back our own self and own self realization.

Old Shiva temple. Only Hindus can go inside the temple and visit the shrine. If you a Shiva devotee its definitely worth a visit. You can see the cremation grounds from the temple ledge and it wasnt a pleasant site for me.

amazing and unique. Expensive entrance fee by Nepalese standards but well worth the visit. Interesting temples and where local people are cremated on a funersl pyre which is a moving and unique sight to witness.
Good to see the ceremonies. It's wonderfull to see the ceremonies off the dead people. Good to see how every culture his own tradition.

Nice. It is a nice place to see the crazyness of the ancient culture, where many many things were built in the same space to thank the goods.
There are lots of monkeys. Be aware!!

..Holy..Holy..Holy... Bliss.
Get immersed in the holy experience. The people at temple don't accept money to have priority Dharshan.
Praying From all four direction of the Deity is soul satisfying.
Better read the history of temple well in advance as the guides (official and non-official) don't explain any.
Morbid viewing. The central temple is closed for non-hindus. The gaths, very they cremate people are a ghastly sight.

A very Holy and Peaceful and sacred place in Nepal. A very Holy and Peaceful and sacred place in Nepal. It is the temple of Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu. It is only for Hindus. Everyone should must first go there.
Magical Experience. The Temple has a great History, Love the Art Work on the Temple which is all engraved in Silver...The place is very Holy of Hindus and the energies were High...

Heritage site of Nepal. Pashupatinath Temple is oldest Hindu temple of Lord Shiva . Temple located on the banks of the Bagmati River . The temple is listed in UNESCO World Heritage Sites list.
The temple remains closed between 12:00 Noon to 5:00 PM therefor we have plan accordingly.

A True Cultural Immersion. Our group of three spent a few hours there on the way to the airport to go home after trekking in both Bhutan and Nepal. We were able to witness several cremations, a blessing of a recently deceased person, the colorful Sadus, the various temples and statues, and the monkeys. Visiting this place is an absolute must while in Kathmandu. We even enjoyed seeing the cotton candy vendor carrying around his bright pink wares.

A msute see in Kathmandu. We visited the temple and surroundings in October 2014. It is a very important Shiva site and the most important Hindu shrine in Nepal. The temple is surrounded by many buildings and of course, the shore of the Bagmati River where cremations take place. You pass by vendor stalls on your way towards the temple. You may see many cows meandering about as well. To visit the Pashupatinath Temple, we utilized Prem, a guide. Highly recommended. He has a unique perspective as he lived about the temple as a street child and provided very worthwhile explanations of all that you’ll see. After being adopted by an American couple he furthered his education and earned a master’s degree. Prem’s English is very good and a tour with him to visit the temple area is an unforgettable experience. We concluded our tour by viewing, from some distance and across the river, various cremations. Prem can be reached via telephone: +977-9849082363 or e-mail premthapa305@hotmail.com

Evocative and spiritual. Down on the Ghats I always find this place a mixture of calm and evocation where life meets death and the body returns to the five elements! Personally I think this is a must with a good guide to explain everything about the meaning of what's happening here! Also interesting to note there is a division of area between the commoners who are being cremated and those higher in society!

Life ending ay of hindu befor burning death body. Bigest Temple of hindu shiva god in hole world, oldest and holiy holy for all hindu.
you think of life what about when you view live burn death body.... and puryfing body on barmanall,soon person dai.
Interesting!. I witnessed a Hindu funeral here when I visited the Pashupatinath Temple. A must-see if you want to learn and understand more about Hinduism.

Worth a visit. A large temple complex with a exotic cultural feel of Nepal - lots to see and plenty pf walking/ climbing. The cremation areas near the river are a little depressing to watch while you are sightseeing
burial. Even it is about burning dead bodies it is worth going there. It is a very old place and a lot of exiting symbols in the area

A member of our party was denied access as they had the wrong skin colour and did not fit the guards definition of a hin. A member of our party was denied access as they had the wrong skin colour and did not fit the guards definition of a Hindu despite beng a Hindu. Shameful and totally inappropriate and against Hindu Sanskrit. Other than that a must see place for Hindus. None Hindus cannot enter and even Dalits (untouchables) were only granted access in 2001. Again shameful. This did not stop the guards charging tourists for a ticket which they could not use however.

Interesting place to observe hindus. It is a site overlooked by many tourists. When i went there in an early sunday morning, i was the only tourist. I saw great hindu architecture and a cremation ceremony. It is a unesco world heritage site so make sure to visit. The entrance fee is $10, expensive compared to other sites in the kathmandu valley.

shiva statue manifested as Shivalinga!!. The temple is very popular and famous in Hindus. The temple is located about 7 km from Kathmandu city. It is a temple worth to visit !!. It is one of the Panch Kedar kshetra. One can do abhishekam of Lord Shiv in INR 1100/-.The temple is situated on the banks of River Vishnumati or Bagmati. In the temple complex, there are many other temple of God and Goddess.Don't miss the temple of Shakti (Maa Durga) known as Guhyeshwari devi, which is very near to Pashupatinath (less than 1.5 km) and which is one of the 51 divine shaktipeeth of Maa Durga.One can purchase Shaligram, a holy stone from the market just outside the temple.It is a must visit temple.Cheap accommodation is not available nearby, it is available in kathmandu city.Other important Hindu Temple in and nearby Kathmandu :1) Dakshineshwar Kali2) Budha Nilkantha3) Changu Narayan (15+ km from city)4) Krishna Temple (Patan)5) Baglamukhi temple and nearby temples (Patan)6) Jagannath temple (Hanuman dhoka square) and nearby templesIf you want to visit these temple, you can cover them in max. 2 days.

Eye opening. All you need to do at this attraction is turn up and watch. Have a guide with you if you can to explain what is going on, it is quite something to witness. Watch the monkeys as they are cheeky, especially if you have food and young ones. Im not convinced kids under the age of 16 should really go to this attraction as it is quite graphic what is going on. There is a sense of finality about it. There are lots of Yogis (holy men around) and the smell of Marijuana is in the air, so just keep all this in mind. Well worth the visit though.

A spiritually charged place. Overall ambience was good. One make sure that he/she has a full darshan of all four faces of the deity and understand the significance of them. Also important to know the history of the temple and its significance w.r.t. Kailash as well as the twelve jotirlingaa. You will surpised to know that the temple was attacked, looted and destroyed by the Mahmud of Ghazni like he did for many other Hindu shrines like Somanath in Gujrat.It would be better if one sits in silence in the temple for a while to soak in the engines present rather than bustling through the crowd and be content with just a glimpse of the idol /linga.

Our guide told us the river is tributary of the ganges. On approaching the site it looks like a railway station ,in this case the passengers are going to a one way destinationIt is quite sad seeing other people's funerals ,so I suppose appreciating Hindu sorrow is the main benefitam sure this place could be missed by tourist and dead
Casual Visit. The evening aarati is worth watching, it feels like everyday is deepawali.The burning bodies along side of holy Bagmati river can tell you true meaning of life.

A depressing experience .... I was clicking away with my camera while wandering through the place and suddenly realized what it was and I became too depressed to continue taking photos. There is a river running through this place and people here brought the bodies of their late relatives here to cremate. The scene is quite depressing. However, still an interesting place to visit in Kathmandu since it is among the most significant temples compound in Nepal. The Shiva temple looks really magnificent from up hill. So, only Hindus are allowed inside this temple so you can only get to see the temple from the hill across the river.

Religious Visit. Being Hindu, this experience was extremely special for me, I got to do Puja at the oldest Shiva Temple in the world. Mistake I made before leaving was to give money to the disabled outside the temple and I was literally mobbed( not such a good experience).
An interesting experience.. At first I wasn't sure whether I wanted to see bodies cremated, but was glad we went. It was very interesting to see how the Hindus say goodbye to their loved ones.
Humbling. Lots of history and atmosphere. Having a guide (Krishna) made it all the more enjoyable, again, there is nothing to dislike, just be there and take it all in.

13 th jyotirling. i visited world famous jyotirling of lord shiva named "pashupati nath" 2 nd time. i along with my wife offered abhishek to lord shiva. one can book same through temple committee. body and soul both becomes fresh and energetic by lord's darshan. there is a scope of too much improvement at least in compound area of temple but all we know about most temple committee ignores to spent rupees even in india.

Famous Temple of Hindus. There are many priests in the area but i think they are commercial now. If you want to take pictures of them just prepare small money, cause the will ask you some money for that.
A hindu temple. Interesting place but not one to take photos as also a place of sadness. Expensive bit worth a visit

Insightful experience. While the entry fee is a little steep (Rs. 1,000) the experience is unforgettable. The complex is a myriad of temples and a hustle and bustle of religious activities. From the cremation 'ghats' to the hindu sages who will gladly pose with you (for a fee), there is a lot to see and learn. I would recommend researching and getting a map to familiarize yourself or alternatively hire a guide. There are many hidden things to see and experience at Pashupatinath.
wowww. one of the strong experiences. do not miss!!the vision the sounds and smell. experience for all senses!can walk from there to bodahanth or back from bodanth to pasupathy.

Master of all arts.... . The temple is excellent in terms of art and peace... we sat inside facing the temple for half an hour admiring it's beauty... photography is not allowed inside and if caught harassment will be on like anything... Indians don't have to pay any entry fee...
sacred site. This temple is a most powerful sacred place, dedicated to Lord Shiva. Visit the river behind the temple to witness the holy rituals of the Nepalese people.

Fascinating. I was fascinated by the funerals - there were several the hour or so I was there. I was able to take photos from a respectful distance across the river but did feel intrusive and stopped when one person collapsed with emotion.
For Nepal, I felt the entry price (1000 rps?) was expensive.

Peacefull. When you go to Pashupatinath don't forget the Social House to see an donition in the box!,
When you go siting on the gate you can see how peaceful an cremation is from a dead body. Many many ceremonies you can see.

Well worth a visit. Recommend paying a guide to fully understand and appreciate what goes on here. Fascinating. We visited late afternoon and stayed until 7.30 when the light and chanting ceremony was over. This only added to our experience. This place certainly makes you think. It is definately worth making the time to visit.
Pashupatinath Temple. An interesting place and experience. The cremation ceremony was more simple and people more accepting the presence of aliens then their counterparts in Varanasi, India

Unusual and interesting!. The architecture was pure art! Actually saw a cremation taking place, and the scene was morbid yet has a certain liveliness of gaiety with traditional songs/chants sung nearby. The holy men was an unusual sight, deep in medication. But there were a few who don't quite fit the picture, and would probably expect money for photos being taken. Overall, I would recommend people to go here, it is interesting. We went on a rainy day, and had to keep our visit short due to the wetness.

Peaceful & a place to reflect. Its a surprisingly peaceful place to relax and reflect. Take the local bus from Radha Park area. Costs Nepalee Rs 20 and its a great experience to sit with locals - jam packed :)

Graceful Pasupathinath. The temple is NOT crowded like our Indian temples and is kept very clean. The Western Face of Lord Pasupathinath is available for Darshan when the temple is open and four faces (out of five)can be during the arthi in the morning and evening, when all four doors around the Lord are opened and we are permitted go round the Lord. The atmosphere at that time is mesmerizing! The staff near the gates speak very softly to the visitors!Behind the main temple, river Bhagmati can be seen and burning of bodies similar to that at Benares can be seen.What I did not like was the prohibition of photography, even around the temple.

Most sacred temple for Hindus in Nepal, a must see!!!. This temple is very special.They have about 30- 45 cremations daily.I took a local kid as a guide, he was very friendly and thought me a lot about the Hindu religion and the temple. i think you should take one to understand more about the place,Otherwise you won`t understand much as a non HinduVery important to discuss in advance how you will pay him.Otherwise you might get ripped off.Anyway for me it was a remarkable experience and i would recommend it to everyoneFrom Thamel by foot it takes about 45 min to 1 hour to get there.

Pilgrimage. Always the best temple for the Hindu pilgrims. The Pashupati Trust has renovated some area outside the main gate and it looks really good. People can rest in the Park and chit chat after the visit.

Expensive place with nothing interesting. 1000 Rs for entering the main gate is way too much. One cannot enter the main temples. These colorful monks are happy to have a picture with uou ...when you pay for it later. Cremation area is surrounded by crowd of tourists with cameras as it was a circus show, not the funeral! It is better to visit Monkey Temple.

Not worth the ticket price!. If you have too much money to spend- go there. If not- find something better to visit. The main temple is closed for non-Hindus, that is simply revolting because you have to pay supposedly for visiting this temple. The temple vicinity if rather small and smelly because of crematorium smokes.Much more interesting is outside the temple main gate (completely free of charge) a typical Nepali bazaar with devotional items. You can find many interesting souvenirs there (very cheap because prices are for Nepali and not for tourists).
Good for Hindus . Since only Hindus are allowed in the main temple so may a dampener for most foreigners. Inside area is little dirty with cow and other animal dung.

beware the guides. You can't really enter the main temple, unless you're hindu, but the surrounding grounds are very interesting places, especially the cremation site. Beware of the the monkeys, whose bites can be dangerous. Also beware of all the "guides", who are happy to walk you around and then ask a large fee at the end. Best to bargain the price at the beginning or refuse right away. The park on top is very nice and quiet and it leads to the north-east gate, from where a 30mins walk will lead you to the Bodhnath Stupa.

Recommended! . Visit the temple for couple of hours and take a local guide there to learn about the place. If you prefer to explore the place by yourself, just take a book which describes the place. Walk along the river to see the believers and clime up the hill to have a whole picture of Pashpati's beauty.
Historical. Visited in October, 2014 with family. A legacy of Hindu religion. It is a very old SHIVA temple with excellent architectural design. A must visit for anybody from India.

An eye opening experience to Nepal funeral. It may be hazy, but this is a wonderful place like no other. We learnt how Nepalese perform their funeral, and it isn't just theory, we can get real up close to feel the atmosphere and witness right in front. Highly recommended. The adjacent white hospital, well, that really creepy. https://vinshengloh.exposure.co/pashupatinath-temple-nepal

Temple is located near the Cremation site on river. Pashupatinath Temple and Cremation Site along a river near Kathmandu, Nepal...part of the Hindu tradition is for the body to be cremated after death...many bodies were being burned when I arrived at the holy site...strange idea for me being a westerner cause we are not so open about dealing with death in my country....I am thinking this is more healthy cause we are all destined to be a part of this ritual in some form or another...the older I grow, the closer I am towards my death. the more in touch I am with my body dropping away at some point...seems not so scary any longer...part of the natural process of life...but I wonder how I will be when the day, the moment finally comes when it is time to go...to leave the body I am so friendly with...so accustomed too for all of these years...I am hoping it is peaceful and I am truly ready for the transition

Pashupatinath pride of nepal. Jaya Sambhu !Pashupatinath is greatest Hindu temple lord shiva ,this is my forth times all the time huge crowd at day but this time I visit at evening with my Frn for Aarati song .it was wonderful hope I will visit again I also recommend you no matter which religion you trust you feel more spiritual .this is one of the major unesco heritage site .
Way over priced. First of all. We allready saw this in India. And it was free. 1000 npr p.p. is way to mutch for this smaller place. Not a must see. I would not advice you to go here.

Namaste. The cremation ghats along the river Bagmati are used for open-air public cremations, which take place daily on the south bank. I was told that only royals and higher castes can be cremated directly in front of the temple. For a hefty NRs1000, non-Hindus can enter the compound and witness the open-air cremations. Witnessing the ceremony form the very beginning up to the end was an immensely poignant experience. If you do want to visit here and witness this spitriual and very personal ritual, carry with you some tact and respect and avoid taking pictures or videos as some tourists/foreigners were doing. The sad part was that some of the people who work for the temple secretly allow tourists closer to the viewing cremation deck and let them take pictures or videos for a little dollar amount. I was summoned a couple of times, but I politely declined the offer. Just sit from across the river and ruminate on in the experience, a surge of peaceful sentiment will come to you right away. Namaste!

See the Buddhist Caves!. This used to be a very holy Buddhist-site, where to great Buddhist masters were meditating and realizing their mind. The caves are still there and this site has a lot of Buddhist history! I always think that Hindu-places are very dirty and messy and not for me, so our visit was only to see the caves... It is definitely worth the visit I think!
Visit the cremation temple only. Non-Hindus are not allowed inside all Hindu shrines, except the cremation temple. One of a kind experience to watch cremation ceremonies. Hire a guide at 500 ruppees.

Worth a visit. A lot of corrugated iron around, the buildings need restor action. All grubby and uncared for. Little evidence of officials around. The cremation site, although interesting, creates lots of smoke and is very untidy. The river is full of rubbish. Such a shame, as a clean up would really bring the place to life. At rear there is an old persons home, which is a lovely building and very interesting. Go through arch and make a donation.

We were blessed have such a visit. This is my 3rd visit to Pashupatinath Temple on 28th September. The temple had very less crowd and we had darshan to our heart content for half an hour. It was a lifetime opportunity

Temple of Shiva. We paid for a guide here, which was useful as he was able to tell us what was happening, and where we were allowed to visit. He was also able to put the cremations into contexts for us.

Big Beautiful Temple with lots of Monkey and lot of walking. I went in the month of March 2012, You are not allowed to click photo inside the main Lord Shiva temple. There is always a huge queue, being a Hindu I can understand its importance. The river was dry and a monkey took my offering while I was taking tour of the temple ( Attaching his pics ) . You can find lot of out statues which reveals very old culture and presence of the temple. For very old people or who cant walk much, should not take full trip of temple.

Temple?. The cost of the entrance (around 10$) gave me huge expectations. A local guide asking me for 10$ to show me the whole area made me believe that the place is huge an amazing... but it is not. I mean, in terms of religion and tradition, the place has a very strong humanity inside, but in architectural or artistic terms, is not that amazing, also because the most amazing part is reserved for Hindu people.The place is crowded and I felt uncomfortable about having many people around looking at the cremation piles as it was a show...Would only recommend this place if you are looking for a deep human experience, but not just for fun

Memorable. This was awesome. It was raining very slowly when I was visiting this place. Pashupatinath temple situated of many years ago. You will find many shops there, where you can buy some beautiful handicrafts, decorative items. You can go temple from Kathmandu city by Jeep or Tata sumo. Bargaining is everywhere.

For something more serious.... Being able to go and visit this temple is a huge privilege. The temple itself is beautiful, but know that this is where any people that have passed on are brought to be burned. This is tradition in Nepali culture. I was able to sit on the opposite side of the river bank and take it all in, but it was very emotional as the families of these people mourned. Be respectful, quiet, and make sure to be mindful as you might be sitting next to a family member like I was. I didn't speak her language, but as I had tears streaming down my face, I looked at her and touched her arm to offer my condolences. This place also has monkeys! Watch out!

Attack on the Senses. Pashupatinath unveils the real Nepal. Once we entered there were a handful of cremations ongoing, there were cows walking about, and many locals came in and out to pay respect to their gods. The temples were beautiful and very unique. Most of the temples did not allow non-Hindus to enter.

Great!. One of the many temples inside Bhaktapur. This beautiful temple is important to Hindu followers. my friends and i had fun exploring the history and cultural relevance of Bhaktapur and its temples.

Visit to Pashupatinath. Unless you are Hindu you can not enter the main part of this temple. There are touts just past the entrance that can become a bit of a pest. I have visited twice, once with my Nepalese host and on the other occasion with a colleague who was Hindu, so she wanted to visit this temple. The temple is very significant in the Hindu religion but it's a bit lost on those of us who are not of that faith.

Outstanding place to visit but see the warnings. This is a magical place but 2 health warningsa) Families need to be aware that bodies are cremated here and you may see this up closeb) Monkeys are frequent and can be very aggressive so be aware with young children.This is an extensive temple complex and it can be quite baffling if you come in at one of the unfamiliar entrances. You cant get into the Hindu Temple but walk around the side, go across the bridge and walk through the Ghats, up the steps to the temple complexes and just see how water, spirits and people come together. You can easily spend hours here - walking ,sitting, watching but its usually busy so be respectful and see how the spirit world is alive and well. Outstanding
Full Peace of Mind. A Must Visit place... Stayed for almost 02 hours in the premises & was relieved from all the tensions...

Peace and complete satisfaction. Only Hindu's are allowed inside the temple premises. Probably this was my Nth visit to Lord Pashupati since I travel very frequently to Nepal and whenever I come to Nepal I always go for the darshan at least once every visit. As always - you get peace and complete satisfaction once you get the darshan. If you go around 10 am - all the 4 doors are opened and you get less crowd and darshan at ease. The temple opens at 4:30 am and till around 10 am, only the West door is open from which darshan is available which becomes crowded at times. If you go around 10 am, you can get the darshan at ease from any other doors which are all opened and even do Abishek at leisure. Remember, the temple closes around 12:30 noon and reopens at around 5:30 pm, so plan your Kathmandu sight seeing accordingly.

The temple of Lord of the Beings...!. "Pashu" means living beings. So Pashpathinath literally means "Lord of the beings". As per Hinduism Lord Shiva is regarded as the father of all beings and so he is the Lord of all beings. Thus Pashupatinath is one of the important name for God Shiva.The Inner temple well renowned for aged old sacredness. For the "Shiva Ratri " Festival Hundreds of thousand devotees visit this place, including devotees from India. Nepal President and Prime minister also visit the place for to respect the temple, on this day.The river "Bagumati" is regarded as sacred as the river Ganges, in India.Many of the Hindu funeral rituals were done here. Dead bodies wrapped in suitable clothing, burned to ashes on the bank . Then the ashes will be floated in the river water.The main temple, which is keeping the "Linga" is not open for "beef eaters" (non Hindu or non Buddhist or tourist). Behind this temple is the Bagumati river. Beyond the river on a hill there are many more temple structures mixed with lot of huge trees. Those areas are accessible for tourist. Now the ticket is 1000 Nepali rupees per person. Pashupatinath is a World Heritage site. Undoubtedly it is one of the pride of Nepal Nation.
cultural. If you have never seen a cremation, complx of temples,that is the place to go.lots of places to visit or just sit and observe

Important temple but not my favorite. One of the most important temple in Nepal, this is where they did cremation when someone dies, including if not mistaken the royal massacre about a decade ago. It's a little creepy for me, glad i have been there but once is enough.

The Varanasi of Nepal. This is a very spiritual place which is very important for the Nepali Hindus. Next to one of the most important Hindu Temples in Nepal this place is a crematory for both Hindus and Buddhists.
To really fully understand this place you should try to get a guide who explains you about the temple, the crematory etc...
Place to go to view Hindu burial rite. Cremation of deceased Hindus takes place here next to the river. Very interesting ceremony takes place 24 hours a day in full view of all.

Cremation ticket touts. I took the bus to get here, so possibly wasn't in the best of moods. Pre-warned of the fee, I was resigned to forking out. There was a bereaved mother openly wailing just next to the ticket booth. "You must buy a ticket, sir. 1000 rupees!" I think he saw me balk at the cost and the absurdity of the situation. "You can see the cremation!"I walked away, a bit grossed out. I went (was steered) toward the other entrance, where the same selling point was eagerly proffered with a keen nodding action. At that point I walked away for good. I couldn't bring myself to buy a ticket to funeral. I wanted to see the temples, with the cremations a mere addition. No need to push the morbid fascination angle. Its there, of course, but sticking a price tag on it for tourists is totally distasteful.
Indrajatra. It was awesome experience to be the part of the crowed where we see people gods, mask dance which is really fascinating. Because
WORLD HERITAGE SITE ....JUST GOO. one of the most important holy place for the HINDUS around the world .. the place will give u such a divine feeling....amazing

Magnificent. One of the oldest Shiva temples in the country, this has four faces of Shiva in the main temple. There are four sides to the temple and one can get to see the four faces. The architecture is very beautiful. There is an evening aarti which is very nice and also an aarti best to the bagmati river behind the temple in the evening. If one wants to see the river aarti, one should go to the side of the river and not be in the temple premises as they close the temple compound at 7 and the aarti is still on. One has to be careful of belongings as there are monkeys in the compound.

Unique. Spend time, take it to let the impressions sink. On the one side cremations are taking place and the other women and children bath in this river. The long walk up the stairs is worth the forest on the top. You can wander off alone and let the impressions sink. Small cafe on top of the climb is much appreciated for a quick coke. Wish I had more time to stay. Definitely a must go.
Divine feel. What a wonderful place , makes a divine feel every time i m there...really a good place to feel heaven

"Shunya". It is one of the most sacred places for Hindus located on the banks of Bagmati. Kathmandu's main crematorium is in its backyard. I got a chance to be present at the aarti performed in the evening (around 19:00 hrs) on the banks of bagmati. That experience was divine...standing at feet of Lord Shiva - God of destruction or transformation, witnessing the majestic aarti being performed at the other side of the bank and dead bodies being cremated on one side. I felt like I was witnessing the separation of body and soul with my bare eyes.
