Mind went blank, first time in life i felt myself incomplete shunya.Information & Warnings:1) Temple gates are closed by 18:30 hrs2) You will find a lot child beggars....try not to promote that3) Large monkey population....eatables may be snatched fro your hand4) Soft hearted people and small children may not be taken for aarti or in the backyard near the bank of bagmati.....scene of cremation of dead bodies may cast a deep impact on the them.
Amazing!!!. This is one of the thing's you MUSTvisit once in Kathmandu. This complex of temples, shrines and cremation ghats...You woud feel it hard...An experience for life. Beautiful architecture.
Ancient temple. The oldest temple and market,the architecture of the site and buildings,the feel of our ancestors. The stunning carvings on the buildings,doors,entrances,courtyards of palaces
Jai Bhole Nath. Very Nice Place..... Must Visit this place of Lord Shiva. should do parikrama over there. excellent experience

DIVINE PLACE!!!. What a feel amazingly Devine and serene place want to visit many more times. The four side darshana make it unique. There are thousands of shivlings placed in certain order which one touches with both hands and it gives a good feel.

Overwhelming Experience! Must visit!. I reached at 6 PM to witness the evening aarti that takes place. The architecture was awesome. The monkeys were really playful. One female monkey snatched the prasad packet from my hand and then when I pulled it back from her, she pulled my stole. It was quite a show for all those present there. So keep fruits and other eatables out of the reach of monkeys. Behind the Pashupatinath temple, next to the river, there were around 7 cremations going on. The smoke from the cremation was overwhelming. I stood watching the cremation and the relatives of the deceased who have come to bid adieu to the departed soul. The friends and relatives of the deceased were so engrossed in their mobile phones and chit chatting with others, it made me think that there is no use of living life thinking of others. Our life is our own. No one cares once we are dead. The visit to this temple made me realise that life is just one and this life is yours, live it to the fullest without a care in the world.

a must visit. It's a very sacred site to the Hindu. Here u get to see am amazing display of faith of the Hindus. I'm amazed by the ceremony the faithful gone through to send their loved ones on their last journey

ऊँJai Bhole nathऊँ. Very religious very good place in Kathmandu. It's a place filled with tourists, devotees , sadhoos or pandits. It's the biggest shive temple in Aisa. There is a river called bagmati in which cremation r done. It's a very beautiful place & clicking photographs r not allowed. There's a tight security in temple. If anyone wants to rest his mind that person can go there.

wow. You gotta go! There are cremations all the time, but its an amazing cultural experience. Also there are monkeys and holy men. It is well worth the visit, we really felt like we understood the culture after a visit here.
Go, with no doubt. The experince is unique. You can see how the family prepare the body before to burn it, you can see how they burn it and after this they put down the ashes to the river.

Feel the culture in Pashupathinath. Filled with Devotees, Sadhoos, Tourists, Guides,Cows,Corpse Pashupathinath is truly the world's biggest Shiva temple.A must see place in Kathmandu. A Unesco World heritage site.Even though its slightly unclean that doesn't bother when you stand in this holy place. There is a cremation ground in the banks of Bagmati river where the corpse are lined up for their turn. Don't forget to visit the old age home near the temple. If you want to visit the whole temple campus one full day is required.

A holy place with the essence of Hindu culture and lifestyle. Do you want to calm down with spiritual feeling and be your self , please visit this place, I bet one visit will not be enough. Go along or with family but do not rush to see everything at a glace and back. This is one of the place need to spend time to feel

Very clean and very holy. The Temple is very clean , quiet . The temple security handles the darshan and are very co operative and friendly with everyone. A must place to visit when in Kathmandu .. Very serene place

Not your everyday experience. Very spiritual place even for not so spiritual ones. A great temple with amazing art and architecture. Good old saints with ashes on their bodies praying for nirvana is a pretty common sites. You absolutely would love 100s of monkies walking around alone or in families becoming too friendly (also trying to snatch your food/camera away). Behind the temple is the holy river where bodies are cremated. Thousands of devotees visit everyday. If you visit at the right time you will be able to witness the elaborate and amazing ceremony of lord shiva. A must go if you are in Kathmandu.

Majestic place but unclean. It seemed to be the norm in every temple we found in Nepal. There was no cleanliness. And most of the side temples were closed. Although we did have a good experience here. The place is marvellously built and the aarti experience was great. Visit this place in the evening or morning for the aarti.
spritual. Living in the Kathmandu.. I very rarely visit Pashupatinath temple. But whenever I visit it gives a very spiritual feeling and immense confident within. It is closed to non-hindu people.

Very unique experience- Must see. This temple is the ,most important and sacred hindu religious center, facilities include unique structure and attached smaller buildings wothr to see each. Other religions are not allowed inside of central buinding of temple. Bagmati river flows thru the facilities and outdoor cremation of bodies are conducted here with unique ritual ceremony. I and my wife were extremely impressed with this temple and things to see in the facilities.

Tourist at Pashupatinath Temple. I visited the temple in June 2014, and I was guided by a very interesting person. My guide, Prem, had been a street child around the temple for a couple of years, then he started to make some money as a temple tour guide. Then he was adopted by an American family who put him through school and college. Now he is a master's graduate, speaks perfect English, and understands the Western culture. He teaches English and is a tour guide (I also did the Annapurna Circuit trek with him). Back to the temple, it is a very complex and intense Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, who governs destruction and death. Therefore the Shiva sites are dedicated to incineration and death rituals. They happen in open air, and I stayed on the bank of the river and watched the rituals for a long time. The scenery, including the cows along the river, reminded me very much of the holy Hindu city of Varanasi, my favorite place in India. But while in Varanasi you are not allowed to take pictures of the incineration rituals, here at the temple you can, from a respectful distance. You can see some of my pictures here.If you need an outstanding guide for the temple, Kathmandu, Annapurna, or other sites in Nepal, here's Prem's info: +977-9849082363, premthapa305@hotmail.com
Great to see this Hindu temple. This is a very old temple where thousands of Hindu people visit daily. It has a magnificent ambiance outside where you can see all the Hindu rituals.
holly destination. very pleased with arrangments by the temple staff.they have kept place in a nest way.you will be compelled to medittate

The oldest Shiva temple, must visit for Hindus. Pashupatinath Temple is considered a very holy place for the Hindus, and it was truly a blessing for me to have visited the temple.Make sure you visit in the morning between 9:30-10:30 to see the Lord from all 4 Doors, if you visit in the evening you will get to see only through one.Unfortunately non-Hindus are not allowed inside the temple, you can see from outside or see from the backyard. You can visit there in the evening between 6-7:30 when there is live devotional music(satsang) played and Aarti is taken.

worth visiting, the presiding deity , world heritage site- Pashupathynath temple is - spiritual experience of lifetime. I walked from my hotel in front of the airport, about 20 minutes, well done walkway , a midst greenery and well lined trees. Walking along this path beside very large Golf Ground, itself is great experience. My visit to the temple is par-excellence - spiritual experience of lifetime, with simple, humble devotees , thronging the temple. On the Parikrama of temple I saw the statues of Adi Shankara and his first disciples- who visited here 1200 years back , arranged the procedure of prayer , by Brahman from South India- Udupi. It was great experience visiting this temple for believer.

Hindu culture. This is one of the main cremation locations in Kathmandu - quite a change from Western traditions. You cannot enter the temple unless you are a Hindu and the focus is not on tourists so you should engage a guide to get the most from your visit.

Amazing. This place is so interesting. It is the cremation site for the rich and the poor in Kathmandu and has many parts to it. One part is for old people sponsored by Mother Theresa foundation and has around 250 people that are housed and stored. The cremation area is something that I have never seen before and the ashes are committed to the holy river. There are holy men and shrines and well worth the visit

Shiva's palace is here... To enter the main shrine you must be Hindu..but still a great place to visit.. There are the cremation sites along the river and Shiva's invisible (to us) palace is on the uppermost hill... Many sadhus, Hindu holy men, stay here all year round but many more come on Shivaratri..usually celebrated in the autumn...a very sacred pilgrimage place. The area is quite large so be prepared to walk...look around as there are many sights, often in the more out of the way spots... Definitely a must visit.

Impressive, definitely worth a visit. A bit crowded with a few annoyances, such as monkeys and begging holey men. However, it's a unique location where you may watch (albeit voyeuristic, it felt intrusive) very personal cremation ceremonies. We watched for about 15 minutes, which is enough because you see up to four cremations at once, each in a different phase.You can easily walk around here and visit the temples. A personal guide is expensive ($15) and with a good tourist guide book, you'll manage perfectly on your own. I can't remember whether there is a fee for visiting the temple grounds.Recommended is to visit this in the late morning / early afternoon and then take the 1 mile walk around 3 pm to Boudhanath and watch the sunset there with a cold Everest on a rooftop terrace. Perfect day.

Architecture great but.... The temple is not kept clean. The two level structure is beautiful and it's a shame that non-Hindus are not allowed. This really needs to be shared with everyone. The cremation area is fascinating and the monkeys are fun to watch, although one did try to grab my purse.

Not allowed in. I was not allowed to go in. At the entrance gate, I was asked to prove that I was a Hindu. Quite shocking! I recited the Gayatri Mantra (sacred Hindu chant) only to be told that I needed written proof! (From who?)I was quite disappointed by this attitude but still enjoyed walking around the site.

Must visit. I have been to many temples, and Pashupatinath is among the most unusual. You can witness the Hindu cremation rites, meet some unusual monks, and see some striking shrines. This should be a place of great solemnity and private worship. Unfortunately, the intrusion of commerce leaves a bitter taste in the mouth. First, the 1000 NR entrance fee is quite steep; second, beware of getting attached to a self-appointed guide; third, you can take photos, but if you shoot people, they expect to be paid (not mourners, but priests and others). I got a classic shot with three monks, but it cost me 2500 NR. And touts try to sell you trinkets.All that said, however, this is still a place you "must see" on a visit to Kathmandu.

Lord Shiva's abode. The temple is surrounded by natural beauty on the banks of Bagmati River and is thronged by devotees of the Lord. Its a place to let your soul rest with the divine.I am no one to review Lord's abode, its He who is reviewing us all.Om Namah Shivay

Cremations At Edge Of Bagmati River. I spent over an hour observing the ritual of Hindu cremation taking place at the edge of the Bagmati River. The pyres were built with carefully placed logs in a rectangle around smoldering embers, the body placed in the center, more logs added to cover all sides. The fire is fueled with straw or smaller pieces of wood to insure a strong fire. The family attends and watches this final ritual in the life of a Hindu believer. I entered a Park and then walked about 200 yards to stand across the Bagmati from the pyres to observe the ritual. The walkway is made of concrete and extends down to the waters edge. There is no fee to observe from there.

Pashupatinath. Going upto temple of pashupatinath with walking thru rain makes steps slippery but anyone coming here should visit this area here also we witnessed the final rites of hindu dead how they attend and bath the person b4 cremation

I didn't regret to pay entrance fee 1000R. To the crematoria you get take bus from Ratna Park (15R) and after you can continue to Bodnath stupa. Crematoria is sad, breathtaking and shocking place. Now entrance fee is 1000R, but I didn't regret to pay it. I spent hours watching burning bodies there and ceremonies there. If you come, on the left side there are cleaning ceremonies of the dead bodies and there is a place for burning rich people. On the right side there are many burning places. In this place you can realized how our bodies are easily transient. If you are in Kathmandu, find a half of the day and spend time there. It is worth.

Amazing experience. No words can describe when you are swarmed by the people full of faith and are bowing to the almighty. The temple is a very different in terms of architecture and the images. It s a pure bliss, an experience beyond words. Thousand of lamps lighting on the four sides of the main sanctum sanctoruium was great. Visit and feel blessed.

Absolutely Blissful !!!. Om Namaha Shivaya ...When we are to Kathmandu , we should not miss this spiritually aligned absolutely blissful neat and clean temple.Positive vibrations fully filled in this tremendous temple , when we sit in silence after having darshan we can feel the whole lot of positive vibrations over here.Very easily accessible form all parts of Kathmandu and very close to airport .Behind the the temple , cremation of dead bodies are done in the river as it is being done in Varanasi Ghats , this is also very special in this temple .Thanks a lot for everything ...Loving you so much ...Shivoham ...Peacefully yours.S M Bega Raaj.

Expensive Entrance Fee. Arrived by noon time. Our guide said it is strictly for Hindus. But still we can walk outside the boundary and have a look. Still we have to pay entrance fee for that which is 1000 rupees - about 12 dollars. We decided not to go in.
Interesting grounds. This is a very interesting site. They cremate their dead here. there is also an old folks home here. It is a big area and I would take a guide to see it properly.
om namashivaya. It is better to go in the evening for a Aarthi pooja in the temple as well as in banks of the river next to the temple

Greatest experience on a Kathmandu tour. Pashupati is most important Hindu temple in Nepal. Altough I expected to stop for a quick visit, I stayed there for couple of hours, observing cremations of deceased Hindu people, yogis, Hindus praying, monkeys. Just absorbing the incredible atmosphere. Place is crowded with bit boring sellers demanding money but they are not aggressive. Definitely must-see.

Very interesting Hindoe temple. Also very historic and interesting temple to see.The Hindoe people burn their dead family, friends here with special service.I don t recommend when you have little children

Astonishing architectural beauty. The roofs of the temple are embellished probably with gold and the four main doors are adorned with silver.It isthe most sacred temple of Hindu Lord Shiva in the world, We enjoyed to visit this place

Greastest Hindu Temple in Nepal. Lord Shiva is known by many different names; and Pashupati is one. Pashu means leaving beings, and Pati means master. In other words Pashupati is the master of all living beings of the universe. This is how lord Pashupati is eulogized in the Vedas, Upnisada and ohter religious books.Pashupati area is regarded as one of the most important places of pilgrimages for the followeres of Hinduism. Thousands of devotees from within and outside the country come to pay homage to Pashupatinath every day. And on special occasions like Ekadasi, Sankranti, Mahashivratri, Teej Akshaya, Rakshabandhan, Grahana (eclipse), Poornima (Full moon day) people congregate here in far greater number. Pashupati area is also included in the list of world cultural heritage. was build in 753 AD happened to be the ruler 39 generation before Manadeva (464-505 AD).

Very interesting. Pashupatinath is a really interesting yet sometimes somber place. Entry is $15 which is a bit over the top like a lot of places, however there is a lot to see. A guide will attach himself to you and I found, in my case, it was worth paying a bit extra as he explained everything. There are quite a few cremations every day and you are allowed to watch. You're not allowed to enter the temple if you're not a Hindu. Right up the top is a small deer park which is fenced in though but you can walk around it and it's quiet and peaceful. You will come across the usual holy (or not so holy) men who will pose for a fee. The Aged Care facility is an amazing place as it is so very different to our western ones.

Pashupatinath Temple. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most sacred Hindu shrines in the world it is the richly-ornamented pagoda houses the sacred linga, or phallic symbol, of Lord Shiva. Chronicles indicate the temple’s existence prior to 400 AD. Devotees can bee seen taking ritual dips in the holy Bagmati River flowing beside the temple. Cremation of the dead body Hindus/Buddhist takes place at the bank of the same river.

Holy, traditional and great for Photography!. Be aware, the guides latch on and demand money.. like most places but just be aware! We however had a guide for approximately half an hour to talk through the crematoria ghats and the religion, which was actually very informative and knowledgable. He however was expecting a huge amount demanding it away from the main area and hidden, which was quite intimidating. Be strong and donate a small amount. The area however I found fascinating and probably one of the main highlights in Kathmandu. Certainly not to be missed by any means! Really glad to have come and definately grab a picture with the holy saddhu's around the area!
A World Heritage Site. This temple has a lot of history. Beautifully done.There are 4 entrances to this temple which open post 9.30 am. Only draw back is that only Hindus are allowed here.

Nepal's Varanasi. Pashupatinath, home to Shiva as the Lord of Animals, is a must see in Nepal. This is the most important cremation site in the Kathmandu Valley and boasts a beautiful temple to Lord Shiva. Sadly for tourists, the temple is only open to Hindus, but one can walk up to the entrance and peek inside or get a view of the temple from the opposite side of the Bagmati River - Nepal's version of the Ganges. Often, when visiting, tourists find cremations going on - Hindus in one area and Buddhists farther downriver. Watching a cremation and understanding what it means to have the family intimately involved in sending family to the other world, is quite an experience. It is also fun to visit with the local sadhus or wise men. Remember, though, if you take a photo, they expect to be compensated. You can also walk up the hill on the other side and come down past the Gujeswari Temple, with good views of Boudhanath. In the old days, this area used to be farmland, but now it is dotted with apartment houses for Kathmandu's growing population.

Spiritual Bliss. The temple is kept improving, thanks to the pressure from UNESCO after announcing it as a world heritage site and generous financial contributions from India. I visit Temple whenever I'm in Kathmandu and feel diving blessing of lord Pasupatinath.

Paupathinath Temple. The four faces of the Lord pasupathinath can easily be seen by following the devotees from one entrance to the other. The security staff understands the agony of the tourists and are helpful in making the queue move orderly allowing locals who crowd around standing for a long time.The top side of the linga could not be seen and we understood that only the king and the assigned priests know what it really looks like.Beware of pandits who boast that they will do abhishek and arrange special darshan. Nothing like that is possible. They make you sit chant some mantras give you some flowers and a rudraksha mala and collect a hefty sum of money and finally leave you in the queue only..The locals follow some order but tourists visit the way they like and it is acceptable. Worshipping and darshan of Lord Pasupathinath gave solace, peace of mind and happiness. Worth visiting and spending some time.

Worth praying.. We worshipped at this temple during this Holy month of Shravan and it is a God given opportunity to worship Lord Pashupati Nath during this auspicious time. But for cleanliness, we liked everything and none can do much better.

World Heritage Site. Don't miss the evening Aarti at around 7:00 p.m. In the summer but basically when the sun sets so it depends on the time of year you go. It is spectacular with live musicians and singers with the priests. This Temple is an amazing historical landmark in the area. There are many different deities that can be found in the hotel. Unfortunately a lot of the mini temples are locked on the inside and you can't view them. I think they need to do a better job with maintenance since it is a world heritage site. They should have it opened fully as opposed to partially. The. It's of the river there is great and the locals have started to work on clean up efforts along the river and the river itself throughout the area. A very quick drive from the Hyatt Regency Hotel. Pictures are not allowed inside the temple. You need to take your shoes off to enter the temple and the shoe storage place shuts down at 6 p.m. Be prepared to maybe carry your shoes in a bag if need be.
Pasupathinath Temple. Its just a beautiful temple and ofcourse its soooo famous and a mustdo in Nepal.Photos arent allowed so pls respect that and dont go clicking.They will just confiscate ur camera
World Heritage Site. We witnessed the evening Aarti around 7pm.... The Temple is one of the world heritage sites in Nepal... It is worth visiting whilst in Kathmandu....

Shiva Temple with a twist. 'Heritage site' declared..not very clean..but a perfect place for street shopping..The temple with Ghosala is just amazing.. dead bodies are burnt on the banks of the temple, the ashes being immersed immediately. The architecture of the temple s so detailed..Defi a place to visit..
Very holy place. Very old and historical pilgrim but not well maintained by the local authority. It should be developed in better way to attract more tourist/devotees

Not convinced. I felt it was a bit of a shame to turn the process of death into a tourist attraction. If you have a genuine interest in Hinduism and cremation from a spiritual perspective I would definitely say go. We were there on a day when there was a politicians cremation and learning about the process was interesting, but I still felt it was a bit voyeuristic. The sadhus who wander around seem to be a part of the money making process and I wasn't convinced of their spiritual integrity. This is the only place in Kathmandu where we were really hassled by street hawkers.

A Must visit for Hindu Pilgrims. Whenever I visit Kathmandu, Pashupatinath Temple is the place where I will visit at any cost. I find the devine peace there. The ancient temple of Lord Shiva is one of the Jyotir Linga, which means one of the most worshiped Shivlinga.The atmosphere here is superb. The river near temple is used for hindu last rites when a person is died.

Not Worth it. Apologies to all fans of Pashupatinath Temple, but it wasn't worth the money I paid. $1500 rupees is not that much for a tkt, but compared with other great sites like Budhanath Temple which we paid $300 Rupees it's a big let down, considering you can't get inside the Golden Temple or any other attraction in the Heritage site. Ignore the guides as they would be useless. It's different and culturally chocking to see cremation ceremony taking place, but there are some other amazing sites in Kathmandu.

7th visit. My 7th visit to this temple. Saw the evening AARTHI and also spent considerable time in the temple complex admiring the various statues. The sanctum this visit was cleaner than the earlier visits. The menace of PAAN chewing and spitting has reduced but still needs to be more thorough.

Historic Hindu temple. The temple was very much on my itenary and enjoyed the Darshan and Pooja being performed by the Locals.Overall cleanliness could have been better.I offered tip to the people but they refused saying they work for The Lord .I liked this attitude very much.Did shopping ourside the temple area.
Har Har MahaDev. Amazing Feeling.. the first place u should visit.. also seen some aghori babas :)little bit rush all the time but its worth to wait to see the lord..superb place

Racists. I am married to a fair woman and was told I as an Indian could enter but my WIFE could not. Did not matter if we were Hindu or if she was Hindu. If you are white, you are not allowed in. You can pay 1000 rupees to see bodies being burnt and relatives crying, if you are white, but you cannot pay to enter the temple. It does not matter if you are a white Hindu or a fair indian Hindu, you will be turned away from visiting one of the holiest places in your religion. This goes against everything the hindu religion teaches, it's embarrassing.
Religious Travellers. This temple is worth a visit for the religious traveller looking to capture the history of religion in Nepal.

Commercialized Exploitation. Pashupatinath temple is tauted as one of the most significant Hindu temples of Shiva in the world. The temple is located on the banks of the Bagmati River in the eastern part of Kathmandu and serves as not only a place of worship for Hindus, but also a crematory. Plain and simply, Pashupatinath Temple is a tourist trap. Entrance for non-Asians is $10 (1,000 nrs) and that's the first opportunity to fork over money... Bombarded with people offering a "guided" tour, the average tourist will get fleeced out of money by those looking to earn a quick buck. The Sadhus (Hindu holy men) were opportunistic as well, charging people for photo ops. The temple complex has a very dark and ominous feel... and something about all of the tourists taking pictures of the funeral pyres and grieving families just doesn't seem fitting or respectful.Save the 1000 rupees for momo's or a walk around Bhaktapur!

It's a one in a lifetime feeling!. A must visit to feel the tranquility and blessings of Lord Mahadev.The experience is truly a journey within.To observe the Aghoris is a revelation in itself.The historical and spiritual significance of this beautiful temple can only be felt in person.

God Bless.... Visiting a place of such a significance and history was very exciting. The statue of Nandi is very attractive. Went on tuesday..thus was saved from the crowds..had a good darshan. As with hindu temples..cleanliness is an issue..Architechure is quite different from temples normally we see in North india.
Must visit. Must visit, not just for spiritual reasons but also architectural beauty. Beware of people selling offerings outside as they overcharge a lot.

Beautiful and Interesting Hindu Complex. Entry fee is quite high at 1,000 Rupees. I would definitely recommend getting a guide to understand the true significance of the complex. Tourists are not allowed enter the main temple but they can walk around the complex viewing the cremations of bodies, various small temples, monkeys, cows and Hindu monks (who are willing to pose for a picture for a small fee). Our guide made this a truly enjoyable experience.

beware. Pashupatinath temple in Kathmandu may be considered as one of the holiest Hindu shrines. But beware while visiting the area. There is a gang of robbers operating around and in the temple which the local police have been unable to bust. They steal and rob travellers of their valuables by diverting their attention in talks related to the temple under the pretext of helping them. Many have lost their money, expensive mobiles and the like. Also a person claiming to be the priest will ask you for money (nrs 1000 plus negotiable) to take you inside the temple by another route bypassing the crowd. This implies that if you have money you are allowed to see the shrine faster unlike others who may have to wait because they do not have money enough to pay the priest. And this all when they claim that God treats all humans equal. The area is also very crowded and not so clean.

Holy Place for Hindus & best attraction in Kathmandu for everyone. If you are in Kathmandu, once you most have to go to Pashupati Nath Temple.If not your tour will not finish ....This Place is the head of four holy (CHar Dham) place as a Whole Hindus. Every One will enjoy here.... So deference and so nice.If you like to see all Temples than you have to go east of temple Jungle Side you will see very beautiful view.

Jyotirlinga in Nepal. Famous temple with Huge complex housing old age house, gaushala and last rites area around Bagmati river. Avoid people approaching you for special puja etc. Darshan and puja is not very crowded at all. Cleanliness in Mandir area needs improvement.
Holy Palce. Holy Palce for Hindus .. But not very clean ...visisted with long time back . Pls be aware of touts . But temple is worht a visit once in life time . Pls take care of your belongigns

Okay. You may want to engage a guide to fully understand the significance of this venue.

Peace in a chaotic temple. The temple itself is very nice - and quite well organized now. However, be careful of unscrupulous priests who can tie a red thread or 'gift' you a rudraksh mala and extort money.The main sanctum houses a beautiful five faced shiv ling. Must see - from all sides. The ancient architecture is also something to admire. Try visiting on a weekday / non-festival / early morning - you may get your peace and quite.

Amazing temple complex. I and my wife visited the temple during our recent Nepal tour. The place is beautiful and the complex sprawling. But the cleanliness is poor. There are a lot of touts and scams by the priests. Also the cremation at the river behind the temple is quite nauseating.

lovely place. Pashupati Tample is holy temple where we had seen that lots ofHindu people worshiping there. This place has more then hundredsof Hindus gods stupa. which was interesting to see and know by our guide.

See,Feel and Think. This place more then different then other attraction of Kathmandu.This place totally holy place of Hindu people. The structure of temple with different varieties of Gods. This is holy place where Cremation will be done after the death of Hindu people just behind this temple on theside of Bagmati River.... Lovely place with different Activities of Hindu.

Wonderful experience.. Visited this place twice,once at the afternoon and another during evening.You can go in without paying the fee (1000nrps for foreigners) after 6.45pm. They usually have this light ceremony with three local priests that pray to god Shiva around 7pm. Pretty interesting ceremony. You can get some flowers (for 'throwing away' your bad habits into the Bagmati river) and sweets(banana, with the blessing from god Shiva) from the priests after the ceremony ends. During the ceremony, you can dance along with the music.

A must visit place. Mobiles and camera are not allowed inside the temple..its said ringing mobiles so you can very well make it silent and take it in..This temple is the main reason lots of people go to kathmandu..you will find lots of decorations in silver on the temples..try to visit the temple with time in hand there is a lot of things that you will see..Only hindus can enter the temple..

HOLY PLACE. The pilgrimage centre of Kathmandu. The hindu devotees visit here in large number. A large area of temple, relatively clean & holy atmosphere, lots of Sadhus around and pigeons also. When we visited a noble activity of blood donation was going on in the premises.

Shiv Temple. Its like any other Hindu temple. Very crowded , surrounded by touts , pandas asking you to perform Pooja. , not in the temple but in the open garden. Pilgrims are fooled.Darshan is not so good experience.

Waste of time. It is just a horrible experience going there. A commercial temple, selling Hindu beliefs to tourists. The so-called sadhus (monks) there, collect money from people to pose for pictures. We had cameras and were approached by these sadhu's agents with opportunities to take pictures at good price !! So much for simple living. We couldn't get out of there faster!

Fascinating cultural experience. Most westerners definitely have a different idea of how death is dealt with. It may come as a shock to some that the cremation is so public, and the rituals alien to what we're accustomed to, but I found the process as explained by our guide fascinating. Also good photo ops with the Sadhu's and a person dressed as Hanoman. All we could see of the temple complex was from the other side of the river. This was a good start of our tour.

OK, but not great, and the ongoing cremations are a turnoff. This is a large Hindu temple complex and perhaps the best in Kathmandu. That said, there are many more interesting ones in India, so if you are going to India, I am not sure Pashupatinath is worth much time. Tour guides urge that people see the ongoing cremations there. Frankly, I've seen it before, and it was both a bit grisly and seemed intrusive to stand and watch families as they conducted these intensely personal ceremonies. I wouldn't visit again.

horrible!. Well, I knew it was a Unesco world heritage site but i didnt know it is gonna be so expensive! 10$ for Nepal....is kinda pricey. Anyway, while bying tickets someguy (obviously a gide) somehow managed to "let me tell you smth about this temple" thing so I was enchanted to listen to his explanation of some Buddhist...things...for good 15 mins! And I didnt want to listen to it at all! And I realised I would have to pay if I dont kick him off me now. So I said i ont wanna listen to him and gave him 250 R (all I had at that time). Temple is terrible, dirty, full of monkeys, cows, their poop, dirty people asking you to buy useless stuff....And u cannot enter the main temple if u r not Hindu. So what's the point of paying so much money? To see the dirt and poop? I saw it enough in Thamel. Anyways, NOT recomended!

A holy shrine for Hindus dedicated to lord Shiva. Pashupatinath temple is one of the holy shrines and highly revered by Hindus. It is a temple of lord Shiva and it was built in 400 AD is almost 1600 years old now.We visited the temple on June 14th, 2014. It was a good experience and there was not too much rush. We managed to do the Darshan in less than 10 minutes, which otherwise can stretch to 3-4 hours in certain times of the year.There are hundreds of monkeys in the premises, but they are quite docile and don't attack humans. But they are quite naughty and one of them ran away with my wife's sandals and shred it to bits!

Its a UNESCO World Heritage Sites!. I am not going to share the history and hows beautiful is the temple. :) But i have some tips to share after my Visit.1. Firstly, please prepare 1000 Nepal Rupee Entrance Fees. this apply to all the foreigner (excluded visitor from Nepal Neighbour country). 2. Some local guide will be waiting nearby the ticket counter and approach for touring services. Try to talk to them for few minute to make sure they really can speak good english/chinese. Some of them might only good in greeting and introduction. For the touring services, they will ask for 5 USD or 500 Rupee. 3. a facemask is a MUST. This temple also an Cremation Site. And they did it in open air. 4. The Mother Theresa's old folk's home is near beside the temple. Based on my tour guide, this old folk's home have more then 150 old ppl. If you don't mind, just drop some giving to the donation box. :)As a conclusion, this is a MUST VISIT place. Please don't miss it.

Om Namath Shivaya. What a feel amazingly Devine and serene place want to visit many more times. The four side darshana make it unique. There are thousands of shivlings placed in certain order which one touches with both hands and it gives a good feel.

A must visit when in Kathmandu. A big temple complex this, cameras and phones not allowed inside the complex though I saw people using them inside. You can greeted to a huge bull idol as you enter the temple and you get a sense of templeception since there are many idols of gods within the complex. The crematorium is visible to public and you can watch all the proceedings. Also once outside the temple complex, it's a haven for portrait photographers. A must visit for people who travel to Kathmandu. It's a 10 minute drive from Thamel, and costs 20 npr if you take one of the mini vans from ranipark

An beautyful Temple. I was there with my family last month.Its an beautyful temple.People have strong belive n faith on this temple.We had the pleasure to do the Rudravisekh,which i cant never forget.It was a realy great feling.The surrounding is beautyful.Especially the birds who were in a large numbers to get food from devotees.We enjoyed a lot there.Overall a must visit when u will be at Kathmandu

Completely divine..!!!. It is the only best place in kathmandu.You just cannot miss Pashupatinath if you're visiting Kathmandu. The temple in itself is a marvel. It is huge in size. Pashupati ji is located in the centre of the temple surrounded by many small temples. The huge nandi bull is awsome.The temple is amazing, it is chaotic with people everywhere. This is a world famous temple. So don't miss it. You will feel happy and blessed.
Different in a Good Way. I was amazed that this crematorium was open for the public viewing pleasure. Numerous cremations were in process allowing me to see various stages in the ritual.

Quite a let down. The temple is adjacent to a crematorium.The revered temple is managed by personnel who i saw kept pushing people away. Considering that Nepal and its attractions are probably the biggest source of revenue to the state, the management should try to be more courteous to visitors from far and wide. Compared to many temples in India ,this temple is probably badly managed by people.

Shiva, the Lord of the animals. At the Bagmati river - as holy as the Ganga in India and the holiest place for Hindus in Nepal you can look from a close distance how the bodies of the dead are openly burnt, to help the soul come free of worldly existence and guide it to higher world's between death and rebirth. The soul's essence is eternal and rebirth on earth - sooner or later - is guaranteed for every living being according ti their karma. The place to meditate on absolute universal justice and the immortality of your own true essence.

Not Quite What I Expected. Not sure what I expected to see but I found this a bit boring. The less important people are cremated on the right and the more proserous are cremated on the left. I did witness a ceremony where people were gathered around the body and could hear the cries of a woman mourning that I will never forget.

Hindu pilgrimage. One of the most pious place for the Hindus. No footwear allowed in and no photography inside. It is a cremation ground too and the remains are drooped in the river. Worth visiting to get a feel of the religious devotion.

Fascinating!. Including an open air crematorium where from across the sacred Bagmati river you can view cremations taking place. Our guide explained the process and answered all of our curious questions about the ceremony. Absolutely fascinating!

Closed, but.... The temple itself is not open to non-Hindus and is protected by high walls, but its setting on the sacred Bagmati River and the complex of minor temples, bathing ghats and crematory sites in its grounds make this an extraordinary place to visit. The final stages of the Hindu cremation take place in the open air on the river bank, from anointing the body, to setting the pyre alight, to cremation, to shovelling the ashes into the river and preparing a new funeral pyre.A home for the elderly sits adjacent to the crematorium with a huge, shifting pile of firewood outside. One wonders what the residents must think, being within sight, sound and smell of their eventual departure from this world?

No. 1 on my list. You just cannot miss Pashupatinath if you're visiting KTM.The temple in itself is a marvel. The huge nandi bull is awesome. But what took my breath away was the evening arti on the ghats of the river Bagmati. Simply mesmerising and one that will stay with you forever.

TRIP TO NEPAL. Nothing different from a usual trip to any holy renowned place of pilgrimage in India. It was so unorganized that one had serious doubts as to whether we were at a holy place or merely a place of attraction that symbolizes the spiritualism in nepal

Best Got Better.... Hindutva is What You Need To Be There... Nice Temple With Normal Affairs As Present in India...Religion is Enjoyed At Every Corner With Nice Shops For Rudraksh, Idols And Other Things..must

Just AMAZING!!!. What a day, I actually went back again! The temple is amazing, it is chaotic with people everywhere. If you are lucky you just might see a cremation. You can get a great photo with the Holymen, just be ready to hand over a small amount of cash. This is the only way they make money so they are more then happy to pose for a photo. If you tip nicely you may even get blessed!

Lives up to its claim. This is a world famous temple. It was featured in a few Hindi films.
There large Nandi here is breathtaking.
No matter how many days you stay here, ensure a visit here.
It is liberating.

Can be missed.... Went there hoping to see the temple but was turned away as it was only meant for Hindus only..
Paid R1000 and didn't see much.
There is a deer park there but saw no deers too..
Felt a little bit ripped off after the long taxi journey there …
Not really worth it.

Holiday. Wonderful temple, huge grounds to walk. Please be prepared to walk. Beware of monkeys. Beware of your belongings as well. Only Hindus are allowed into this temple as this is also where they cremate the dead.

Pashupatinath temple or Lord of Shiva. Pashupatinath Temple stands in the center of the town of Deopatan, in the middle of an open courtyard. It is a square, two-tiered pagoda temple built on a single-tier plinth, and it stands 23.6 meters above the ground. Richly ornamented gilt and silver-plated doors are on all sides.On both sides of each door are niches of various sizes containing gold-painted images of guardian deities. Inside the temple itself is a narrow ambulatory around the sanctum. The sanctum contains a one-meter high linga with four faces (chaturmukha) representing Pashupati, as well as images of Vishnu, Surya, Devi and Ganesh.The priests of Pashaputinath are called Bhattas and the chief priest is called Mool Bhatt or Raval. The chief priest is answerable only to the King of Nepal and reports to him on temple matters on a periodic basis.The struts under the roofs, dating from the late 17th century, are decorated with wood carvings of members of Shiva's family such as Parvati, Ganesh, Kumar or the Yoginis, as well as Hanuman, Rama, Sita, Lakshman and other gods and goddesses from the Ramayana.Pashaputi Temple's extensive grounds include many other old and important temples, shrines and statues. South of the temple, for instance, is Chadeshvar, an inscribed Licchavi linga from the 7th century, and north of the temple is a 9th-century temple of Brahma. On the south side of Pashupati temple is the Dharmashila, a stone where sacred oaths are taken, and pillars with statues of various Shah Kings. The Bagmati River, which runs next to Pashaputinath Temple, has highly sacred properties. Thus the banks are lined with many ghats (bathing spots) for use by pilgrims. Renovating or furnishing these sites has always been regarded as meritorious. Arya Ghat, dating from the early 1900s, is of special importance because it is the only place where lustral water for Pashupatinath Temple can be obtained and it is where members of the royal family are cremated. The main cremation site is Bhasmeshvar Ghat, which is the most-used cremation site in the Kathmandu Valley. The preferred bathing spot for women is the Gauri Ghat, to the north.

Burning ghats. We saw several funeral fires and a body draped in orange about to be put on one of the fires. Other fires were being raked out. There was not much water in the river, but more nearer the temple. Cows were lying on the former river bed. Some monkeys chasing around.A good view of people watching from the temple, holy men with bowls in front of them and offerings, families sitting around.It was quite dusty when we were there.

Spotless Place.. This place is a "Mini Varanasi", here is al the cremations take places, so be prepared to see that, and remember, that those are Hindi funerals, so be respectfull. To get here you can take a mini van from Rathnapark and ride with the locals for 15 rupees. Entrance Fee to the place is expensive $1.000 rupees.

Realize the value of Life. This temple is beautiful and meaningful in many aspects. One can learn about life from this place. It is so peaceful to stay at the top and watch the "Aarati- Reverence." Life is so busy yet peaceful. On the other hand, you can see the end of life here. The dead bodies are cremated here. This makes us realize the value of life: at the end, we are taking nothing with us. So live happily and spread happiness.

Not for the squeamish but a good cultural learning experience. This is a very important Hindu temple and crematorium. I would recommend that you acquire a guide unless you are already knowledgeable about this process. The small river actually is a tributary of the Ganges, important for Hindus. There will likely be bodies burning on the stands above the river but they are covered up - it is OK. You can not enter the temple area but are able to stand across the river from it and the ceremonial cremations. Walk up the hill behind you for a stunning hilltop view.

A very moving experience.. Wow! What an experience, for us a must see in Kathmandu. Entry, as everywhere, could have been cheaper, but the experience will live with us for a long time to come. Not exactly a lighthearted, fun experience, and it took us a while to come to terms with what we were seeing, but we both walked away thinking that this was a once in a lifetime experience.
great place to visit. this and Boudhanath were my favourite places to visit in Kathmandu, you can see the cremation ceremonies and take photos to real and not real sadhus, very nice experience.

A must visit. An interesting place to visit and a must on your list. I had the chance to witness a live cremation there ! A 5$ guided tour is recommended, the guides will approach you when they see you're a foreigner :p oh and did i mention you can take a picture with a Sadhu for 1$ :D

expensive and not pleasant. It was expesive (about 9-10€) for seeing the death burning. The smell is imposible to stand! Not pleasant at all and all three persons we visited had the same opinion. Also probably a black market on tickets as we asked by a guard to give him our tickets instead of payment.
Not to be missed. The best architecture and very lively place. Hindus can go straight to the temple while others can see it from the other side of the Bridge.

Interesting. This was a very interesting location. The fee to get in was the highest I paid: 1000 nrs for a westerner and the first time I learned about the "tour guide" problem for western (and female) tourists in Nepal. I had someone approach me who wanted to show me around all the sights. This was common in many of the other sights I went to see and I learned how to say a firm no (which in Nepal is essentially saying " I don't need". )As a non-Hindu, I could not enter the temple, but did see the rest of the complex. I went in the late afternoon, so I was the only westerner there. I would recommend going earlier if you are traveling solo.

Pashupatinath temple. Its a very important religious place for the hindu, unfortunately ppl arent allowed to click snaps around the temple premises, coz the architecture is simply awesome. Its somewhere close to the airport.The only thing u have to be careful of is ur belongings.

A visit with Sadhus. There is an area at the Pashupatinath temple where the Sadhus sleep, cook a meal and rest. It likely served as horse stables in the past, but are well suited for housing the humble Sadhu. There are two I like to chat with… one has lived at Pashupatinath for about 25 years. The other is an 86 year old Sadhu. He had a middle aged woman helping him. There are a couple of Sadhus who don't like to have they photos taken and they will make clear their objections.GJS
Sunset date. Just so calm and peaceful. You will feel happy and blessed. TRULY a rememberable day, i would want to visit here like everyday. Thank you Sanjiv for taking me here.
Must Visit. on the contrary to every one it is a clean place and the Deity has many healing powers a must for believers of God.

Intriguing architecture. This is a site of extreme religious importance for Hindu's. Unfortunately, non - Hindu's aren't allowed inside the temple. But the temple is a wonderful repository of unique architecture combining styles from South East Asia and India. The intricacy of the work is truly spectacular. Make sure you spend a few mins inside the Bhairav sanctum. Its a spectacular idol that truly brings out the aggressive form of Lord Shiva. Also, walk through the multiple Shiva linga maze which feels unique in its own way.

Heritage and Respect. The name compasses a lot of respect and the same is applicable to this great architectural beauty the moment you reach there. Filled with devotees from all around the world the breathtaking views of the temples just provides an icing to the cake. We were also quite lucky that the moment we reached the number of people were less and so we were able to view this great monument without hassle.

I fount it spiritual and religious . The significance of Pashupatinath I got to know, when I saw the crowd of Hindus there from Nepal and India. I felt Pashupatinath held great power within it. Its the place that Hindus into a single bond and makes us feel how important religion is for the unity of human race.  The temple has great architectural innovation the art on the doors and walls gives us glimpse of the detailed fine art that prevailed in ancient past So i recommend to all visit the heritage historical place

dont listen to those stupid people complaining about the price. some backpackers just want to get everything for free.... its not like that.....it cost 10usd but, its really interesting and if you TRY TO TAKE PICTURES in GANGES river in varanasi you ll get in trouble coz the police andthe scammers work together there to catch tourirsts trying to take pict of the cremationin kathmandu pictures are allowed.... if you just want to see and not take pics go to varanasi its much bigger ... but if u want to take pics go to this one in nepal
Pray. Went there often to pray and it is very very good place to spend morning for it has all the natural forest with animal which re fresh our mind and soul both at a same time.

Cremation. I had never seen cremation ceremony before, this was an eye opener for me. I enjoyed the cultural education provided by my excellent guide Dil but the pollution made my breathing challenging by times.
JUST AMAZING !!!. Very nice teme I have ever been . I become speechless to see the beauty of the temple . The temple is very famous among HINDU people. MUST visit once !!!

Well maintained place. The temple complex has been well maintained and clean. The area around the shoe collection point can be managed better. The management should control the priests from hounding the devotees to perform various puja.

temple visit on full moon day!. We had the fortune to worship the Lord of the Pasupathinath temple on full moon day during the third week of may14. It was a wonderful spiritual experience. We had an expert guide from Mac Travels & tours, Thamel, Kathmandu, who made our trip arrangement in expert manner

Exotic visit at its best. This is something that you won't get to see everyday. This temple is huge, and is the site for many festivals and celebrations. On one part of the temple grounds however is the cremation river, where bodies of the deceased are purified for the last time before being cremated.It is fascinating to see how other cultures grief and treat the subject of human mortality, and this was definitely both enlightening and unique for non-hindus.

Not Worth It. 1st time I came here is because people recommended this place to visit.Only take minutes from Thammel.Pay 1000 rupees each was to expensive.Otherwise ok, we just try.in front of the ticket box, there's a man who explain places that cannot take pictures.And then he follow us to all the places explain.Overall, this places is not really good to take a pictures.Because you cannot take picture in the temple. and here the surprise, that man who follow us was a guide (he didn't ask or introduce himself)and then asking 2000 rupees just to "guide" us.Come on, 4000 rupees to both of us, for just visiting this temple.Not worth it at all.

LORD SHIVA, LORD SHIVA and LORD SHIVA. There was NOTHING to dislike about this TEMPLE.For Non-HINDUs, the outer (larger)perimeter contains a plethoraof STATUEs, carvings and other HINDU paraphernalia.Remember, the average NEPALESE is quite honest and trustworthy- not so the souvenir shops and stall holders-you must BARGAIN with ALL sellers

Thought provoking. I didn't know what to expect, having read reviews describing the Cremation areas as "confronting and disturbing". I visited with my 25 year old daughter, and whilst the concept of sitting quietly watching the cremation formalities and rituals across a small canal seemed intrusional (and difficult to explain to others), we found it to be a thought provoking and contemplative experience. There are two cremation areas - basic platforms and "no frills" for commoners, and an area for more affluent people, with more ceremony and ritual.There was no sign of grief or drama, as the cremations seemed to be conducted more as a final formality and farewell before rebirth.A most worthwhile visit, which gives an enhanced understanding of local culture and thought. At no stage did our presence feel unwelcome or out of place - we were simply observers (amongst a few hundred others) quietly observing part of life's cycle.An important part of the Kathmandu "experience".
Ancient era comes alive.. Excellent temple which gives feel of anciant era. Excellent statues. Good facilties like water, restroom etc.

Serene. I regret not reaching the place earlier. It was my last day in Kathmandu and I reached temple at around 6:45 in the evening, time when temple was about to close and aarti (hindu prayers) was being sung. However, amidst the sound of aarti, jumping monkeys, people from vivid places I found the magical tranquility in the atmosphere. Pashupatinath temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and i definitely felt his presence there. I wish I could have stayed there longer.

Other Worldly. It is hard to describe this place, relaxing, sad, confronting? It will leave a lasting impression on you. Witnessing cremations and death so publicly is very alien from the way we deal with it in the west. For many this may be the first time you have seen dead bodies and it feels wrong to be taking photos and watching families experiencing grief. It is almost like a factory. Smoke wafts up from multiple funeral pyres. It takes 3hrs to burn a body and they get through 30 a day. The charred remains are just pushed into the river. There is the spiritual aspect too, gold robes, offerings etc - the whole place is drenched in traditions. The Sadhu's are great characters too. They will pose with you for photos for 10 or 15Rs. Spend some time here just to soak in the atmosphere, have respect for the mourners and don't be too intrusive.

arthi darsan. Pashupatinath Temple is a must visit for siva worshipers,this temple and ketharnath temple at utrakand india make the bull avatar of lord siva.half here,half there.if u have time visit for arthi darsan after 6pm,really enthralling experience,the puja and the crowd chanting mantras what an experience.there is a hanuman statue in front a rare sight,hanuman is usually found in vishnu temples.a big bull statue is awesome.don't miss 365 lingams in the compound.

Simply magical. Pashupatinath temple was one of the most important places for me in Nepal. The experience I had there was incredible, unforgettable, full of magic and amazing energy. I would like to go back as soon as I can and say hello not only to my new friends but also to some real Sadhus I've met there:))

X Rated Carvings. If you want to check out some of the most sexually explicit and downright bizarre carvings, make sure you have a close look at this temple in Bhaktapur's Durbar Square. Some reviewers have got this confused with the cremation site in Kathmandu which couldn't be more different. Guides will delight in showing you all sorts of sexual goings on carved on this wonderful Hindu temple.

My first Nepali temple!. This was the first temple I visited in Nepal. Lots of interesting people, and lots of cheeky monkeys! Very educational seeing real funerals and traditions here... an authentic experience of people and life. And some cute cows walking round too!
Moving. Felt odd watching something we consider private but was very eye-opening and well worth checking out.
impressive. Go not only to this place but also go to the in front of pashupatinath there is the mother theresia house for old people
Funeral Pyres. A strange experience. To western eyes, it felt like I was intruding on private grief, but obviously it is a public ceremony, so it's not really an intrusion. Quite moving.

Incredible. For European beeing first time in Asia way of dealing with death is strange and a bit shocking, burning bodies and families watching it from the other side of the river is definitely a "must see" when younare in Kathmandu

Worth a visit. Unfortunately can't go near / inside the temple unless you're Hindi. But the temple complex is large and it was really interesting to hear from our guide about the cremation ceromony and to actually see it happening. Very emotive. Heat was fierce mid April @ late morning - so plan accordingly + take water and a hat - there's no real shade. It's worth taking your time to stand and watch.

A Solemn and beautiful experience. I was fascinated by the ritual burning of dead people. It was beautiful but definitely made me look at my life; it is limited, and I don't know the day or time of my death.
Temple visit. Great place for uplifting your spirit in name of god.the complex is huge and has antique features.Its facinating.

very special place, recommend to go early morning or late afternoon. a very special place where you can see temples, body burning ceremony, meditation holes, monkeys, community of Baba (walking monks), or just take a walk in the woods. I'd recommend to go early morning, or late afternoon, when the sun is not empowering. It's worth spending a good half day just take it slow, please do note that there's no WC here, so come prepared!

Rich in culture and religion.. The place was rich in culture and religion. My taxi driver just brought me there and I enthusiastically bought my ticket and went in. However, I was not aware at first that it was the place where the dead were cremated. I found the place dull and filled with a lot of sadness. I was not prepared to see the deceased about to be cremated when I got there.

Pashupatinath Temple. Bustling area alive with monks, holy men, tourists and monkeys. The ghats show cremations at various stages. Decorated with marigolds and fragrant with the scent of incense. Not to be missed

Impressive and hard to take. While it is important to understand the role of cremation in the Nepalese culture, foreigners may find being suddenly thrust across from smoking pyres a bit hard to stomach. The monkeys wandering the grounds and impressive stupas all offer interest; the entire experience is overwhelming. While it is important to see, it is not necessarily fun to be the witness to these rituals.

a real slice of local life. People just going about there normal day with the cows, bull and monkeys, there's no place like it. Towards the back of the area away from the river is a quieter area. A must see as the largest Hindu temple in Nepal.

I learnt heaps this morning!. I was somewhat reluctant to visit this cremation site and Temple. I didnt wish to appear disrespectful to the grieving families but how wrong I was. I now understand loads more about the Hindu customs regarding the way they celebrate the life of their departed loved ones. I thoroughly enjoyed my morning visit during which I saw several different stages of the process.
pashupatinath. It's very important to visit this temple for Hindus.This was my 3rd visit. There were huge crowds but it is managed well now & could take the darshan from four doors easily.

Not much to see for 1000 rupees. If you have been to Varansi to see public cremations and Sadhu, this temple is not worth paying 1000 rupees. You are not allowed inside the Hindu Temple except for the grounds outside the temple. There wasn't much to see and we spent less than half hour wandering around. On the other side was one public cremation and a couple of Sadhus walking around.

A Fascinating Place. As you can read in the other reviews, this is a place that will spark a lot of thought and reflection. Yes, you do see bodies in various stages of the cremation process and you most likely will be able to view a funeral ceremony/ritual. We had a guide with us and he was vital to helping us understand each aspect of the process.We entered the site from the back and took the long steps up to the cremation view-point. I highly recommend this route as you can see the deer in the adjacent park; the monkeys all along the way; and the various shrines at the top of the stairs. Many folks who came from the other entrance missed this area.Note: You may wish to bring a breath mask or bandana along as the smoke from the cremations tends to blow right across the river.

horrible workers.... pushed us throughout. once we enter the temple the workers kept pushing us overlooking the age of the visitor .... old people children women ,,,,, the workers were very horribly behaved.....the temple is nice but they need to check on the staff there...

An eye-opener. I really did not fancy visiting a cremation site but how wrong I was. I came away with a far greater understanding and huge respect for the Hindu tradition. It is busy, there are lots of hawkers and tourists but there are also many local people just soaking up the atmosphere as we did.
Shiva temple. wow! I fell wonderful and totally blessed when i visited this temple..holy place nice artichect and sculpture..

Hindu Temple. This Hindu temple is quite a sight. Surrounding the temple, you will encounter monkeys, wandering cows, hawkers, the holy men and incense smell for starters. Then you will witness the Hindu cremation rituals. When you go up the first set of stairs be sure to stop and take photos behind you. The view is amazing and the best place. The ground tapers off past this point. The other best picture op is through the doorway of the line of temples open on all sides.

Not for the faint-hearted. If you don't want to see bodies being cremated in the open air then stay away. In the west we hide death behind curtains, in Nepal the don't and in Pashupatinath temple you get very much face to face with death.

Not too intresting. The entrance is quite high at 1,000 rupees and you cant go into the temple proper . You can only stand on the other side of the river to watch a funeral ceremony and the cremation which is next to the river which at the time of writing is dry. Better to go with a guide.

Very precious Hindu temple. Pashupatinath temple purely related to the Hindus is the holy temple for them. It is the temple indicating lord Shiva( The Destroyer) according to the Hindu epics. He had home here in the bank of Bagmati river so as it is also situated in the bank of Bagmati river. This temple is very old about 300 years old. You will also have to pay some entry fees to go inside. You can see the splendid artitecture of the temple and lies north east of Kathmandu
Interesting. Its a great temple, worth one visit, though lots of monkeys around! Some even took the chanas I was eating...ha ha. But enjoyed the visit...

Cremation ceremony up close and personal. I was surprised that the tourist ticket was really high compared to other places in Ktm but it was worth it! Go to where they do the cremation process. I was quite shocked at how close it was to the spectators. A guide I "accidentally" hired explained a lot of the history of the place, I think it was well worth-it.

Somewhat uncomfortable, but interesting. The temple itself can only be peered at from across the river - for non-Hindus that is. the cremations can be confronting, take a scarf with you to cover your face as the smoke will find you at some point! We wandered around for a while, went up the hill to the small little temples, it was fun to talk to the 'holy' men who will charge money to have a photo with you. Additionally we walked around the market, very colorful! Beware the friendly locals wanting to tell you all about it they are tour guides and expect to be paid, clarify a price before they lead you anywhere.
Well worth a visit.. Hindu sacred place. Shrines, temples and burial by the lake (the smell of the smoke was thick in the vicinity of the fires). But very interesting to see.

Temple & Bagmati River. We caught the taxi from Kathmandu to the town it cost 400 rupees and he dropped us of right at the ticket booth. Tickets are 1000 rupees each however you are no allowed into the temples unless you are hindu so you are left with walking around the streets and the opposite side of the river where the cremations take place. It is interesting to see the different rituals occur, there are lots of people offering guiding services too. There are plenty of sadhus in all sorts of colourful dress and body painting willing to have their photo taken. Please be respectful of the families mourning and don't take intrusive photographs. We walked to the next town to the Bodnaht Stupor & caught a taxi back to Thamel 500 rupees but it is possible to catch a local bus
Love it. I truly can say I enjoyed my visit over pashupati temple and get to know about modern nepalese fine arts

It felt like gate-crashing a funeral. I did not enjoy my visit. As a non-Hindu, I felt uncomfortable, for two reasons. Firstly, we are not allowed into the temple and it has to be viewed from outside, across the river. Truth said, there is not much to see other than a large structure, which is not as attractive as a number of others in & around Kathmandu. Secondly, there were a number of cremations going on, and apart from the fact that I have no desire to see one, it felt offensive to be spectators to such an intimate and sorrowful event.Thirdly, the surroundings are dreadful: the river Bagmati is horribly polluted with sewerage and general rubbish (smelly) and there are a number of mangy dogs lurking about (would they bite?). The buildings are not well looked after and the general ambiance is jaded and slovenly.Lastly there are a number of "sadhus" that loiter about looking very grand in all their finery and painted faces, extorting money from foreigners to have their photos taken. They didn't strike me as the real thing at all (and I have heard that indeed they aren't!). Just for show!I appreciate that this is a Hindu holy site, and thus respect the way they maintain its function. I feel the whole site should be closed to foreigners. Don't leave us to be gawkers treating it as a sight-seeing opportunity.

Temple and outdoor crematorium. It's hard to explain this place.The first thing you do is to pay 1000 rupees (around 10$) to get in. It's a high price because non-hindus can not get into the temple, but if you surround it and go towards the river, you will see the crematory in the middle of the river. Outdoor crematorium where tourists pay to get in, is in itself, a bit extreme.When we went there were seven or eight funeral pyres. Some were finishing, other ones were just arriving. The smell, the river, the fire... everything is shocking.We went with young kids, and of course we had to explain before reaching the place, and of course during the staying. I have to say it was a very good conversation with my daughter.
Very interesting. I have never been to a temple area like this before, it is worth seeing. I will not spoil it for you.

wow. what an exposure to another culture, Cremations, Holy Men, Stoned Yogi's, you are right on the river and amongst the locals watching various stages of cremation. Its listed as a World Heritage Site

An interesting experience. This is such an experience and I can't really explain how I felt visiting it. Because in my own culture cremations and burials are very private affairs, I felt a little like a intruder into other people's grief. The ritual wailing of the women before the cremation was rather disturbing to me and it felt somewhat disrespectful to be wandering amidst so many families grieving for loved ones as they were being cremated right there in front of my own eyes.Trusting that it was not disrespectful to the Hindu people (after all I'd been charged Rs1000 to go in and wasn't even asked not to take photos) I walked round the large site trying to take in as much of this interesting culture as I could. There were monkeys running around and cows roaming freely amongst the tourists and the mourning relatives of the deceased. The architecture and the history was fascinating.Some of the young guides were a little insistent, but I did manage to persuade all 4 of the persistent young men who approached me, that for me this was more of a spiritual experience for which I appreciated having my own thoughts, and for whom only I could be my particular guide. Having said this, I'm sure these guides are very knowledgeable.Certainly an interesting experience, though, due to the cremations, not one that everyone can stomach.

Worth a visit. This is one of only a few Hindu temples we visited .. the rest mainly being Bhuddist. It is very interesting to see .. especially the bit near the river which is used for cremations and also checking out the row of towers which have been aligned in a row so you can look straight through. The only downside is that compared to other places of worship it is pretty dirty and given you have to remove your shoes to enter that does kind of put you off.

A must for every Hindu!. Visited Nepal in Nov 2013. The main reason for the visit was the divine and holy Pashupatinath Temple. A very huge and beautiful main temple with smaller temples of different gods and goddesses around it. It is situated on the banks of the holy Bagmati river which is regarded as the Ganga of Nepal. Many rites and rituals are performed here on the banks of the river. The main deity Shri Pashupatinath is a big and totally divine Shivalinga with four heads.The early morning and evening Arti is another major attraction. An extremely holy and spiritual experience, not to be missed.A place i would love to visit again and again.Bam Bam Bhole!
Breathtaking Experience. The history, flags, and beauty make this a must see location. Say a prayer and photograph a few monkeys.

huge temple. being told that it is the biggest hindu temple in asia?its a temple where most hindus will be cremated can see relatives are moarning for their deceased family member. and its also a place of the huge hindu temple in kathmandu

A place of great devotion. So much to take in at this temple, from the cremations, the worship, the amazing atmosphere, the monkeys running along the roof tops, the cows freely wondering around, .....there is so much to take in that a lengthy visit is necessary to get the most out of it.
A Temple. Good place. Same like most Hindu temples. It is a crowded place. It will pleasure to see the historical value of this place a part from getting in to temple to worship!!
Not my thing. I went because I was fed up with people telling me it was the best place to visit. I found it voyeuristic and tragic. Never again.
Impermanence. This is a good place to see the law of nature and culture of the Indian people in Nepal. Instead of the going to Varanasi in India, this is a place to visit on a much smaller scale.

A Beautiful Temple of Lord Shiva. This temple complex is very big and Beautiful,and worth seeing .The temple like all other famous temples has a lot of security, due to the crowd they hardly let you see the deity even for a few seconds,I wish I could have spent some more time inside the temple.We had done a pooja there which was quite nice but this is not done inside the temple but outside.and they give a mala of panchamukhi Rudraksha as prasad.

An atmosphere you wont find anywhere else!. We found this sunset visit simply amazing! So much going on- singing, drums, burning bodies- lots of pilgrims. The hospice just above the ghats was touching. We felt very privileged to see an alive temple with everyone doing their thing! The time of day added to the mystery but it got dark before we could see everything. We were able to see the back of the bull (not being Hindu) and walk around most of the complex. We were befriended by a student who became our most competent guide and even walked us back to our hotel! Images and an atmosphere we will never forget....

A real experience but ..... Very pleased to visit the place again after eight years, it still has it's special atmosphere but what a pity the government decided to ask an entry fee of 1.000,- Nepalese roupies !!

Jawdropping!. I was on a planned tour with a terrific local guide who talked me thru this large area, certain areas foreignors cannot enter but walking around the temples is enlighting, then he asked if I wanted to go to the crematorions, which it didn't dawn on me, until walking down the hill and seeing the bellowing smoke below. Then I laid my eyes on 5 areas that were actually doing the cremations, and couldn't believe that this very private procedure back in the US is done out in the open, many onlookers from the opposite bank, able to take photos; no words to describe this, have to see for yourself.After seeing this I was a little more prepared when I reached the River Ganges, in Varanasi India the next day and saw the same but closer.Very interesting and compelling to say the least.

same complex as the crematorium. It is a nice temple structure but there is just too much for the senses- visually you have live cremations to view, kids begging, hawkers selling trinkets, Holy men posing for pictures for donations- bottom line for me is that i don't think that a families grief and surrounding ceremonies are meant for tourists with cameras.
A Haunting Place. This is a strange one... For us we felt as though we were intruding on a very personal time of grief. However.. it's a compelling place to see how other cultures deal with death.

A great couple of hours. A lot has already been said about this place and I would recommend this as part of a 1 day or half day visit when you combine it with Bouda Stupa which is only 30 mins walk away. This will give you and insight into 2 religions - Hindu and Buddha

Dont miss the ghat behind the temple. A calm and serene place where you can the last journeys of the people. The old structures around, a small jungle at the back, the holy atmosphere adds to the aura of the place.

Confronting cremations of Pashupatinath. I had heard about the cremations at Pashupatinath so had tried to prepare myself for it. The first thing to assualt the senses was the sight of an amusement park that is on the grounds. The large swinging pirate boat seemed strangely out of place. Perhaps this wouldn't be as real as I thought.You enter through a large gate that then becomes a largish path that winds its way up to the actual crematoria site. And yes it gets real. Passing by the sadhus etc, you come to the river where at any time of the day people can bring their relatives who have passed away to be cremated. There are platforms along the river where after ritual bathing/cleansing of the body the fires can be lit and the bodies can begin their reduction to ash. Its confronting to be so intimate in a strangers life as you see them grieving. But the process is highly ritualised and peaceful. The temple is filled with cows, and beggars and sadhus and grieving relatives, and a general sense of peace. You cannot enter the Hindu temple itself but are allowed to peer in, and can catch a glimpse of the extremely large testicles of a golden bull. Take the time to really see the whole site and appreciate all of the rituals that are happening. from the sons honouring their fathers deaths yearly, to the pilgrims coming to the biggest Hindu temple in Asia, to the locals digging pennies out of the ashes. For a site dedicated to death it is full of life and visually explosive.

A real eye-opener. Before visiting Pashupatinath I was concerned that it was using death and grief as entertainment for tourists. I needn't have worried and I'm now very glad I have been there. For a start, the whole approach to the temples is lined with a multitude of stalls seeling offerings. Hindus vastly outnumber tourists, and although the ghats are used for cremation, there is no intrusion upon the rituals and a good distance maintained between grieving families and ordinary visitors. The most sacred temple is reserved for Hindus only but the whole vast complex can be seen from the hill on the opposite side of the river so that you can begin to undertand how it all works. It is a quite extraordinary place.

Ash to ash..... Firstly, the main sanctuary is prohibited to non Hindu. You can only stand at the main entrance. Photos at the entrance is permitted but not the inside. So, I may be at the most holiest place for Hindu but I can't get in.If you can stomach to witness the funeral of the Hindu, then one may stay on. I will not elaborate on what I witnessed.
