Let's just stay its different and may be a wee bit primitive but it's their culture.

Extraordinary!. The whole area around the temple is an assault to all of your senses. The structure is a sacred Hindu temple with worship to Shiva. Surrounding the temple, you will encounter monkeys, wandering cows, hawkers, the Sadhu Babas and incense smell for starters. Then you will witness the 24/7 cremations. The whole thing is a mindblower. Advice is to be with a knowledgeable guide who can explain Shiva, the temple, the cremation rituals etc. If you can find our guide, Probin, get him - fantastic.A word of advice. People in our group and problems with their eyes with all of the smoke etc. You should tote some eye drops.Will never forget this experience.

A must-see. Non-hindues are not allowed inside the temple sanctuary, but there is plenty of interesting things to see in the area surrounding it. This was one of the high-lights of our trip to Nepal and I would recommend to make this a high priority on your agenda if you are in the vicinity.

Unexpected. I was fascinated by the sight of the cremations - it sort of helped understand the religious core of Nepal that I'd observed over the previous days exploration of the Kathmandu valley. It was so worth going even though my guide was a bit dubious about taking me, I hadn't expected to see real cremations and to be honest it didn't feel too intrusive. You must not visit Kathmandu and miss this.

So different to be. A surprising monument. Temples, river, burning of dead people, monkeys, people to search for money into the ashes of dead, cows, holy people and so many more. For me it was more surprising even from Khajuraho in India. Nepal in General was a nice surprise.

An old age temple for Hindus only. Situated close to airport this temple has restricted access to Hindu religion follower only due to the belief imminent from centuries.River Bagmati flows next to the temple.Visit it during morning or evening hours (before sunset) to enjoy the overall architecture.
Impressive and heartrending. This Temple reminds us of our temporary stay here on earth.This visit was both heartwarming and heartrending.

Ancient Hindu holy site. We came with guide (I recommend it) on Lord Shiva Day with 700,000 pilgrims from near and far. Foreigners not allowed in the temple itself but the whole scene, river with cremations, ash-smeared naked saddhus, immense throngs waiting on line from 3 AM, food and info. booths, amusement rides, crowds of all classes, dressed up, devoted and having fun. Really a must.

Hindu symbol. Got a different and nice vibe when I went there. Lots of people, monkey and intersting architecture. The temple area is huge and the vicinity itself has numerous temples, all of them are ancient, so i felt I went to the ancient settlement and the government has preserved the old houses in and around the temple.

The most important site in Kathmandu!. This temple is a fascinating insight into Hindu culture and customs. Non-Hindus cannot enter the main temple, but the grounds of the temples are beautiful in itself.Make sure to visit Mother Theresa temple, which is now a shelter for the elderly. For a true insight into Hindu culture get close to the funeral pyres but be warned that for some it can be a bit overwhelming. Make sure to take in the views from the other side of the river.

Fascinating. We took a guided tour of the temple and that was a wise decision. The temple complex houses many interesting things (apart from the Shiva temple) like Hindu crematorium - always busy - home for the aged, a Hospice, a cornea retrieval centre (!!), music academy and so on. There is an "Aarati" (worship) of the river Bagmati -held every night - that was fascinating to watch.

Magnificient Temple, Must see. Unlike other hindu temples, the architecture of Pasupathinath Temple is like a pagoda temple.The shrine is also very different from other shivlingas. The first thing you notice while entering the shrine is a mighty golden statue of a bull or Nandi. Behind the statue of Nandi, is the four headed Shiv Ling.There are other temples of Ganesha, Bhairavnath, Durga, Narayana with in the shrine.I did not expect that burning rituals are also done within the same premises by the side of baghmati river.Overall it is a divine experience.

Beautiful Temple Visit. Visited the Pashupatinath Temple as part of our Kathmandu site-seeing tour, and definitely worth visiting. After experiencing the quirkiness of The Crematoria, it was nice to wander round this temple and enjoy the colours, sounds and smells. One of the most popular tourist attractions in KTM and quite busy.

Must see in KTM. History, religion, life and death, happiness and tears, everything mixed in one place. One of the holiest Hindu temples world wide, most important for Nepal, is not accessible for non-Hindu people. This doesn't matters. You can see hundreds of small temples around, mingle and discuss with people. Visit elderly people home, take a photos or mingle with Sadu's, 3-4 hours minimum visit

Very interesting place. Westerners are not allowed inside, so I just strolled around the outside. I got to see a hindu cremation ceremony taking place, which was truly fascinating. One of the locals explained me the meaning of the whole ritual and steps of the process. Despite the badly english, i understood and it kind of really made sense too. The river was dirty but it was something I already knew through my research before the travel. there is this small white temple across the river and a bit further into the woods, which I am glad I discovered. It was sort of deep vibe and I felt very much in peace with myself, if you know what i mean.
Rai. Good to see rubbish than any other part of the world.Smells burning human flesh even your 1000 mitre away. Can’t believe how people of Kathmandu manage to spend their lives in such a condition.

MUST-DO in Kathmandu. This experience was the BEST in Kathmandu. The only thing, it's easy to get ripped off. There are many frauds hanging out around the temple, ready to offer tourists a *deal*. Actually, never follow those people. We made that mistake the first time. The second time, we went without a *tour* guide. We went at exactly the right time on a Wednesday evening and got to go inside the temple and pray, not just struggle from a peephole. We saw all four faces of Pashupatinath and received His own flowers from His heads. Then we saw the holy saint Aadhi Shankara's shoes and Shiva lingas from different places. Amazing.

Shivaratri festival. P. Fascinating is the only way I can describe my experience last Thursday the 27 th. Feb. so many Sadhus smoking pot ( illegal but allowed for the festival). Hindus making puja to the gods in the shrines and temples and then down to the river to watch the goings on, listen to music, wander among the sadhus and get their blessings if willing to pay. Not being a Hindu we could not enter the temple of Shiva but we were able to wander around the many shrines. We came in from the back, across the river from the temple and went in the morning when the crowds were not bad. Returning early afternoon was frightening, with crowds pushing both ways up the stairs. A friend went in the evening and there were huge crowds then too.We also saw a cremation as they take place on the river near the temple.

incredible experience. Some may find the open cremations a little hard to handle but it truly is an incredible experience to see this very important temple in the hindu culture. Go with a guide just before sunset and take it all in.

Worth a visit. Non- Hindu's cannot go inside the temple but you may roam the grounds. The price for admission was slightly pricey and there are plenty of hagglers (with any tourist site in Kathmandu) but while culturally shocking (open air cremations), it is certainly worth a visit. There are also good photo ops with the Sadus

Ancient temple and crematorium. i went to this place with a tourist guide who explained me in details all about the temple. At a first glance it was not really interesting for me because is not really well preserved, however after understand how old is it and the meaning of it my perception changed completely. I was able to observe the cremation and the ceremony before it. Next to the place an hospital is located where patients in palliative care are sent to be closer to the holly river.There is a toilet facility (not really good) exclusively for tourist. The entrance fee is quite expensive for Nepal (1000 NR) but is a must see place in Kathmandu.

Must see - a key Hindu temple in Nepal. A good place for a contemplative few hours. Pashupati is one of the main Hindu temples (if not the biggest) in Nepal. It is also the center of funerary rites with, it seems, river-side cremations going on all day / every day.Very crowded with the faithful from all over the country and presumably beyond. Rather fewer tourists - felt rather out of place here, surrounded by celebrants and mourners, but nevertheless was not made to feel an outsider.Recommended.
Beware of the monkeys. Visited Pashupatinath after 6 pm, in the middle of a shower, barefoot. Beautiful temple and great 'darshan'. But we also had to watch out for monkeys and stray cattle.

A temple and a crematorium. Whilst non Hindu's are not allowed into the temple (as is the case with all Hindu temples in Nepal) you will still be able to enjoy the structure from the outside and you will definitely be allowed to the river where bodies are cremated by their loved ones. Whilst there we got to witness a cremation in progress, we observed the dipping of the feet in holy water, the placement of the body by family members onto the wood pile , etc. Also as it was an official who was being cremated, the military was out in force to pay their respects, fully decked out in uniforms with gun salutes. Though we did not stay for the full proceedings, it was an experience.

The biggest holy temple Nepal. Pashupati Nath, the biggest holy temple in Nepal that I found as big as it in any places around the country. The place is very beautiful thousands of devotee Hindu people being in queue to get it to the temple to offer their ritual. I strongly recommend to visit this site otherwise your Nepal visit would stil incomplete.

Hindu Mythology - Well Maintained. Its a great temple and has a lot of relevance as per the hindu mythology.This is a must visit temple. Beware of the touts who will try to indulge you in poojas for some small amount, but ultimately, touting you for a good amount that can regret of.
21-23 Feb 2014. This is my second visit and I feel very blessed as I was able to see the all the 4 faces of Shivalingga very blessed for getting this experience. Tq Lord Shiva

not to be missed. if u r touring kathmandu this is something u shouldnt miss..full ancient god cravings and gives a peacefull feeling..can hire a guide outside the temple for around 500 to 700 rupees which will be of immense help if u r not in a tour group

The sacred temple of Hindus. Likes: The structure of the temple and the faith of people coming there to worship lord Shiva. Moneys of course, but have to be careful with them.Dislikes: Too much of crowd. Bad arrangement to leave your slipper/shoes outside before entering into the temple. Rest room floor is not dry (Of course i know that i expect a little to much) LolOther Points:1. You can see hindu's final ritual for death. 2. February 27 or some day in last two weeks of February is a festival of "Shivaratri". Could be good time for you if you want to experience the madness of people to worship the lord. If not, better check the nepali calendar before going there.3. Also Mondays, are not suggested if you cannot stand in crowd.

Zabojad Resham Firiri Tour 2014. An unforgettable historic site in Kathmandu City Center that allows you to cross some Intouchable saint Sadhu's that are waiting for you to pray for you and take a souvenir picture of your visit.

Worth a look . This place is worth a look if you have time. Lots of guides with haggle you so be firm from the beginning or they will follow you around the whole complex.
Some good photo ops with the dressed up men in orange! 'Namaste'

The Sadhus are entertaining characters. Only born Hindus are allowed into the actual temple itself (which looked amazing through the cracks). Foreigners are allowed around the back where the burning ghats are located. We witnessed three cremations, and a fourth deceased person was bathed with the river water. That was emotional to watch. And also distancing as it all just seems part of life to the locals. The Sadhus perched high on the other side of the river are entertaining characters and worth the few dollars they charge to allow their photo to be taken and to receive a blessing. My interaction with the Sadhus was a highlight of the Temple. A fantastic temple, well worth a look, even if it is just the outside for non Hindus. (I understand their desire to worship in peace without all the tourists taking photos).

Atmopsheric and Interseting. This temple offers a fascinating insight into Hindu culture and customs. The Temple complex itself is quite beautiful. Although non-Hindus cannot enter the main temple, you can stand my the door and peer at the giant golden bull inside.There are various little temples and pavillions around which you can go in, including the five-pointed Mother Theresa temple, which is now a shelter for the elderly. You can get up close to the funeral pyres if you wish... Though this is not for everyone, it can be an interesting cultural experience. I would recommend taking a guide as they can explain more about Hinduism and the temple's history if you are interested. Though don't pay more than $10 (bargain this down if you can).There is a small bridge which offers good views along the river, and on the other side of it some steps leading to the Bodnath Stupa. If you face the bridge then turn left past the funeral pyres in front of the temple, you will reach the meditation caves. One of them is known as the "Jimi Hendrix cave" as it's apparently where Hendrix lived for a while. My guide said there is a celebration of Hendrix there every Sunday from 2pm onwards, not sure if this is true though?

Avoid Mondays !!!. A very nice temple ...but just avoid Mondays and Saturdays.There are lots of pandits around to do your pujas.I just did the darshan and they dont rush you through. You can take your time.There are monkeys around (huge ones) and some even are bold enough to jump on your shoulder !!!Walk to the temple from the front gate.Do not enter from the back (your driver may use that road) as you will see the Ghats where they cremate the bodies...

Different views for different people. My husband did not mind the cultural shock so he took photos and videos. Even paid the older guys in costumes to take their photos.For me, I was glad I didn't take a big breakfast that day. For me, I guess only 10 min would be enough (but consider that not cheap fee.....)For my teenage-daughter, I guess she wouldn't have enjoyed it.

A must-see. Warning - only Hindus are able to enter the temple, so you may not see as much as you hoped. there are ample grounds to walk around though. go with a a guide to give you the history and tell you what it is all about.

Expensive ticket fee. Cremation ghat. Emotion guaranty. Except the expensive foreigner ticket fee and the tourist guides all around, the place is great to see some hindu ceremonies, cremations and rituals. The holy water is so dirty, black and smelling so bad. Maybe with the support of tourism the hindu community can clean the site more often. It is a shame to see all those garbage thrown everywhere.

Love the Sadhu's. Visited in the afternoon with my driver as guide. I headed straight to the cremation side and I got goosebumps watching that. Funny thing was it was separated into 2 - one for poor/middle class while the other side for the rich people. Walked up and saw the Sadhu's, and I started clicking pictures while they were posing for me. Luckily they didn't charge me.Will revisit in one of the festivals

Important Hindu site. The main draw to this temple is it's significance in Hindu culture. It was not visually spectacular, and non-Hindus cannot get very close to the temple. Though it is interesting to see the temple and the cremations at the river, showing an important part of Nepali culture. There were some monkeys too.

Expensive entrance fee with limited access. Perhaps it's the fact that this is where Hindu funeral and cremation takes place so publicly that makes it feel uncomfortable, coming from a place where funeral is a private affair. The entrance fee is also very steep at 1000 rupees and there is additional fee if you want to go inside the temple (only for Hindus).

amazing. It is amazing to visit this place, to see what the culture of the cremations is. I also felt little uncomfortable because it is a place to where people are saying goodbye to loved ones, so you have to be beware of this.It's really nice to have a look at the temple, it really looks amazing, but for Westerners it's not allowed to go inside the temple

for a spiritual you. Considered to be one of the most important temples dedicated to Lord Shiva is a holy destination for Hindus. It also is one of the UNESCO world heritage sites. Located on the bank of river Bagmati in kathmandu in one of the busiest areas of the city, it is easily accessible by all sorts of public and private transportation system. Though the main temple permits only Hindus inside but the premises around are open to people from all the religions and the atmosphere is spiritual enough for everyone regardless of religion. The place might seem chaotic in the first look but there is a different kid of peace among the chaos, the nagas and the yogis sitting all around the temple, the old ladies sitting in groups and singing, the pigeons, monkeys and cows, the hustle- bustle is one of a kind. There are shops around selling prasad and stuffs like rudraksha and pearls but I would advise everyone to be careful while buying such stuffs ensuring that it's original stuff and don't hesitate to bargain. So, Pashupati has got something for everyone it's a place full of goodness and positive vibes and an experience one of it's kind !
Great Temple. For you, its also the main attraction to visit for your experience. YOu also can find local guide who can take care you for a day. But its very crowded if you go for festival time.
World Heritage. One of the holy shrine for Hindu religion. This temple is based on Shiva God, Most visited place by all the tourist.

Brief 5 Minutes when the Door opened. The Temple gate opens for 5 minutes at 2pm. We were hounded by the local Panda( Pundits) for performing Havan and Pooja. All it helped in was putting us third in the row and avoid long queue which formed quickly and many could not see the Deity as the gates closed in 4 minutes. Great place worth a visit for Shankara Bhaktas. Could have been cleaner and without the middlemen.

A moving place. My wife and I were struggling with whether to visit or not, but we found the temple grounds to be well kept (better than many places in Kathmandu - and restoration is ongoing under the auspices of UNESCO) and the experience of seeing these cremation ghats does give one pause, but was very moving nonetheless. If you don't plan on going to Varanasi or other sacred Hindu sites, this is a manageable and interesting place to spend an hour. Also, close to the airport, so very convenient.

Positive vibes and relaxing mind. After cancellation of my Lukla flight, I got a chance to visit Kathmandu city and been to Pashupatinath temple. Temple is very big and is easily approachable being at city center. Temple architecture represents monastry style.Photography is prohibited to capture temple structures and surroundings.

Its a must see place. The biggest and most important hindu temple, the cremation place for all hindus. Its a fascinating place. The architecture of the temples are beautiful. Monkeys monkeying around. Bells ringing. Sadhus (holy men) in their attire, some even with mobile phones :). You will not get bored here.Although sad, watching the cremation ritual from the viewing place opposite the temple is quite fascinating. Don't forget to look at all those shivalingas built in a straight line. Its beautiful.The only annoying thing is they charge foreigners nearly $10 when they can't even go into the temple!! Rip off I'll say.Overall, must see.

crematory. This was a very mystical and spiritual place to visit. We were there during a few of the ceremonies and it was worth seeing and experiencing the death ritual. It commanded quite and respect.

''very positive vibes when you reach inside temple ''. visiting kathmandu my main intension was to visit pashupatinath temple i felt very positive after i did puja and attended aarti in evening hours no camera or taking pics is allowed one of the hindus most dhaarmic places to visit

Unpleasant yet interesting nonetheless. This is a holy site and the oldest hindu temple in Katmandu. Seeing so many dead bodies and the cremation wasn't a pleasant sight but i guess it was an interesting experience non the less. What i found more fascinating are the sadhus (people with the paint on their face). They make you pay a "donation". i gave them 100 rupees and took multiple photos with them. I also enjoyed the view from the top which you can go up the stairs if you would like. The entrance fee is 1000rupees.

important Hindu temple with ghats. A World Heritage Site, travelers cannot visit inside the Hindu temples, but most probably, you can witness the cremation of some bodies. For Westerners, this may be shocking, but this is the cycle of life.

Large and Active Temple. Another of the must see temples in Kathmandu. The temple is still active and very larger. There is a lot to see and photograph here.On average they cremate 30 bodies a day here, so you will most likely see a funeral in process. Other parts of the temple have very historical and cultural significance.I enjoyed walking around at our own pace taking photos and admiring the history. You will get plenty of exercise here.
Love it. Must visit, like the Sadhus there. Temples, Sadhus, visitors, beggars, a different sight. Look left or right, your eye will catch something exciting.

The Holy Temple. There is a holy river, holy man, holy cow and there is a deer park. we saw many activities there, people pray, a cremation for the dead people, washing the dead body in the holy river. very interesting there

Know the culture. As others have mentioned, foreigners are not allowed to enter the temple. So go around to the river side to view the cremations, visit with the "sadus" (holy men"), watch the monkeys, etc. One can still get a lot of good photo ops from this side.

A must see for Kathmandu. No visit to Kathmandu is complete without visit to this temple, of course, for the religious minded, it is a must. Pashu means animals. Lord of animals is the literal meaning. Lord Shiva is the ruling diety. You can buy rudraksh beads from the shops nearby

Spiritual. Visited there as a part of organized sightseeing tour. Seeing the dead bodies being burnt invoked strange feeling. 4 stars because it could have been kept a little more cleaner. A must visit if you're interested in some Hindu traditions.

Interesting, not for everyone. This was a large, unique Hindu temple. Non-Hindus are not allowed in the inner temple area but are allowed to walk the grounds, view part of the inner temple area from above, and witness the live cremation ceremonies. There were four live cremations happening when we visited, and it was interesting to witness. Honestly, though I was behaving respectfully and dressed modestly, I did not blend into the crowd here and felt noticeably more conspicuous here than at any of the other temples or sites that I visited in Nepal. I did not find the people friendly and left earlier than I normally would have. Admission is a steep NRP 1000 for non-SAARC tourists. Recommend with reservations.

Amazing. Ancient temple with beautiful diety of Lord Shiva. Unique with 4 faces. Wonderful to watch the performance of Arathi by the priests from South India. Misterious sculptures. Wish I had some to explain the meaning and purpose of those sculptures.

Visit to Pashupatinath. This Temple is one of the 12 Jyotirlingas which has importance in Hindu religon. On second day of our arrival in kathmandu, we visited this temple. It was crowded, but not as much was expected. There is a facility to keep your shoes at Shoe counter. The temple has a unique archtectural touch & one can take darshan from all four sides of temple. If you are visitng kathmandu, you must visit this temple.

A treat to eyes. it has been place of desire for me as a shaivite and also as an explorer. the temple is really old and truly deserves the UNESCO heritage site tag. The compund is huge, clean and friendly.

Interesting place!. Although the temple looks impressive from across the river it is a shame that non Hindus are not allowed inside. Probably the most interesting aspect of this place are the live cremations taking place right infront. It felt a bit odd witnessing these but it was a fantastic experience of something that we never actually see in the west.

Hindu Funeral Rites. This very important Hindu temple is also the location of Hindu funeral rites for those who live in Kathmandu and, if you were raised Christian and know little of that religion's ceremonies, it is very eye opening. After you pay the entrance fee, you walk along the Bagmati River toward the temple itself. The other side of the river is where loved ones are washed and cremated after death. For me it felt as if I was watching something extremely personal and I was hesitant to take photographs. My guide, Vishnu, grabbed my camera and had no problem with it. As we walked along he described the process to me. Because the Bagmati is considered a holy river, shortly after death, families take the body to be washed in the river (slightly up from the cremation site) and then cremated. In general, only males are allowed to wash the body and attend the cremation. The oldest son walks around the body three times with the priest as it lays on the pyre. Then, with the assistance of the priest, he starts the fire from the mouth of the deceased (I assume an accelerant of some time type is involved). The family and friends stay while the priest attends the body as it burns. I felt very culturally ignorant to know so little about Hindu ceremony and, even though I was uncomfortable, I wanted to understand. As we walked along, Vishnu asked me about Christian ceremonies and when I described the 2-3 days we view the body at a funeral parlor, HE was clearly uncomfortable, but interested himself in knowing more. This site is really fascinating and moving, but prepare yourself to deal with things that you may find disturbing to watch. There is a smell involved and over time for me, the combination of that with simply dealing with death itself made me not want to linger. On the lighter side, you can have your photo taken with the Hindu holy men that are at the site. One of my favorite photos from Nepal is with two of these men; one of whom was a real card! The temple is further down, and as with all of these temples, only Hindus can enter. I'm glad that I didn't miss this; it gave me a personal window into Nepali life.

Erotic Carvings in the Pillars. I think some of the reviewers here are lil bit swapped between Pashupati Temple of Bhaktapur and Pashupati of Kathmandu. Although it is the replication of Pashupati Temple of Kathmandu.But the most thing I can remember from the Pashupati Temple of Bhaktapur is it has 24 carvings of erotic scenes in its roof pillars. I am not sure, whether Pashupati Temple of Kathmandu has the same thing or not, since I never enter the temple. Only Hindu can enter Pashupati Temple of Kathmandu.I do believe that Pashupati Temple of Bhaktapur, is one of the most unique and visited in that town ...

The saddhus and cremations are really different. Get your photo taken with a colourful saddhu for a few rupees. Literally watch a real cremation take place. Its like nowhere else. But not for everyone.

PEACE AT PASHUPATINATH TEMPLE. This is one of the most important places in the world, and we're terribly lucky to be allowed to set foot into these sacred places.It's very large, so allow plenty of time, wear sunscreen and drink plenty of water. Be sure to rest often during your visit and let the ambiance soak into your being.

Living heritage. If you want a taste of Nepali Hindu heritage and culture, this is the place to be. This is one of the holiest places for a Hindu. However, non-Hindus are allowed in most areas except the temple proper. As you go in from the main gate, you will encounter a lot of bulls - don't freak out, they are harmless; bulls are sacred to Hindus and devotees feed these bulls. If you don't want the hassle, don't enter the main complex, but walk to the back. You will get to see numerous small temples adorned with traditional Newari architecture. As an added attraction you get to see the Hindu crematorium. The traditions and practices here haven't changed for hundreds of years so soak it up as much as you can.

Supreme Holy Spot. One of the largest Hindu Temple in Nepal. Not allowed to visit inside the Temple for Non-Hindus religion but wide place to explore around. Cremation, Sadhus, Holy Rivers, Forest are the another attraction beside main Temple. It charges Rs. 1000.00 per visitor which cost about US$ 12.00 current value. Easy to access and nearby Airport.

Must Go Place!!!. It is a very religious place, hindu all over the world come to this place to have the blessing of Lord Shiva, who is the symbol of life and death. No where one can have a peace like this place...its internal peace. There are so many shiva lingas and the area is quite big one can spend the whole day going around the Pashupatinath area. If you are travelling to Nepal, it's a must to go place.

A place to pray. The temple complex is large and a gives breathtaking view. Guides there are very informative and give a running guide on the do's and donts as well as explanations on the various deities that are installed in the temple. Overall it was a worthwhile trip to the temple and i fully recommend it to one and all

Great Temple. One of the important Hindu Temple to visit. Its one of the main attraction for Hindus (Indians) to visit Kathmandu. We had good darshan of the main deity from all the 4 different directions. There are some monkeys around inside, so please watch out if you carry some eatables in hand.
Too Crowded,Tourist trap. Not worth it as the temple is too crowded and not properly maintained considering it is a world heritage site.

Hindus Only!. Only Hindus are allowed to enter and they are very strict with the no photography rule. I'm a Hindu and the only thing that left me dissatisfied was the lack of any information around the temple at all. Also, don't bow your heads to get blessings from everyone who offers it as usually, they are more interested in ripping you of your money. By the side, there are 125 small lingas which is nice. Also, there is a big linga served by rather young priest-clad youths. They insisted on doing a special puja for the more "affluent-looking" tourists and demanded 5000rupees per person thereafter. Just try not to get your Pashupathinath experience ruined by such happenings.

Do not miss coming here. This is the Varanasi of Nepal. It is a little strange watching a funeral and cremation as a tourist attraction, but if you take it as something to expand your mind. Funerals here are very public and it is an interesting contemplation of the meaning of life. Provided you are not squirming, it is a really interesting place to visit. There are many monkeys here too, and so that adds to the atmosphere. Watch out for hawkers, some can be a little too eager to sell, and the sadhus are happy to take a photo but for a price. Take some small currencies with you for these events and for the beggars that are found on the path up the hill to the deer park.

Pashupati temple. A UNESCO WORLD heritage a must visit for all hindus,I from was there with my wife 21 November to 28 November 2013,but what annoyed us was the guide who tells us what we need to do( we did not ask for the guide in the first place} the moment we left our van ,this guide followed us ,we were unaware we have to pay for his service until we were about to leave,so those who intend to visit this temple ,do not allow any guide to follow u,if they insist just tell them this is not your first visit.from my observation ,this only happens to foreigners,please be aware ,dont let this guide fleece you.

Excellent place to visit. We visited yesterday. I found it pretty clean and well kept. We were allowed entry to the temple complex because we are Hindu. There are hundreds of monkeys inside the complex as well as a deer park. Take care, not to eat or drink inside or the monkeys may snatch it from you! My niece was drinking juice and one of the monkeys took the juice box from her to drink the rest. Unfortunately the main temple was closed until 430pm, but we were able to pray at the smaller temples that are part of the complex.

Like no where you'll ever see. It's and amazing holy place where people bring their dead relatives to be cremated. You can see the whole process from start to finish. It may be too much for some, and they do charge about 10 USD at the moment to get in.
Hindus. Pashupati Nath is one of the my favorite and peaceful place in Kathmandu. I like evening Pray at there.

Religious faith prevails over tourist attraction. A UNESCO world heritage site has been a symbol of Hindu faith since 4th century. Hindus across the world come to Pashupatinath Temple in hope to get free from the cycle of birth and re-birth. The temple is situated at the banks of Bagmati river which also serves as a Hindu cremation ground. Non-Hindu tourists may be disappointed as the entry inside the temple premises is strictly for Hindus. Leaving aside the faith and religious significance, i found the premises very dirty and choatic. The priests in various small temples (within the compound) try to rob you by offering customized prayer menu for the happiness and well being of family. Please just ignore them and don't be a fool. Please take care of the belonging all the time to avoid any unpleasant experience. Use only trusted car services to go around Kathmandu and confirm the fare with cab drivers as they usually befool tourist by asking for Indian Rupee instead of Nepali Rupee. Have wonderful stay in kathmandu!Rating: 2.5/5

Good experience. I have no idea how a local could get it wrong :), but I was told that this temple was open from morning 4 AM to evening 9 PM. Please understand what this means - if you are simply looking at walking around the courtyard and looking at the ghats etc yes please walk in anytime. But if you want to offer prayers and worship the deity, please know that they close the doors to the sanctum sanctorum at noon and open it only at 5 PM.
Best Place of the world.. Pashupati is world famous temle..it is beautiful with many stupas and other many beautiful things...Please i suggest to everyone go for here..... :)

The Temple of Passing. After visiting 76 countries it is hard to see or experience anything radically different. Pashupatinath is an education! Despite the guide books recommending to exercise respect with one's camera and to stay clear of the ghats; relatives did not mind me recording videos right next to their burning relatives for Turner's Travels on Youtube. Close study of death is pushing the boundaries of the education for the seasoned traveller.

Out of time. Really amazing experience in this temple where the Nepalese cremate their dead : Children playing next to the dead people, Nepalese staying there to look at cremation all day long. It seems like a place out of time where life and death are brought together.
Pristine, and so peaceful. a must ggo and experence it yourself....the experience so sublime and serene, it cannot be put down in words....DIVINE....so captivating....!!

If you're not Hindu, you're looking through the door. So, the Shiva art on the outside is interesting, but you're basically looking at the backside of a big brass cow, since non-Hindus can't go inside. The larger world heritage site is pretty interesting, including the cremations along the (filthy) river, smaller shrines, sadhus-for-pay, etc., but the temple itself is unavailable. The pagoda architecture is worth noting, and the people-watching is good, but between the large number of (sacred) cows and their manure, the pigeons, and the cremations and the unshod feet, be prepared for olfactory overload.

Nepal offers several exciting place to visit.. "We were a bunch of four college friend and visited the country some two years back. We friends had been to some other destinations like Dubai and London but this country has some unique things to offer.The temple was the best among the entire place we paid a visit to. We were initially reluctant to visit the place but our guide was so much informative that he gave us information about the importance of the place. There were a great number of visitors and tourists. We took over hundred pics and all were of different items. I recommend the visitors to spend at least two to four hours at this temple. We were a bit unfortunate to visit this place thoroughly as we were running of time. Some stalls were also set up which were selling historical items related to the temple."

Holiest of the Holy Temple in Nepal. A world heritage site - only Hindus can visit from inside - a very powerful place dedicated to specifically lord Shiva - but Also home to all our Gods - clean well kept - ideal to visit early morning

Very interesting. Interesting to see the cremation ritual and the site itself has some very impressive buildings, beware of the guys you try to follow you around and give you information on the site,they ask for $20 US and dont show you the whole area,the one i had also tried to get me to buy necklaces from the numerous touts that patrol the area saying that it was not a lot of money to me!!! if you can ignore these guys and go and look around it is worth the visit.

Disappointing this year - no monkeys.. Where did the monkeys go? And now they charge $10.00US to get into just one part of the temple (you must be Hindu to enter the main temple) and I'm not sure there is much to see.

Humanity at it's Finest, Very Moving Place.... This is a traditional Hindu cremation site. it is confronting and beautiful all at the same time. It is not for the faint of heart as multiple funeral pyres burn simultaneously incinerating recently passed Hindu locals. It is a must do in Kathmandu and an excellent opportunity to learn about the Hindu culture.

Interesting place but really expensive!. This holy Hindu place worths the visit if you've never been in India, especially in Varasni.However, I was mostly disappointed because:- the site is far less impressive than Varasni- many tounts, false saddhus.- when we arrive at cashier, a friendly guy starts to ''show us the way'' of the site. After a few mins, we realised he was a guide. We didn't want any and he wouldn't take no for an answer so it takes a long time to get rid of him. We were then harassed by a lot of ''guides'', something that can really spoil your visit...- most of all, they have doubled the fee entrance recently (from 500 to 1000rs) without any clear reason. We later learnt by local people that the money isn't used for the improvement of the site - something you can clearly notice during your tour.Too bad.

Grim but interesting. There happened to be a lot of burning going on when we went, so the acrid smell in the air was off putting, however it is an interesting place. Not too many tourists as well which was surprising.The cost is the most disappointing part. 1000 rupees despite what the guide book says. The architecture is fascinating as is the ritual.
pasupatinath visit. lord shiva looking same on four sides is nice bu tin the temple premises stray animals doing rounds i didn`t like that too whn my friend was bitten by the dog

Pasupatinath temple visit. Read and heard a lot about this temple but for me the visit was with good and bitter memories.good in the sense that i visited the temple at 5.30 pm during Harathi time when the doors from four sides are opened and I could see the rituals from close.but as it was winter it was dark at that time with dogs and other cattle roaming freely.my friend went to have darshan of Kalabhaira temple with in the same premises.There she was bitten by a stray dog.How can the temple authorities allow a stray dog.After that we had to go around the Kathmandu town in search of Anti Rabies Injection for 2 hours.Luckily I was a doctor otherwise imagine the plight of others.

overwhelming and beautiful. I strongly suggest being mentally, emotionally and spiritually prepared for this, it can be very overwhelming and confronting to see open cremations especially if you are not expecting it. most of the grounds are very beautiful and it is a lovely and interesting place to visit, however prepare yourself for what you are about to see, hear, smell and experience. Also dont look at the monkeys too long.
Watch out for the 'guides'. Very interesting site to visit. Tip: after you've paid the 1000 Rupees entrance fee watch out for any guides who try to latch onto you - they will expect a fee
Famous Shiva Temple. A must visit place, you can take camera, but cannot click inside the temple, you can take photos from the outside.

Heaven On Earth. Its like a heavenly feeling, truly a place where god resides. I got a chance to visit it the second time. I am at loss of words when it comes to defining how i feel. For doing a good darshan, try and visit early in the morning.

Hindus great pilgrimage places. we see many temple complex, forest , devotees. Holy man enjoyed and begging. more than that dead bodies cremation. after seeing that i have great sense of the impressive Hindus philosophy. we great recommendation to go there and itself it is a knowledge of the Hindus civilization.

Bit of surreal experience. I visited Pashupatinath about a month ago whilst visiting Kathmandu. I spent most of the time trying to convince people that I was of Indian origin to avoid being swindled out of entrance fees. My attempt as Hindi was okay but not convincing so I opted to speak Punjabi in an attempt to confuse and convince all the same time. It worked and I was allowed into the main area reserved for Hindus only. Once inside, I was greeted by a persistent priest who tried to sell me a pooja (prayer) for 5000 NPR! Once I shooed him away, looking around the main religious area was difficult as people viewed me with suspicious looks of 'is she or she not indian". Although amusing, it somewhat took away my experience of this place as although not religious I have a general interest in these things. That aside, the open air cremations were not as ghastly as I thought they would be, though I hastily retreated when the smoke got too much. Animals roamed everywhere. As you enter, there are lots of cows being constantly fed along with hundreds of pigeons. Beware of the monkeys as they are cheeky but make great photos. Bit of surreal place, lots of sadhus and priests trying to rip you off, animals and humans trying to coexist in some strange way. Worth going just for the experience and fascination of seeing life and death at the same time.

Sensory overload. Bodies burning, funeral music blaring from tinny loudspeakers, hawkers, hustlers and beggars, feral dogs, angry monkeys, holy (oh yeah?) men daubed in ash and paint demanding money to pose for a photo... to the westerner this has to be one of the weirdest places on Earth.It's worth a visit out of macabre fascination, even though you will feel ripped off by the graveside. But if you think Pashupatinath is a normal, traditional Nepali scene don't kid yourself. Apparently the Nepalese who send off their deceased in the holy river think it is just as tacky as we do, and they want the excessive trappings of tourism driven from this place. You can't blame them.

no happy place to visit. I went there on Nepalis election day.So everything shut down no have transportationI heir bicycle to go there street up hill down hill have to track bike.Can't rid it....so have to many asked till reach there.When i arrive there....place not to clean have many human and animal excrement.Entrance fee 1000Nrs I am entrance to main gate it allow Religion only .It's no have sight on there I am walk into that place...someone told me off....s.o.r.r.y.I to walk on right hand side to see ceremony of funeralit make me feel no so good....I have to asked myself I want to see kind of this....Why i came here for.....Culture Took picture?

Holy Sadhu !. Those holy men have a great business taking photo money from the tourists. Alas, I was guilty once of paying them to get some brilliant photos. The site is a must see though on cremation days it is not everyones cup of tea. You can not enter the Hindy temple (hindu only).

Most sacred Hindu temple. We came to visit around sundown, when the temple was opened for Hindu (only) pilgrims. It was fascinating to watch and a local guide explained us the site. Consider taking a guide, especially if you are unfamiliar with Hinduism. The Puja ritual (singing and music) in the evening was wonderful and people sing and dance along with it. Definitely try to watch that (it is on the other side of the temple).The ghats, where Hindus are cremated within 24 hours of death, are down by the river. Take your time if you are hesitant about watching such a funeral. They take place 24/7. First, the deceased gets washed on the northern side of the bridge. Then the cremation is done on the ghats. For me personally, it was fascinating to watch the funeral ritual.

very unusual. you can see on one side of the river people eating and splashing in a water and in a few meters, next side washing of a dead body and preparation for cremation. I was a bit shocked standing in few meters away from cremating body, ash of cremating fire was falling on my hair and listening the story of castes...Shocking but very interesting place. Good chance to think about life and death and some other philosophical issues.the guide who join you upon your arrival will extort money.

Must if you haven't been to Varanasi. This temple is the holiest Hindu temple in KTM. It is very big, I mean the whole complex is spread across the both banks of the Baghmati river. The temple itself is not accessible to non Hindu and architecturally is nothing special.I see everybody is talking about cremation. Two days before KTM we were in Varanasi, and compared to those cremations in Varanasi, those at Pashupatinath are far less impressive. Besides, it was too much for our stomachs to watch those sad scenes again.The people, pilgrims and locals at the temple, we found far more interesting. But beware of them. Half of them are not real holy men and pilgrims. They are dressed in such a way to take photos with them and then ask for money.

Green and park like. A local Nepali friend took me here, and it was a lovely glance into Hindu culture amidst wonderful architecture and gardens. The monkeys and deer were fun too. Walk up and down to get to the sacred river to see the cremations waiting to happen. It does cost 1000 NPR forforeigners to enter. Could easily spend a couple of hours enjoying this holy site honoring Shiva and other central Hindu gods and goddesses.
Truly divine!. The feel about the place brings out the spiritual side of yours. I witnessed the evening aarti.. amazing experience. Must visit.

Hindu Cremation Site. I will never forget my visit to this Hindu temple since I personally witnessed the cremation of bodies. You will also hear the wailing of relatives crying before their relatives and loved ones are cremated. Its interesting to see bodies in a pyre of wood and some of them being place near the river where young boys jump and swim. There are a lot of interesting buildings ,events and people to see in this Hindu temple specially Hindus who cover their bodies and faces with colored dye.

dream fulfilled. filled with mostly local public. but a very different kind of temple compared to indian temple.
the tradito is also different. memeorable experience in visiting the shiv linga.

The Holy Way. Pashupatinath is considered as the holiest Hindu Pilgrimage and as me being from Kathmandu I have been there countless times. Nowadays it has become very clean compared to olden days and which is praiseworthy. A must visit for all the Hindus who go to Kathmandu.

Another approach of mourning. This place is a must-see, though it can be very dismal and/or depressing. On the shores of the narrow Bagmati River locals cremate their deceased on 24/7. The main temple is for Hindus only, but the site altogether is a very impressive sight. Try not to run through this; it is time to meditate on life and death there.

Temple with great value. It is regarded as one of the famous temple for hindu people. Has great art and architecture and moreover, the belief of the hindu people towards the lord Shiva is appreciable. Full of architecture and ancient art.

i have Faith.. Pashupatinath is a deity and much revered by thousands of pilgrims who come here everyday. The legends go back thousands of years. But the modern day control and highhandedness of the priests in charge disturbs me.

Nice temple ... Liked the temple, the sheer size and the rituals going on is worth a visit.
However non Hindus are not allowed into the main temple. And there is a fee to enter the temple.

Amazing. As a western Christian its not every day I see people cremated in the open and then dumped into the river. Amazing to see how they celebrate the end of life. Great area to walk around and explore. Get a guide if you want to learn the history.

Most popular Hindu destination!!. Pashupatinath temple is the major destination of Hindus all around the world. It is one of the most significant temples of lord shiva. It's religious values and history have earned its place in unesco world heritage sites. Artistic excellence of wood carving can be observed in various parts of this temple. It is situated on the bank of bagmati river.

DIVINE EXPERIENCE !!!. First of all !! to let you this.. this temple is only meant for Hindus and yes most of the times being a non Hindu you are prohibited to enter .. now once you are inside the temple.. trust me you can actually feel a strange energy surrounding you .. yes you will experience it.. an very ancient and an amazing construction will not stop you from gazing at the beautiful wooden carvings at the top of the temple. extremely sacred place .. also you have many temples in the same compound of this temple one being a kaal bhairav temple..must see.. at the back of the temple you have many other small temples full of sadhus.. mind you !! most of these sadhus are fake and they are there to make money by clicking photographs with the visitors.. a small bridge goes over the river and yes you have got a lot of hindu last rituals being performed there with ashes being submerged in the river..now i suggest you to cross a bridge going over the river and enter a small forest ..and go upto the top and descend down to one of the sacred hindu shakti-peets of ghuheswari!! dont miss this.. in all an amazing and divine experience !!

Thought provoking. Although we weren't sure about visiting this because of the cremations and left it until our last day, it was a moving experience. Traveling to the other side of the world, one needs to open up to things that might make you squeamish at home. Seeing the open-air cremations is only a small part of visiting this huge complex of temples. We took a guide who explained the meaning of a lot of the rites, as well as the details of the different temples. Meeting and being blessed by the sadhus was a humbling moment and seeing the caves and simple housing they lived in precariously perched on the mountainside, showed the depth of their devotion. Is was a privilege to be allowed to observe tis holy place.

Pashupatinath Temple. Very interesting old area.
But watch out for the professional holy men,they're very expensive.
Otherwise its interesting just to walk around by yourself and pick up on the atmosphere.
Tends to gets smoky around dusk.
Could be much better. People here do not mKe you feel very welcome: the temple is off limit for non hindus and the place is not kept clean. Too many tounts too

Absolutely amazing!. I don't think I have encountered an experience such as Pasupathinath Temple before. Thankfully we hired a guide at the entrance to the temple. Best travel I advice I can give you. We might have just walked up to the rivers edge to view the first few funeral pyres on the other side and then left. Fortunately our guide took us all around the entire complex, with the climax being the section of the temple where the bodies wrapped in orange cloth were lying along the river waiting to be burned. The view from up high from the opposite bank of the river of the entire ritual will stay with me forever.

A real privilege. What a privilege to be allowed to this temple to observe the local cremation ceremonies. It was Kathmandu in the raw.There was a bit of hassle from touts trying yo sell us things but it wasn't so bad.

Makes you think. This place really makes you think about your mortality, which is not always a bad thing. From the point of cultural understanding it was really very very interesting to follow the cremation, even though one cannot avoid the feeling of peeking into someone's very private family occasion.Keep away from the monkeys and the sadhus who are after your money (sadhus) or camera (monkeys).

Earthbound Expeditions tour of Pashupatinath Temple. I visited Pashupatinath Temple as part of a half day tour of Unesco world heritage sites in Kathmandu. It was amazing. It is the temple where Hindus farewell their dead. The guide from Earthbound Expeditions was well informed, I felt privileged to see this religious and personal part of the Hindu religion.

A place for all people. I found this place the most fascinating of all the Kathmandu Temples. It's a good idea to have someone show you around but make sure you agree a price beforehand. Once again Nepal's capability of sharing Temples amongst religions is very clear. It has an atmosphere of peace, the Crematoria is not a distraction but a part of a way of life. Very interesting.

must-see for anyone who's tradition it is to put the dead in coffins under the ground. though touristic (fat germans using their canon mark II with giant tele-lense pointed at the bodies whilst their family honours them for the final time is the norm), this place has to be experienced for anyone who wants something completely different from their culture. glue-sniffing children are abound as well and will shock you too. very interesting stuff, bring a mouth mask

Most amazing, vibrant temple in Nepal. SO many temples in Pashupatinath! Literally a temple on every corner. It is worth getting a guide to tell you about the significance and history of the temples, some of which are thousands of years old. There's also lots of shopping!
must see. very beautidul temple! it is similar to the temple is kathmandu but this is little. always full of tourist, well maintained.

Another Kathmandu must-see. You could spend days here but at least a few hours is a minimum if you want to see and experience the beauty, history and current goings-on at this temple complex. You should also be able to see a cremation in progress if you are there at the right times. This is another Kathmandu must-see. For a bit extra, I'd recommend getting a guide to take you around and tell you the history and meaning of all of the things you will see while walking around this beautiful site.

One of the natural dominants of Kathmandu. A lot was written about this place. It is one of the dominants of Kathmandu and every visitor of the city goes there. We did the same and spent some time there just sitting and trying to feel the spiritual atmosphere of the place. It is worth just stop....

Add it to your list of places to go. Yes, this temple is very interesting and it is worth paying a few dollars for a guide to tell you all about it. We saw many cremations of varying economic status. It was a bit overwhelming at the start, especially when families arrive with the bodies and bring them to the water. But once you deal with that, it is very interesting and worth a visit. We got pressured by those "Lonely Planet" guys (that's what they called themselves), especially the one with the very long blonde hair and painted faces - they wanted me to give them $20 each!! Don't succumb to the pressure! I'm not rich. I gave them $20 for 6 of them. For 2 photos, that is more than enough! Apart from that and pressure from the guide to pay $20 (we had been told by our driver to pay $5!), once you get past that, it is well worth the visit.

Cremetorium. This was such a unique experience for me. A wolrd heritage site, this place had half a dozen bodies burning as we arrive. It cost nearly $20 steep by nepal standards. But you could see the cremations. There were tons of "holy men" asking for pictures and then asking for $$. Got some great pictures fo the holy men and the temple itself, but it definately left a sour taste in my mouth as we left. (or maybe that was the smoke of the bodies that we walked through as we exited..)
particolar temple. this temple is in Pasupathinath area, a particular area near airport of Kathmandu where dead and birth are assembled...
spiritual experience. we arrived at sunset, when the light of the dark started.... some dead was burning and puja pray started....a strange and mystical experience

Pashupatinath, Kathmandu. I found the Hindu Cremations at Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu Nepal very interesting. The use of natural materials such as hay etc to burn cremate the bodies is interesting as well as the ceremony.

New Experience. This is a very interesting experience with people being cremated on the edge of what used to be a strong flowing river, now just a channeled stream. Mourners and tourists mingle as if it is simply another day at Pashupati. There day we were there, there was a military cremation and the body was covered in flowers and there was a gun salute - extremely interesting and quite sureal.

Unforgetable Experience. Pashupatinath is the oldest and one of the most important Hindu temples in Nepal and is listed in UNESCO World Heritage sites list. The Temple's existence dates back to 400 A.D, although the present temple was built in the 17th century after the previous one was consumed by termites. We walked along the 500m or so promenade to the temple proper, a walkway lined with little stalls selling incense, marigolds, beads and other religious bits and pieces. The Pashupati complex is huge containing many other old and important temples and shrines and is a popular spot for tourists and devotees. We visited on a weekday so there wasn’t a big crowd there. I found it a very moving experience watching cremations take place on the opposite side of the Bagmati river from where I was standing. But it’s all done in a business-like way with little fuss in accordance with the Hindu beliefs of the continuing cycle of birth, life, death and rebirth. For me it’s an unforgetable experience, one I definitely recommend if you’re coming to Nepal.

Hindu cremations and photogenic sadhus. Nepal's equivalent of Varanasi costs an eye-watering 1000Rs to enter (though if you approach from the entrance closer to the Boudha you might get there for free as we didn't see anyone there checking tickets!) Here the cremations of the dead occur on the banks of the holy river. It's very moving moving but you'll need a strong stomach as you may see heads of hair a-blaze! Unlike Varanasi, there's no problem taking photos and a cluster of photographers on the opposite bank quickly gather after 9am. The sadhus arrive between 8-9am and gather in a prominent position close to the bridge where they make a healthy living posing for photos. Expect to pay 100Rs. This will buy you as many photos as you like. Its well worth it as they look amazing!

It's the only site where I actually hired a guide. I visited here my first day in Katmandu and it's the only site where I actually hired a guide. I had been here 15 years before and had a very dim memory of it. I didn't recall having seen cremations or the many ceremonies for family conducted by priests. I enjoyed taking photos of these scenes and of the temples on the Bagmati river. My guide took me all around including up to the top of the hill and through many of the far flung temple sites. His greatest value was that he showed me the best places to take pictures - many guides won't pick up on what you want to do and will just recite the text that spins in their head.

See to believe. Many who have been to India will find this a familiar site, but the arrangement and intensity here were more extreme than other Hindu temples I'd seen. Please - show some respect and don't snap pictures of the cremations. I know it's hard, but imagine someone showing up at YOUR mother's funeral and putting a camera in your face. NO. The fee to get in here is around 10 dollars US now, and part of that is discourage too much tourism to the area. If you go in there and act like a jerk, you'll make it more expensive or perhaps one day even forbidden for other curious foreign eyes to experience.Seriously, go here and behave yourself. Watch out for the overly photo happy 'hermits' volunteering their mugshot for cash.

expensive entrance fee but worthy!. The entrance fee was 1000 rupees which's very expensive compared to living cost in Nepal, but the temple was interesting enough to pay for, especially the cremation which you could see before your eyes. Besides, you could see lots of people's believes and beautiful culture that's worth every rupees.Tips: 1. I took a mini van to this temple and it cost only 15 rupees. ^^ 2. On the way from main street to the temple, there's a snack shop which its samosa and roti ring were very delicious!!! try it here, it's really cheap as well!

Lifetime experience. This was my second time in Pashupatinath; even more emotional than the first one as this time I got to watch a Hindu cremation ceremony from the very start to the end, taking place on the ghats located on the banks of Bagmati River. You cannnot say that you have visited Kathmandu unless you have not visited Pashupatinath. This is a unique experience as one could see life, death, hope, despair all in the same shot. However, the smell and smoke might be disturbing for some people so you can bring some wet wipes or scarf to avoid this.Entrance to the main temple at Pashupatinath is forbidden for the Non-Hindus but still you can take a glimpse of the Nandi bull.

The Vatican of Hindus!. Sadhus, Holiest Hindu Temple, Cremation - all the "holy' gathered in one square - we were amazed. As our family have Christian and Muslim background, teaching the kids our other faith is part of our parenting philosophy. The search for knowledge and truth for the kids actually got sparked in this place. Lots of ideas, lots of questions, lots of rituals.We were also able to visit the elderly house just besides the crematoria place. It was a good lesson on life, death and making each day counts. A holy and spiritual day for a non- Hindu family.
A great world heritage location to visit in Kathmandu. Only Hindus can enter into the main temple. Not allowed for other religious people to enter into the main temple.

Pashupatinath Temple Kathmandu Nepal. Pashupatinath Temple Kathmandu (Nepal) is one of the most significant Hindu temples of Shiva in the world, located on the banks of the Bagmati River in the eastern part of Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal dedicated to Lord Shiva. Pashupathinath is the guardian spirit and the holiest of all Shiva shrines in Nepal. In the sanctum of the temple, there is a very attractive, about three feet high Shivalinga with four faces.These faces are also defined as the symbol of four dharmas and four Vedas. Pashupatinath Temple is regarded as one of the most important places of pilgrimages for the followers of Hinduism.Thousands of devotees from within and outside the country come to pay homage to Pashupatinath every day. Pashupatinath temple is the biggest and most visited temple of lord shiva in the world.According to legends, the Pandavas sought the blessings of lord Shiva to atone their sin after the battle of Mahabharata. Lord Shiva eluded them repeatedly and while fleeing took refuge at Kedarnath in the form of a bull. On being followed, he dived into ground leaving behind his hump on the surface and appeared in Nepal as Pashupatinath.

wonderful ancient temple. It is an ancient temple having mythological and historical value for all Hindus. Lord Shiva is known as Lord Pashupathinath here, because the shape of Linga is the head of sacred cow. All the four sides of Linga are having different faces. Only Hindus are allowed inside the temple and photography is strictly prohibited. The Temple is situate on the banks of river Bagmati.If you are in Nepal, this is the first place to visit. Do not buy any rudrakshis as suggested by your tour operators or guides from the local shops. Most of them are fake and do not take risk of wasting money.

pashupatinath. Very moving experience. We saw several funerals taking place with bodies being cremated by the side of the river. Also were introduced to real Sadhus living by the temple. Very emotional visit highly recommend

Amazing ritual. So yes, we saw them burning their dead. We saw them bathing in the filthy river searching for coins or whatever leftovers from the dead. We barely missed animal sacrifices in a temple, but could still find ourselves inside a blood-drawn circle. We also saw a paralysed monkey that had tried to play with the electric cables. It was all disturbing. So many questions and self-wondering coming in bursts and we were incapable of reacting and of understanding. Another culture, another world.

Hire a guide for a an hour. A guide will provide you much insight into the practices of the cremations and won't cost you much (about 10$. And do stop to take pictures of the sadhu and leave them a tip. (even though they are fake).

What an amazing place. I saw this once on tv but nothing compares to seeing it in real life. We spent two hours there in the company of a guide which is essential to really understand what's is happening around you. We saw funeral pyres, sadhu religious men and lots more. Do visit if you are in Kathmandu!!

A glimpse of spiritual life. An amazing spiritual centre for Hindus, pilgrims and ordinary folk alike. Sit by the banks of the river and watch life unfold - a procession carrying the dead, the rituals, the cremation; on the other side, you can see people eating, praying, etc. Then walk up the hill and watch monkeys dart in and out of trees; the braver ones will come near you but they don't attack (unless you hv something edible in your hands). and Please note that the govt recently started to charge tourists an entry fee to visit the temple complex, but it's worth it.

Great pilgrimage centre..... Worlds Hindu temple is pashupatinath temple is Nepal's important place. Many Hindus visits this place.Old and beautiful temple.lord Shiva came here with Parvati for honeymoon In the form of animal...story tells. In the morning are viewed from hotel.

Well organised to handle huge crowds. Pasupatinath at first sight looks no different from any other temple in Kathmandu but once you are in, you find the mighty Nandi and the imposing temple complex. There is so much to it that one can spend hours even if one is not offering the puja. The cows loitering and the flocks of pigeons too lend grace to the place. Foreigners can be seen clicking pics from the other side. Though photography is restricted inside one can still come back with few memories from the area around the main temple. The shoe stand is well organised and there are few priests to disturb. I found the viewing gallery in front of the main temple to be of great benefit.
Long way for nothing. It was a long bumpy trip to get here. It was very dirty and not inspiring. There are better ways to spend your time in Kathmandu
worth a visit. what an usual feeling you get when visiting this attraction well worth the visit though . you don't feel as though your in Nepal more like India

No need to go. If you are not Hindu then no need to go there. It will just waste your time. Renovation works are going on. Bad smells captured you when you will enter the place. It's a must visit place for Hindus, but not for the other religion. There is nothing to see here.

Pashupatinath Hindu Temple. Pashupatinath is believed to be one of the biggest Hindus temple of Shiva, It is regarded as most sacred among the Temples of Lord Shiva. Only Hindus believers are allowed to enter the Temple Premises. Non Hindu Visitors are allowed to have a look at the Temples from other bank of Bagmati River. This Temple has gold pinnacle Pagoda style architecture has four main doors, all covered with silver sheets and two level roofs are of coppers with gold covering. There is a statue of large bull near to the western door which is also cover in gold. There is a small river by the side of the Temple which is believed as Holy River, Hindus believe that they will go into the Heaven if they cremate into the bank of this river. So there will be many cremations going every day. So all these made very interesting place to visit in Kathmandu valley.

A Place of Fascination and Contemplation. Death is part of life. At this most holy of Hindu temples bodies are prepared and cremated in the open and death can be experienced in life. In the west death is hidden, discrete, outsourced to professionals. For a temple that deals with death it is, as others have remarked, a peaceful place, yet one full of life, mystery and evidence of a rich culture. It is a one stop shop for everything - shaved heads, the right robes, the wood, the accelerant, etc. everything is available there. Non Hindus cannot go into the temple at the centre of the complex, although you can stand at the entrance and look in. Otherwise you are free to wander, and wonder. It will most likely be an experience you will never forget. I have visited this place many times when we have visitors and for my own interest. A place of fascination and contemplation.

Didn't go in; objected to the stiff entry fee.. Trying to turn a temple into Disneyland. Shopping all around; many people dressed as holy men who then want to charge to have you take their photos. Made me doubt their authenticity. We walked all around the outside, which was not very impressive.
Too pricey for how dirty it is. It is very interesting as you can see the cremations, but considering the price for the entrance, the place is almost ruined down and dirty.

Serene !. An important temple for Hindu's. Full of stories and anecdotes. Great place to meditate. You can pick up some antiques at a great price near this temple if you are really good at bargaining.

A vibrant place. Visited this temple with a group of Hindus , as a non Hindu there were parts of the temple I could not visit.But I was able to walk round the outside areas looking at the buildings , & visit the Ashram at the back of the temple & the area where the funeral pyres are.Everybody was friendly with many people wanting to stop & chat.The rows of stalls selling garlands & offerings & gifts are fun to wander up & down.Well worth a visit
Hindu Temple. The admission fee is rather high. You can walk around the outside of the Hindu Temple and observe a Hindu funerals.

nice place. you can have darshan of lord pashupati nath temple. It is a very nice place to get peace in nepal. I visited it in the month of june, 2013 the weather was pleasant and i had darshan of god. Not very much crowded during the month of june. Only Hindus are allowed to enter the temple and rest of the persons can visit it outside.

Disappointing. The closest most people get to see this famous & sacred Hindu Temple is from across the other side of the Bagmati River, overlooking the cremation sites. Whilst is a highly revered and moving site for a lot people, we found it a little disturbing and intrusive.

Funerals, monkeys. you cannot go into the temple as only Hindus are allowed. But the funeral pyres by the river are shared by Hindus and Buddhists alike, along with Sahus and lots of monkeys. Funerals are 24/7 as the dead are cremated a couple of hours after dying. Definitely worth a visit, you feel like you are in India.
THE TEMPLE OF LINGAS. Another great place and I was thrilled that I could touch all the lingas and I got a rudraksa garland. Met some sanyasins and got their blessings.
on a hill !!. This temple situated on a hill gives you a nice view on the city but try to go with bus, taxi, car to the top and take the stairs for the decent.

Moving experience. I found this site to be very emotional. What an experience to share in such a tradition of Nepal.Tip for a first time visitor, would be the local who walks beside you from the beginning is your guide. We were lucky to have a well educated, fluent English speaking local. Please note you are expected to pay for the guides service. If you do not intend on paying for the service, let them know from the start.

Nice Place. Very nice place. Lots of god and goddess. Very interesting arts and sculptures.Lots of Monkeys. Near to the river bank cremation part is done according to the hinduism. I do not understand why only hindu people are allow to get inside... why not other religion?

Har har Mahadev. The oldest Hindu temple in the world. The lord of all animals. The richly-ornamented pagoda houses the sacred lingam or holy symbol of Lord Shiva. One of the among 11 jyotilingam of Hindu religion.Har har Mahadev

Still thinking about the experience.. Pashupatinath Temple is a unique place for anyone not too familiar with Hinduism. It was hard for me to reconcile the concept of a public cremation. The place itself was surreal. At one point there were children swimming in the 'river' literally a metre or two away from a deceased person (the body was covered) having his feet dipped in the water prior to the cremation. Monkeys were sitting adjacent to this eating food scraps while behind this there were about four cremations taking place simultaneously - all at different stages. Family members were performing the required religious rituals and onlookers (friends and tourists) stood observing. (Hard to believe!) With all of this happening, there is still an enormous amount of dignity and serenity.It is well worth one's while to take a face/mouth covering as there is a fair amount of smoke and I struggled with the odours that wafted through the area as the wind blew in different directions.It is a photographer's dream!

oNE oF a KIND!. WENT ON A MON MORNING, FEW TRAVELLERS ARE ON SITE,OUR GUIDE EXPLAINED ON THE RITUALS AND CUSTOM IN CREMATING THE DEAD. WE WITNESSED ONE CEREMONY, IT'S HEART WRENCHING SEEING THE FAMILIES WAILED THROUGHOUT..Many monk with colorful faces&unwashed long hair will invite visitors to take pictures,thus earn some tips. From understanding, they did not contribute much towards the religious/praying part, more like a gimmick to attract foreigners!The washroom near main entrance is rather bright and clean(odorless)compare to many attractions, as commonly known in Nepal, water is unavailable at the basin!Nevertheless, we treasured this sighting as the most unique experience
jai bholenath. a must for every hindu coming to kathmandu. shiva temple with a history, must visit 2/3 times if u r staying there even for 2/3 days. must see the aarti.

Unique Experience. We were able to watch how the dead are prepared for cremation, from the body preparation, dipping feet in the river, to the cremation lighting.This is a stinky, dirty place, with cows, dogs, and monkeys all around. But it is definitely an experience not to miss while in Kathmandu.

Saw a funeral, got attacked by a monkey. This temple is really interesting! You cannot go into the temple itself, that is only for Hindus, but a 1000rupee ($10) ticket will get you into the area surrounding the temple; streets of markets with coloured dust for the forehead and religious items, the river and cremations and funerals happening on it, the altar areas with people dressed up traditionally (tip for a photo!) and then Hindu rituals taking place at various points with the Brahmin. You can then walk through the large area surrounding the temple - watch out for the monkeys though if you have food they will want it and attack you for it! Also you will be harrassed the whole time by people who want to offer you a tour of the temple... we didn't take any up on the offer.
Beautiful. A beautiful and interesting place. But you can´t go into the main temple if you are not hindu but you have to pay more.

A sacred place for all Nepalis. incredible place to visit this sacred place for all Nepalis and millions of foreigners who come to cremate the departed.very peaceful and lots of prayers.Revered and worshipped both by Hindus and Buddhists.

Amazing. This is an amazing temple area. Though one cannot enter inside the actual temple, it really is amazing to see the cremations of the bodies. It gives a full new meaning of life.. Also, it is a unic temple in the world, a world heritage site and worth visiting.To see the cremations can be somehow violent to some..more than anything for the smell of burning.

Mixed feelings. You pay a hefty entrance fee -R1000! to wander around the premises. There's only a couple of temples which are ok, but the main attraction seems to be watching the cremation ceremonies, which feels a bit bizarre, as families mourn their loved ones while tons of tourists watch and snap pictures, all sorrounded by cows... a bit strange...

A great must-see place in Kathmandu. It's a huge religious site for Sadhu's. Also, there are cremations every day. It's a bit weird. How would you feel if a bunch of Nepali's with big cameras came strolling through your funeral party? But it's fascinating, so you don't care after a while and shoot away.The entrance fee seems to vary from 1,000 Rs to 0 Rs, depending on how you get in. One guy wanted 1,000. A few tourists ahead of us walked away not paying anything and we followed suit. The supposed ticket vendor then wanted 500 Rs at which point we just laughed. You can stay there for hours, just sitting and watching.

An archetype of arts. Wow it is really a great place to visit. You can see such a things that you never finds in whole europe. Its a cultural place of `hinduism and contains lots of artificial arts and also example of handicrafts in ancient time.....Visit atleast once if you wanna gather more.....

Heavenly, must visit for Hindus. This temple is a very important one for Hindus. Once can see lots of pandits doing prayers for devotees and in the centre there is Shiva temple with Nandi at the gate.
