At the back of the temple hindu dead bodies are taken for rituals and one can see bodies burning therein. Infact, the foul smell goes around everywhere there.Sorry to see that non-hindus were not allowed inside it and so were cameras.

Educational. We weren't allowed inside the temple but were able to stroll the grounds. There were a number of funeral pyres going on and there was a ceremony in progress that we were able to observed from the other side of the river. Our guide was very informative. I got to meat some holy men with their mud caked bodies and long dreads. One thing I was very shocked by was they allowed their 'holy river' to be clogged with trash and debris. I know that their culture/customs are different but it didn't make it any less upsetting.

Worth seeing, but potentially creepy. It's not every day you get to see the Hindu ritual for the dead. First starting with bathing the feet, dripping water in the mouth, then the public cremation, and finally the ashes placed in the river. But here it's happening all day, every day, at a half dozen cremation stations. At first you feel like you shouldn't be watching the families go through the ritual, then you realize a lot of people are. Our guide explained that since there are a large number of traditions, many local people also gather to watch in order to learn more. Definitely worth seeing, though it became a bit creepy when the wind shifted and we had to walk back through the cremation smoke.

Not for the faint hearted... A true piece of Nepal, dead bodies and all. This is where the locals are cremated in view of all that can cope with it.It is a spiritual, reverential place of great beauty and antiquity.
Place of Hindu god. It is the place where Mahadev lives. Most of the hindu people visit once in theirlife. ithis place is very huge you can see many temples and monkeys and seeings around it.
Lord Pashupatinath. A very old and traditional temple, needs to be well managed and need lots of cleanliness. Over all it's good

The Sacred & Not be missed place!. It is one of the main attractions of Nepal which you should not miss! The main temple is out of bounds for the cameras. The Nandi outside the main temple is grand & awe inspiring. The shops next to the main temple are famous for Rudraksh ( holy beads used by Hindus in religious rituals)

Interesting but beware of the cost!. I recently finished a 2 week work project in Eastern Nepal and had only 1/2 day to tour Kathmandu. The Pashupatinath Temple was one of the sites I saw; spent about 45 min there. First, they used to charge 250, then 500 and now, as of April, 1000 rupee to get inside. About 10 USD. The Temple itself is only open to Hindus but you can wander around the grounds. I hired a guide because the guide I came with did not know about the history of this temple. The temple guide was excellent. He was very informative and spoke English well. It was not clear to me he worked for the temple; I thought he was on his own (though did produce an authorized govt guide card). He charged me another 1000 rupee. While there a number of women selling beads tried to hit me up. I took a photo of one place and had to pay a tip. Then had my photo with some holy men. Before the photo the guide warned they would be looking for a donation. Fair enough. After the photos, I asked the guide how much. He did not advise. I gave 50 rupee and was told this was not enough. So I asked (again) what they wanted. He said 100 each! That would have been another 6 USD. I handed over about half that amount---300 rupees. Then, the end of the tour, the guide "suggested" I also tip him. He suggested i give him 5 euros (a note I had in my wallet, which he apparently had noticed). Ridiculous as that is about 7 USD. After having already forked out 23-24 USD, I was just done. So I did not tip. The guide was not very happy and neither was the other guide I had hired but could not tell me anything. He made some comment like, "well he just went into the tourist office, they probably pay him." I had such a fabulous experience in Eastern Nepal where are no tourists and people are not tainted. This cast a shadow over my experience. The other part was seeing other tourists take photos of families grieving while their relative was being cremated. Over the top in terms of disrespect. I could not wait to leave this dirty, crowded city of over 7 million people.
For Hindu Only. See the beautiful and huge temple. Beware that strictly only Hindus are allowed to enter the premises.

A busy but fascinating place. This is where the open air cremations take place. There is no objection to you watching, we chose to be on the other side of the river from the pyres. This provides a respectful distance with some place to sit. There are ash covered holy men wandering around and the place has a very spiritual feeling. You pay a small admission charge which is worth it.
Awesome place. Awesome place to visit specially during great Hindu festival Shivaratri...Peoples around the world gather to enjoy with sadhus!!!
Sadhus. Here you can see the Sadhus. Sadhus are friendly and they bless you...Got an opportunity to see the Ghat rituals, Pooja and lots more.
Amazing Darshan. Nothing to say, this temple has its historic value and a must place to visit for Hindus. Seeing the crowd its difficult to agree that you can get a good darshan, but its systematic.

The magnificent temple of Lord Pashupatinath. Lord Shiva is known by many different names; and Pashupati is one. Pashu means leaving beings, and Pati means master. In other words Pashupati is the master of all living beings of the universe. This is how lord Pashupati is eulogized in the Vedas, Upnisada and ohter religious books.The present architectural nature of Pashupatinath temple came into existence as a result of renovation by queen Gangadevi during the reign of Shivasimha Malla (1578-1620 AD).The temple of Lord Pashupatinath stands in the middle of an open courtyard. It is a square shaped pagoda temple built on single platform measuring 23.6 meters from the ground. There are gold gilt doors on all the four sides of the temple. Inside the temple there is a narrow walk engulfing the sanctum from where one can have closer view of Shivalinga.In the sanctum of the temple, there is a very attractive, about three feet high Shivalinga with four faces. All these faces have different names and significance. The face facing east is known as Tatpurusha and the one facing south as Aghora. Similarly, the faces looking west and north are known by the name Sadhyojata and Vamadeva respectively. The upper portion of this linga is known as Ishan. These faces are also defined as the symbol of four dharmas (the most famous places of pilgrimage for Hindus) and four Vedas (sacred books of Hindus). The images of Vishnu, Surya, Devi and Ganesh are also placed in the sanctum of the temple.Pashupati area is regarded as one of the most important places of pilgrimages for the followeres of Hinduism. Thousands of devotees from within and outside the country come to pay homage to Pashupatinath every day. And on special occasions like Ekadasi, Sankranti, Mahashivratri, Teej Akshaya, Rakshabandhan, Grahana (eclipse), Poornima (Full moon day) people congregate here in far greater number. Pashupati area is also included in the list of world cultural heritage.

God's abode. Discipline maintained in the temple with respect to timings as well as parikrama touched our heart. In many famous temple in India you get a unpleasant experience with pundits, however this is not a case with Pasupatinath temple.

Burial Service for Official. A local political figure who was respected by many passed away while I was there. I was able to get press access to the event and check out their burial ceremony. Great event on a sad event.

Fantastic creation of human beings. One of the Very nice Hindu tampel in world.if you want to see hand Smith and natural historical place then you must come to see it.its not possible to describe in only few words so thats why you can see first than described your self.

lord shiva lives here. situated on the bank of river bagmati this world heritage is abode of lord shiva ,the supreme god who destroys everything when furious.non-hindus are not allowed but they can have a glimpse from the other side of the river.you will find a huge statue of nandi the BULL ,here contrary to the hindu belief there are four doors to get into the temple.usually hindu temples have the main door facing east..a wonderful structure and unique place to visit.nice,cool and sprawling
Pashupati Nath ki Jaya. i like the improved system of Pashupati as it has become for clean and systematic........... Jay vole nath ...

Beautiful grounds to explore, but overpriced tickets for foreigners. This temple is essentially a large park with many buildings, temples and grounds to explore. A river runs through it where you can see bodies being burnt in funerals. Lots of green spaces surround the temple, and you can spend a good part of the day relaxing, strolling, and exploring. You can't enter the temple building if you're not Hindu, as with other Hindu temples, and many signs will remind you of that. The only thing that disappointed me greatly though is the large sum we had to pay to enter the grounds as foreigners. At 1000 rupees per foreigner, it was the highest we have paid in Kathmandu to visit any attraction.Overall, it is worth a visit, but does have have some drawbacks, including the ticket prices and not having access to the courtyards of the temples at least, which you can peek at through the temple gates. I suggest adding another site to your day after visiting this temple, and one that is nearby which I suggest is the beautiful Boudhanath stupa, which is also surrounded by restaurants and cafes if you wish to take a break or have some lunch.

A must see! Plan to spend a few hours here. One of my favorite sites that I visited while in Nepal. Very special place. I was so lucky to witness a number of open cremations the day that I visited. This was a very thought provoking experience and provided a very different perspective on the circle of life.

A different way of doing things. We couldn't go into the temple as we were obviously too tall/too fair and not a hindu or buddhist, but somehow we acquired a guide even though we hadn't asked for one! His English was good and he explained things which I'm sure we wouldn't otherwise have found out. It was a most strange experience and felt slightly voyeuristic, even though our guide assured us that people are welcome to watch. It also seemed odd that anyone would site an old people's home for those without family or means, a hospice and cremation ghats all on the same site. A short walk from the Bodhnath stupa, it's a good idea to combine these 2 places in a days sightseeing.

Intersting. Thia place is interesting for the local culture, however itus not kept clean at all and the two major temples inside are forbiddent to foreigners. The so called hindu sages all around look more like a bunch of city beggars. Such a pity.

Holy Pilgrimage Site for Hindus. I was told this temple is a pilgrimage site for all Hindus. Indians from India also come to this temple to pray. Situated beside drying river, the temple is not far away from the Thribuvan International Airport and just a few hundred meters away from the airport golf course. Nice place to see around such as the row of stupas that encase Lord Shiva's lingga & the crematoria where witnessing of the rituals for the dead before being incinerated with the use of hays and timber right in front of your own eyes. It is also near a spring deer reserve.Too bad, the main Temple is out of bounds for non-Hindus.

beware of touts. if youve ever been to the major temples in india, you will get an idea of what i' talking about. you have touts and 'pandits' all looking to make a fast buck off gullible devotees. careful of what you accept, it had to be paid for. the temple itself is not cleaned properly and cameras are an issue. if you dont like crowds, give the place a miss.

Now you pay 1000 NpR to watch the ..cremation. The visit of the temple is off limits to foreigners. Politely say "Hindus Only" but if you are or look like local -even if you are Muslim or Buddhist -they will allow you in, free of charge. What remains for the visitors to see is the cremations which take place along the river . Not big attraction itself but the whole story makes an interesting stopover if you have time. You can give a miss if you are short of time.

Big and dirty. As with most Hindu temples, the place was dirty, crowded and noisy. The temple itself is lovely, but the area is over an acre large, which makes it an amazing place to walk about, or sit under some shade and just meditate / chill.

wow! what a place to witness. watching the cremations with the people working out up above it kind of blew me away. life, death and all kinds of in between...
the Sadhus took the cake. they were absolutely over the top. unfortunately i did not bring enuf money to tip them well as it was my last stop before the airport....

its very old and hisorical temple but its not being managed properly and needs lot of improemnt in thei administrtion.. its nice and very big temple and was main purpose of our visit . administration of the temple needs lot of improvement . they don't allow non Hindus to visit inside the temple. I feel they should allow them to visit . there are lot shilling and old temple on the right side of Pahupatinath across the river.there is nice small café on the hills and we had nice time there enjoying the view with nice hot tea.
So many temples but all different. You must be able to put the poverty behind you. If you can do this, seeing the religious places and learning about their history is extremely fascinating
Time too short.. We had a truncated time in Kathmandu and managed to see most of the city.I would reccomend more time and some of the tickets can be stamped , to allow you back the next day.

Biggest Hindu temple. Pashupatinath is one of the biggest Hindus temple.This temple is dedicated to lord Shiva (most powerful god of Hindu religion) but there at temples of other gods too. Pashupati area is very peaceful temple though you see huge crowd any time you go.

rewelacja. kompleks swiatynny, warto , w silver temple old men house full of smile quiet old people,,,,alsko one houre for pleasaure and photos..also crematotium , hindu temple, beggars /over 100 / ,special place.very special

Very Different!. As a solo female Western traveller i was glad I hired a guide there, a young University student took me around for an hour and I paid him 1000NPR. I would not have seen or understood half as much without him. Money well spent! The crematoria ghats are fascinating. Non Hindu's are not allowed in the temple. Be prepared to pay to have a Tikka administered or to have a photo taken with Sadhus. Many beggars which can be intimidating.

Good place to visit.... it is arguably the most important temple in the kathmandu. read up on the net before you go, so it all makes more sense. we didn't see the crematoria. but the temple inside is very pretty and very intricately carved. and there are a lot of sadhus around - and none asked for payment for pictures! photography is not allowed within the temple complex, but you can carry your camera in and keep it with you. just be careful where you step - it is the temple for the lord protector of cows.. so there are a lot of cows.. and hence cow dung... every where.
great experience,. it was totally Hindu temple but so much interesting to learn about Hindu religion & their worship way, lots of place to visit, area is bit not so clean,

Funeral Pyres on the rivers edge. So, you see it on tv - and you think it looks odd. But, when you get here it feels normal - and the ownership of the experience is definitely aimed squarely at the family of the deceased.
The yogis around the place are happy to pose for pictures - if you pay them first.
Overwhelming!. We visited on the last day of a major festival, so it was almost too crowded to move. There was so much to see, though, that I'm glad we didn't pass on this.

for hindus only. really don't get why non-hindus are not allowed, a bit discriminating I would say...
however we could walk around the outside perimeter but did not enjoy seeing other tourists taking pictures of cremations. how would these people feel if strangers were taking pictures of treir granma's funeral?

For Hindu's only!. Whilst I appreciate the religious significance of the place, it's a total waste of time for non-Hindu's. I was erroneously told that I could enter the temple but, as wih many other Hindu temples, that wasn't the case. All I got was a fleeting view of Nandi's backside. Add the racist 1000 NR entrance for non-Asians and their morbid fascination of intruding into others' grief (through disgracefully taking pictures of cremations) and you'll understand my contempt for the place. I absolutely hated it!

Quick visit to Kathmandu. Fascinating place, although the fact that non-hindus cannot visit the inside of the temple is unfortunate. The site is in need of care and upkeep which is surprising considering there is a 1000 rupee entrance fee, and while I willingly paid the various yogis to take photos of their colorful outfits, the place starts to feel like a bit like a run down tourist attraction as opposed to a religious site. Still well worth the visit especially as a counterweight to the more sedate and elegant Buddhist temples.

Large Hindu Temple which needs cleaning and more care. This is a very large Hindu temple and unless you are a Hindu, you would not be allowed to go into the temple. For Europeans, there is a fee of Rs. 1,000 per person and if you are from a SAARC country, you will be allowed to go in free of charge. Although the temple is out of bounds for Non-Hindus the rest of the premises houses a lot of things that might be of interest to you. This place has a lot of examples from classical Hindu architecture and there is a bit of a climb to get to the top of this place as well. You will have to cross a bridge and the view here is extremely beautiful although the river itself is not that clean. However, you will not be able to enjoy much of that beauty because of the sellers who try to get your attention and practically stalk you!!!!When you get to the top, you would be able to find a quiet corner and enjoy a bit of peace in the midst of small shrines which are scattered all over the place. If you go up here, you might want to be careful of the bulls and the monkeys.

Great but still need some cleaning at river side. It has a lot improvements there since last time, last time when i went there it wasnt maintained well but this time it was really appreciatable, and yes be careful of monkeys too

Pricey but worth it. This was expensive in relative terms and you are hassled at the gate to take on a guide. If we had more time, I would have negotiated one, but we only had an hour or so. Was interesting but beware of all the hawkers!

Religious importance. Pashupatinath temple is one of the holiest temples in the Hindu religion. Flocks of devotees throng the temple and it is said sins are absolved after a visit. The pujas thaat are conducted here are full of rituals. The temple is adjacent to a river but it has not much scenic beauty.Further only hindus are allowed into the premises.It is a must however for hindus visiting Nepal.
Cultural shock. When you are have different culture and beliefs this place is a bit shock. Our guide well explained the place and crematorium area, I feel lucky that I don't have to see that.

Great hindu temple in the world. Pashupatinath is one of the biggest Hindus temple in the world. The supreme holiness of the site stems from the Shiva linga enshrined in its main temple. It expresses the very essence of Hinduism as pilgrims, priests, devotes, temples, ashrams, images, inscriptions and cremation ghats intermingle with the rituals of daily life, all sprawled along the banks of the sacred Bagmati River. The temple’s origins are obscure.

Great hindu temple in the world. Pashupatinath is one of the biggest Hindus temple in the world. The supreme holiness of the site stems from the Shiva linga enshrined in its main temple. It expresses the very essence of Hinduism as pilgrims, priests, devotes, temples, ashrams, images, inscriptions and cremation ghats intermingle with the rituals of daily life, all sprawled along the banks of the sacred Bagmati River. The temple’s origins are obscure.

Do i belong here?. Pay round ten euro. U allowed to watch from the other side. Not allowed to cross the bridge to the temple. Can be shocking burning people. I feel like outsider watching private things. But the feeling to experience this is very special. Be respectfull with taking pictures.

strong place. very strong and magic experience, must see place in Kathmandu.everytime i am comming back to see ,,little varanasi,,if you have more time, you can spend more time in this place and visit forest and places without any tourists.
Lovely Place. Make sure this is on you list of temples to visit. The Hindu architecture at this location is fantastic.

Jaya Pashupatinath. Hindu biggest temple in the world, felt so peace and religious after visiting the Loard Shiva Temple, may be its too high entry fees for the forgnier, and no any facility what you pay for it, and its interesting to see the funereal ceremony.Jaya Pashupatinath, Kata Shiva

Amazing. Definitely my favourite temple to have visited! There was so much going on, and so much to explore. Very much worth a visit

Fascinating.... Traveling is about getting up every day and seeing something you have never seen before.....Pashupatinath Temple and Bagmati River cremations is certainly in that category! I was surprised that it did not make me squeamish at all. It just seemed so natural, as if it happens everyday...which, of course, it does. It was just sooo interesting! Of course there are monkeys and cows and the Sadhu holy men are wonderful photography subjects,even if you do have to pay them. It was absolutely something I would not have wanted to miss, one of my Kathmandu highlights. We did have our own guide with us, which helps make it that much more interesting, besides the fact that you have someone to answer your questions!

Understanding the Culture. We paid the $10 entrance fee and gained a wealth of knowledge as our tour guide (who met us there) explained what we were seeing and answered our many questions about the culture and religion we were seeing in practice. We're not allowed inside the Temple, but there's so much more than just a temple there. If you have an attitude of respect and are there to see the architecture and to better understand the people you are living among while in Kathmandu, this is a necessary spot to more fully comprehend the practices of the people. I would also especially recommend this place to those who practice a religion other than Hinduism. Many conversations will arise from what your group sees and experiences there and it will give you a heart for the people.

You pay for visit but can not go inside.. You pay too much to see the temple and carving bot you are only allow to go next to the rive side to see the crimination. It was written on the gate that it is allow for hindus only.

Temple of the dead. A very holy place and therefor Europeans are not really needed there. Coming from an other country you have to pay 1000 rupies (pretty much) and then you are not allowed to enter the inner temple if you are not hindu.
a must!. the entrance fee of 1000 NPR shocks but is it worth! 50-60 dead bodies get burned there daily. Special atmosphere!

A must see. This is a very interesting location where you can witness the ritual cremations that are happening throughout the day. Late afternoon as good as the lights comes through the drifting smoke. Remember to respect the event that are happening her and watch the monkeys

Great religious and Historical place. The temple lies on the bank of the Bagmati, the holy river (as per the Hindu legendary book)s. We have to walk up few stairs to main temple from the River side, but this gate remains closed often, so the visitors should have to check in through another gate. This is the temple of LORD SHIVA, one of the universe himself for the hindus,as this is the god of all the living things including the animals and Human beings. Open cremation can be seen close by the temple, where almost every moment we can see at least few dead body being cremated.To the opposite, cross the river we can see stone made Shivalayas, each of them contain one Shiva lingam . pashupatinath the holy place. very crowdy place.We hardly could have darshan in minites. pushing and pulling the thiefs take undo adavantage. we lost uor money trvel papers. still shivaling is unik it having 4 mukhas an important jyoitirlinga.the only out side of india.The ghats on bagamati river is good but not clean. typical nepalian stracture

Not as great as its publication... I visited Pasupatinath on my way back to hotel in Thamel after visiting Bodnath. Taxi costs around Rs 200 from Bodnath to Pasupatinath, but you can also walk if you want to enjoy street scenery of Kathamandu. My taxi driver offered to guide me around temple for free if I took his cab back to the hotel, but once I pay the Rs 1000 entrance fee, one of the guide there told him to leave since only official guide is allowed. The guide insisted to use his service by telling me many spots inside the temple are holy and I need someone to guide my way through. Well, I do not have a choice. Inside, there's nothing much to see, no cremation, and only Sadhu are the main attraction. Plus point is the shelter for elderly accross the temple's main entrance, I was there to take some picture but end up talking with doctors from India who is doing voluntary work, really enlighting. Btw, I end up paying Rs 1000 to the guide :( so better negotiating the price upfront if you are followed by guide, and keep small rupee notes in your pocket.

Open air cremations. This collection of temples is massive and impressive. As everything in Kathmandu, it is a bit dirty and you will find stray dogs, monkeys and of course cows. I had never seen a cremation and found the whole ritual, from arrival of the dead person, washing, preparation and movement to the pyre fascinating. The entry fee is 1000 rupies, which is a lot for Nepal. Children don't pay.

great experience but not for soft hearts :)
History. Very much enjoyed visiting this priceless treasure. The architecture is beautiful and the sense of peace is inspirational.

Place of worship. If you are going to worship, then it is a typical Hindu temple with all the good and bad that comes with us.

Worth hiring a guide.. A taxi dropped us off and we kind of "fell into" hiring a guide. Considered the most holy temple of Shiva.... Located on the banks of the Bagmati River, the temple is just outside of Boudha in the outskirts of Kathmandu. One can see devout Hindu pilgrims visiting the temple daily as well as funeral pyres of local and not so local Hindus. The local Sadhus or Babas are very nice and interesting to talk to and will do their best to answer questions. The Milk Baba is especially friendly and world famous. Shivaratri, the annual celebration of Shiva is a crazy and jubilant event that is not to be missed if you are in the area. All in all a worthwhile place to visit, and one of the few major Hindu temples that even allow non-Hindus inside.
Faith overwhelms the senses. If you go with devotion - just that is enough. However like most Hindu shrines - this could do with a lot better facilities management.

the cremating temple. i had no idea what i was visiting..but our guide told us it was a cremating temple and showed us the cremating site (up to 45 a day) alongside a river that flows to the ganges...i could barely handle the smell of burning hair (and please no jokes about bbq)...our guide (beware of probin (sp); he overcharges) showed us where the rich people are cremated (up stream) and then the boys looking for gold (yes, the gold teeth from the rich cremated)...we crossed the bridge to view a series of lingam altars...thus the theme of life and death...
An ultimate divine experience. It was really a divine treat to visit Pashupatinath temple.Really felt some strong force inside the temple premises.Do remember to visit Parvati devi temple nearby.

Colorful and intense experience. It was the first thing we visited and it blew our minds. We witnessed a ceremony with an animal sacrifice, wondered around the temples and spent there a long time just watching the different ceremonies and rituals happening at the same time. You can take a bus from Ratna Park to Pasupathinath Temple. That enhaces the experience for sure!

Cremations are cool, site is underwhelming. This Temple is very pricey because of the cremations. We were fortunate enough to see a rather fancy one, but after about 15 minutes the ceremony had ended and we took to wandering the site. Ultimate Place for Hindu's. excellent experience.not crowded but people should be allowed to stay inside a few more moments.little bit more cleanliness desirable. But in Devsthan always such things happens. Location divine.

Magnificent Temple. This is a Must Visit for every person coming to Kathmandu. The temple is huge & it takes a while to visit all the shrines inside the temple. Beware of the shops close this temple as they will charge you quite high for normal stuff.

World Heritage Temple. ashupatinath Temple One of the most sacred Hindu shrines in the world, Pashupatinath lies 5 km east from the city center. The richly-ornamented pagoda houses the sacred linga, or phallic symbol, of Lord Shiva as well as the noteworthy gold plated roofs and silver coated doors. This is the abode of God Shiva and is the holiest of all the Shiva shrines.Religious pilgrims and sadhus, like the one pictured here, travel all the way from the remote areas of India to visit this sacred sight, especially during Shivaratri (the night of Shiva) that falls between February/March. Even though these devotees have denounced worldly possessions, each carries a Sadhu ID (identifications card) to freely cross over the border between India and Nepal.Chronicles indicate Pashupatinath’s existence prior to 400 AD. Devotees can be seen taking ritual dips in the holy Bagmati river flowing beside the temple, also a World Heritage Site. The crematorium is just outside the temple and it is a dream of almost every Hindu to be cremated by the side of Pashupati Aryaghat after their death.

If you've never experienced Ghats then its a must. Took a friend who has never been to Varanasi where we were able to watch the entire ritual , from Family gathering , grieving and support , to the preparation of the funeral bier and the actual burning. The experience is a quieting one, making way internally for consideration of issues of life and death which was a gift, as it seems as though in the West we run from the calm consideration.

Pashupatinath Temple, Kathmandu, Nepal. This is a very good temple of Lord Shiva. It is spread in huge area. Apart from main temple, there are many small temples inside the campus. It is being told that Bhim ( one of the Pandavas in Mahabharat) wanted to worship Lord Shiva and he was searching Lord Shiva in Himalays. To take test of Bhim's devotion and to hide from Bhim, Lord Shiva hided himself in the look of a buffalo. But, Bhim identified Lord Shiva even in the form of buffalo. Then, Lord Shiva (in the form of buffalo) tried to hide himself by going beneath the ground(land). But, Bhim caught tail of buffalo. The place where Bhim caught the tail is presently known as Kedarnath (one of chardhams of Hindus) and Shiv linga in Kedarnath(India) is rear part of buffalo and the front part (face side) is in Pashupatinath, Kathmandu, Nepal.The shiv linga in Pashupatinath is having four faces of shiva on four sides of shiv linga(East, west,north and south). The devotee must perform Darshana of all four faces. There are many brahmins available in temple . Devotees can perform "Pujavidhi" through them with nominal charge @ Rs.311/- . Overall it was very good experience.

Educational, Moving & Inspiring. Located 30 minutes from the heart of Kathmandu is this Hindu spiritual temple(s) & cremation site. It can be very confronting for people who have not seen an open air cremation on a funeral pyre, let alone 10 in a row all burning simultaneously. It is sombre and reflective, yet also a fascinating step-by-step peak into the Hindu culture and tradition of cremation and and celebration of life. As you walk through the grounds you are exposed to every aspect of this process and as unusual as it may sound, photography is welcome, common and in some cases encouraged. There are many iconic Sadhu's (holy men) lounging in hidden nooks and prayer areas in the buildings surrounding the pyres, they come complete with their long dreadlocks & glazed eyes, particularly the younger ones. Take a little time to do a thorough walk-thru if you're chasing a photograph of an older 'wise' Sadhu, if you look closely and explore the myriad of mini temples and surrounding buildings, you are bound to see some extremely photogenic locals! These amazing characters won't talk but many will pose for photos and welcome the opportunity if a few Rupees are on offer. (Always show respect and ask first or point at your camera and nod, watching for their reaction) There is also a cornea depository bank just behind the main cremation area, it is the very last stop in a long list of processes and rituals. The spiritual river trickling through the grounds and separating it into two distinct sides is the iconic Bagmati. This section flows very slowly during much of the year and with all of the activities on the banks and never-ending dumping of ashes, it is nothing short of putrid and foul. It remains however, a highly recommended spot to pay a visit to while in Kathmandu. You will leave with a deep appreciation for the fascinating and ancient processes that occur in religions around the World. It is one of the most significant Hindu temples of Lord Shiva in the world that is open to the public. (**note: a few specific areas are off limits to women and non-Hindus- signage is posted**) Allow for 2 hours. Entry fee in effect. Taxi from Thamel = 25 minutes.

confronting. Unusual site seeing experience. Being able to watch photograph smell cremations. Amazing photographic opportunities the seemingly infinite 15 votive shrines. Photographed next to 108 year old Sadhu with his five foot dredd locks rapped round my neck. Down side tourists getting to close to the cremations they should show more respect.

Most visit this Temple while you are in Kathmandu. I like the way they cremate the body on the river bank and it's open cremation is highlight of this place. There are many platform for Higher cast and to lower cast people too. I disliked the things that they have not keeped the place clean even they charge $7 per person entrance fee, so i would say they should keep everything need and clean with that money.
karma. Temple and surrounding are dirty. I do not know why temples are kept that way! I am a Hindu too. I do not mean to offend anyone in Nepal.

visit there in the evening. the entrance fee is 500 rupees...it really worth the money...you'd better there in the evening if you want to have a glimpse of the death ceremony...don't worry about the smell, it is not smelly at all...

Interesting Temple. Very interesting Hindu site with temples and river.
Location is close to the airport
must visiting when in KTM

must visit ,don't miss. me and my wife visited the temple in the morning,already a lot of devotees there,at the entrance u can see lots of pigeons being fed also number of sadhus.hindus alone can enter the temple at the entrance a big nandhi statue (bull)and a small nandhi statue ,made of some yellow metalthe main deity has four faced siva,there r 4 entrances.there r some other deities around.don't miss 365 lingams,local people worship pne lingam eveyday ,they say the hindu creamation site is also near by.if u r lucky u get a rudracha garland.u will experience lot of inner peace.it is near katmandu .so u can visit easily

Hard to explain one's feelings. This is a very surreal experience. It is difficult to process the experience in Western norms. American grieving process is very antiseptic. This is (in our experience) a very strange process. The river where ashes are distributed is considered holy, but to the observer is horribly polluted, complete with trash, livestock wandering and dogs. Bodies are cremated on pyres located above the river and ashes spread into the river below. Families of the deceased gather with the body next to the river prior to cremation. There is a building located next to the temple that functions like what we would consider a hospice. When a person is deemed terminal and near death, they are brought to this place to die at a holy site. It is a place to be respected and one needs to be cognizant of this and act accordingly. You will be set upon by very aggressive folks trying to sell items on the way in and out. They will follow you relentlessly until you finally reach your ride to leave.I would recommend this to anyone visiting Kathmandu, but be prepared for an experience the likes of which you have never seen before.

a revered Shiv Temple. things are quiet organised, one can even book different poojas a day in advance. suggest you to take a guide , their knowledge is good and they are helpful and not expensive. Foreigners are not allowed in so no point wasting money there, suggest a little hill lock next to the temple for a view.

Inspiring. Entering Pashupatinath is an inspiring experience. It is a sacred place, where cremations take place. You can just feel the atmosphere and looking at the ceremonies is an amazing experience. I would like to point out that you are looking at funerals, so be respectful of people, I think you do not want that people come and go, and take pictures of your dears' funeral.

Symbol of Kathmandu, Nepal. The most powerful temple for the hindus across the world. This site brings tourists from all over the globe due to its stories & also the work of art couple with the archeological value. Its a World Heritage site.
Ancient Shiva Temple. We had a nice darshan of Lord Shiva in the great temple. When entering the temple by the river side, we could see some volunteers cleaning up the river and the banks.
A strong experience. Pashupatinath Temple is a unforgetable place in Kathmandu. There, the Nepali culture shows its strong aspects, in all senses. If you go to Kathmandu you have to go there.
Sacred place but full of dirt, plastic bottles, bags. Interesting to see but hard to find that it was so dirty even bearing in mind that this was one of the most sacred places...

strange but I dug it. some interesting stupas and ancient Hindu sexual relief artwork to be seen. Also this is where local people have cremation ceremonies for their deceased. The mood was not somber or formal. lots of people, beware pickpockets. also watch out the fake holy men who will try and charge you to take a picture
visit to temple. Its wonderful visiting, simple and no hangama around temple. Te moment you enter temple premises guides will surround you, no need of guide. You visit yourself.

Solemn and exciting but overpriced!. We went to discover this holy Hindu temple with its historical details but not allow to enter as it's reserve for Hindu unfortunately. Instead, we were assigned to watch a funeral service of hindu rites at the opposite stand. Though we never seen one before which could 'excite' ones, it should be a private affair and respect the departed , not expose to the public. Worse still we have to pay double for entrance fee (was up after its new year day). This is like stealing from the dead and am sure they can rest in peace!

Shiva temple. The most important divine place in Kathmandu. Entry fee is high (NRs 1,000/-) but worthy place to see the Hindu traditions in practice in a single place. Sadly, non-Hindus are not permitted here.

1000 NRs - Really?. It was a rip-off at 250 NRs. I don't mind supporting tourist attractions, but there is a limit. Everybody else walked in for free. They stopped us (westerners) to extract an entrance fee (apparently needed to pay for all the fee collectors). The site has not benefited noticeably from the fees and generally offers little to see.

was on the list... but worth the visit.. For one i have visited many temples and this by far was one of the cleanest.Only Hindus allowed in the main temple, for the blessings but the area around is very nice. Great architecture.

Best place to visit in Kathmandu.. Go with plenty Of time, it is a temple complex and crematorium. I sat for hours and watched a single funeral progress from washing and mourning to enshrouding to being set on the pyre and burning. Probably not for everyone. For me this was a rare glimpse into a very important ceremony. Highlight of my trip.

Historically Beautirful. It is just amazing to be able to see history as such still standing.The artistry and the architecture of the buildings are awe-inspiring.The bathing area was pretty cool and you could go in too!!!You get a feel of the culture and that you are standing in a historical place.Definitely worth the visit.
good experience. it was a great to be experiencing the different culture in this part of the world, the place is dusty but still good for a day's trip.
Most interesting. Take your time to walk around and get the feeling of the place. I can highly recommend to hire a guide for a few hours since there is many things happening in the temple area.

Very interesting religious site. We visited the temple in Kathmandu prior to departing for our Khumbu trek in May 2013. I had read about it before coming and was very curious to see what it was all about. Most interesting was the religious cremations of Hindu loved ones through the complex. 24 hours after death, those being laid to rest are brought here and placed upon concrete tiers lined next to a small river which is supposedly sacred to all Hindus. After a brief ceremony the dead are cremated on the tiers in public with their ashes being spread amongst the river. Incredibly serene and interesting,this temple was probably my favorite side trip while in the city. The architecture of the complex is also very good and the sight/smells are unmatched. Beware of the entrance as their are many oxen and cattle roaming freely as well as vendors haggling for a sale. Once you enter take in the sights but if you want to take pics I recommend walking to the back of the complex and up the hill overlooking the temple as there are many others doing the same and it is more respectful. There are also a few asthetics within the complex willing to do a photo op for less than $2 USD if you're interested. It will cost you $1000 rupees o get in or about $10 USD. Check out my pics and enjoy!

Highly impressive temple. It shows the real life and that life goes on. Very sereen atmosphere. Impressive to be part of a very private occasion. It brings death near to life in the most positive way.

Get ready for a interesting walk. Be sure and get one of the locals as a guide. I used a 1-armed man of about 40 that was fantastic. This site is extremely large with a lot of walking to do but well worth it. Wear comfortable shoes and be ready to go up and down. Bring water with you that you know is clean. So much to see so be sure to set aside several hours. Well worth the visit.
the temple is a great architectural achievement. I was sorry I could not see the temple inside and also other areas. but it was an interesting experience.

A Rare Glimpse. Visiting Pashupatinath gives rare glimpses into the end of life that is so hidden in western society. Take a guide so you can get a deeper understanding of the place and the many kinds of rituals that occur there.

Thought I'd be afraid but I wasn't. Thought I'd be afraid but I wasn't. In fact, this was the most memorable part of our trip. The cultural significance of this site is astonishing. I was in awe and ended up staying almost 2 hours instead of the 30 minutes I thought I would only manage. We had a local guide and driver with us which I highly recommend. The smell can be overwhelming at first so I stayed high up on the bridge. Bring money to tip the Babas if you want a picture with them.

Unforgettable. This was a great experience! We loved the magical feeling of this place. It is like entering another world...Being greeted with "Would you like to see some burning bodies" i was a bit reserved but i am so glad i visited! Having a glimpse into a different culture, different burial ceremonies, ancient temples and beautiful surroundings...it made the visit go by too fast and even the heat didn't matter much. Highly recommend visiting the place.
Fascinating. Make sure you stop and watch the public cremations - it's quite acceptable for members of the public to observe what we would usually consider a private ceremony.

A view of another world. This is one of the holiest of Hindu sites (only Hindus are admitted to the inner temple), to Western eyes, where loss and grieving are private matters, watching cremations taking place out in the open is quite raw. But you should not be deterred by this as the architecture is well worth seeing.

Our famous Pilgrim,Lord Shiva's Peace Home.. If you come hear for an experience similar to what you get in holy cities such as Varanasi then expect to be disappointed. The sadhus (or holy men) are fake and are only after money. There are kids on drugs (glue sniffing) and the river is almost dry. The guides will take you in the daytime - but that's pointless. You MUST go in the evening around 07 pm. for the place to be interesting. And if you've not been to Varanasi then you will probably get a kick out of the area.

Impressive place, the entrance fee is quite high but not unavoidable. We arrived today at the temple and got spooked of by the enormous entrance fee.A staggering 1000 R. to enter a sacred hindu site.If you are backpacking that could take up a big part of your budget.And if the money would all go to restoring and maintenance of the place.... but as with Durbar Square you know that's not what's happeningThe first way of avoiding this is to get involved with one of the dodgy "tour guides" that offer you second hand tickets that where purchased in the morning and valid for one day.They will resell the ticket for half the price including their guide services.We where quite put off by the whole situation and decided to take a stroll around the area.Whe ended up on the other side of the hill where a small trail leads you up the hill and along the fence for the temple grounds.You walk along a nice park where people play cricket and picknick in the park. There is a small set of stairways which lead down to the cremation area,You end up somewhere that feels behind the scenes of the temple. From there you can stroll around and leave the same way,

Not for the weak-hearted. Overall, a pretty disgusting place. The river is a tiny stream flowing through piles of garbage. The temple grounds are filthy, the burning bodies, animal sacrifices, etc., do not add to the charm.

revered place of lord siva at Nepal. According to Puranas lord was discovered by a Cow at this place and hence it is called as Pashupatinath. This temple reveals that lord Siva not only love to human beings but animals too.Pandavas were searching lord Siva during there way on heavenly abode but Siva disguised himself in the form of an animal but recognized by Bhima and he tried to catch him but Siva disappeared,this incidence relates to Kedarnath ji at Uttrakhand and the mouth of disguised Siva appered at Pashupatinath temple at Kathmandu in Nepal.The temple is neat and clean having idols of Budhe Neelkantha, Vasuki Snake ,Maa Parvati, Lord Bhairon ji and big metal idol of lord Nandi ji.The situation is near banks of Bagmati river and 12 Sivalinga are also siutated on the banks of the river. Unfortunately river is having no flow of pure water. performance of Cremation alongside river is not good. it increases air pollution and against the Hindu feelings.Places of cremation and Pashubali should be separated from temple premises. Nepal being Hindu Rashtra must consider this fact.However there is no snatching of money by pandas and mandir is having 4 gates for Darshan.While at Nepal one must visit this revered place of Lord Siva and seek the blessings. The heritage is well recognized by UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITES and dates back to 400 A.D. Lord Siva and maa Parvati visited this place to bless upon the devotees according to Hindu Shastras.

Not A Patch on Varanasi.. If you come hear for an experience similar to what you get in holy cities such as Varanasi then expect to be disappointed. The sadhus (or holy men) are fake and are only after money. There are kids on drugs (glue sniffing) and the river is almost dry. The guides will take you in the daytimes - but that's pointless. You MUST go in the evening around 7pm for the place to be interesting. And if you've not been to Varanasi then you will probably get a kick out of the area.

Heart of the hindus. This place is not only old, but its also very sacred. it is one of the most important heritage for the Hindus. This sacred site offers a scene that is really very hard to forget. The rituals to prayers that people offer there is really something to be acknowledged. This place is huge and it is definitely a place to experience a glimpse of hindusim and its faith in the people's heart there.

Unbelievable. Well......what a life experience this was. We watched the ceremony from start to finish as the dead were carried to the holy river, feet bathed, and the custom of preparing the body for cremation...right through to the laying of the body on the wooden platform, placing the fire in the mouth and then covering the body and allowing the cremation to take place. Unbelievable!!!

A confronting visit.. At this temple you can easily visit THE burning ghats. Here the hindoeist people burn their relatives. In can be very confronting, so look at yourself and expessialy your children.Its an easy walk from here to the bouddanath stupa. Ask your way and THE people will show you.
Pashupatinath Temple. This is the famous holiest Hindu temple of Nepal. Thousands of travelers are visited this temple during the seasons.
Nice Temple. Pashupatinath Temple has its own value for Hindu religion. the idol of lord shiva is of parash rock told by our guide.

Must See. As filthy as this place appears on the outside it offers an incredible cultural experience. I visited this temple twice to do my photography. I was rewarded with amazing pics of the Baba Ji's to the actual cremation ceremonies that were taking place.

A rare chance to visit one of Hinduism's most sacred sites. too expensive. 1000 roupies, that is 10 euros and you can not get into the temple, which is reserved for hindus, the only thing interesting is the crematoria but still 1000 roupies this is a lot of money in Nepal

Becoming a rip-off destination. At Rs1,000 each it is getting expensive. Think carefully especially if you are on a budget. There are other places that provide more and the money is being used to resatore and maintain them

Sense of spirituality and religious divine. Brilliant! if you go to the temple early morning lets say around 6 or in the evening after 6 and afternoon at around 2 you will enjoy the calmness and can avoid the crowd also would give you a sense of spirituality and religious divine of the temple! have visited the temple 3 times in past one year every-time I visit there is new facet of Hinduism I get engaged to!
Crematorium. Really interesting. Worth seeing just to see how the different cultures manage death. Have opportunity to be photographed with holy men

It is a very spiritual experience it was a night like no other i am attached to that place personaly for many reasons bu. it was beautiful ...lot of spirit magical sunset views and we witnessed special Monday Puja for Lord Siva time which was an experience like no other .Hundred of people chanting and singing together with live music while the sun was setting behind the beautiful roof top of the Temple.Amazing .Must see!

not for the faint of heart. culturally awakening. Its worth paying someone a few ruppies to explain what is all going on. This is a 24 hour affair but I was there in the late afternoon and saw all that I needed to.

A magical experience.. Visit in the evening at about 18.30pm. Each night there is a celebratory/ mystical and musical ceremony to worship Lord Shiva. It is a spine tingling experience, never to be forgotten. The celebration lasts for about an hour. I have always found the Hindu participants so welcoming to visitors.

Very moving place. A sacred Hindu place and very moving with the cremations happening right in front of you. I visited all the major attractions in Kathmandu and found hear and boudanath stupa the two best.

Heaven for Hindus. Excellent temple, Very sacred for Hindus Beware the temple is right next to cremation ground. the view of cremation ground may disturb a lot of people and children so better stay away from the outer boundry of temple. Other then that very nice place

Conflicting. I visited Pashupatinath as part of a day long UNESCO heritage site tour. Of the four major sites we visited this was my least favorite. It is a very holy place for Hindus and is where all cremations in Kathmandu for Hindus take place. Please note these cremations are visible and in the open air. Bring a scarf or mask with you. You will 95% sure see at least one cremation. On the day we were there there were four occurring when we walked in. Non-Hindus cannot enter the temple and most end up staying on one side of the complex. I have been to a lot of holy places of all sorts of different religions before and this one didn't have the feeling like a holy place. It felt like it was a neglected place where people are easily taken advantage of. There are also "sadhus" sitting around and will let you take a picture for a price. It just overall had a negative feeling to me. I kept trying to see and feel why it was holy but I couldn't. You will also most likely get hassled from the street all the way to the temple complex by people selling things. If you go I would plan to spend less than a half hour here.

It's right next to cremation place. This temple is only allowed for Hindus to enter, others can only view it from afar. It's right next to the funeral home of Kathmandu where you may see deceased being cremated. Please try not to take pictures to respect the family members of the deceased.But it's an UNESCO site.

Touching place. The Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most sacred and important Hindu temples in the world and dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple is located on the banks of the Bagmati River and you could get a good feel of Hindu traditions and culture there. You can find a little pagoda town full of monkeys running around but I felt a bit uncomfortable seeing the cremation ceremony from the other side of the holy Bagmati River....

A must visit. We've been there in March 2013.You'll have the opportionity to see local funerals - that is - local burning of the deads.The place is interesting and gives you an insight to the local religious ceremonies.I'm not sure that it would be the best place for children...

Shiva place. its great place to see real, powerful face of Shiva. i like sit deep inside park, on ancient stones, listening to the birds and monkeys. good for any kind of meditations if you are practicing

Spectacular temple with corrupt priests. If you are a Hindu, visit this temple but avoid doing darshan. There is no bhakti-seva among the pandits here. They are only after money and are extremely greedy. Non-Hindus need not worry about this as they won't let you in. My husband had to wait outside in spite of being married to a Hindu.
An evening at Pashupatinath. A great temple to visit. I liked the drum beats from the attic of the entrance. The temple has no artificial constructions. Its pure and magical!
Excellent temple. The temple area is huge and is really worth visiting especially if you are a hindu. Get yourself blessed.

Interesting insight into Hindu rituals. Although only Hindus can enter the actual temple, there is still plenty to see on the site. The sight of burning bodies may not be for the squeamish but the rituals are fascinating. I'd recommend a guide to give you a good understanding of what's going on but, as with most things in Kathmandu, negotiate a price before you start. From here you can walk to Bodnath and the contrast between the two sites is worth seeing.

Lord shiva's unique temple. I always wanted to visit this temple and this time I got a chance..its a very holy place , an ancient temple of lord shiva..I went there at around 11 am..which was aarti time and I was lucky to watch all the rituals..its si spiritual and mesmerizing.. Can't express exactly in words..must must visit temple of kathmandu for everyone. Taking snaps inside the temple is prohibited.

Hindu Temple and Cremation Place. as well super exotic and a beautiful big Hindu Temple where you see them in their religious practice and also for funerals (burning the bodies like in India giving the ashes into the river) must do in Kathmandu

beautiful people. very nice to walk on cool weather day, I was sitting down at a corner watching how the local would move around so carefreely, it is unlike where I come from, everyone seems to be either rushing home or work. Beautiful culture and people.

Efficient though too bad about the river's condition...... Late Feb-Mar 2013Pashupatinath - was a funeral and cremation place. Apparently the sacred river is dirty because all things that are brought/used for the funeral ceremony must be thrown into the sacred river along with the ashes of the dead. The dead is fed with rice grain and sent off with tikka powder as final beautification, given drink from sacred river and covered in yellow cloth. Packs of natural oil are placed on logs of wood, unclothed and burnt just as is, in the belief human enters the world naked and thus, will return naked. Similar to what Job noted in the book of Job in the Bible - "naked came I out of the earth, naked, shall I return." ! It is interesting to learn that the river is cleansed once a year by the head of towns, armies, police and locals. This part of temple is opened 24 hours, 365 days, very efficient indeed. A mask can be handy if you have sensitive sinus depending on the timing. If you were superstitious and not used to seeing the dead, it is better to just look from afar and leave before entering the final part of this temple. If only a way could be found to put the dead and his/er final belongings 'eco-ly' into the river........

Janam jaturta vinasak lingam(by worshipping shivlingum you can actually get rid of process of taking birth again.. Nice place with intense feeling ,good view of shivlingums in one row ,ceremation ceremony and ghats for brahmins,vips and royal family...only thing i dont like the concept of not allowing inside non-Hindu i was with the friend and he was stopped as he is foreigner so i didn't feel like to go inside too..Main logic behind this is that temple is known as pashupati (god of animals) and somehow they linked animal category only to cow and stops non-Hindu to be sure that anyone who eats cow meat should not enter the main premises..But to my dismay i see many Nepali people eating on streets,restaurants and common places buffalo meat which is also from the same family line of cow and animal too for this also they have a logic that buffalo is a carrier of yama and a symbol of devil so eating it is considered eating the devil??? crazy logic as i myself is a Hindu and traveled most of spiritual places and some spiritual rituals and beliefs is not understandable by me and many others too people are simply following it because its going on from many generations and as hindu we really have to understand what is logical and which is not instead of just following it as our elders did.

Hard to rate this unusual place. I would have given this place top marks except for the heavy feeling one has upon entering it. Definitely, one of the holiest Hindu places in Nepal. But the whole open cremation process that is open for everyone to see is hard to describe. Definitely NOT for the faint hearted as the deceased is not fully covered.

Not worth the price if you are not a Hindu. First of all, the ticket counter made me pay even though I am Indian. The tour guide hovering around us tried to stop me from going in with my ticket because when I did, everyone was really pissed that I was forced to pay and made me get my money back - which was nice. The temple itself is beautiful but the surrounding area that the tourists get to see is not really worth the entrance fee.

A 'must see' !. I visited this temple while on my recent trip to Nepal. It is a must see in Kathmandu. It is a huge campus and finding the main temple may require some enquiries. You will see a lot of Sadhus - most of them dressed in dazzling orange dresses. Don't be surprised if some of them are smoking dope - after all, they are worshipers of Lord Shiva.Couple of things i didn't like about the temple - 1. Only Indians are allowed to go inside the main temple. Hinduism is never restrictive. Foreigners have access to all outer temples and the outer area of the main temple campus.2. There is a cremating ground right inside the campus - that adds a bit of uneasiness.

Do not leave KTM without visiting this place. A must see for all visitors to Nepal. There are hundreds of Hindu and Buddhist temples in KTM but this should be in the top of the list. Visited thrice in my 11 days stay. SrinivasanMuscat, Oman
a must!. This is a fascinating cultural experience for visitors. Give yourself the time to visit. If you can, read up on Hinduism and Hindu death rituals before you visit.
A fascinating cultural experience. Learn a bit about Hinduism and Nepal first, if you can. Some of what the guides will tell you is hogwash, but it's always entertaining.

A very different shiv temple. It is quite unlike a shiva temple. It's a shanti peeth and only Hindus are allowed in the temple. The place is divine and has a good feel to it. One one side of the temple there is a cremation ground which has a bad stench to it. Overall good experience and recommended. Beware of the touts on the way
Nice - but not a favourite. There is a bit of a walk, past the inevitable hawkers, to get to this temple. It wasn't my favourite.

Hindu Temple. This is a UNESCO supported site and is undergoing quite a bit of redevelopment. You can also witness a live cremation!!!! Something I found upsetting in Nepal in general is that you cannot enter a hindu temple unless you are a hindu.

Worth a Visit for Westerners. Everyone should come here to witness the public Hindu cremations. As a westerner, when you get there you should pay for a guide (negotiate first - no more than a few hundred Rs) to understand more of why its a public ceremony and the reasons behind the part of the ceremony. It's a sad yet fascinating place, but like I said, worth seeing once.

A true cultural experience. We discretely viewed a funeral from the far bank of the Bagmati River. While the smell and smoke were unpleasant, it was something we had never experienced in our lives. The sadhus roaming the grounds, various families waiting for their loved ones to be cremated, and people with various health problems begging for alms added to the tone. As non-Hindus, we were not allowed to enter the temple itself, but we did walk up to the front and look inside as far as we were able. The children using magnets to fish for coins in the river was interesting as well.

Smell of burning hair can be a bit much. Love it or hate the sight of burning bodies is something many people find quit emotional. The Bagmati is not a big river at this point so you don't get the same feel as Varanasi but then you are much closer so its feels more personal. Make sure you walk up to the tombs on the hill as well and keep your eye out for monkeys !!

Only one in Nepal. Pashupatinath is a Hindu temple on the banks of the Bagmati River in Deopatan, a village 3 km northwest of Kathmandu. It is dedicated to a manifestation of Shiva called Pashupati (Lord of Animals). It attracts thousands of pilgrims each year and has become well known far beyond the Kathmandu Valley. The temple is barred to non-Hindus, but a good view of the temple can be had from the opposite bank of the river.

Cremation site. Near this temple is a cremation site along the river. I found this very interesting, as there were several cremations going on at the time. Our guide explained about the Hindu customs regarding death and cremation. Non Hindus may not enter the temple.

Shivaratri - a must for western tourists. We visited the Pashupatinath Temple on the first day of the legendary birthday of Lord Shiva, with at least a half a million hindus. Surprisingly things were far more peaceful than expected. Don´t miss it !!!Don´t start off before 3 pm. Take the shortcut from the airport side and scramble to the temples an ghats on the eastern side of the bagmati river. Here you can get close contact to pilgrims and sadhus. Leave after sunset, when things get a little freaky.
Another must see in kathmandu. You can not miss this place. You should be prepared for the visit. To see the cremations all around. You should visit both sides of the river and walk around. Enjoy it

Be sure to see. To visit this area and be viewing mourning families from across the river then observing their deceased family member being cremated in front of people taking photos was quite interesting to say the least. It made me feel both entranced and intrusive at the same time. A very worth while place to visit. An entry fee is payable and be wary of people who push themselves on you as a guide then expect payment.

Fascinating and surprisingly peaceful. This is a great place to visit and is an integral part of Hindu/Neplaese culture. Spare at least an hour for a good look round and a walk up the hill for some great views. Many have suggested asking an unofficial guide which are very inexpensive.

Interesting, but nothing special. The temple itself is off limits to all non-Hindu's and so you can only walk around the outer grounds and if you are into that sort of thing, watch the bodies being cremated beside the filthy stream. OK for an hour or so, but not worth the Rp.500 entry fee in my opinion.

Serenity and Chaos at the same time. A visit to Pashupati Temple in Kathmandu is an absolute MUST. This is a busy place with many different things to see and experience. I was amazed how on one level I felt as if I was part of the process involved with families dealing with the death of their loved ones contrasted with the cheeky monkeys who run around ready to snatch anything you might have. These two things happen side by side so you experience the emotion of life and death at the same time.It is a place you can take time to reflect on what is really important in life, and it is quite moving to see the rituals involved around death and yet this is a happy place to visit. Go and visit and just see what comes up for you.

Shiva's 'birthday'. we happened to be fortunate enough to visit here the day prior to Shiva's 'big celebration' day so things were really ''pumping' here and literally 'thousands were there., so there was LOTS to capitivate you. Not so sure if it would have been so diverse on a 'quioet day' As with all 'tourist sites' around KTM you are reaching into the back pocket for entrance fees again- and not that cheap either!

Excellent to see with unofficial guide. To visit this place without a guide can feel a bit uncomplete. Luckily there was a young student at the entrance offering his duty for....you will pay me in the end as much as you want. So I learned a lot about this amazing place. Hope at least most of it was truth :)
very good temple. heritage architecture.great place to have serenity.the temple is a place to take blessings.beautiful temple.

Amazing. The temple is an amazing place to visit from funeral pyres and saddhus, votive shrines and monkeys...all gives an interesting insight into the culture. Shame about the river and the litter. Well worth a visit.

Devotion and Grace Personified by Lord Siva. This temple is a must see place, when visiting Kathmandu. You can get a complete feel of Hindu culture and Vedic traditions at the site; filled with incense sticks, mantras in the air and bells ring.This temple has 4 doors and the deity can be seen from all the four doors and stays always crowded. Photography and wearing shoes/slippers are not allowed in the temple premises. There are a lot of stores selling Rudraksha beads around the temple and do check for the authenticity before you buy them with a good bargain.You can feed pigeons or give any offerings to the temple as wished. Kindly avoid the river banks at the end of the temple as that location is used for cremating the dead (As per Hindu Traditions).

My favorite attraction in Katmandu. You have everything at Pashupatinath: ancient sights, current culture (cremations); monks, monkeys, deer. Just an exciting and interesting place to be. My favorite sight in Katmandu.We had someone follow us around as a guide; not asked for...he just followed us around, told us about the sights, and expressed disappointment about the size of our tip.

Sombre atmosphere. Makes you reflect on life, death and your destiny. Only wish is that the govt and local people will do something positive to alleviate the litters and bad pollution to the precious river.

Cremation site. The temple is on the banks of the Bagmati River and is aHindu Temple. You have to walk quite a few stairs to reach the top platform. On the banks opposite the temple is the Cremation site. we actually watched the preparation for a cremation and then the full ceremony. after the cremation, the ashes are returned to the river.

This is a place where the dead bodies are burnt. I was every much eager to see this temple but sorry to say I was not happy at all after I see because this is a place where the dead bodies are burnt which make me very sad

Life (and Death) in the Raw. This place is South Asia's answer to Federico Fellini.... Pashupati is sacred to Hindus, especially followers of Shiva. To walk its extensive grounds is to stroll through some of Hinduism's most sacred lore: "Here's where Lord Shiva leapt across the river"; "Here's where a part of Devi's body fell." (Buddhism's too: Tilopa and Naropa allegedly meditated there, on the banks of the Bagmati.) It's been around for more than 1700 years. So visiting it is like a wal through human history. There are gangs of monkeys and rows of fake holy men, preening their moustaches and demanding huge fees for photos. The paths along the river are an open air funeral parlor, where families cremate their dead loved ones. But the forest and temple complexes up bove are a tranquil place where real holy men meditate and pilgrims wander in peace. It's a bewildering, fascinating place. Worth a visit. Know that it's life "unfiltered".

Colorful Hindu Shrine. Don't just go to see the burning ghats. These are sacred Hindu shrines, and the devoted are colorful and friendly. Lot of flowers and temples. Take care with your camera, the monkeys can be a bit annoying.

Nice architecture and devotion. I was astonished mainly seeing the area of the whole paspati temple. It was big. the architecture is note worthy, the place is moderately clean. I see people have lot of time for devotion in god in Nepal. The dead people are burnt openly which is bad and all ashes are thrown in the rivver which flows through.

Waste of time!. The place is really dirty with bad smell all over the place as corpse were brunt openly and also throwing the ashes in the canal making it worse. Due to burning the corpse the place is really suffocating. Its better not going there unless you are hindu.

heritage. me and my husband just got back from nepal.had the chance of visiting the temple.in one word its huge and of course of religious significance for hindus.I was happy to see a world heritage.But the smoke and smell was suffocating sometimes.its one of a kind experience to explore the chita burning(cremetion).Not enjoyable for all but for those who care for a heritage.Its free for the SAARC countries only.

Connect to Lord Shiva !!. Pre Book a Puja - a day earlier by going to the Temple office - enjoy being close to the Lord & take Eternal Blessings !!
A Must Visit for anybody Spiritually Inclined - Located in the Heart of the City - Next to the Airport - No Ques - No Trouble Some Temple Priests !!
Beware of monkeys. I visited the temple just before it was about to close and while standing in front of the shiva linga I witnessed a monkey who had caught hold of a mans back.
Strong stomach required. Here you can look down on a Hindu temple and cremation site. You will also be accosted by sadhus (wandering Hindu holy men).

You'll likely see funeral ceremonies on the riverbank. This site is interesting, although non-Hindu's are not allowed inside the temple. This holy site is near the Bagmati River where cremation ceremonies are held daily.
blissful. blessed are the ones who get opportunity to visit the temple.there is always heavy rush so plan accordingly

Nice Shrine, Lots of Monkeys, Burning Ghats. Well worth a visit. There's lots to see, plenty of temples and shrines in the park behind the main (hindu-only) Pashupatinath temple. A lot of monkeys too, which don't mess with you if you don't annoy them. The burning pyres on the Ghats are also a humbling experience.

Heritage comes Alive!!. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most ancient temples in the world. Had the previlege to visit the temple in Feb-13. You might find some rush after 9 AM so try to visit earlier to avoid the rush. The temple is very big & it might take some to visit the entire temple.Please note that the entry is for Hindu's Only(Although didn't like that).Outside the temple you may find many small & big stalls for "Rudraksh". Remember if you are in Nepa, buy the Big Rudraksh. The Big Rudraksh are the one which are found in nepal. The small ones are brough from India & they might be expensive due to that. Remember to bargain heavily if you are buying.

Amazing and scary at the same time. The experience was eye-opening. I went there in the evening and saw a gathering of people along the river. They were about to do a funeral with a dead body wrapped in yellow cloth lying on the stairs by the river. The atmosphere was indescribable .. Haunting, too real, yet beautiful. The fact that the air you breathed in smelled of burned corpses could make you feel uncomfortable but at the same time conscious about your presence and the meaning of life and death. I wanted to explore the hospice but my friend was too scared to accompany me. We left after 10 minutes. if you haven't seen anything like this, visit this place for once.
A must in Kathmandu. Very strange place for a westener. It is possible to follow the funeral service. Odd place. I would recommend going there in the evening when it is dark.

Another moving experience. I loved this place. We were there at sunset and the sun setting behind skeletal like trees on the top of the hills created a wonderful image. Seeing the cremation fires burning and people saying their final goodbyes to their loved ones was moving but also a very life affirming experience.

Must see experience - but not for the faint hearted. We spent several hours at the Temple and surrounds and found the whole thing absolutely facinating. You dont need to be Hindu to respect their beliefs in the River and God(s) and how they approach and deal with the topic of death and there is no better way to learn about it than to see it in action.We had our hotel drop us off and then were appoached by a guide at the gate who was very knowledgable. My only regret is not negotiating a fee in advance as I fear we probably paid a lot more than market rate but chalked that up to another lesson learnt as a traveller.It was especially facinating to see the whole cycle - the Nursing Home, the Hospice, the Crematoria, the Temple, the Widows area, and even the caves and chanting mourners up the river. Of course the river is filthy ( they cremate up to 50 bodies a day !) it was sad to see children trawling the river for valuables but this is not unique to the Temple, nor Nepal. The resident religious men will hit you up for a dollar or two for photos but its a small price to pay for a very unique photo !

Not for Everyone. A very significant temple for the Hindu faith and the temple itself is not open to Non-Hindus. Never the less, the complex is worth a visit and most significantly the Crematoria that is located outside the temple along the river.This is the part that is not for everyone. Standing across the river from the temple you can witness the preparation of the dead and ultimately the burning of these bodies on funeral pyres.

Hindu culture to the extreme. This was my 2nd visit to Pashupatinath where I introduced my sister to this unbelievable site. First of all, non-Hindus are prohibited from entering their temple, but there's plenty to experience in the environs. Many foreigners are a bit shocked to see the non-stop cremations burning along the river, but they do make for some interesting photos. Beware of the non-stop stream of "local guides" who will nag you to death. This site does not require a long stay and we were happy to move on to Boudanath and Swayambhuath for a more relaxed Buddhist cultural experience.

The Ultimate. The Ultimate Shiva Temple in the world!I have been here twice. This trip was something special as i had arranged before arriving to get a special pooja done.The experience was more than just spiritual as you are part of ancient tradition and history. The temple priests are extremely humble and helpful with all requests.I am planning another visit - hopefully for Shivarathri 2013 - which i believe is the biggest Shivarathri in the world.This site comes extremely highly recommended as the temple is well maintained and kept neat and tidy - you will enjoy this temple. Also, read about the tradition and history first - this will enhance your experience of the temple.

Oldest Shiva temple in Nepal. We reached the Pashupatinath temple during the evening aarti and witnessed the complete ritual followed in it. The people were friendly and guided us at most times. Loved the sanctity of the temple campus. The water body in the lake was serene in the evening. We only wished we could spend some more time.One can buy red coral beads and 'rudraksha' here.
Great Place to meet Devotes. Great place with numerous of god and goddess all around. The environment is itself devoted. Must visit place for the travelers who come to nepal.
