Get a guide to give you more detail. To a westerner, the complexity of this place may be totally surreal. We had an amazing guide who explained a lot for us to be able to realize what this place is and its significance to the Nepalese people. Another unique place to go see and experience.

A holy place for Hindus !. Pashupati Temple is the most significant Shiva temples in the world which is highly regarded by Hindus. It situated in Kathmandu, Capital of Nepal, besides the bank of Bagmati river. In earlier days only born hindus were allowed to enter into the temple. However, now the visitors are allowed to enter the temple but no one can take pictures inside the temple premises. The Big bull made up of brass guards the door of the temple in front. The temple has four doors in four direction which opens only one time in a day. On the Shiva Ratri and Teej festivals the temple is highly crowded and Government has to deploy thousands of police men in order to manage the visitors.

Get to view some unusual traditions up close. The entry fee of 500 R was well worth it. Keep in mind that you will have someone approach you not long after entering, just having a chat to you in English about different things around. My 9 year old twins and I went twice. The first time we just wanted to be left alone and relax but the guy wouldn't leave despite us ignoring him at first. If you don't want them to keep on, you must be really, really firm. The kids were impressed with the cows roaming around. The holy men covered in ash was another hit. If you take pictures with them they don't mind but you must give them a tip. About 30 R is ok but they will look at it as though you have given them a piece of dirt. Don't worry about that. There are so many amazing things to look at. The burning pyres with families sitting around. The wrapped bodies laying beside the river, waiting to be put on the fire. This a place where the guide is definately worth every penny but fix a price first. We paid 500 R for an hour or so. It's worth walking up the beautiful steps and sitting for a while, looking over the river and the people. The prices of souvenirs is inflated here. At least 50% off. Just walk away and they will follow you. We took a private taxi from Thamel as it was quite warm and easier with the twins. 300R each way.

If you aren't Hindu, you won't get in the Temple. You can see firsthand the pollution in the holiest river in Nepal, but if you are not Hindu you cannot get into the actual temple, only the courtyards.The grounds were nothing truly exceptional. It was interesting seeing the cremation ceremonies going on.There were lots of people around, seemed to be locals. Monkeys are around too, so beware of your food/bags. The old "Babas" that are holy men with dreadlocks and traditional clothing are most likely only there because they want you to pay to take a photo of them, or with them. Don't fall for that. I enjoyed other historic sights in Kathmandu compared to this.

Experience it the once.... We hired a tour guide and experienced in one day the holiest place for Hindus and Buddhists - good contrast from Pashupatinath and the Boudha Stupa. I think to really appreciate this place you do need a guide or a good travel book to find out the importance of this place to the Hindus in Nepal.Not a lot to do and if you are not a Hindu you cannot enter the temple so only an hour or so needed. The Saddus were funny as there were 4 of us in our group and each time we went to get our photo taken with them they whispered to us their price. Started off at 300 rupees and the last person was asked for 800! Didn't get their price! On a serious note this is a place of mourning and also to be respectful to the grieving families- I didn't like when people were taking pictures of the funeral pyres like it was some tourist attraction. For me it was something I had only seen on the tv so to see it first hand was interesting but also moving.

no more never. this is the place which i would never visit again . it is worth a visit once to know the importance and the heritage importance. How a place can be kept unclean , we got to visit this place. corpse being burnt at one place , dust pollution , dirty water , noisy, urchins troubles;dirty smell; beggars , so called sadhus who sends creeps up your spine . a very uneasy feeling after this visit to this pshupatinath

holy pilgrimage. very holy place with lots of pilgrims from india and abroad very serene atmosphere lots of monkeys have to be careful needs more basic toilets and wash rooms drinking water facilities and police out posts some good restaurants for snacks and tea

Place of Death. Interesting, but you have to read to make you mind before you came the first time. Very special for Hindu and difficult to Westerns. Odor, very dirty river and observers... Do not recommend to visit

Fascinating to visit. Visiting Pashupatinath is a fascinating experience. Go and sit and watch the world go by as there is something happening in every direction. Take your camera as well. Noone seems to mind having their photograph taken.

Challenged my identity. This temple challenged me greatly. I must admit, I could not wait to get out of there once I was inside, yet when reflecting, I am glad I visited and had the chance to feel uncomfortable. Being a white woman, I was a minority and stared at by everyone there. There were bodies being cremated right in front of me and being pushed into the cement creek below.I say that it challenged my identity because I went there believing that I embraced difference and culture but realised that when placed into an environment where the caste system is explicit and "in your face" That I struggled with it immensely and did not embrace any of it. That being said, it was an experience I'll never forget

Amazing place. If you can come in from the side, it won't be so stressful as coming in the main entrance, where you will be hassled non-stop to buy something.I went there twice, and the second time came in from a side entrance after crossing the river, and it was really nice and local. Come out near the deer park zoo part.The top of the temple is very old and peacful, so it is well worth to walk up to the top of the Hill and spend some time there. Here you can meet some interesting Hindhu Yogis also.
Peace...... Go Relax and let the peace flow within you... Nice place if you are alone and want to spend some time alone..
Impressive and beautiful place. Go here to (from a distance) experience the burning ritual of the Nepali people. It is also a beautiful place with the temples, trees and holy people (saddhus).

AMAZING experience, but not for the weak hearted. I have been there a couple of times, and I would HIGHLY suggest spending a few dollars and getting a tour guide to explain what is going on. On two occasions, we got a tour guide and were amazed by what was going on. The first time we paid a kid near the entrance to take us around and he explained who the people were and what the ceremonies that took place there were all about. The second time, we actually got to see the entire process from the time that a body is washed in the water of the river to the actual cremation. Once you understand what is taking place, it becomes much more spiritual. I HIGHLY suggest going by... and even if you dont see a cremation, the Sodu's are always fun to chat with

A Experience. A really interesting experience but also quite bizarre. Loads of tourists arriving to watch funerals. Families are saying goodbye to their loved ones whilst tourists look on. Nearby a woman washes her clothes in the 'river' and another near her washing her hair. Some amazing temples.

Amazing. This amazing Hindu complex is one of the most venerated in all East. Though one can not enter the temple itself, the compound is ver large and there are many other smaller temples one can visit. Here people burn their dead.

Fascinating. Very interesting temple complex. Not all accessible to non Hindus, but lots to see. You may see the cremations taking place, which I found interesting, but some may not. You can get pestered a bit here , and the sadhus WILL want money for a photo. The entrance fee is a bit steep, but well worth a visit for a couple of hours
Preparation before visiting Varanasi. It's one of the holiest places for Hindus where they cremate the dead. Not for the faint-hearted. Visitors are allowed up to the bridge. A "must see"!

another high place of Hinduism worth being seen for its activity. The place is worth being seen for its architecture, offering various constructions of Hinduism style, but also for the activity going around it, it's obviously a religious place placed high in the esteem of the city people

Mixed emotions. A great spiritual place for me and fulfilled a longheld wish to visit and pray. Fortunately landed on a day when it was not crowded and had the opportunity to soak in the place and atmosphere. Caution when utilising the services of Pandits around the temple, it is a nexus of Indian pandits and out to make some good money. Did not feel the recitals & chanting by them had any spiritual connections.
great experience. Have one of the locals guide you through. It's worth the $10 to have a guide. Really neat experience, especially if cremations occurring.

culture shock. this is a very sacred, important place to the people, for a westerner it is quite disturbing in one way , fasinating in another, the holy river is here, where the dead are brought to be creamated, visually it is quite challenging

Amazing experience. It was a very spiritual place and seeing so many devoted hindus is really amazing. The temple is beautiful, luckily as I and my family are hindus, we were able to enter and it is a truly magical temple, there is something special about it that I would definitely recommend other hindus to visit. If you cannot go inside, it is still nice to soak up the atmosphere outside and witness people going about their business.

Something really different. I felt a bit uncomfortable watching the cremation ceremony from the opposite side of the river...the river is filthy and really, I couldn't wait to leave. Our guide was describing what was happening during the ceremony but I felt sorry for the families as it is such a tourist attraction with everyone taking photos. There were monkeys running around which took your mind off what was happening across the river....for a few minutes. This is a place I won't forget in a hurry and a definite insight into another culture.

Different and thought-provoking. We had been recommended to make the Pashupatinath Temple our first stop and were glad we did. It gives an insight into Hindu culture that it is hard to find elsewhere. It is not beautiful and it is not clean and there is poverty and there are beggars and there are funeral pyres and cremation ceremonies and there are criplings and the river is incredibly filthy. Still, it is thought-provoking and different and quite unforgettable. Following a tour of the grounds we walked from Pashupatinath to Bodnath along the route described in the Lonely Planet guidebook and recommend that peaceful stroll through suburbian Kathmandu.
Fascinating. A fascinating insight and an amazing window into another culture. Not to be missed when visiting KTM

Impressive place. This is an amazing temple, and dedicated to the godess Pashupati, an ephitet of the godess Shiva. It has two remarcable parts, the crematory area and the pagoda area, both separated by the main river.The crematory area is, generally, full of tourist that doesn't respect at all the pain of the families that are suffering for their deads. It's a frivolous fact to see how the tourist shoot photos and more photos without thinking in this, it has became a show. My reccomendation is to watch this ritual with respect and silence, but above all, to visit the pagoda area in which only a few tourist are interested to go. You can go just going to the right following the path of the river, climbing the long tram of stairs.You will find a little pagoda town full of monkeys. Beware of them, they are WILD, dont show or give them food, otherwise they may attack you, I've seen it. Treat them like they are: animals. If you're lucky, you'll be able to see the monks that live there doing their tasks. This is a really pacific place where you can enjoy the peace of the swayambhunath.
Spiritual. I liked the place for it's sense of spirituality and our place in the world order. I would go back and visit here again when I return to Kathmandu.

Mystical experience. In our western society, we don't have many encounter with death, in Pashupatinath things are different, I saw many cremation ceremony. It felt very strange to know that dead body were lying under the pile of wood and dried herb, don't worry it's all we can see. It's impossible to see the actual body. This experience has touched me deeply, I highly reccomend a visit to this site.

Splendid. This is a splendid piece of architecture. Very different from the temples one sees in India, or the gopurams in southern part of India. The pagoda like style is very unique for a temple. There are lot of small temples in the vicinity. The statues of the deities and the Shiva Lingam too is huge in size , and worth a look . Temple premises tend to be crowded, and littered be ready for the same.
Pashupatinath. Very thought provoking The hospice on the banks of the river then the funeral pyres. Lots of Sadhu. I found it a beautiful calm place

Interesting but very dirty. The temple is something you should see on a visit, as it is the holiest place in Hinduism, but be prepared for filth. The grounds are littered with trash, burning waste, and burning bodies. You can witness cremations happening right in front of you on wooden pyres. Out of respect, we took very few photos and only when we knew it was ok. The families of the deceased light the fires and in most cases their relative has died only hours before. We hired one of the numerous guides to tell us about the temple and I would actually advise it. They do know a lot and its fun to talk to them. But negotiate a price before. A reasonable price is around ten dollars US, paid at the end. If your guide goes above and beyond, feel free to give a small tip as extra. Our guide was great, but if you don't like any that approach you, just waive them off until you find someone you like.There is a lot of history here and its worth a look.

Shree Pashupatinath Temple has a reputation of “the Temple of Living Beings”.. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most significant Hindu temples of Lord Shiva in the world, located on the banks of the Bagmati River in the eastern part of Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal. The temple served as the seat of the national deity, Lord Pashupatinath. The temple is listed in UNESCO World Heritage Sites.Pashupatinath Temple has a reputation of “the Temple of Living Beings”. Every day, thousands of pilgrims from all over the world come to pay homage to this temple. Come here to get a deep explore of Hinduism.With its astonishing architectural beauty, it is the embodiment of faith, religion, culture and tradition. Pashupatinath is a holy temple of Hindu lord Shiva who is known as Pashupati that means the master of the whole universe. The most important festival celebrated in this temple is Shivaratri or the nights of lord Shiva.The River Bagmati that flows next to Pashupatinath temple is also a holy river with many sacred properties. Hindu devotee plunge into the holy Bagmati river daily and recite the verse from the ancient Vedas. It is believed that plunging or bathing into the holy river releases from the cycle of rebirth. Thousands of pilgrims from all over the world come to pay homage to this temple, so it has a reputation of “The Temple of Living Beings”.
Simply Amazing!!!. HIndu temple with all the trimmings. Cremations, wandering sadhus, puja ceremonies, you name it. Don't miss it!!!

Most sacred temple. Shri Pashupatinath temple is one of the most sacred of the hindu temples, is the Lord Shiva temple. It is said that this is over 2000 years old and is very unique due to its architecture and also the story of its existance.Only hindu religion people are allowed to enter the temple. The priests of the temple have always been from India for generations, and it continues.Monday is the sacred day of Lord Shiva, and therefore many devotees from Nepal and abroad visit the temple.Carrying mobile phones, camera and any article made from leather is strictly prohibited. There are lockers provided free of cost, to safely store your belongings.There is one main temple, surrounded by several smaller temples in the main premises. A huge 'nandi' bull is seen facing lord shiva.The main Shiv lingam has four faces of Lord Shiva in four directions.

Interesting. This place is so incredibly different from anything we've seen before Pashupatinath is one of the most sacred places in the Hindu religion. It is set up much like the Jewish temple of old, with different courtyards for those who are Hindi & those who are not.To the right of the complex is a white hospice building where the near death await their final hour so that they might have their feet placed in the holy Bahgmati river while they die, so that their spirit may escape on to paradise. Try to find a Guide. But Please try to take picture with discretion.

Life and Hindu Death. This temple is not to be missed for an insight into the death Hindu rituals. Nuff said.Our guide actually brought us to the other side of the river where are can have a good view of the funeral rites. Some explanations would be good to explain what the family members are actually doing. This site is a mini-version of what you can see on the banks of the Ganges. Everything is up close and easily viewed. A visit to Kathmandu would not be complete without this

Fascinating. An amazing insight into Hindu culture. We didn't need a guide to just time to sit quietly and observe the cremations and ceremonies down by the river. There are also lots of interesting temples and buildings to see. Its an easy walk from here to Bodhnath Stupa ( down the steps at the back of the site and then ask way). Its amazing to really immerse yourself Hindu Culture for the morning and then be surrounding by aspects of Buddhism for the afternoon.
Life and death meet. A site for the living and the dead... death and impermanence can be studied and may help towards acceptance.

A taste of India!. The car which was taking us around had to be parked a distance from the temple! The temple does bring in a sense of Indianism in it! A nice place to see! Though the surroundings were a tad bit untidy and unkempt! Walking around without slippers was seriously an arduous task!

Not to be missed. Its very overwhelming to take a walk through Pashupatinath. Try to avoid the guides. Be discrete with your camera, even though other tourists isn't. Go here by yourself to sense the atmosphere, its very powerful.
An experience. Tourist go there for the Hindu cremations. And yes, it's an experience to watch it. How strange that may sound. It's bad the mail temple is closed for non Hindus.
Strap in and prepare to re-think most everything. This is a powerful and dark place. Prepare your emotions if you are not a Shiva-file. From my perspective, not to be missed.

Old and Holy. Well spread, one needs to walk bare feet to reach the interiors of this majestic shrine. Long queues on prayer days - but quite well disciplined and steadily moving ahead. The architecture as well as the mysticism around the shine should be seen to be believed. Truly sacred
Guide recommended. Best if you have a guide to explain the process of Buddhist / Hindu cremations. A very insightful experience

Incredible Part of Nepali Life. This is a large temple dedicated to Shiva and is the temple where the dead are cremated. I hired a tour guide who spoke great English and provided me with quite a detailed tour. I ended up paying him USD $20. Might be high, but he was good. Anyway, the temple itself is in a sprawling complex that spans the highly polluted Bagmati river. Along the river, the dead are cremated and their ashes pushed into the river. It is apparently the holiest river in all of Hindu. From across the river, you can watch the preparation and cleaning of the bodies, their movement to the cremation stands, and the cremation. It's quite a spectacle. You can also wander the grounds and see the Brahmans and other holymen/women. If I recall, the entrance fee for foreigners was NRps 500.

memorable. Like:Understood the History, culture & tradition of Nepalese. Was very interesting to see their method of performing the Last rites, was an eye opener.Dislike: The temple authorities were biased towards foreigners (non Hindus) entering inside the temple.

Can be a challenging temple to visit.. The evening ceremonies and chanting from high on the bank opposite the temple are worth seeing. Unless you are Hindu you wont be allowed in the main temple, but you can see a good deal from that bank. But be prepared for the funeral pyres.
Amazing temple. Its a nice temple. The idol of pashupatinath has 4 four faces and one can visit the idol from 4 doors. One must visit this temple if visiting Kathmandu valley
be aware of monkey.they can bite u. I have visit here with my family.at there we can't take camera because they didn't give u to use it.

The Great Hindu faith Place. Pashupatinath is the most important Hindu Temple in Nepal. It is situated 5 km east of Kathmandu on the banks of the holy Bagmati River. This is the temple of Lord Shiva one of three major gods in Hinduism. This temple has two tiered golden roof and silver doors. Although only Hindus are allowed inside the main temple, visitors can clearly see the temple and the activities performed in the temple premises from the eastern bank of the Bagmati River. The other attraction of visiting this temple is cremation death human body. On the bank of Bagmati River there are many cremation spots. On those spot there is almost always a cremation going on. While walking around Pashupatinath you will meet many devotees and sadhus (wandering Hindu holy men). This temple was listed in the UNESCO’s World heritage monument list in 1979.

i go Pashupatinath Temple of Liveing Beings after Bhaktapur and Patan here is 1 in my list. i so so here because i scare monkey lol and dirty little in river because them burn body ............. i shock and surprise but i not like i dislike disappear
Fascinating. Fascinating place and very touching to see the cremating places. Especially if you've also been to Varanasi in India, since the two places are so very different.

Amazed!. It is quite amazing to me to see monkeys walk around the temple and pass human beings without so much as a glance (though we were staring at them all goggle-eyed). Small monkeys, big monkeys, HUGE monkeys... just walking around like it's the most normal thing in the world! And i guess it is, for them! :) I got to the temple in the evening, after dark, and found it extremely peaceful, with more animals than human beings and loved the experience!

Never a dull moment. I have traveled to Nepal many times and have visted Pashupatinath on every trip. It is actually a very large park with monkeys, sadhus and public cremations. I think it's a must see place for anyone traveling to Nepal if you're in the Kathmandu area. I personally find the cremations fascinating and if you ask around you can find a sadhu who will perform penis yoga for a fee. My only advice would be to stay clear of the younger men who will approach you wanted to be your tour guide. They have a lot of information to offer but also view tourists as "marks" as they divide up based on the various languages visitors speak. If you go to Pilgrims Bookstore you migh be better off getting a book instead of a guide.

This was a new experience.... ...I thought I know a lot and I am able to capture different cultural behaviour - after visiting this place I made a big steo forward. I was so fascinated about this place about the people, cultural differences, monkeys....etc.

Cremations and monkeys. This temple is right on the river and chances are there will be a cremation going on while you are there, which is a fascinating though somber sight. There are also masses of monkeys that are so close you can pet (though I wouldn't!). This was a big plus for me, but might be a big turnoff for some.

Interesting experience but could have been alerted.... An interesting experience but guides could have pre-alert tourists on the possibility of bumping into ongoing ceremony where dead body are being carried along the path to be cremated. Non-Hindus, maybe Asians who are superstitious may find this to be a taboo Just keep your ears opened for "sea-shell horn" blowing and step aside - this is the signs of opening the path as they carry the dead body to the burning place.
ancient temple. very nice temple with a lot of history. if you are not a Hindu, you cannot go inside. Highly recommend it

Totally Recommended!. I was in the temple 3 times during my trip to Nepal! But of course being a Shiva devotee i am a little bit biased and would naturally recommend Pashupatinath temple to just about anyone.But the first time i stepped into this wonderful place i was overwhelmed with emotions and it was something everyone should experience at least once in their life.But of course Non Hindus are not allowed into the main temples but once can always sit by the Bagmati River and get a different feel of the whole surrounding.Anyhow the first day i went bit too late thats like 8 am and its already crowded!So the 2nd day i went around 6 am and that was better as you can do your pooja at your own pace and maybe get a look at Lord Pashupati a while longer and then you can join the bhajan group and sing along Shiva devotional songs..All in all i would recommend this place again and again..Oh yea stay away from sadhus if you can! and you dont need a guide to go around the temple..just be cautious of your surroundings and take care of your belongings..the usual precautionary steps which applies everywhere..

Holiest place for Hindus. This temple is one of the oldest and the holiest place for Hindus. Nepal is the only Hindu country in the World not India as India is secular not Hindu! Lord Shiva took a temporary abode here till found by the Gods again. The main temple is open to Hindus only all other faith have to stay on the back side next to the cremation grounds. If you are Hindu then use a guide who can tell you the history of the temple and explain the meaning of all the writings and idols. It was a divine experience for us. If you are looking to buy the holy bead "Rudraksha" then go to one of main shops. Its all authentic but expensive so bargain.

It is great place for Hindus. It is always been talked about by parents and grand parantes. It is one of the sacred place for Hindus. We visited two times as for first time could not get good Darshan. Beware of Pujari's there. they will cheat you

Don't be fooled by the tour guide!. Apart from being convinced to be guided by a tour operator, the place was really cool. Watching live cremations, sitting with a Baba in his house while the rest smoked marijuana (for health and spiritual purposes), it was quite surreal. Finishing the tour with a trip into the retirement and aged care facility, we were encouraged to dig deep and give back to them. A bit of a ploy, but what do you do.

an experience!. For me it was a powerful experience.You walk throght temple buildings. Lots of monkeys and Sadhus.At the main temple, by the Bagmati river, you can watch funeral ceremonies, where the dead body was washed and then burned in the ghats. For Respect to the families, its better if you stand in front of the ghats.

Strong experience. The temple itself is nice with monkey roaming around. Burning of dead people on river bank ghats is a very strong experience but might not be pleasant to everyone. For me it was great place to see together with Durbar Square and Bodnath Stupa.

Temple of Lord Shiva. foreigner except hindu's are not allowed inside the temple area but you can see the architecture from outside too and there is a bagmati river flowing behind the temple. and you can also see lots of monkeys around the temple. need to be careful from monkies while walking around, they will be looking for a chance to grab a food from your hands.

unreal!. It was a glimpse into another culture. It was mesmerizing to watch a funeral. I feel sorry for the ashes going into a dirty sorry excuse of a river though. The monkeys freaked me out there were so many. Watch out for the fake holy men wanting you to take pictures for money. I took a shower when I got back to my room. Half hour later I took another shower. It's something else.

Stunning architecture and watch funeral ceremonies. This big complex is a must-see. Only half an hour from Kathmandu, the temple is full of old shrines and temple buildings and populated with monkeys and holy men. At the main temple complex by the river, you can watch locals perform funeral ceremonies where the dead are washed with the water of the holy (though horribly dirty) river and then cremated on the river banks. It's a humbling experience to watch. Up the big stone steps on the hillside there are numerous stone shrines and at the top yet more, plus more temple buildings. You can also walk from here to Bodnath stupa (the Lonely Planet guidebook has walking instructions). If you arrive before 9 in the morning you can see more locals going about their worship and ceremonies, before the tourist crowds arrive. Allow a few hours for exploring the whole site.There are hundreds of monkeys in this temple but beware, some are aggressive - I was actually attacked by one for no reason other than staring at it! Also do not carry open food if monkeys are around, they *will* try and take it off you!An amazing place for both sights and culture, it's a crime not to visit this if you have more than a day or two in the Kathmandu area.

a heavenly abode.... being christians / non hindus though from India, we could not and did not enter this heavenly abode. fully understand the sentiments as there are a few places in India too non-hindus cannot enter. but a very beautiful complex..
Wow!. shocking to see people cremated in public but i respect their culture and traditions. It was eye-opening experience. Very disturbed by how polluted it was.

Huge Hindu Temple complex. Beautiful temples - check out the mirrored view .. from the end of the line of shiva temples above the burning ghats. There is a walkway through the jungle up past the deer park that goes all the way to Boudhanath Stupa.

Interesting. This has to be one of the most unusual and interesting places that you could visit. It truly is extraordinary but it is not for the faint of heart. Cremations are going on 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. A must visit if you find the Hindu religion of any interest.

A glimpse of culture and religion. This Hindu temple in Kathmandu gave me an amazing glimpse into another culture and religion. Situated on two banks of the river, it is, like many religious homes, also a site for funerals (and in this case, cremations). While we were there, several were going on. Our guide explained the rituals, then left us to observe or not, as we chose. While I realize this may not be for all, I found it interesting and enriching. One of the big reasons I travel is to experience and appreciate the cultures of others who are different than myself. I felt privileged to have visited here.Non-Hindu visitors may not visit the main temple on one side of the river, but may visit the opposite side, which in addition to providing a view of the main temple, also has various religious artifacts.

Gates and temples and nursing home. Be afraid of gides:) They started talk but it's not free and prise is high. This place is the complex of several temples and gates for cremation, and caves for meditation. There are a lot of little Shiva lings in small temples. Rows of them stand opposite gates. There is a little deer park opposite the main Hindu temple. You cold make good panaram Kathmandu photos there.

Worth the visit, but not for everybody's eyes. The place is one of the holliest hindu places. Here is where they bring their beloved ones to be cremated when they die. The architechture and perspectives are unique. Before going there you have to be aware that thi is a cremation place. You see dead people about to get cremated or in the process, so the smell is strong and in my case I could see human remains burning, which is not unexpected to see. If you are too sensitive, then you may avoid this place. Also be carefull if you are travelling with children. I personally do not recommend it, since there are too many monkeys and it's easy to fall in many places. Remember, this is a holy place in Nepal. It might be a different world and you will see many things you won't understand, so keep in mind that you are the visitor, this belongs to the hindus and it's up to them to understand and judge, not to us. Enjoy the experience and embrace the differences.
Not for the squeamish.. Open cremation not for the faint hearted. I found it actually quite moving and a very cool place to visit.

wonderful!. although non-hinduist cannot go in the main temple, it is well worth the visit and you can linger there for hours as this is quite a vast area to walk about. you can easily walk from Bodhanath and back through the suburbs and avoid yet another taxi ride. it is worth going to the top of the hill, for another view of the valley and first peeks at the Himalayan range.

A very special Hindu Temple. This is where the Hindus of Nepal want to end their worldly existence, Pashupatinath is not put on for the tourist, It is where families bring their loved ones to be creamated. Please be respectful . It is something you will never forget.

interesting sights. a great insight into the cremation practices of hindu culture. an amazing place with sadus all dressed in yellow and orange with their faces painted. the colourful palettes of tikka powder, resident monkeys, a little bit like the varanasi in india

A Touching Place. Together with our excllent guide, Mr Kumoda, arranged by Good Karma trekkinng, we spent 3 hours at this most sacred of nepali Hindu sights. We respectfully viewed a cremation from a distance and witnessed part of the preparation of the body for the cremation. Not being Hindu, we could not enter the shrine but that did not take that much away from the experience provided by our excellent guide. The Bagmati river is just filthy with trash but the visit was impressive.Take the time to visit this site in detail.

Aarti Ceremony at Pashupatinath. Even if you visit the Temple during the day, you must go there at 6 p.m. to watch the aarti ceremony on the banks of Bagmati River. It is fascinating.. Music with mantras, kirtan, bells, insence, light, etc..you had better live this heart-touching experience and offer you life-long gratitude to the Lord of Living Beings :))

Lord Shiva's Temple. A must-see on any visit to Kathmandu. The temple and surrounding area is a fascinating spectacle. Non Hindus not allowed into the main temple - you can only see Lord Shiva's bull Nandi, a huge brass statue from the entrance area. The two areas of the Hindu funeral service are just inside the main entrance - Purification area to the left and the cremation area on the right, both on the banks of the holy Bagmati river. Show respect by keeping distance from the bereaved families. Great view from across the river directly opposite the main temple at the seating area. As you look from this location - diagonally to the left behind the cremation area is homeless refuge run by Mother Teresa's order, diagonally behind you to your left is a school for young boys who will become Hindu Holymen (Sadhu). Take a look at the eleven small 'shrines' each identical in construction and each containing phallic symbol of Shive.
So Peaceful. Despite being peak season, this place seemed so peaceful (after the souvenir sellers leave you alone!).
Fascinating temple. Each time I return to this temple with a guide-I learn something new. There is much to learn and appreciate in this ancient temple.

Must see this. 3 cremations were in progress whilst I was there. Whilst sad, it was an amazing experience to witness. The fact that the ashes are swept into the river I found a bit odd coming from the west, but I wonder what happens if the river dries up. I loved this attraction and could have stayed for hours more. Get your photo taken with the religious men for 100 rupees

Something to experience. This temple is what they say the most holy one among Hindus. As a tourist, I was however deeply touched by their cremation ritual. Dead bodies are burnt by the side of river. Monkeys roam everywhere, like many of the temples in Nepal. Every sight around this place is vibrant - worth visiting there.

Pashupatinath is not for the faint-hearted. It is a bit bizarre to find yourself looking at someone's cremation. There were many biers and the air was thick with the burning. Holy men a-plenty willing to have their photos taken for a price. Definitely not a 'fun' spot but an insight into an aspect of Hindi life.
Nice temple. Dont need a guide, just walk around and enjoy the environment.The place is so beautiful and simply awesome to wonder and ponder around such wonderful architecture.

Worth the visit. This is the place to visit if you are intrested in local culture. Go early in the morning, cross the bridge and take a seat opposite the ghats and just watch. And please do NOT go to close to funerals. Would you like if tourists showed up at your funeral and take close pictures of you lying there?

Good place to see. It was a nice place to see. I saw two bodies being cremated along the riverside. I was not Hindu, so I did not visit the temple. Instead I just walked up and down the pathways in the area. There was plenty to see.
intense. Intense experience unless, perhaps, you are a mortician. I would think carefully about taking children.

Not for the faint-hearted. This is a very interesting visit. We saw 2 bodies being cremated and the families mourning. Did feel a bit of a voyeur but decided to go with the flow and enjoy the experience. Intrigued to see process of burning the body and to learn a littlevofvthe history of this temple. I would definitely recommend this to all visitors.

mmmmm..... mixed feeling here. Didn't really enjoy watching the deceased being cremated but I guess these experiences are all part of travelling. Interesting, though. Lots of 'holy men' wandering around, who will let you have your picture taken with them if you pay. Not sure if they're really holy or not!

Temple is hidden from view. It was interesting to see, and I'm glad that we went, but the Temple was off limits unless you are HIndu, and let's face it.. the temple is why you go. Unless we missed something, you couldn't even see but a small portion of the actual temple.. the monkeys were interesting, but scary and I had several of them threaten me when I unwittingly got too close.

the holiest place in ktm. On the shore of the Bagmati river lies the temple of pashupathinath, a Hindu temple where every holy man in Asia should have visited. on tghe Gaths along this holy river the ritual burning of the dead takes place. Very impressive.

A Hindu Experience. I found the place both fascinating and challenging. Standing watching a family cremate their loved one was surreal and I was grateful to them for seeing it. The history, religion and cultural make up of the place is most definitely worth seeing. Try get there earlier in the morning before the main crowds and it is worth getting a good guide to explain the ins and outs. However the guides are more forceful for the fee ( a little too costly for my liking compared to other local) and the fake holy men can be a little cheeky on why they ask, but I did find them entertaining and worth having a pic with.

Amazing sight. Our guide explained the whole death and buriel process for Hindu's and we watch several cremations at the time of our visit. Amazing and different but make sure you go with a guide who can explain the ritual and the grieving process for Hindu's as it is truly fascinating.

Average. This was not our favorite, before you reach the temple there are lines of people trying to sell you traditional merchandise, then once you pay the entry fee you are swarmed with "tour guides" wanting a "minimum fee", then there are the in "full costume holy men" asking for a small fee to take a picture of them posing with you, it goes on. We did not watch the cremation ceremony as just felt inappropriate so we spent our time there strolling the area, taking in the pagoda style of architecture and paying homage to this significant Hindu temple on the backs of the Bagmati River.
Real Nepal. A place full of tradition, faith, history, the real face of Nepal. Don't miss it! really spiritual and suggestive

Okay, but the main temple is restricted to Hindus only. A little disappointed with this place as the main thing to actually see is is restricted to Hindus only, yet we paid a lot as tourists to enter. It is a cremation ghat however, so we did get to see a cremation ceremony by the river, which was unexpected. Apart from that there really isn't much that you can't see anywhere else in Kathmandu.

Amazing Cultural Experience. It feels very odd terming this an "Attraction" in Kathmandu - It is after all a Hindu crematorium. But I can't help saying that I highly recommend it as a cultural experience. We went in the afternoon - brutal sun - so don't leave without your hat, sunscreen and bottle of water - oh, and tho' I hate to admit it, a camera. (Discreetly used.)There is a small entrance fee and unless you are a scholar of anthropology/Hinduism, you will find it useful and more meaningful to hire a guide - shouldn't cost more than 400 rupees for about one hour if you are a couple/small family. And, if you feel its appropriate, at the end you can tip and round it up to 500/=. Always agree on the fee before you embark on your guided tour, The guide will show you the funeral pyres and this might come with a warning if the BBC were going to televise it - "some scenes are graphic and unsuitable for young children" - or those with weak stomach. We arrived to see a partially burned body - blackened feet clearly visible. Observing the rituals is undeniably fascinating - the washing of the deceased's feet in the river, wrapping the body in orange cloth, decorating it with marigold flower garlands, and even the ritual walking around the body after it has been lain out on the bamboo fire chamber before starting the fire - in the deceased's mouth. The bizarrely made up Holi men with their loin cloths are more than happy to pose with you for photos - for "small money Madam!" Although this is not called the Monkey Temple - that name reserved for another temple here, the day we went every monkey in Kathmandu had come for a picnic - they steal the offering plates (especially tempting since everyone puts out bananas!). Very entertaining. Allow about one hour. This is not a place you want to sit and eat and drink. You will just drink in the cultural of it all and marvel at our differences - Our cremations so private and planned down to the last detail. These cremations so spontaneous and taking place so openly. I came away and immediately started to google many things that the guide had told me to better understand (and check his accuracy). It is a whole education.

An incredibly diverse Temple. We visited here late in afternoon and walked through the complex admiring the architecture while dodging the cows and monkeys.Ensure you either have a good book or a guide as this is one of the most important Hindu Temples of Lord Shiva as well as being a Unesco world heritage site.

good to see. found it really interesting to go see, couldnt get into the temple and found it a bit confusing, Payed the 500 rupee but Im not really sure what for as there was no one to collect of check tickets and you cannot enter the temple but the ghats are definitely worth a visit if you can stand the smell and the smoke.

Incredible, eye opening. For someone from the "western" world, this was an incredible place for us to visit, just to soak in the atmosphere and to watch the people and experience the cremations. Very educational and emotional and something you will never forget. Don't miss it.

The burning of budies is not a pleasent sight. The only reason people visit Psshupatinath is to see the cremation of dead Nepalese. We did not like it. The place is dirty. The smell is horrible. We will not return.

strong experience. Unless you want to be shocked, I would not advise to visit it. Public cremations, dirty river, smell of burned meat and a thick cloud of ashes in the air. It was quite a strong experience.

An amazing look into the life and death of Hindus.. Pashupatinath was a solemn look into Hindus end of life practices are carried out. The funeral pyres seem to be going around the clock, and the mourners endless. A guide is crucial in my opinion as most guide books only point out the basics, but a good guide will answer many questions about the rituals you see happening on both sides of the river.*Note: There are plenty of tourist police that are very friendly, but are busting unlicensed guides. I witnessed many groups losing their guides they paid as the tourism dept is trying to crack down on frauds. Licensed guides go through rigorous studies to insure accurate information and good presentation is given to all tourists. Make sure yours has a license. I can recommend Kumar Dahal which I used for multiple days and was very helpful and informative. kumarngo@hotmail.comPashupatinath and Bodnath Stupa are close to the airport area, try to work that into your plans when you are nearby; either coming, going or taking an Everest flight. I hired a car and driver through my guide, so I was able to hit these as soon as I landed and just left my luggage in the car.

If you want to see a cremation of a human body. It is a very interesting site but only if you are able to handle strong smells(burnt human flesh). Not clean at all. You will find a good number of "exciting saddhus" to take a picture with. You can just see the "ghats" cremation sites from the other side of the river

Jyotirlinga in dire need of maintenance. Its one of the twelve jyotirlinga of Lord Shiva. But is in a very sad state. It needs repair and regular cleaning of the surroundings.The temple is open at 5 AM but closes in the afternoon and reopens at 5 PM. Only Hindus are allowed to enter. Inside a number of temples of other gods & goddesses are there. At the back is river baghmati and also the cremation ghat for Hindus. If you are religious then you will not mind the sorroundings and love the temple.
A difficult place... worth going but not an easy experience, better go in the afternoon/evening otherwise might be too hot and intense (the smoke everywhere doesn't help either..)

Fascinating place. Although I felt uncomfortable watching families going through their very personal cremation ceremonies, as well as a fair amount of physical and psychological unease at breathing in smoke containing human ashes, my visit to Pashupatinath was totally worthwhile. Not just the ceremony, but the architecture, the colours, the intense characters I photographed...well worth going.

An eye opener!. This is in-your-face Kathmandu at its best. But you must have a stomach for burning bodies and transient sadhus etc. This is a place to see but probably not to linger. Note that not all of this site is open to non-Hindus.

Pashupatinath Temple. Interesting , Funny though it may sound walking in I actually saw a few monkeys mimicing the humans and were going round the shivling in silence heads bent ! Unfortunately as I tried to take a oic they ran off !

Tranquil. Pashupati is a beautiful old set of temples and the current spot for cremations--Its a little strange watching cremations just across the river--seeing full bodies--but its still a serene atmosphere--if you go up into Pashupati, atop the hill--you'll get great views and see old sadu babas (drifting holy men) hanging out, smoking chillum, and drinking chai.

Amazing place. Pashupatinath is a wonderful place to visit. The weird Saddhus (all dressed up and no place to go), the pilgrims, the atmosphere.... it's my kind of thing! It is also a very live temple, with a burning ghat (Do not take pictures!!) and an old-folks home (before the ticket office to the right). Visit these old people; they have no one else and they enjoy seeing visitors. If you can, bring some sweets and cigarettes. Yes, cigarettes, as everyone brings fruit, but all they want is a smoke. Yes, smoking is dangerous, but these people are 120 years of age and are waiting to die here, so give them a break!

Not exactly a place for people who has a low tolerance level of human cremation. It is indeed a sad place, this is where they cremate dead hindus, they do it by the river bank. Be aware of taking picture as some consider it offensive. Just cross the bridge to the opposite side, look for a nice place to sit, and zoom all the way your camera and take a quick snap. Monkeys are everywhere, be careful with your cams or bottled water, they might just snatch it.

Ancient and Eternal. Although foreigners are not allowed into the main temples, one can explore the extensive temple grounds. There is a feeling of sanctity that permeates the whole environment. It's easy to forget that you are surrounded by a city of almost 5 million people. The noise and pollution fall away and you can enjoy the feeling of peacefulness. I can see why it has been considered a special and holy site for many generations.
No worth to pay fee 500 Rs. Becouse you are not allowed to enter inside of the temple dont pay the fee of 500 rs. when we went to the ghat nobody ask the payment so i guees its free.
temple. the temple gives some advise of human being life and the temple made up of single rock and also near the single tree house

A must see temple for Hindus. Just travel once to see the Temple,and a must for all the devotees of Lord Shiva a great structure and a life time activity also get the aura of the peaceful environment. The Maha Arathi at 6.00 PM is enchanting,

Eye opener.. This is the first I have seen a cremation which I witnessed right from the start. The tour guide told us that we are lucky, we get to see a cremation from the beginning! It is open and public, we sat across the river and could see the ceremony. We didn't go into the temple itself as it is only open to devotees, however we did get to take beautiful pictures from across the hill. Do visit this this temple and witness the cremation, it is eye opening to say the least.

Cremations. I have read about public cremations and it was most interesting to see first hand how the cremation ceremonies were carried out. It was raining the day I was there, which made it even more dismal. Just around the corner from the cremations was an "old folks home" somewhat dismal also, but interesting.

the best in kathmandu. i am a devitee of lord siva and pasupatinath is an very holy shrine for me.i have visited it at least 20 times earlier. this time i went after 4 years.and what a transformation !! the periphery development is excellent.the gardens,approach and exit roads etc. are very good now.the river bank is also very beautiful now.the facilities have improved tremendously.and the lord himself is benevolent as usual.will definitely visit again.hearty thanks to the temple trust for all round improvements in this holiest of shrine.

For some bone-chilling for others elevating experience!. In any case it is a once-in-a-lifetime journey - for a Westerner, that is - into another approach towards death and morning. A must see! Beautiful, meaningful, informative. You can learn more about Hindus and Hinduism here than anywhere else in the "outside world"! Be respectful and very open!!

Peace of Mind. You need to definitely take some time out to view this architectural marvel even though you are an atheist...entry into the temple premises is only for Hindus..for others you can get to the main entrance only. Cameras are not allowed within the temple premises. You need to switch off or keep your mobile on silent mode inside... there is a hindu cremation ground just adjoining to the temple. there is the Bagmati river flowing next to the temple

Impressive Hindu site. This is a pretty huge temple complex that is sadly not very well maintained. However, there are interesting sights to see, even if non Hindus are not allowed inside the main temple. There are the obvious Hindu cremation ceremonies but please be aware this is a funeral, not sightseeing objects, and thus I don't think it is quite appropriate to take photos of the process while also dressed in pretty revealing outfit (I saw one tourist like this, hasn't she heard it is one of the holiest sites in Nepal?). Anyway, it is also worthwhile to observe the complex as there are interesting Hindu stupas and other objects to see and of course, there are what I suspect, fake Sadus (Hindu holy men) who will pose for photos for you for a nominal fee. There is also a deer park nearby that if you care to explore, you may encounter some deers from behind the fence.
Another world. Not for the squeamish but a fascinating place even though non-hindus are not allowed into the main temple area. This is a truly Nepalese experience.

Its not all Buddhism in Nepal. Many people think of Nepal and think Buddhism, but Hinduism is more common in the Katmandu valley and the average Nepali will tell you they're the same thing anyway. So its good to pay a visit to the holiest site in Nepal. It might be good to get a guide or any Nepali friends you've made to take you so they can explain some things to you. For those coming from India it may seem a bit small scale but its a well preserved site and has lots of interest. A word of warning though, they do cremate bodies and as with the rest of the world people at funerals don't think of them as something for tourists to take photos of. Whilst I was there once I saw a camera nearly end up in the river (not the place you'd want it to end up) when a passer by saw what the tourist was doing with his telephoto. So remember to act like a human being and you'll have a very interesting and fun time. Up the steps theres a game people play where you try to walk across the stairs to put your hands in a hole (whilst having your eyes closed) just one of the things you wouldn't expect in a temple complex. Oh and watch those monkeys!

Not very impressive, but still worth a visit. I might be a bit biased on this, because I was really tired by the time I visited this temple so I did not find it as interesting as the other temples. Plus some won't allow you to enter the temple if you are not a Hindu. But still worth a visit a visit. It is interesting to witness some Hindu traditions performed outside the temples.

A must visit place - But sadly not maintained at all. As a Hindu, it is a must vist place for us.Thus there was no point being in Kathmandu and not going there. The temple is made very beautifully and is really a big one. The atmosphere is really great.But that is all, the experience is worst I had ever in any temple. Starting from entering to keep your shpes to unwanted fakirs, there are issues everywhere. There is no cleanliness at all and that is the biggest issue. No maintainance it seems is done.I must say, in my life this was the first temple where I did not feel a sense of peace which somehow magically comes in even a crowded temple.

Worth a look. It's one of Kathmandu's major sites. I thought I'd find seeing people being cremated disturbing but once I got there I realized they are actually dead and don't feel a thing. It's 500 rupees to get into the site but a lot of tourists approach it along the river from the airport road where you won't get stopped to buy a ticket. The guys offering to be a guide can get annoying but just pretend you spent all your money on the cab fare. They will go away.
Must visit.. I liked the ambience of the temple. I wish if they took better care of the temple as it was unclean in several places. It's a place not to be missed.

A must visit for a Hindu. Pashupatinath is a temple which every Hindu should visit atleast once during the lifetimeIt is known as one of the most miraculous temple in the worldWe even got a chance to see a Bhajan song perfomed by the devotees on our visit the sad part only Hindus are allowed inside the templeso if you are a foreigner u would not be allowed to enter
Lord Shiva needs care. Badly maintained temple....monkeys keep jumping and walking all around....we saw the evening aarti besides the Bagmati river. It was average at best.

Interesting place but you can't access the main temples unless Hindu. This is supposed to be the biggest Hindu temple in the world and it is interesting although a large part of it is blocked off exclusively for Hindus so the temple is a bit inaccessible to the general public.
Pasupatinath. Holy place. No photography allowed. Right place to buy authentic Rudhraksha. Try not to go on a Monday as its the day, locals offer prayers and its very crowded.

Helps to understand the culture. Although this is one of my least favorite places in the world, it is an essential part of Kathmandu, and should be seen at least once. Western cultures tend to isolate death from life, but there is no hiding it here. Watching the families publically mourn their relatives is always heartwrenching for me. I do not believe I would have the courage to watch my loved one's cremation, but seeing them endure it gives a glimpse into why the Nepalese are so strong of constitution. Sensory overload is part of the experience. Remember that you are not on a NatGeo shoot and the people at the temple are not actors. Even if you don't "get it", please respect that this is a deeply spiritual experience for many of the people there. Even so, while the Babas (Hindu priests) may allow you to take their photo or offer you puja (Hindu blessing where they put a powder mark on your forehead called a tilak), compensation in the form of a monetary "offering" will probably be required.Going to the temple with someone who understands the religion thoroughly will help you gain much deeper insight into the deluge of symbolism. If you do not have any Nepalese friends to walk you through, be careful to hire a reputable guide; not everyone who offers their services really knows what they're talking about, but they surely will be able to make something up! The fee gets you onto the grounds and from here you can observe the funerals and many of the murtis (statues), but you must be Hindu in order to enter the actual temple. Try not to be offended that a higher fee is charged to non Hindu westerners. After all, it is their religion and we are only spectators. I don't think I would take young kids here unless the family is Hindu or you are willing and able to answer an awful lot of questions and deal with the possibity of nightmares. It can be intense, especially if you are raising your children to be spiritually aware. It may be tempting to buy souveniers, but the prices are exhorbitant. Do not pick the marijuana outside the gate. It is not free and someone IS watching. The Babas may be smoking it, but if you try to buy it or pick it, you could end up meeting a plain clothes Nepali policeman in short order. This is not personal experience, but something that has been publicized in the Nepali papers in recent times. The 70s are over.
One day I will be part of the show. This time I was struck by the tragedy of it as you see relatives weeping and legs sticking out of the pyres.
JUST A TEMPLE. The approach is dirty and only Hindus are allowed to enter. If you do not know the cultural significance of the temple you will not be able to appreciate it much.

No need to be apprehensive. I was a tad apprehensive about visiting as I didn't want to be perceived as an 'intrusive tourist', however after a few minutes into the visit I was completely at ease and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The taxi from Thamel should cost no more then 250RS, entrance 500RS and it is worth while to hire a guide as a good one can be very informative. The guides won't say how much thier services cost and like you to make a 'donation' at the end of the tour. However, they will make subtle hints throughout the tour saying 'I'm a poor student and need books' - which to me seemed a typical scam. We paid our guide 600Rs for a two hour tour, although he mentioned that 40$ US would get him a new text book.

Religious place!. I am French and my wife is Nepali; so religious so I frequently have to take her to different temples of Kathmandu. I go here so often and get amazed with lots of people worshiping Lord Shiva. I am not Hindu so I am not allowed to get inside the main temple however I respect the norms and values of the people. You feel so religious whenever you reach the place. You will probably get blessing too....you do not need to go inside the main temple to get the blessing, just worship from your heard to your soul!
A lot of spirituality. This temple is very importand for hindu. You can see cremations and a lot of temple. To do with a guide, so he can explain a lot of thing about this beautiful temple.

Get all your senses overwhelmed by this unique Hindu place. Combine Pashupatinath with Bouddhanath afterwards. The contrast between a Hindu and Buddhist atmosphere -so closely together in terms of location- can’t be more intense. Pashupatinath overwhelms every visitor with its beautiful temple complex and ritual burnings at the river, its omnipresent colors and scents, and its constant crowd of people along cows and monkeys. By contrast, bouddhanatah, located maybe only a km from Pashupatinath, submerges you in a complete opposite atmosphere. The huge stupa are an attraction for spiritual rest that you feel everywhere around you. It is good to do Pashupatinath first thing in the morning, take 1-2 hours to wander around and taste the atmosphere before it becomes too hot and then head to Bouddhanath to refind your breath, relax, make a spiritual tour around the stupa and finally sit down for lunch in a nice restaurant with view on the place.

Watch our for the dead!. Wonderful and truly interesting place. Quite expensive to visit but worth the $8 entrance. The river is lined with 24/7 cremations, whereas up in the woods at the top, the small shrines and temples, where the Red Monkeys hang out, must have been the inspiration of the jungle book's scene "i wanna be like you"
Average temple w/ great histroy and relics. Too crowded and somewhat dirty!! I guess it's for believers and ardent devotees. Sorry..but only Hindus are allowed in here, which i did not like.

Temple of Shiva. This is usually the first place shown to you on your visit to Kathmandu during sight seeing.Leather articles and photos are not allowed inside the temple premises although you can take snaps outside the temple.The diety here has four faces , in case you need to perfrom pooja a token is to be taken one day prior to your visit. When we entered temple we could see line at 4 different doors , not sure which one to take we managed to take all 4 spending some time in the line.The shivling is huge so you dont have to struggle looking at it. For photos when you come out of the temple wear your shoes and walk across the creamtion area to the small hill opposite the temple. Perhaps you can have good snaps of the locality and the temple. You have benches there to spend time. You can also come across sadhus engaged in photo shoot for a fee.
Sacred hindu temple. Saw this temple and took some pic from outside. You are not allowed to enter inside. Only hindu and buddist would be allowed to enter the main temple.
Excellent and Mind blowing. It was sea of colours of faith on first monday of Sawan at Pashupatinath.Lakhs of people worshipping

Crowded. The Temple how ever allows only hindus to pass in to temple and temple has a history which can be heard by local guide at temple! ..however there is little management skill missing inside, i hope authorities look into it! .. But every one has to Visit temple

Pashupatinath. Pashupatinath Temple is the oldest Hindu temple in Kathmandu. It is not known for certain when Pashupatinath Temple was founded. But according to Nepal Mahatmaya and Himvatkhanda,[2] the deity here gained great fame there as Pashupati, the Lord of the Animals. Pashupatinath Temple's existence dates back to 400 A.D. The richly-ornamented pagoda houses the sacred linga or holy symbol of Lord Shiva. Thousands of pilgrims from all over the world come to pay homage to this temple, that is also known as 'The Temple of Living Beings'.

Pashupatinath Temple. The Cremation Grounds is like a specticle...a show for visitors....it was very upsetting. Its sad to see the place where Locals are bidding farewell to their departed ones being turned into a show...the stentch of burning flesh....the muck in the "Holy River"...the Only SORE POINT in an otherwise GLORIOUS NEPAL.
Nath - O - K - Nath........Pashupatinath. Jai Bholey...........must must visit for all Hindus when in Kathmandu. It is not only a temple it is one of the pillars of Hinduism.
Amazing. Again, another must see as we just don't have anything like this in Europe. The Sardhus are just amazing and very photogenic (for a small fee)

Cultural diversity at its best. This Hindu temple is a must see. There are over 200 cremations daily visible to the public. We were entertained by dozens of monkeys while witnessing a cremation of a public official. The process is symbolic, religious, intricate and steeped in Hindu tradition. We were lucky enough to have a guide share with us the process and tradition.
I ndia in Nepal. If you cross the river and go a ways up the far side, you can see into the temple and also see the cremations. I think the young sadus (holy men) are fakes.
i like it most. lifelong desire to see pasupatinanth fulfilled.i like location

peace come auto matically. amazing place on the earth as one should dream , we were told it will be crowded and we should take time out before we go ,but we were out within an hour . very small line normally we get anywhere in the temple , beautifully crafted sculptures all over temple .and most important you get peace of mind when you visit

Hindu's must visit pilgrim. Hindu's must visit pilgrim, too many monkeys, what i dont like is the the pandits asking you to all sorts of puja's costing 1100 bucks, the guide asking you to pray with special rudraks costing 700 each minimum of 3

The biggest hindu temple. The temple is huge, so don't think to visit it in a short visit! At the main entrance you will be surrounded by hundreds of local guides offering their services: you choose if you want them to take you around, but you could even just stroll around and see. If you do not want to pay the entrance fee at the main entrance, we found out that there is another one next to the building where only hindus can get in, on the other side of the hill: after climbing up the hill we ended up there and went out of that entrance/exit that I guess is used only by locals who do not pay for sure to go to pray...

Hindu Temple. a very religious HIndu temple, where all the cremation is going where you can see, if you are dare enough. but you are not allowed to enter the main temple unless you are Hindu.worth visit !

See it if..... Go here if you've prepared yourself for the experience. I had an excellent guide who pretty well explained enough. I had been to Varanasi four times and thought that was enough preparation. It was not. Perhaps it was the time of year (Nov. 2009) and just a day after a special observance when crowds come leaving so much behind, but it felt very filthy. I did enjoy getting my fill of the Sadhus sitting/standing around. Sometimes it feels like they've dressed up for Halloween in order to earn money from tourists. I was willing to pay. Didn't care for the dogs, but there were no issues.
The living Goddess. We've seen it but nothing special no photo's allowed, but there was nothing worth while getting on camera and no living goddess.
Very poor. Poor security, full of pick picketers, our bag was stolen inside the sanctum, security worker were not helpful and made very rude remarks. But the police was helpful.

Bizarre!. Interesting history of the Living Goddess but a bit creepy when you see a six year old done up like a dogs dinner! However it does give the less fortunate girls from poor families a chance to be spoilt.

Rare Hindu Temple. One of the oldest Shiva temples dating back to the Mahabharta days. Being managed very well. However, the local pandits are bit of trouble but still one can easily manage. Four sides entry with different purposes of visit and fulfilment is a unique feature of the place. Gold and silver work in the walls and top of the temple also makes this temple unique. One can witness all types of Hindu saints here. Temple is situated on the banks of holy Bhagmati river.

Religious place. It is a religious place, nice old structure. It is near the airport. The oldest temple of Lord Shiva. The place of worship. Must visit this place if you are visiting Kathmandu. Adjacent to this temple, there is a cremation ground also.

Culture shock. As a westerner it was a bit of a culture shock to see bodies being prepared for cremation and seeing the actual cremation outside the temple. As a non Hindu I was not permitted inside the temple but I had a guide for ten U.S. Dollars who give me an hour tour of the temple grounds including an unobstructed view of the cremations with excellent explanation of the customs and practices. The guides definitely make the visit more memorable.
Amazing. No words to express this experience. Breath taking!
Facinating. Quite strange watching funerals taking place, up to 40 a day sometimes. Get a guide to show you around and explain what is happening

A cultural reality. Pashupatinath is no particularly pretty, in fact it's almost grim. It's crowded with locals who go to hang out there and you will see lots of Hindu holymen (baba) encouraging you to photograph them for a small sum (ironically). However, it was probably my favorite of the so-called tourist spots in Kathmandu mainly for it's humanity and reality. I saw my first dead body (2 actually) in a hindu cremation ceremony. I have a decent knowledge of buddhism, christianity and Islam but have never before witnessed any Hindu ceremonies, so it was a revelation of sorts. I visited Pashupati on my second full day in Nepal, so it was also somewhat of a culture shock, in a good way, it was exotic and fascinating. Because of the spiritual element it is not inundated with tourists taking photos and you have more of a sense of the local. While my review may not make the place attractive to visit I thought it was amazing. There is also a deer park with lots of monkey's too, which are always fun to watch. It is ancient and the architecture is great, however if you don't like steps it's not particularly accessible on a hot day.

Not for Everyone but Everyone Should Visit. Not everyday you will see cremation but you can here. Just remember no pictures of the family and the cremation. Take your time stroll around to see the history behind the temple. Yes the river is filthy but don't let that stop you from visiting the Temple. You can visit all areas except the inside the Temple itself and the cremation area unless you are Hindu. Cows monkeys and deer are around. Don't pass on an opportunity to visit here.

Extremely spiritual, but dirty. No question that this place does really have a sense of magic, but the Bagmati is such a disgusting river & on a personal note I hate the monkeys. Not the first place I would visit in & around Kathmandu- start with Bhaktapur or Bhouda and then move on to this and Swayu.

Interesting Temple. This is a site where Hindus cremate their dead and fuenrals were taking place when we visited - which I found a little disconcerting as we seemed to be intruding on peoples grief. There were cows and monkeys within the site and many small birds - as the local people provide food for the animals.
Very Religious. everybody Knows Pasupatinath Temple. Very religious and big. Situated near Airport. Allowed only for HINDUS.

The holy people. In Nepal just outside of Kathmandu on the way to the airport is a temple .. Unfortunately I didn't have the chance to visit there, but my objective was to see a group of people called the Sadu .. They are holy people dressed in cloth with colored faces of different shades and styles ..I was lucky enough to see a couple while walking through the markets of Kathmandu in Thamel and got a few photos .. For a few rupees, they will gladly stand with you and give you some blessings as well ..

Sadhus. Although you're not able to enter the main Temple if you're a Westerner,it's still worth a visit.You'll be charged 500Rs to get in but the money goes to the up keep of Pashupatinath.Once inside, you'll find many Sadhu's.Some covered in not much more than ash and others dresses in bright orange robes.Most have long dreadlocks and nearly all want you to take their photo.Be willing to pay them a small offering for their photo.That's usually all they want and in return they will give you blessings.Most speak great English and are happy for you to sit with them chatting.Spend time sat by the burning gats or in the Tilopa and Niropa caves a little further down the river.And please don't forget to pay the elderly peoples home a visit while you're there.It's worth getting a guide, they're cheap enough at a few pounds ( around 300-600 Rs ) they're very much in the know,don't rush you around and are friendly.They'll approach you as you enter through the gate.If you don't want to take a guide, just tell them 'no' and they won't bother you again.Enjoy you're time there, it's a lovely place.

The site is excellent. There is an entrance fee of 500 rupees pp but it's worth paying to see this site. Getting a guide is recommended as they tell you where you are allowed to go, and what you are looking at. Also they tell you when you can take pictures. The crematorium part was not smelling bad when we were there and we learned from our guide that there is only a bad smell when the dead bodies are old (waited for 3-4 days before burning). From here, you can walk to Boudhanath Stupa.

The Highway to Heaven. I like Pasupatinath very much, You need to read something before visiting it but it;s really worth to do it. You can see Hindu cremations overthere and meet many sadhus. This is special place where you can little think about your existance and life. NonHindu are not allowed to main shrine. Entrance fee is quite high (500 rupies) but it;s worth. Of course remember that this is place as all funeral places so you should not interup and behave correctly.

Please respect the mourning and do NOT take photos!. I went here during a funeral rite. It was a strange feeling to sit there and watch someone's funeral, but it was at the same time somehow calm and comforting to see how family said their goodbyes and prepared the body for his journey covering it with beautiful clothes and flowers. The ceremony took hours. And then there were some Western tourists, shamelessly taking photos, in their tank tops and shorts. Please, have a little respect and cultural sensitivity! I felt shame to be a Westerner.

For people with a religious Bend. I went to Katmandu primarily to vist this temple and I was satisfied. Amazing place and a must visit. The place is clean and not a typical Temple where you find people asking for alms. Nice to pray and the system is streamlined as well. Take some prasad before entering and dont get duped by people trying to sell you stuff there. Its all available back once you have prayed. Enter the place before 1230 in the noon to see the main temple.

cleaneness. The local people have to keep the area clean. They have to maintain the buildings, so that people can view them as it was 15yrs ago. In the evening couples sit all around the monuments and eating and drinking and making it dirty.

Very interesting, but perhaps a little intrusive?. Non-Hindus are not allowed in the temple, but I got a feeling we weren't welcomed even near the temple. I must say I felt uneasy seeing mourning families perform funeral rites right in front of us while toursts fill up memory cards snapping photos of their loved ones being cremated. I guess I just didn't feel comfortable making their spiritual rites a tourist trap. Also, the vendors in this area are far more aggresive than any other place in Kathmandu. I was latched on to for 30 minutes at a time by a few different vendors. I know they are trying to make a living, but the constant tugging on your clothing for attention completely distracts one from why they are there.

Very interesting experience. We went by with our guide who gave us the rundown on the temple. As soon as you walk in, you see the river and the area where the religious cremations take place. There were several taking place during our visit, and it was a culture shock to see the entire process. Once you turn away from the river and walk up a bit, you can also see the Sodu (the guys who have white faces and long dreads). They let you take pictures with them and are quite funny characters.

Nice. If you like visiting temples etc then this is a must. However its not the cleanest place. Its quite filthy in all honesty. Also you must keep in mind that there is a cremation ground here which is always busy. So if you have children may not be a good idea to go as these are quite morbid/disturbing things to see.

An eye and mind-opening experience. To the western eye and mind the Pashupatinath Temple may be a bit jarring. The idea of watching the mourning as well the mourned as bodies are cremated is quite foreign to the typical western ideas around death, however, there is something quite humbling and beautiful about witnessing this. A guide is definitely helpful here, but be cautious of the men who will offer you information and chat expecting to be paid. If you're going to pay someone just choose carefully, but hearing the history from others is definitely helpful. Also be prepared that "holy men" will expect compensation for allowing you to take their photos.
Beware. It has become much cleaner now but beware of the men calling themselves "the priests assistants" as well as pick pockets !!!

Extreme visit experience. This visit to the Pashupatinath hindu temple proved to be an extreme experience. Non-hindus are not allowed inside the inner art of the temple but can visit the rest if the grounds that have plenty to offer. Especially the crematoria along the very dirty river was an unique and new sight. Every hour or so a body was brought to the river banks were in the presence of family and friends the body was purified puting the feet of the deceased in the water. Also family and friends washed themselves with some hands full of river water.
