After that the body was placed on a wooden structure, carried to the nearby crematoria platforms, also on the river banks, placed on a stack of wood, and after a short ceremony, more wood and straw was placed on top of the body and set on fire. In the mean time the remains of other fires that had done most of their corpse burning were shoved into the river, the crematoria platform splashed with several buckets of river water until all washed down into the river and ready for the next corpse burning. Add to that the general rubbish and cows that make the river their home, while poor children try to find still something valuable in the river. You have to see the filth of the river to understand that after this unique experience we were also dying, but more for a good shower to wash ourselves mentally and physically clean. Still, highly recommended as a new experience and reference.
dirty way to say good bye to the world. temple and surrounds are filthy,dust of burnt bodies can be choking,"holy"river not the place to be finally dumped.but a must for cultural travellers

Must See. This is definitely one of the most crowded temples in Kathmandu. The amount of faith that the people of Nepal have in this place is just crazy. This place draws a huge amount of local citizens every day, esp Saturday, who believe in taking the blessings of Lord Shiva before everyday business

What to say?. The Bagmati river is very polluted, it was a truly interesting place to visit. You can stand on the opposite side and watch the cremations of the dead, I saw them in other stages of the funerial process as well. There are the painted Hindu Holy Men that are willing to pose for photos, don't let them try to hustle you for a lot of money. I had one that kept wispering that he knew I had at least 20.00 USD I could slip him. A few NPR is enough. Very interesting place.

Creepy but fascinating. Watching a wedding while bodies are being burnt at the same time!Very moving and something I will never forget. Very surreal place as while all these intensely emmotive experiences are happening others are just going about their daily business. Dogs and cows are drinking water out of the filthy river, children are fishing for rupees which have been thrown into the river, sadhus are milling around trying to get paid for photos with tourists. All in all well worth the experience.

An interesting experience. A special place, but very interesting. Seeing a dead person being burned might sound strange, but in Nepal it is everyday life, and it is very interesting just to walk around the place and learn more about hindu and buddhist culture

The Best Hindu Plce I ever been.. Certainly Pasupati nath temple the largest temple in Nepal. Located on the bank of Bagmati river and has lots of shrines around temple. Thousand of pilgrims visit this temple. If you are Hindu going to Kathmandu then please do not miss to visit this temple.

No entry in temple itself, still worthwhile. This compound of temples and buildings is bustling with locals and visiting religious leaders or tourists. Take your time to walk around and get a glimpse of the silver temple portals through the entry gates. Tourists are not allowed in. One can walk to the rear of the temple and witness cremations. A guide is very useful as they can put things in perspective and explain about the various parts of the temple, religion and rituals.
special place, but not for everybody. Read something about this temple before you go there. The place is very interesting, but might be difficult for some people, especially not hiduists.

Divine place- Must visit. A Superb place, very divine.1. Must go place if one at kathmandu2.Only Hindus are allowed3.Go in the evening , one can get a chance to be a part of the divine aarti at 7- 7:30 pm4.If one has a strong heart and have interest, Cremations are performed at the back side of the temple on the bank of Bagmati river, you can see it.5.Aghorees are also seen there.6. Badly restored temple.very shady entrance of the biggest temple of the country, very sad to see it.7. Security is very loose.8.You can find dogs also inside the temple.9.No entry fee for SAARC nationals.One must go for shiv Shankar Shmbhu.All said and done the experience is superb.

Worth visting. Visitors were very respectful as people washed and cremated their loved ones at the side of the river. The Holy Men and crafts were fascinating and the site was well worth a visit aloow the entry fee is quite high.

Holy men around the temple. I loved watching the holy men covered in white (human) ashes. They have renounced everything earthly, material, pleasurable, sexual... all to wipe their slates of past karma. Cremations are held close by, which was an interesting experience too.

Worth a visit. Pashupath is very different from anything you will see in the west - part temple complex, part public cremation site. The temples are worth seeing but unless you are hindu you are not allowed into the main temple.The best view of the whole complex is from the steps on the other side of the river, opposite the Royal Ghats. You can closer views of the cremations if you wish from the bridge. Families do not seem to mind, but it is best not to be too intrusive. It is probably better to visit in December or January when the river is higher as there is a fair amount of rubbish in it which is revealed when it is low.

Be Considerate When Touring this Sensitive Site. The number of camera-toting tourists could potentially take away from the sense of sacred significance of this site, and please don't add this to your itinerary if you doubt your ability to act respectfully and without judgement. You will likely see recently deceased being carried to the banks of the river and cremated, so not for the faint of heart. Also, before you start snapping away on your camera, imagine what your reaction might be to foreigners showing up at a funeral of your loved one, taking photos and expressing their awe at the rituals. Read up on Hindu beliefs on cremation beforehand to fully appreciate the ritual.

Good Experience. I was a little hesitant to see cremations up so close. I think a visit like this really opens you up to the cycle of life and reminds you to enjoy and appreciate just living. There is lots to see here beyond the cremations. I had a hard time breathing due to the smoke so we spent most of our time exploring other areas. There is a home for the elderly that is worth walking through.

LOOK WITH APPRECIATION, NOT VOYEURISM. Get rid of any ethnocentricism before you visit Pashupatinath. This is a place where you can learn to appreciate that other people have some quite beautiful, very different ideas to yours. You will see the newly-deceased being cremated; you'll witness the grief of their loved ones, and the care with which they tend the body. Yes, the river is disgusting and dirty, but to the local people it's holy - don't be judgmental. Oh, and watch out for those pretend-sadhus who hang around ready to pose for a photo-for-a-price - real sadhus don't do that!

By far left the biggest impression on me. Seen most of the sites in KTM and surrounding Valley but this place was the most intense. Once you're there you will understand. Recommend really early morning to avoid the crowds. Great photo ops here but please show some respect by not taking pics of bodies being cremated.

Eerie, but strangely beautiful!. Visiting an open air crematorium is not something you would expect to enjoy, but the Pashupati Nath Temple is one of the holiest temples in the world. Worshipped by Hindus and Buddhists it is an example of religious harmony. The whole area is surrounded by ancient temples of archaeologically and architecturally importance. You cannot help watch (from a distance) the burning of the bodies along the river side, and see the families accept the fate of their loved ones without tears, without sadness but with relief and calm. There was a strange eerie ness of the whole place but it was also beautiful.
Incredible atmosphere. We were lucky to witness couple of cremations and this was an incredible experience.

no words. Visiting this place has made an extremely bad impression. Still, in the Western tradition funeral ceremonies are really sacred, they are not arranged as an open show, where crowds of tourists are allowed to be and take pictures. Heat, a monstrous dirt, stench, moaning and weeping relatives and as a mainstream of all this - poor river Bagmati, forced to absorb all of this nightmare. I'm having serious doubts that Shiva is pleased with such "worship". The most sad thing was the river, unbelievably contaminated; I felt a great shame for humanity.

Must See. We went here on our last night in Nepal, and I could not think of a better way to end the trip. You will not be allowed inside the temple if you are not Hindu, but definitely make your way to the holy body of water located behind the temple. We visited around sunset and there was lots of activity still going on.
Just amazing. This is not for the weak of stomach, as dead bodies abound. If no issue, then do not miss this cultural icon.
A major Hindu site. It's incredible to watch "public" cremations. Unfortunately, non-Hindus and non-Buddists are not allowed inside the temples.

Not impressed.. Pashupatinath is a very large temple complex dedicated mostly to the Hindu lord Shiva, but has been largely overlooked by common maintenance or trash cleaning responsibilities. We were at first impressed by the 1000rs entrance fee (being as how we were just at the Buddhist Temple, Bodnath, for 150rs) and so were expecting at least a whimsical sign of care. But alas, trash everywhere, dead or dying trees, temples in various states of disrepair, beggars and con-men, a nearly complete lack of food or drink, stunning views of what was once a river (now a trickle, lined with garbage and animals) and at the very back - an iron barred open space of dirt and trees filled with some very exotic deer. Disappointed.
Enlightening. Liked, life and Culture. Disliked aggressive monkeys.

Hindu sadhu's. This is the temple where they have cremations. There are many funeral pyres. Got to see a funeral taking place. Was interesting to watch the rituals. The sadhu's were fun to see. Come prepared with a bit of money as they will expect that if you snap a picture.

the sacred temple.. this is the holiest temple of Hindus -all the Hindus pay homage to this temple every year on Shivaratri. Place is ancient unique enlisted by UNESCO world Heritage site. but the sewage of this place is not controlled instead thrown all in in the holy river -doesn't looks good.

such a nice place. the place was really crowded place, but it was suppose to be also because it is the biggest temple for hindu religion. the area was really big and so many visitors in the temple. they always have aarati in the morning and evening. we enjoyed a lot. if some body die then all hindu nearby take the body to the temple and burn. any way it was a nice temple with beautiful location.

a must see. Definitely a place to see. You can see cremation from 8 am to midnight and animal sacrifice if your are lucky. Culturally very rich and interesting. I recommend using a guide ( 500rs per group)to have all the explanations
Must see. I have visited and blessed by the god shiva.... You can see people faith there

One of the most intense places I've been to.. This is one of the must go to sights if you are in Kathmandu for oh so many reasons.Expect to see cremations, religion, ill mannered foreigners and immense corruption all in one place.The sight is best enjoyed with a guide book. Be warned that there are many "guides" who come up and talk to you while forcing their services upon you. Make sure to tell them you are not interested and be very persistent. Our "guide" who told us that we could pay him whatever we felt like later, forced himself upon us with his very friendly demeanor and soon had us gypped, He started demanding exorbitant rates once the tour was only halfway done. Also do not take pictures with the Saddhu's despite however insistent they are that you take pictures with them. They demand ten Euro for a picture afterward.Go to learn about the temples fascinating history and be amazed about how so much of human nature is so brassly on display here. Not suitable for children.

Don't know where the money for the expensive entrance ticket goes but the place is so poverty stricken. My lasting impression is of a place that exploits and preys on the poor .... where ever the money goes from the entrance tickets for this and the surrounding hindu temples it doesn't seem to be invested in supporting the many poor people or even on the infrastructure... the experience left me sad...

Kathmandu stopover. Visiting a creamtorium sounds very strainge but in fact its was really interesting. I would recommend you hire a guide as we did and you will get a very good item of whats going on, why and the history involved.

Fascinating and eerie. There are 2 different entrances, one for Hindus that allow entry into the temple on river right, the other for non-Hindus on river left. Having been there 3 times over 10 years, it hasn't changed nor stopped being fascinating. There are steps where you can sit and watch the goings-on. Whether it be the preparation of a cremation, the symbolic dipping of the corpse's toes into the river, the sadhus (holy men) in their various poses or states of holiness, or the monkeys chasing each other around. It is especially eerie at dusk as the night nears, and if there is no water flow in the river in March you wonder where all the crematory leftovers end up.
very strange. please ask your guide about AGURI BABA as well. you will be surprised!!!!!!!
Lord Shiva House.. Holly temple Pashupatinath. Simply the great lord of hindusium. Around the temple good enviroment and many other temple.
must visit. You may have to stand in a queue for sometime for puja but it is worth it. Do a puja not just a darshan.

Hard to stand it.... It's a pretty unusual place and not easy to be there as we saw some animal sacrifices and then they open up the animal in pieces also the preparation of the bodies and the cremation...The atmosphere very heavy, hard to breath with the smell of burnt flesh, woods and rubish all over... so be prepared of what you will meet there or don't go at all...Definetely a unique and unforgettable experience...

Sacred & amazing. We went there in the morning and it was Monday.There were thousands in the queue.We went round the temple and returned without having darshan of the deity.In the evening,we went again and we had nice darshan and puja.Down below,on the river bank a pyre was burning with lots of people there.Large no. of flower and bead shops are there around the temple area.For Hindus,paying a visit to Pashupatinath Temple has special significance.Non-hindus are not permitted inside the main temple.

Another temple. The entrance fee was expensive (Rs500)! And the man at the entrance would guide you innocently around the temple and ask you for a USD20 tip! Other than that, you're not allowed to enter the main temple building (only for Hindus) but you are allowed to observe any funeral processions that's taking place while you're there! A truly eye opening experience.The sadhus constantly smoke weed and pose for tourist shots and demand "picture rupees" after you take a shot of them. Oh and check out the old folks' home beside the temple! They are real friendly and wouldn't ask for "picture rupees!".
Unbelievable.... You HAVE to go there. It's so magic. So peaceful, so impressive...

Scary and culturally rich place. We've seen 3 bodies covered with flowers being burned as part of the Hindu tradition. You can get as close as you want depending on how courageous you are.This is quite a big complex so expect spending a much longer time here. Each area has a story and is deep in history, it is best if you have a guide for you to appreciate the place more.
Peace of Mind. One of the biggest pilgrims of Hindus. I personally felt very nice and relaxed after having darshan of Lord Shiva. Must go temple.
evening time after 7 pm is the best. I was adviced to be there after seven, worship with music and dance we likes it very much!

Hindu Temple. This is the oldest temple in Kathmandu. Has a big history behind how it was built. If you are a Hindu you can enter the temple if not just able to look from out side but can definitely take pictures. Pictures available in facebook page of Samsara travels and Tours.

temple still working. its working hindu complex of temples and creamatories, take lokal quiad/cheap. /and go firts see from the top of hillm the go visit, some of areas are only for hindu/religion/ also is very amnazing silver temple, now open for visitor, place for homeless people,/nobody charge you, everybodys friendly smilimg/

Creepy!. For some reason, I found the place creepy...perhaps because they have a cremation site within the complex. The temple itself is nice to look around but in the winter, it's uncomfortable taking off your shoes and walking around for so long. It's a good place to visit for those who are religious, but for couples looking for a fun place to hang around, this is probably not the place for you.

The best Hindu Srine. If you whant to feel real India skiping experience of the real one - come here... even the hords of tourists will not let you disappointed with real power of this ancient spiritual capital for all Hindus

Mixed Experience. The temple by itself is beautiful and seeing the huge Pashupati nath temple was lovely... but I guess it needs cleanliness atleast the day we visited it 25/11/11 it was having some sort of foul odour and litter around which according to our guide came from a pile of litter etc which were'nt cleared in a while... also though it may be helpful to some ppl but the preists continuously following you to get some or the other pooja done can spoil your mood as they constantly keep disturbing you till you give away with something...
Hindu Temple. The best place for me to pray. Beautiful temple. Can't take a pictures inside the temple. Strictly prohibited.

Truly incredible place! One of the 'must see' places in the world.. Being very honest, I didn't expect much from this visit. "Yeah, another temple" I thought. I was soooo wrong! Pashupatinath complex is truly amazing, fascinating and spiritual. Temple complex is located on the way to the airport, just few km from Thamel. There are plenty of buses and taxis around, but probably your driver would decide to wait for you. We did that and that was mistake - you should take your time and do not rush. Pashupatinath is quite large and there are so many things to see and experience. Entry fee for foreigners is 500 NRP (approx. 4,6 EUR).At the entrance (like everywhere in Nepal) there are "local guides" which can help you. I usually refuse to use their services, but this time somehow happened that I didn't... That was absolutely the best choice I could do. Our guy, Prabin spent with us almost 2hours explaining in perfect English all sights, traditions, rituals and habits. It was stunning and I couldn't ask for more. Plus his sense of humour and professional approach and knowledge made our day. If you decide to go there, I can provide you his contact phone number and he could guide you around for some acceptable amount of money (not set, but you can agree before). Going back to the temple it was really touchy to see how bodies are prepared and later burned on the Ghats... You can see that from the distance or just from above. I know that this may be sad occasion, but as far as I was advised tourists do not interrupt in these special private moments. It is up to you if you wish to take photos or not. It is definitely something different. Prabin explained differences between ceremonies and that was really fascinating.Main temple, Pashupati Mandir is not accessible for non-Hindu. I really didn't care that I wasn't able to visit main shrine (as I am not Hindu) - you have to accept that. All area and other accessible parts are worth visiting.Go there in the morning as this is less crowded and everything is just waking up. Incredible feeling. You're surrounded by hundreds of pilgrims, visitors, animals, Sadhus (holy-men or just "commercial holy men" as well)... I know that smell and dirt (“holy garbage in the Bagmati River) may impact your personal impression, but I was stunned with this place. Next time when in Kathmandu will spend there definitely few more hours...I only regret that we didn't have more time - 2h was far too short to see everything. Thanks to our guide we could actually see and understand many of the places. If you are interested to get his contact, please message me.

All of life is here..... Amazing place. We spent hours here. The people are the main draw. From Sadhus, grieving relatives, relations, pyres smoking and burning and graves/mounments. A vast 'park' with all of life here..... amazing
fine. poor cleanliness, as in all hindu holy places, but high on the spiritual list.

Filthy Bagmati River. The river has actually been converted into a sewage flowing drain. One gets a feeling that the authorities have never really cared to make this world heritage site look better.We went to see the famous temple with great faith and expectations but were hugely disappointed.

One of the oldest and marvellous hindu shrines!. The temple is an ancient place of worship. It has powerful enegies. One can witness special pujas here. Its very crowded and at times not very clean but if one can lift oneself away from the mundane then one can experience the real power of devotion. Its a Lord Shiva temple and one of the most important shaivite shrine. After visiting the temple one cay buy good quality rudraksh beads outside. Only Hindus are allowed inside the main temple which can be a bit troublesome for the western tourists. My western friend had to stay outside when I went inside to do the puja.
Scary to see up close but.... one of the most interesting cultural visits. most folks would not like to see the cremation services, but it was fantastic.

Pashupatinath at a glance.. Pashupatinath means master of animals. Located on the west bank of the sacred Bagmati River in Devpatan, Pashupatinath is one of the most revered shrines for the Hindus.Lord Shiva, one of whose manifestations is Pashupatinath, is the most worshipped among pantheon of the Hindus Gods.

garbage everywhere. Beautiful temple with garbage strewn everywhere, very dusty and excessively dirty, This is meant to be a place of worship - why can't people keep it clean, so filthy with garbage allover the place. Pity - could be such a beautiful spot -if only people were a bit more civic minded and respected the place.
No a fan. With 5 visits to Kathmandu under my belt I generally miss a visit to Pashaputi these days. I understand the reverence that it is held in but I find it generally an abbrasive place to visit.
Bam Bam Bholey. One of the magnificant temples of Lord Shiva situated near to the Kathmandu Airport

Best during MahaShiva Ratri. Sadhu's hang out in various spots adding some color to the white-washed temples with lingum inside. There is always a cremation for interest if you like that sort of thing - culturally it is interesting to see the puja and ceremony that is preformed at the time of a death.

A Sacred Highlight & a Must See Experience. We stayed at Dwarika Hotel and were able to walk to the Pashupatinath temple complex in about 20 minutes and we mingled with the street venders who sold weird and wonderful food as well as tacky souvenirs.It is a sacred sight which was very rambling and there is so much to see.We were not allowed to enter the temple but this did not detract from our visit in any way. The main sites for us were over the bridge and on the riverbank. There are several cremation Ghats and a number of them were in use. I must confess to a morbid fascination of watching several embalmed bodies in various states of cremation. Why? I ask myself, I suppose it is so different from my culture that I found it so captivating. I was also captivated(again) with the variety of holy men who paint themselves from head to toe in strange bright colours. Not sure if this is a gimmick as they are more than happy to pose for a photograph providing you give them a tip!Plenty of other temple sights to see, be warned of the monkeys, they are everywhere and so many of them and it is advisable to not eat food as you are liable to lose it! The other warning is that the place is very dirty with rubbish strewn everywhere. However, do not let this put you off, this is a sacred hindu temple and an experience you are unlikely to repeat.

Pashupatinath Temple. Pashupatinath Temple is one of the most significant Hindu temples of Lord Shiva in the world, located on the banks of the Bagmati River in the eastern part of Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal. The temple served as the seat of the national deity, Lord Pashupatinath, Nepal is a secular country . The temple is listed in UNESCO World Heritage Sites list.[1]The temple is one of the 275 Paadal Petra Sthalams (Holy Abodes of Shiva on the continent). Hindus alone are allowed to enter the temple premises. Non-Hindu visitors are allowed to have a look at the temple from the other bank of Bagmati river.It is regarded as the most sacred among the temples of Lord Shiva (Pashupati).

A must see in Kathmandu valley.. Non-Hindus are not allowed entry to the temple, but a visit to the grounds is intensely moving. We sat across the river from the cremation ghats and watched as families went about the process of committing their loved ones to the afterlife. It was quite an honor to have the opportunity to observe the process.
wonderful experience. grear destination for holy shiva worship. love the pigeons flying over you. the atmosphere was overwhelming
Stark reality. This temple reminds you of the cycle of life and death; an extremely important concept in Hinduism.

like an exciting TV documentary. our tour guide decided to bring us to Pashupatinath in the morning because they were having cremation ceremonies in the morning beside the river. We never entered the temple but viewed from across the river, which gave us a great vantage point to observe the cremation rituals. What as sight! while we were there, we saw one that just finished, another one ongoing, and a third starting. One of them was a rich and famous Nepali so you could see the dramatic contrast in preparation, rituals, number of well-wishers, number of dhalit workers, etc. You read about it but it doesn't get to you until you actually see it happen in front of your eyes. Of course, the tour guide has to be beside you giving you the background and insights.
place of temples. listed in world heritage it is full of temples , you can get various arts & the crafts here in the temple. It is Hindu temple.
Borne ; ) Be? Burn.. That's it. - Is it? Pashupatinath will tell you. Almost all about it. Specially the burning part ; )) HERE WE GO! Here I will GO!
Gods Haven. I was lucky to be there during Shivratri ! one tip go early in the morning for a peaceful & hasslefree darshan.

A fascinating slice of Kathmandu life.. This is an amazing place! In Hindu culture, people must be cremated soon after death, and this is the place where it all happens. It is worth getting a guide (one will approach you and offer his services for whatever you would like to pay) so you understand the cultural significance of the ceremonies.

pashupatinath. I like the pashupatinath because it is a holy sared place and they maintain the palce as it is and you will see hoe the people culture, and I one thing I dont like there is the river it is better to see that river not to have garbage dot make the river to be with the garbage

Hindu temple. it was very nice experience to see the temple like pashupatinath. it has very old historic story and was very excited to see many followers to go and worship in the temple. Monkeys were bit scary.

Overwhelming. A very interesting place to visit and learn a slice of hindu belief. But when there is an ongoing open cremation, the smell can be quite overpowering (like burning hair magnified). I was watching one taking place while standing on the bridge in the temple grounds. There were 4 sadhus (hindu holy men) in colorful face painting and apparel. My friend told me that they are from India, not Nepal. They can be photographed with anyone for a price. For a more reflective moment, the events in this place make one think about earthly life in the perspective of eternity, like the mist in the morning and gone in a short while.
Site of Hindu cremations. A visit here allows you to see and feel the end of life processes. You get a sense of just how different we treat death in the west

all devotees can see the lord clearly from a distance. Here lord Shiva can be seen in ancient form (animal face) facing four directions . Nice arrangement ,so that all devotees can see the lord clearly from a distance , so that ( wooden sloping stairs with a landing in the middle facing the front of lord Shiva) but one has to move in a queue to see all four faces of the lord and complete a parikrama (a complete round) . Large premises with a lots of other deities .A large Kal Bhairav idol , the priest (woman) gives a heavy punch on the back of every devotee while leaning against the idol , it is said to eradicate all evils of life . On the other side of the temple the sacred Bagmati river (now heavily polluted ) where the human corps being cremated and the ashes were thrown in to the river. There were lots of human bodies in the river bank waited for the rituals , which reminded the scene of our Swarga Dwara ( Puri dham –Orissa-India) . The evening Arati is special , one must attend . The shops on the way to Pashupatinath sell different types of salagrams ( one must have the ability to identify them ). By the way we can buy the original Rudrakhya and salagram from Nepal .
the best temple. what a top and number one perfect beautiful temple located in ktm that i visited last year.I always recommended you to visit once

A Hindu Cultural experience. Pashupatinath is a biggest Hindu temple in the world. Even though the entrance to the temple is only for Hindus there is a lot that you can explore here. There are different ways to enter the area hence you might not see all of what the temple area has to offer depending on which route you enter. If this is you first visit I would suggest you enter through Gaushala (this is also where the main parking is). There are lots of shops here where you can buy antiques but be sure you bargain. If you are not a Hindu you cannot enter the main area but there is a path between the temple and parking which leads you to a place called "Aryaghat". This is just beside the river and cremations take place here. You can walk on the other side of river towards a small hill . This place is very spiritual. Lot of benches are placed here under the trees, where you can sit, watch the cremations and see the temple. You can also see around 50 small temples here which are in built in same fashion. From this place you can start a small hike (30 mins ) or so into the temple forest. It is basically just staircases leading you deeper into the forest. Legend has it that this is where Lord Shiva lived. The walk is beautiful and you can see deers jumping around. The finishing of the hike is at another temple (guheswori) so make sure you know your way back .Also in the evenings there is special ceremony beside the holy river where people chant mantras and they have lights and incense burning all over. This is just magical. The cremations may scare you off a little but if you want to know about Hindu culture and experince spirituality ... this is the place in kathmandu.the only restroom around is in the main temple area (non hindus allowed) . there is no restroom on the 30 min staircase trek so use it before you start. Also be careful of tourist guides here.....some of them are fake people just aiming at money.

Lord Shiva is here...live. the most famous of lord shiva in world and a must see for hindus. but here u may find a lot of monkeys n langurs which can snatch ur belongngs. but if u dont mind go ahead n see the huge nandi statue. all around the camus u find wonderful temples n statues.

Non-hindus not welcomed. Non-hindus are not allowed into the central precincts. Still there is quite a bit to see. Wild-looking sadhus sit around waiting for tourists who they can charge money to pose for. We didn't stay long because all the smoke from cremations was burning my throat.
unique!. take your time there, get used to this place which is uniqye, just find a place to sit - look - feel the vibrations there!

Impressive a must do. Take your time when exploring the temple. Sit down and stay there to see all the rituals. Don't rush, immerse yourself in the serenity. I really enjoyed the contrast of this place.
Hindu Temple. Nice religious place but so many people around there and we are not allowed to go inside.
An amazing cultural experience!. An amazing cultural experience! Really opens your eyes to how the Nepalese people spend their everyday lives!

Non Hindus are not allowed to enter. There was a festival day. Once we payed the fee, we were announced that non Hindus are not allowed to trespass the entrance :( Our visit was only around gardens, trying to have a view of the temple and river. Not recommended.
Amazing. It is a very important place for pilgrims. Also it is main shrine for cremation.

Scarred but worth to explore!. They do not allow us to enter in the temple but it was best decision to visit Pasupati Place. It makes us scarred to see the death people and to see directly they burning them but nice to explore Hindu culture.

Incredible. The place that all former royal family were cremated at this temple,smokes of cremating corpses coming off the temple with a far away view as non Hindus not allowed inside, be careful with religious matters in Nepal.

An Experience in Itself. This is one of the holiest Hindu shrines and is a marvel in itself. I have been there 4 years ago and things have certainly improved in the last 4 years.There is the usual long queue to enter into the temple and you need to have at least 3-4 hours in hand for a good darshan of Lord Pashupatinath. This being a very old temple made of stone you have to keep in mind that it is a bit slippery in some places.Western tourists would find the open air crematorium a curiousity !

amazing. pashupati nath is one of the biggest religious temple in nepal it is situated in kathamandu district which near by the international airport
Good for a days' excursion with the Durbar square and Boudhanath temple.. Good for a days' excursion with the Durbar square and Boudhanath temple.

Spiritual destination.. You have to know a bit about the rituals around the cremations, otherwise it does not make much sense what you see there.The "holy man" sadhoes are very irritating.They live without money and just for the riligion, but they stronggly demand money for every picture you want to take. So don't do that please.....

Amazing but shocking. The most popular hindu temple in Nepal and one of the holiest for Hindus all over the world, this temple should definitely be in your list of must see in Kathmandu. The sight of open funeral pyre might come as a shock to many so be prepared.

Nice temple, bad karma sourroundings. Generally speaking the temple is interesting. Just notice that crossing the river there is a crematory, and actually the smell and the smoke of burning corpses could get you. So if you are sensitive avoid the area, or bring a mask.

The most holy temple for hindus Pashupati is a Hindu god, Also one of the eight avatars of Avalokitesh of Budhhists vara. This temple is the most sacred temple for Hindus and for non -hindus it is place to see funeral rituals of Hindus.the temple is very beautiful with hundreds of statues, small temples of lord shiva and other hindu gods scattered within its premises. The main temple is also a masterpiece with beautiful carvings. The two storied golden roofs, silver doors on all four sides, five faced statue of lord shiva, two bronze bulls (one very big and other fourth of its size) in front of the western door etc makes this temple very beautiful. As photography is restricted the actual beauty of the temple area is not much known by the tourists. There is another very significant temple near it, the temple of Unmatta Bhairab. Unmatta Bhairav is supposed to be the fierce menifestation of lord shiva. The idol of Unmatta Bhairav in the most stark nudity exposing the pro-creative organ in its most prominent form. this god is believed to protect the children, also who can not conceive for a long time comes to worship this god. There are such several marvellous idols. When climb down at the bank of Bagmati where cremation goes on, one can see a small but very important statue of KALKI or Kali (not goddess Kaali). This statue is half buried into the ground. This statue is said to be built during Kiratas period (fifteen hundred years ago) and believed that if this comes out fully the earth will be destroyed and new origin starts again. In the evening one can see special arti a(worshiping with lights and hymns) t the bank of Bagmati. I think guides should tell this to the tourists also besides death rituals. They can see the temple of kali (or Birupaksha) ..to see the statue I think they may need a normal binocular........ If possible good to try evening visit to see the Arti......P.S. Free entrance for Hindus while NPR 500 for non-Hindus

Himal mandap treks and expedition. I went to Nepal to do the EBC trek, with literally no planning apart from my tickets from Kathmandu to Lukla, I was pretty much clueless, and not sure of what Katmandu would offer me. As soon as I walked out of the airport we were greeted with a warm smile and a helping hand, little was I to know that this would be the only point of contact that I would need during my time in Nepal.From then on everything was taken care of, from accommodation, to the most authentic Nepalese food, that only people with the right information could find, to all of my guides, tours and transport while I was there.From Pashupatinath Temple to Swyambhunath Temple to Boudha, Patan, Bhaktapur Durbar Square, the list goes on. We had specialist guides who were experts on each particular area, as well as a driver/ guide who would fill us in on any of the missing bits. I would recommend a camera, and that's it!!! everything else is taken care of.Loved Nepal, loved Kathmandu, Loved Pashupatinath, Loved Himal Mandap, without them I would have been lost.Thanks heaps for making it such a wonderful experience.
Hindu temple. The world famous hindu shrine,spend an afternoon here it"s well worth it.

lovely. yet another unmissable place if you are in Kathmandu.All the sights are fantastic. Well kept. Easy to get to. Affordable entry. This is the most expensive of the Kathmandu entry fees, but at 500 NPR it is worth thge money.

WOW. The purpose oof my visit was to go to Pashupatinath. The powerful feeling of the temple is outstanding. It is a huge temple. You can go in only if you are a Hindu. Non- hindus are not allowed inside the temple

exciting. the whole experience was fantastic ,For the first time in my life i felt so much at peace.

Not really a tourist attraction...keep your camera in your bag. Going to Pashupatinath was a fascinating experience but in some ways a bit uncomfortable too. The bodies are washed in the river first then dressed in white & orange sheets before being laid on the pyre. Only Hindu's are allowed in the temple but you can peek in from the door. Special place to visit for everyone. Pashupatinath is an important Hindu temple in Kathmandu, dedicated to Shiva.You have to pay an entrance fee of 500 rupees per person, knowing you can't visit the temples (only allowed for Hindu-people). You'll certainly will be approached by young Hindu "guides" who will try to sell you a guided tour. We firstly didn't want this tour, but then decided to agree for a small fee because it was a young student who spoke perfect English and didn't push us to take the tour. And in fact, it was very good. We got a lot more information than mentioned in the travel guides and were informed about the cremation ceremonies who take place around the clock on the river banks. So certainly a place you should visit when you are in Kathmandu and yes, a guide (if you feel comfortable with the youngster who approaches you) is recommended.

A must see place near Kathmandu. It is situated at the Bagmati river, the second holiest river to Ganges. First of all it is a very important place both for hindu and budist people. Unfortunately not hindus are not allowed on the main temple, but you can enjoy the view from the rivrside to people on the other side, in the temple. And you can visit small Shiva temples on the open riverbank - each is housing a lingam, a fertility symbol. And you can see how people are embarked to their last journey in fire. The only problem there are very insistive street salesmen/women who cannot let go of you without making a purchase. It is advisable to stay firm and refuse to buy anything otherwise you will be surrounded by a crowd of them.

Very atmospheric. Full of character, strange for westerners to see bodies being publicly cremated - can feel very uncomfortable but intriguing. Colourful and great for photographs of the brightly dressed holy men and the dozens of monkeys.
Amazing Hundu temple complex. There really is no place else on earth like this; a must visit site.
A very spiritual place. I was allowed to go into the temple being a Hindu and it was an immensely spiritual experience. This was one of my highlights on my trip to Nepal

exotic but obnoxious. Being one of Unesco's world heritage in Kahtmandu, Pashupatinah keeps being exotic all the way through although lots of guts are needed to walk by the river lingered in a dreadful stench. Better get a mask just in case. More than dreadful, i should say deadful, since they cremate the dead people on the benches of the river. All a show. At the entrance, dozens of people will try to sell you necklaces, bags, rings, etc and will follow you until they succeed. Bargaining is mandatory. Gurus, women dressed with saris, monkeys, dogs and a troop of tourists intertwine in this particular place.
If in town you should visit this. Worth a visit. Get a guide (200 rupee) to tell you about the tempels and about the ceremonial burning. Entrance fee is 500 rupee.

House of gods a midst culture. Pashupatinath is one of the most visited places in Kathmandu with over hundred thousand visitors showing their presence here. Pashupatinath is the holiest of all temples for Hindus.Different shades of lives can be observed here. With Rishis and Shadhus (hermits and worshippers) chanting prayers to playful monkeys in the vicinity. Pashupatinath is also considered to be the holiest place for cremation for Hindus.River Bagmati flows aside the temple. It is said that the river used to carry crystal clear water back in 1960s but sadly at present water is impure and unhealthy. It is also believed that water holds power of gods and washes away all sins and sorrows. Sounds, lights, people and exquisite experience of Nepali traditional culture, Hindu god worshiping and a warm feeling of being closer to gods is what Pashupatinath offers during a visit.

Excellent world heritage site. We decided to get a guide for this area and we were not disappointed, he was a student but was full of the history and knowledge of this site, it cost us 500 rupees, the entrance fee was 500 rupees per person too. During our visit two cremations were taking place and it was fascinating to hear all about the cremations and the rituals of the family of the deceased.Watch out for the holy men... our guide said you can give however much you wanted to have your picture taken but then one of them said after we had had our pictures taken that it was 100 rupees per holy man and in our case that was 500 rupees as there were 5 of them... needless to say we took plenty more photos to get our monies worth!This is a must visit site when your in Kathmandu.

Fascinating, yet sombre, cultural highlight. We visited Pashupatinath (Temple of Living Beings) on our second first morning in Kathmandu. This was by far the highlight of our trip to Nepal. Though some people may find the thought of watching cremations disturbing, we found it to be culturally insightful. Non-Hindus are not permitted into the main temple, though there is plenty to see at spots that are accessible. We wandered around the complex for a good portion of the morning, before taking a seat in the shade across the river from the main funeral pyres. We watched from a distance as three bodies were washed, carried to the yak-butter covered stacked wood and then set alight. We then watched the process by which the wood, with the body, is burned down to ashes, following which the entire burning pile is pushed into the river. We then walked across the bridge to be closer to the funeral pyres, and watched as one deceased lady was laid to rest on the wood while her family removed her gold and other items.The smell from the burning bodies is not so bad, though you can hear the body sizzle as you would if you were at a BBQ. It is a good idea, especially if you are standing reasonably close to the funeral pyres, to carry a handkerchief to shield your nose and mouth. If there is a wind the ashes are blown in all directions and you certainly want to try and avoid getting ashes in your lungs.If you really want an insight into life in its purest form then you must visit Pashupatinath – for a most fascinating cultural insight the entrance fee of Rs 500 (around USD 6.80) per person is well worth it. This is real life – this is not a site staged for tourists – it may not be suitable for children, unless they are mature enough to understand what is going on, and it certainly is not a place for people for whom the thought of death is disturbing. With that having been said, I repeat what I said in my opening line – this was by far the highlight of our trip to Nepal, presenting an interesting yet somber insight into a culture that has existed for thousands of years.

Nice Temple. The temple is very nice, it has very significant value in Hindu religion, it is one of the great place to visit, only Hindu's are allowed to visit this temple, Non-Hindu Tourists can view it from outside only.

Spiritual bliss...... One should visit the Pashupatinath Temple while in Kathmandu. The temple is near the airport but once you take the lane towards the temple, its very very quiet. You can feel the calm and the energy surrounding the temple...Camera's, mobiles and leather products are not allowd inside the temple-so make sure you dont carry it-there is a private shop just outside the temple where you can rent a locker for the visit duration....You can buy offerings (optional) for the temple at 300 Nepali Rupees. Many touts and guides are awaiting outside the temple-choose prudently, maybe a older person as guide is better option. The priests inside will expect a dakshina (optional) for their services-you may use your discretion. 50 to 100 nepali rupees is ok. More is upto you....A good place where you can deposit the shoes in bags is also available within the temple premises just before you enter the main temple gate so do not deposit or leave your shoes way outside the temple.527 Shivalingams are there which are supposedly to be in existance since 13 century-it is said all sins of last lives are forgiven if you walk through the lanes of the Shivalingams...Donations are an optional effect. You may donate at the donation boxes rather than handling out cash.....

Don't miss this. This place is so interesting as it is where they do the cremations. Going with a guide is not a bad idea since they can explain what is going on. Plan on staying there a while so you can see the ceremonies (2 hours or so).
must visit. this place is a must see for all tourists. You'll probably spend a couple of hours here. Be smart in using your camera...Dont pay more then Rs. 250 for a taxi from Thamel.

NOT A TOURIST ATTRACTION...THIS IS THE REAL THING!!!. since 2008, during three trips to nepal, i've visitedpashupatinath on many occasions, the most recentbeing march 2011, the day before the birthday of 'shiva.' if you enjoy photography...without doubt,this is your place. one could spend hours here,seeing the cycle of life take place right in front of you. hindu belief is that as soon as possible after death, the physlcal body should be burned, so thatthe spirit may be freed. this ritual goes on aroundthe clock here. families gather to say goodbye to the deceased, while the body is prepared for cremation...part of this may include many family members taking photos of the deceased with cellphone cameras... during this time, a priest from the temple prepares a funeral pyre on the other side of the complex. the body is wrapped in cloth, carried to the pyre, and then around it three times.often, foods are left near the body to accompany the deceased on their journey. family often have to fight-off pesky monkeys, who want their share of the fruit. the eldest son, often dressed in white, the color of mourning, will light the fire...andthe family sits peacefully, while the body is consumed. whatever is left, is swept into the river, where young boys then plunge in to recover anything that could be sold for a few rupees. there is nothing gross or gruesome about this...it's just death, another part of life...as it's dealt with by another culture. in fact, it'sjust another page in your book of education. if you conduct yourself with respect, you may take photos from across the river. unlike in veranasi, india...you're not beseiged for unreasonable sums of money. a telephoto lens of reasonable length will get you as close as you'd want to get. it seems as though most are here to pay respect to the dead, and to pray, rather than to scam tourists... in veranasi...wewere asked for 1,000 inr ($25usd), for onephoto...better to come to pashupatinath. also in the area, are 'sadhus' or hindu holy men...some of them are real characters, and very worthy of your photographic efforts. they'll expect money...so you should go to pashupatinath with lots of small bills...20 and 50 rupees...for this purpose. see the attached photos. if you visit from year to year...you'll see the same guys... this year i brought same photo prints...they werefascinated. there are guides available near the entrance on the airport road...i've never hired one, as i always move about with nepali friends. either can help you run the gauntlet of semi-agressivevendors near the entrance. the entry fee is modest...whatever it is...it's well worth it.

Be prepared for burning bodies.. Really interesting. People throw coins and statues in with loved ones. The kids sift through water full of human ashes for items to sell. No one minds. which i thought would be disrespectful. Go down to where they are. Tell will pay per item. Dont pay at end or you will get kids swarming you.

A definite "must see" if you're in Nepal!". The day we arrived as we crossed the river our host pointed out the fact that creamations were taking place. It was definitely not something I had expected to hear or much less be able to observe while in Nepal. But of everything we saw, this was probably the most intriguing. It very difficult to put it into words but it overwhelms your senses. Even emotionally, it's very overwhelming-if you're planning to visit Kathmandu, I would definitely recommend you visit this site-even spring for the few rupees to have a guide explain everything as you go through!

Special experiences over cremation. On the date we visited Pashupatinath, we found hundred of people over there... and we just noticed many policemen around. Our guide told us that a high-ranked police official was under cremation. We observed the whole process, which was both shocking and interesting. It was the first time seeing this in a short distance. There are a lot of Hindus priest. They asked for the photo taking but I did not as I did not know if they would ask for $ after photo. Are they real priest or just some way to get tourist money. Who knows?Apart from these, as we are not hindu, we just can't see much. But, the entrance fee is Rs 500. It is pretty high when compared with other temples in Kathmandu.

You feel like you are out of place here - amazing to see it however. You get the feeling that you should not be here from the moment you arrive, what is worse is when you take out your camera in some other worldly fascination to capture the scene and show everyone at home what you witnessed. The Hindu priests (called Bhattas) can be seen walking around the complex, do not (unless you want to at lease) make eye contact or take their picture without permission, they do not take kindly to this. If you want a picture simply offer them some Rupees and they will be more than happy to pose. Probably my highlight from Kathmandu, a must see in my opinion to all visitors of the city.

More than I expected, the most shocking place I visited. It was our first day in Nepal, we hired a gide who took us to the pashupatinath temple. The first sight I remember was a body of a dead person carried by his family. I kept walking by a bridge and saw three bodies in fire. It was amazing to see all that people praying and burning their deads. And there was more, the other side of the river, that runs inside the temple, was habitated by Sadus and many, many monkeys.I didn't expect to find so many diferent and socking things in that place. If you are in Nepal, must go there.

Very interesting - just remember to be respectful!. Very interesting place, this is the Varanasi equal in Nepal - everybody from sadhus to tourist peacefully together. Just remember to be respectful, since there are crematations and funerals going on all the time. Not recommended for young children.

It's not for everybody--even if we're all headed that way. We got to visit this temple on our first day--and were welcomed by women in red, gathered around a fire, celebrating. It was absolutely fascinating. Much further in, our guide pointed out the river, rather dried up due to lack of rain. Further down...a cremation was going on. Quite a surprise, but still this being a holy place--we saw all sorts of human endeavors--from the celebration of life, to the release into the next world. I don't think it's for everybody, especially the squemish--but hey, it's Nepal. And at the least, it makes for incredible stories.

Unbelievable. Pashupatinath is well worth the effort. We had hired a guide who was walking around the entrance who spoke excellent english and was very knowledgeable. Well worth it but check em out before you commit. This temple is where the Hindus come to be "released" for lack of better words. The dead are burned here and their ashes tossed in the river. There is also a hospice there where the dying go as it's bad form to die in your home. I'd suggest reading up on the Hindu religion a bit before as it would make more sense. I wish I had. There are monkeys, holy men, shrines, deities, the whole works here.
